<leme no="497">

<page sig="[*]1r">
<section type="titlepage">
<heading>
The New World 
of 
English Words, 
or a 
Generall DICTIONARY 
Contaning <expan type="y+e">the</expan>: Terms Etimologies ---
Definitions of hard words, as they 
are deriued from other Languages, 
there proper significations through&shy;
out <expan type="y+e">the</expan> Artes &amp; Sciences, whether 
Liberall or Mecanick - 
by E. Phillips -- 
Printed for Nath: Brooke at the
Angell in Cornhill 
1658 -
</heading>
</page>

<page sig="[*]1v">
</page>

<page sig="a1r">
<heading>
THE 
NEW WORLD 
OF 
ENGLISH WORDS: Or, a General 
DICTIONARY:
Containing the Interpretations of such hard words as are
derived from other Languages; whether <f type="i">Hebrew, Arabick, Syriack, 
Greeke, Latin, Italian, French, Spanish, British, Dutch, Saxon<f type="r">, &amp;c. their 
Etymologies and perfect Definitions: 

Together with 

All those Terms that relate to the Arts and Sciences; whether <f type="i">Theologie, Philo&shy;
sophy, Logick, Rhetorick, Grammer, Ethicks, Law, Natural History, Magick,
Physick, Chirurgery, Anatomy, Chimistry, Botanicks, Mathematicks, Arithme&shy;
tick, Geometry, Astronomy, Astrology, Chiromancy, Physiognomy, Naviga&shy;
tion, Fortification, Dialling, Surveying, Musick, Perspective, Architecture,
Heraldry, Curiosities, Mechanicks, Staticks, Merchandize, Jewelling, Painting, 
Graving, Husbandry, Horsemanship, Hawking, Hunting, Fishing<f type="r">, &amp;c.

To which are added 

The significations of Proper Names, Mythology, and Poetical Fictions, Histo&shy;
rical Relations, Geographical Descriptions of most Countries and Cities of the World; 
especially of these three Nations wherein their chiefest Antiquities, Battles, and other 
most Memorable Passages are mentioned; as also all other Subjects that are useful, and 
appertain to our English Language.

A Work very necessary for Strangers, as well as our own Countrymen, for all Per&shy;
sons that would rightly understand what they discourse, write, or read.

Collected and published by <f type="i">E. P.<f type="r">

for the greater honour of those Learned Gentlemen and Artists 
that have been assistant in the most Practical Sciences, 
their Names are affixed in the next Page.
</heading>

<term lang="la">Dedit Deus his quoque finem.</term> <f type="i">Virgil.<f type="r">

London, Printed by <f type="i">E. Tyler<f type="r">, for <f type="i">Nath. Brooke<f type="r"> at the Sign of 
the Angel in Cornhill, 1658.

</section>
</page>
