<page sig="a3r">
<section type="institutional dedication">

<heading>
TO THE 
MOST ILLUSTRIOUS, 
AND 
IMPARTIAL SISTERS, 
THE TWO
UNIVERSITIES.
</heading>

<f type="i">Most Equal Sisters,<f type="r">

NEver did any Volume raise it selfe to that 
heighth of reputation, at once to purchase 
every Reader for a friend or favourite: it is 
a known truth, and not to be denied that 
our Language hath in these later Ages been
advanced to the admiration, if not the emu&shy;
lation, of other Nations, and whatsoever un&shy;
natural reproaches have been stuck upon her beauties by the 
petulancy of Criticks, hath strangely, but chiefly, proceeded from 
the unworthy attempts of those that have obtruded on this Age
their transcriptions of Indexes, rather then Dictionaries, as if 
our Language were narrower then the rest of the Worlds, or
to be confined to their short-hand Epitomes: A high mis&shy;
carriage through which the learned and unlearned have most 
unhappily suffered; certainly the Regalia of our Language 
could not have been worse injured then by being vitiated 
and corrupted by such spurious and imperfect Editions: for
</page>

<page sig="a3v">
if the Grandeur of such an undertaking be rightly considered,
no ordinary industry will be required, next the consulting
with the Monuments of ancient Records and Manuscripts de&shy;
rived to us from reverend Authours, there will be occasion 
to peruse the Works of our ancient Poets, as <f type="i">Geffry Chaucer<f type="r"> 
the greatest in his time, for the honour of our Nation; as 
also some of our more Modern Poets, as <f type="i">Spencer Sidny, Drai&shy;
ton, Daniel<f type="r">, with our Reformers of the Scene, <f type="i">Johnson, Shake&shy;
sphear, Beaumont<f type="r">, and <f type="i">Fletcher<f type="r">, and among the renowned An&shy;
tiquaries, <f type="i">Cambden, Lambard, Spelman, Selden<f type="r">, and divers others. 
There will also be exacted from him that undertakes a task of 
this nature, a necessary knowledge of the Languages in which 
he is certain to incounter with a multitude of Criticisms, nor 
must he be wanting in his strictest search of most Dictionaries,
that he may be able to distinguish the terms, several derivations, 
differences, definitions, interpretations, proper significations of 
the words of our Tongue, how borrowed, how mixed with 
others, how with its own. Lastly, forraign Authours are to be 
made use of, and amongst them, the Germans are reputed most 
expert in the Mechanical Arts<emend err="">.</emend>

Thus, ever Honoured Sisters, you are not unacquainted what
Siftings, Anvelings, Traversings, there ought to be of Au&shy;
thours, so that he that undertakes this Enterprize should first 
seriously perpend what difficulties he is to passe through, 
how dangerous it is for him to faile in such a Design, what 
a weight of disparagement he is likely to sink under: a 
Volume of this nature being of no lesse concernment, then 
not onely to informe young men in their deficiencies of 
the right knowledge of words, either for writing or dis&shy;
course, but also to establish those of riper years in their pru&shy;
dentials as an universally through-pac't Dictionary, and may 
serve for an Interpreter or Arbiter of their Studies and hu&shy;
mane Transactions; so that a work thus rightly constituted 
may be said in some kind, to approach near to a Divine 
Skill, and that the rather as it doth in it selfe contain all 
those <f type="i">Idea<f type="r">'s that concern the Speech or Pen, such as are use&shy;
full to drive on and inforce with full vigour and strength, 
the affaires of mankind.

Illustrious Sisters, if we look upon the exemplary incourage&shy;
</page>

<page sig="a4r">
ments of some of our Laureate Worthies, whose noble spirits 
have not suffered the ashes of Antiquity to be raked out of 
her sacred Urnes, as at this time the admired Workes of Mr.
<f type="i">Dodsworth<f type="r"> and of Mr. <f type="i">Dugdale<f type="r"> have informed the World. 
Some of these Heroick Persons out of a farther zeal to pre&shy;
serve our Language from the barbarismes and ruinous defor&shy;
mities of the times, to present her in her native glories, from 
their own more practical and experienc't insights in some of 
the Arts and Sciences, have contributed in what they were more 
particularly excellent, to the building up of this Volume, 
Their names I have affixed to their own learned indeavours, not 
onely as I my self acknowledge their opportune and incompa&shy;
rable assistances, but that the Bookseller so much obliged to 
them for so unusual a curtesie, might expresse his humblest 
tenders of gratitude; as also that you, most Noble Sisters, would 
be pleased to take notice of this your learned Retinue:; and that 
there are Benefactours still surviving to celebrate your flourish&shy;
ing felicities.

I am not ignorant, that though I am thus fortified with the
pregnant aid of those exquisite Persons, to which my own in&shy;
feriour, though studious indeavours are joyned, that I shall ne&shy;
verthelesse fall short of answering the curiosities of some 
critical expectations. Mr. <f type="i">Minshaw<f type="r"> that spent his life and 
estate in scrutinizing into Languages, still remaines obnoxious 
to the misconstructions of many. But let such invading cen&shy;
surers well consider the infinity of mechanical words, how e&shy;
very Art hath its peculiar Terms, and then if they are in their 
right wits, it will seem almost impossible to them, for one man 
though a healthful person that hath spent the best part of the lea&shy;
sure of his life, to erect such a Pyramid, more especially if those 
difficulties are rightly pondered that are to be waded through; the
conduct of costs in that continued converse that must be had with 
Artists, besides the great labour, with which the most generous For&shy;
rainers that have gone about to manage such happy designs, have 
been wasted and tired out; these considerations being ingeniously 
weighed by the wiser sort of men, I hope the learned &amp; charitable
Critick will intertain a favourable approbation of these labours, as 
he cannot find me wanting, at least of a more than ordinary in&shy;
dustry to compleat this Work, both in examining and right di&shy;
</page>

<page sig="a4v">
gestion of my own papers, as also for that tender care that hath 
been had of those happy contributions <f type="i">I<f type="r"> received from others. 
Most Reverenced Sisters, my greatest ambition is your affecti&shy;
onate esteem, which having but obtained, <f type="i">I<f type="r"> shall ever strive to
imploy the best strength of my life and studies in your service; 
in the mean space <f type="i">I<f type="r"> question not but <f type="i">I<f type="r"> have already done my 
Country so much good service as to have stript away those ob&shy;
solete termes that have defaced our language, not degrading too 
much from its primitive integrity, nor declining what with judge&shy; 
<emend err="">ment</emend>I might insert.

To conclude, <f type="i">I<f type="r"> have illustrated and refined it, instated it in its 
proper majesty, rendred it admirably useful for all persons on all 
occasions, worthy of the greatest masteries of Rhetoricians and 
the tongues of our Vernaculous Oratours: with a no lesse honour&shy;
able submission have <f type="i">I<f type="r"> prostrated these my Indeavours at your 
Learned Feet.

<f type="i">EDW. PHILLIPS.<f type="r">
</section>
</page>

<page sig="b1r">
<section type="personal dedication 1">
<heading>
To the truly Noble, and Perfect Lover and 
Incourager of Arts and Sciences, Sir 
<f type="i">WILLIAM PASTON<f type="r"> 
Knight and Baronet.
</heading>

SIR,

<f type="i">IT hath not been the least of my care, that this present 
Work might be as happy in the fortune of its ad&shy;
dresse, as in the publicknesse of its design, which is 
the General advancement of Learning and Arts; nor 
could it have been more advantagiously fortified a&shy;
gainst the various and uncertain suffrages of the 
World, then by being adopted into the Patronage of 
such a Person, whose accomplishment in the Arts and 
Ingenuities renders him capable to judge of what is 
written well or amisse in any of them; and that this attribute doth belong 
properly to your self, is evident to the World by more then a few instances. 
Your admirable skill in Physick manifested in your frequent Cures of the 
most desperate Diseases, and those happy receits you have consecrated to the 
benefit of mankind; Your exquisite knowledge in Husbandry and Horseman&shy;
ship; Your deep insight into the Mathematicks, and the more delicate sort 
of the Mechanicks, as appears by your excellent choice of Jewels, and your 
rare fancy and invention in Carvings, Turning, Paintings, and Annea&shy;
lings, in which the very Artists you have imployed have submitted to 
your politer judgement; Your diligent search into the greatest curiosi&shy;
ties of Nature; wherein how much you have exceeded all others of our 
Nation that have been famous in their Collections, your <f type="r"><term lang="la">Mus&aelig;um</term><f type="i"> aboun&shy;
ding with an infinite variety of the most choice and admired Rarities, 
can sufficiently testifie: And indeed, What qualities lesse noble then these 
I have mentioned, could spring from the vertuous inclinations of your 
youth, which for many years was spent in useful travels (not so much to 
see fashions, as to learn experience, and the true knowledge of men and 
manners) of which the Learned <f type="r">Mr. Greaves<f type="i"> makes an honourable men&shy;
tion in his Survey of the Pyramids of Egypt? These vertues, together 
with the enlargednesse of your mind in making your House the Center of
Hospitality to Strangers and Ingenuous Persons, are no lesse a true mark 
of the Noblenesse of your Family, then the Supporters of your Armes, a 
bearing which is very rare, and onely peculiar to the most ancient Houses.
</page>

<page sig="b1v">
Vpon this foundation it is that I build my confidence; but to me a 
person little meriting in my self the honour of your acceptance, my pro&shy;
pitious Stars have been assistant on this occasion, and have so brought it 
about, that not I, but two Famous Vniversities and the greatest Artists of 
our time, should throw this Work at your feet, and in so doing they have 
obliged me by a favour which nothing can equal but the Honour of your 
receiving it from them by my hands. If what is here more particularly
contained of the more Noble Mechanick Arts, come not up to that heighth 
as to satisfie the curiosity of your excellent judgement in them, yet thus 
much our Volume may without arrogance pretend to, That there is here a 
fairer way begun then ever, for the promoting of that most useful part of
Learning; especially since it could not intend that alone, but takes in all 
the other parts beside: which all together with one consent, like the needle 
tending towards the North, present themselves to wait upon, you, who have 
so great an influence upon them, erecting a Monument to your fame, great
as the glory I aspire to in stiling my self,

<f type="r">Sir,

Your most humble, and most 
devoted servant,

<f type="i">EDW. PHILLIPS.<f type="r">

</section>
</page>

<page sig="b2r">
<section type="personal dedication 2">
<heading>
To the truly Noble and Acomplisht Gentlemen, 
Sir <f type="i">ROBERT BOLLES<f type="r"> of <f type="i">Scampton<f type="r">, 
in the County of <f type="i">Lincoln<f type="r">, Baronet, 

AND 
<f type="i">EDWARD HUSSY<f type="r"> of <f type="i">Cathorp<f type="r">, in the 
County of <f type="i">Lincoln<f type="r">, Esquire.
</heading>

<f type="i">AT such a time chiefly it is, Most Honoured Sirs, 
that a Nation may be truly said to flourish, when 
those that are the most considerable in fortune and 
outward splendour, are also the most conspicuous for 
Learning and inward Worth; nor can the greatest 
Sciences and most noble Qualities be look't upon by 
any with so true an esteem and value, as by those 
who have themselves attained the highest perfection 
in them: and among the rest whom such qualifica&shy;
tions make to be reputed the Ornament of the Age, it had been impossible
that the World should be unacquainted with two such Eminent Persons as 
your selves; who, being as inseparable in friendship and alliance as in the 
affinity of your vertues, could not, without injury to so happy an union, 
have been separated in this addresse. Though decency will not permit 
me to speak over-high of this Work wherewith I here present you; yet this 
I may say, That Fame hath usher'd it into the World, with the attest of 
so many Worthy hands, that never yet in English any Piece came forth with 
happier Auspices; to which there could have been nothing wanting to
Crown its fortune absolutely, but your most equal receptions, for which it is 
prepared, with this return of gratitude, That besides all those other Arts 
and Sciences, of which both of you are equal favourers and promoters, you 
will also have the satisfaction to finde a considerable account of those
accomplishments which are more especially agreeable to each of your pe&shy;
culiar fancies; namely of that Divine and Seraphic quality (which 
first brought order and civility into the World, which mollifies the 
most barbarous and salvage natures, and calmes the unruly passions of 
the Soul) of which one of you is so great a favourer, and so absolute 
a Master in it, that your whole Retinue following your example, are
</page>

<page sig="b2v">
able performers in Musick, and may as truly be called your Quire as 
your Family; As also (which chiefly delights the other of you) that 
most manly and generous Exercise of Hunting, the sport of greatest 
Kings and Princes in all Ages, by which the youth of all Warlike 
Nations have been alwayes spurred on to martial Discipline, and the at&shy;
cheivement of the most Heroick actions: Having therefore so great a 
veneration to whatsoever is excellent and worthy of highest praise, I 
could not omit to celebrate with my utmost indeavours, the owners of such 
perfections; nor could any consideration have more absolutely charmed 
unto your service, the 

<f type="r">Humble admirer of your Vertues<f type="i"> 

Edw. Phillips.<f type="r">

</section>
</page>

<page sig="b3r">
<section type="preface">

<heading>
THE 
PREFACE, 
<f type="i">By way of Introduction to the Right Know&shy;
ledge of our Language.<f type="r">
</heading>

THe very Summe and Comprehension of all Learning in 
General, is chiefely reducible into these two grand 
Heads, <f type="i">Words<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Things<f type="r">; and though the latter of
these two be, by all men, not without just cause, acknow&shy;
ledged the more solid and substantial part of Learning; 
yet since, on the other side, it cannot be denyed but that 
without <f type="i">Language<f type="r"> (which is as it were the <f type="i"><term lang="la">vehiculum</term><f type="r"> or conveyancer of 
all good Arts) <f type="i">things<f type="r"> cannot well be expressed or published to the 
World, it must be necessarily granted, that the one is little lesse neces&shy;
sary, and an inseparable concomitant of the other; for let a Subject be
never so grave, never so useful, carrying in it never so clear and perfect 
a demonstration, yet if it be not pertinently worded, and urged with a 
certain power and efficacy to the understanding, but in a forced, tumul&shy;
tuous, or disjoynted phrase, it will either not be understood, or so 
slightly and with such indifference regarded, that it will come short of 
working that effect which it promised to it self. And it is a thing mainly 
observable, that all those ancient Authours that have written the best
things, have left them to posterity in the purest and most genuine Lan&shy;
guage. Among the <f type="i">Greeks<f type="r">, who have better deserved of the World for 
the excellency of their Works, than <f type="i">Plato, Xenophon, Thucydides?<f type="r"> Who 
among the <f type="i">Latins<f type="r"> have been more famous than <f type="i">Livie, Cicero, Salust?<f type="r"> 
nor have all these been lesse admired for the properness and elegancy of 
their stile, than for the noblenesse of the things they delivered; neither 
have there been wanting of our own Nation, especially in these later 
Ages, those, who are not onely justly esteemed to stand in competition 
with the best of the Ancients for the verity and soundnesse of their mat&shy;
ter, but, have also refin'd our Language to that heighth, that, for ele&shy;
gance, for fluency, and happinesse of expression, I am perswaded it gives
</page>

<page sig="b3v">
not place to any Modern Language, spoken in <f type="i">Europe<f type="r">; scarcely to the 
Latin and Greek themselves. Now as for that subtile distinction used 
by some, between a Language and a Speech, I look upon it rather as an 
over-curious nicety, than any consideration of serious weight or moment; 
nor can I be induced to believe otherwise but, That whatever kind of
sermocination is generally used in any Country, may very properly be 
termed a Language; for if the commixture of a Language esteemed 
the most ancient, with that of a bordering or invading Nation cause it 
to degenerate into a Speech, even the Latin Tongue will hardly be 
exempted from that denomination, since it is no hard matter to prove 
that even that also descended from a Language yet more ancient than it
self; forasmuch as that Latin which was spoken immediately after the 
expulsion of the <f type="i">Roman<f type="r"> Kings, when the League was made between <f type="i">Rome<f type="r"> 
and <f type="i">Carthage<f type="r">, was so altered in the time of <f type="i">Polybius<f type="r">, which was 350
years after, that it was hardly to be understood; and from the time of 
<f type="i">Romulus<f type="r"> we must needs think it suffered a far greater change: yet it 
was so far from being thought corrupted by this alteration, that it was 
judged not to have come to its <term lang="gk">&#x1F00;&#x03BA;&#x03BC;&#x03B7;</term>, or flourishing heighth of elegance,
until the Age wherein <f type="i">Cicero<f type="r"> lived. And if the change which is introdu&shy;
ced by time, not onely not deprave, but, refine a Language, much more
will the alteration that is made by the interspersion of forraign words, 
especially coming from the more southerly and civil Climates, conduce 
to the sweetning and smoothing of those harsh and rough accents which 
are peculiar to the most northerly Countries. And besides, to find out the 
original and most unchanged Languages, we must have recourse as far
backward as the confusion of <f type="i">Babel<f type="r">, which was the first nativity of 
Tongues; and so make a vain search for things which perhaps are no 
where now extant.

True it is indeed, that <f type="i">Scaliger<f type="r"> reckons up about 11 several 
Tongues (others 14) spoken in <f type="i">Europe<f type="r">, which have no affinity or 
intermixture one with another; the chief whereof, not to mention the 
Greek and Latin, which are now no native but acquired Languages, are 
the Teutonick or Dutch, the Slavonian, the Cantabrian, the old Brittish 
or Celtick; these are commonly called Mother Tongues, and those 
which are any way compounded of any of these Mother Tongues, or 
derived from them, some think fit to call Dialects, although notwith&shy;
standing this composition or derivation, such a vast distance may be seen
between them, as renders them unintelligible to each other; whereas 
indeed a Dialect is but the self same Language, spoken in several Pro&shy;
vinces of the same Nation, with some small difference; as the pronoun&shy;
cing of a vowel either broader or finer, or some little variation of a 
word or syllable; in such a manner the people of <f type="i">Sommersetshire<f type="r"> speak 
differently from those of <f type="i">Middlsex<f type="r">, yet both may very well be under&shy;
stood of each other; and so the people of <f type="i">Florence<f type="r"> from those of <f type="i">Rome<f type="r">: 
No otherwise in the Greek Language did the <f type="i">Dorick, Ionick, Attick, 
Aeolick<f type="r">, Dialects differ from one another.

But, not to insist any longer upon so nice a point, my intention 
is, as an Introduction to the particular scope and design of this Book, 
to speak something in general of the Original of our English Tongue, 
of the basis or foundation of it, of the reason of its several
</page>

<page sig="b4r">
changes, and how far it participates of other Languages, and of the 
peculiar Idiome or propriety thereof.

That, what was originally spoken in this Nation, was the ancient Brit&shy;
tish Language, needs not to be doubted, nor is it improbable what some 
affirm, that it was very near, if not altogether the same with, the <f type="i">Gal&shy;
lick<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Celtick<f type="r">, since both these people were by the ancient Greeks cal&shy;
led by one common name, <f type="i">Celt&aelig;<f type="r">; besides, if we consider the solid argu&shy;
ments of <f type="i">Verstegan<f type="r">, and those that have writ most judiciously, concern&shy;
ing the Original of the <f type="i">Brittains<f type="r">, nothing seems to me more consonant 
to truth, then that the <f type="i">Brittains<f type="r"> anciently descended from the <f type="i">Gaules<f type="r">, 
and that <f type="i">Brutus<f type="r"> rather a <f type="i">Gallick<f type="r">, then a <f type="i">Trojan<f type="r"> Prince, changed the name 
of <f type="i">Albion<f type="r"> into that of <f type="i">Brittain:<f type="r"> but certain it is that of this ancient <f type="i">Brit&shy;
tish<f type="r">, there remains scarsely any track, or footstep in the language spoken
at this day in the main part of <f type="i">England<f type="r">, but hath remained intire from the 
<f type="i">Saxon<f type="r"> Conquest to this very time in that part, which is commonly called
<f type="i">Cambro-Brittania<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Wales<f type="r">, to which (being a mountanous Countrey, and 
strong for defence, and which onely of all the rest of the Island was left 
unconquered by the <f type="i">Saxons<f type="r">) a great number of the Native inhabitants 
betook themselves by flight, preserving both their ancient race and 
speech, which from the Countrey <f type="i">Wales<f type="r">, is now called <f type="i">Welsh<f type="r">. In the same 
manner the <f type="i">Cantabrian<f type="r">, or ancient tongue of <f type="i">Spain<f type="r">, notwithstanding 
the frequent invasions of that Countrey by the <f type="i">Carthaginians, Moors,
Romans<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Vandals<f type="r">, is yet preserved in <f type="i">Biscay, Guipuscoa<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Navarre<f type="r">;
and in the Mountains of <f type="i">Granata<f type="r">, called <f type="i">Alpuxarras<f type="r"> the <f type="i">Arabick<f type="r"> is still 
retained, together with the off-spring of the <f type="i">Moors<f type="r">, that in times past 
possessed the greatest part of <f type="i">Spain<f type="r">; as also in <f type="i">Armorica<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Brittany<f type="r"> in
<f type="i">France<f type="r">, the old <f type="i">Gallick<f type="r"> is spoken at this day, which very near resem&shy;
bling the <f type="i">Welsh<f type="r">, is a great argument of the ancient affinity of these two 
tongues.

From this so total a subversion of the <f type="i">Brittish<f type="r"> Empire by the <f type="i">English-&shy;
Saxons<f type="r">, followed as total a subversion of the <f type="i">Brittish<f type="r"> language, and even 
of the very name of <f type="i">Brittain<f type="r"> (which from the ancient habitation of the 
<f type="i">Saxons<f type="r"> near the <f type="i">Baltick<f type="r"> Sea, was named <f type="i">Anglia<f type="r">, or <f type="i">England<f type="r">) a thing
which was neither effected by the <f type="i">Roman<f type="r"> nor the <f type="i">Norman<f type="r"> Conquest, for 
neither the Provincial Latin could extinguish the Native <f type="i">Brittish<f type="r">, nor the 
<f type="i">French<f type="r"> brought in by King <f type="i">Williams<f type="r"> followers, the <f type="i">Saxon<f type="r"> which was then 
in use, for it is observable that where the Conquerours over-power the 
former inhabitants in multitude, their language also by little and little 
prevails over that of the Countrey, otherwise it wasts and spends it self 
till it be in a manner utterly lost, like a small quantity of water thrown 
upon a heap of sand. Since therefore these <f type="i">Saxons<f type="r"> were a people of <f type="i">Ger&shy;
many<f type="r">, and their speech very little, if at all differing from the rest of the
<f type="i">Germans<f type="r">, it is hence evident that our language derives its Original from 
the <f type="i">Dutch<f type="r"> or <f type="i">Teutonick<f type="r">, which seems to be of greater Antiquity then any 
other language now spoken in <f type="i">Europe<f type="r">, and to have continued the same 
without any considerable alteration, and in the same Countrey where it 
was first planted, through a long tract of many ages; for, not to urge the 
opinion of <f type="i">Goropius Becanus<f type="r">, who affirmeth it to have been the first 
language of the world, and spoken by <f type="i">Adam<f type="r"> in <f type="i">Paradise<f type="r">; it is certainly 
the common consent of most <f type="i">Authentick<f type="r"> Writers, that the <f type="i">Dutch<f type="r"> tongue
</page>

<page sig="b4v">
still in use, and possessing a large compasse of ground, is no lesse ancient 
then the very first coming in of the <f type="i">Teutones<f type="r"> into <f type="i">Germany<f type="r">, under the 
conduct of <f type="i">Tuisco<f type="r">, which is no wonder, if we consider that the <f type="i">Teutones<f type="r">, 
or <f type="i">Germans<f type="r">, being the very first people that ever inhabited <f type="i">Germany<f type="r">, have 
continued in the possession of it to this very day uncorrupted, unsubdued
and (as their language, so themselves) unmixed with any forraigne Na&shy;
tion. Nor is the large extent of this language lesse considerable, for as 
much as it is spoken throughout all <f type="i">Germany, Denmark, Norwey, Sweth&shy;
land, Belgia<f type="r">, the Iland of <f type="i">Thule<f type="r">, now called Iseland, and divers of the
Northern Iles, besides those places into which it hath spread it self by 
conquest, as into <f type="i">Gallia<f type="r"> by the <f type="i">Franck's<f type="r">, and by the <f type="i">Saxons<f type="r"> into this 
Iland, where it yet remaineth in a very great measure.

And though our English tongue hath of late ages intertained so great 
a number of forraign words, that every age it seemeth to swerve more 
and more from what it was originally; yet if we compare it diligently 
with the Dutch, we shall soon finde that almost all the chief material 
words, and those which are oftnest used in the most familiar, and vulgar 
discourse, are all, either meer Dutch, or palpably derived from the 
Dutch. For example, the most primitive and uncompounded words, ap&shy;
pellatives, the names of natural things, animals, vegetals, as <f type="i">Earth, Hea&shy;
ven, Winde, Oak, Man, Bird, Stone, &amp;c.<f type="r"> words that imply a relation, as 
<f type="i">Father, Brother, Son, Daughter<f type="r">; Pronouns, and Monosyllable Verbs, as 
<f type="i">Mine, Thine, This, What, Love, Give<f type="r">, besides all our numerals, 
particles, conjunctions, and the like.

Concerning these words it is very remarkable, that most of them 
consisting but of one syllable; neverthelesse, the things that are un&shy;
derstood by them are as significantly express't, as the same things in 
other tongues are by words of two, or more syllables; as the word 
<f type="i"><term lang="en">Good</term><f type="r"> is as proper as either <term lang="gk">&#x0391;&#x03B3;&#x03B1;&#x03B8;&#x03BF;&#x03C3;</term> in Greek, or <f type="i"><term lang="la">Bonus</term><f type="r"> in Latin, a 
matter of no small advantage: for if that sentence be judged most 
praise-worthy that containeth most matter in fewest words, why 
may we not commend that word, which consisting of fewest sylla&shy;
bles, is yet of as great force as if it had more. No lesse considera&shy;
ble is the proper, and most pertinent signification of some words which 
are produced by the coalition, or clapping together of two of these
monosyllables into one, as the word <f type="i"><term lang="en">Wisdome</term><f type="r">, which is compound&shy;
ed of these two words <f type="i"><term lang="en">Wise</term><f type="r">, i. e. Grave, Sage, Prudent, and the 
old Saxon word <f type="i"><term lang="sx">Dome</term><f type="r">, i. e. judgement, or sentence, since wisdome
may most properly be said to be the result of a Grave, and solid
judgement.

By this that hath been said it is evident, that the Saxon, or
German tongue is the ground-work upon which our language is 
founded, the mighty stream of forraigne words that hath since
<f type="i">Chaucers<f type="r"> time broke in upon it, having not yet wash't away the root: 
onely it lies somewhat obscur'd, and overshadow'd like a Rock, or Foun&shy;
tain overgrown with bushes.

Whether this innovation of words deprave, or inrich our English 
tongue is a consideration that admits of various censures, accord&shy;
ing to the different fancies of men. Certainly as by an invasion of
strangers, many of the old inhabitants must needs be either slain, or
</page>

<page sig="c1r">
forced to fly the Land; so it happens in the introducing of strange 
words, the old ones in whose room they come must needs in time
be forgotten, and grow obsolete; sometimes indeed, as Mr. <f type="i">Cambden<f type="r"> 
observes, there is a peculiar significancy in some of the old Saxon
words, as in stead of fertility they had wont to say <f type="i">Eordswela<f type="r">, 
which is as much as the wealth, or riches of the earth, yet let us 
not bewail the losse of them for this, for we shall finde divers 
Latin words, whose Etymology is as remarkable, and founded upon, 
as much reason, as in the word <f type="i"><term lang="en">intricate</term><f type="r">, which (coming from <f type="i"><term lang="la">Tric&aelig;</term><f type="r"> 
i. e. those small threads about Chickens legs, that are an encombrance 
to them in their going) signifieth entangled; and it is worth the ta&shy;
king notice, that although divers Latin words cannot be explained, but 
by a Periphrasis, as <f type="i"><term lang="en">Insinuation</term><f type="r"> is a winding ones self in by little and 
little, yet there are others, both French and Latin, that are match't 
with Native words equally significant, equally in use among us, as 
with the French <f type="i"><term lang="fr">Denie</term><f type="r">, we parallel our <f type="i"><term lang="en">gainsay</term><f type="r">, with the Latin <f type="i"><term lang="en">resist</term><f type="r">
our <f type="i"><term lang="en">withstand</term><f type="r">, with <f type="i"><term lang="en">Interiour, inward</term><f type="r">, and many more of this na&shy;
ture: So that by this means these forrainers instead of detracting ought 
from our tongue, add copiousnesse and varity to it, now whether 
they add, or take from the ornament of it, it is rather to be referr'd 
to sence and fancy, then to be disputed by arguments. That they 
come for the most part from a language, as civil as the Nation 
wherein it was first spoken, I suppose is without controversy, and be&shy;
ing of a soft and even sound, nothing savouring of harshnesse, or bar&shy;
barisme, they must needs mollifie the tongue with which they incor&shy;
porate, and to which, though of a different nature, they are made fit 
and adapted by long use; in fine, let a man compare the best English, 
now written, with that which was written three, or four ages ago, and 
if he be not a doater upon antiquity, he will judge ours much more 
smooth, and gratefull to the ear: for my part that which some attri&shy;
bute to <f type="i">Spencer<f type="r"> as his greatest praise, namely his frequent use of ob&shy;
solete expressions, I account the greatest blemish to his Poem, other&shy;
wise most excellent, it being an equal vice to adhere obstinately to old 
words, as fondly to affect new ones.

But not to dwell any longer upon their Apology, I shall now for 
the clearer Method proceed to the division of them, there are not 
many Nations in <f type="i">Europe<f type="r">, some of whose words we have not made bold 
with, as all of us together have borrowed from the ancients in 
great abundance, some we take from the Italians, as <f type="i"><term lang="en">Abase, Abone, 
Abbord, Balustrade, Balcone</term><f type="r">, some from the Spanish, as <f type="i"><term lang="en">Abandon, En&shy;
velope, Disembogue, Chapin</term><f type="r">; many from the French, as <f type="i"><term lang="en">Desire, Deny, 
Command, Embellish, Embossement</term><f type="r">; among the ancient languages we 
have from the Greek not a few, as those that end in <term lang="gk">&#x03BC;&#x03B1;</term>, with us end in 
<f type="i"><term lang="en">m.</term><f type="r"> as <term lang="gk">&#x03B5;&#x03C0;&#x03B9;&#x03C1;&#x03B1;&#x03BC;&#x03BC;&#x03B1;</term> <f type="i"><term lang="en">Epigram</term>, <term lang="gk">&#x1F10;&#x03BD;&#x03B8;&#x03CD;&#x03BC;&#x03B7;&#x03BC;&#x03B1;</term> <term lang="en">Enthymem</term><f type="r">, those in <term lang="gk">&#x03BF;&#x03C2;</term> with us in
<f type="i"><term lang="en">t</term><f type="r">, as <term lang="gk">&#x1F10;&#x03C0;&#x03AF;&#x03B8;&#x03B5;</term> <f type="i"><term lang="en">Epithet</term><f type="r">, those in <term lang="gk">&#x03BF;&#x03C2;</term>, with us end in <f type="i"><term lang="en">er</term><f type="r">, as <term lang="gk">&#x0391;&#x03C2;&#x03C1;&#x03CC;&#x03BB;&#x03BF;&#x03B3;&#x03BF;&#x03C3;</term> <term lang="en">Astrolo&shy;
ger</term>, those in <term lang="gk">&#x03B1;&#x03C3;&#x03B7;&#x03C3;</term> with us in <f type="i"><term lang="en">ast</term><f type="r">, as <term lang="gk">&#x03C0;&#x03B1;&#x03C1;&#x03B1;&#x03C6;&#x03C1;&#x03AC;&#x03C2;&#x03C5;&#x03C2;</term> <f type="i"><term lang="en">Paraphrast</term><f type="r">, those in <term lang="gk">&#x03B9;&#x03C2;&#x03B1;</term> in 
<f type="i"><term lang="en">ist</term>, <term lang="gk">&#x03B3;&#x03C5;&#x03BC;&#x03BD;&#x03BF;&#x03C3;&#x03BF;&#x03C6;&#x03AF;&#x03C3;&#x03B1;</term> <term lang="en">Gymnosophist</term><f type="r">, those in <term lang="gk">&#x03B9;&#x03BA;&#x03BF;&#x03C3;</term> in <f type="i"><term lang="en">ick</term><f type="r">, as <f type="i"><term lang="en">Dramatick</term><f type="r">, those 
in <term lang="gk">&#x03B9;&#x03B9;&#x03BA;&#x03BF;&#x03C3;</term> in <f type="i"><term lang="en">isk</term><f type="r">, as Basilisk, those in <term lang="gk">&#x03B1;&#x03C6;&#x03BF;&#x03BD;</term>, or <term lang="gk">&#x03B1;&#x03C6;&#x03BF;&#x03C3;</term> in <f type="i"><term lang="en">aph</term><f type="r">, as Chirograph 
<f type="i"><term lang="en">Paragraph</term><f type="r">, those in <term lang="gk">&#x03B1;&#x03C1;&#x03C7;&#x03B1;</term> in <f type="i"><term lang="en">arch</term><f type="r">, as <term lang="en">Monarch</term>, those in <term lang="gk">&#x03B9;&#x03B1;</term>, in <f type="i"><term lang="en">y</term><f type="r">, or <f type="i"><term lang="en">ie</term><f type="r">, 
as <f type="i"><term lang="en">Philosophy, Rhapsodie</term><f type="r">, those in <term lang="gk">&#x03B9;&#x03C3;&#x03BC;&#x03BF;&#x03C3;</term>, or <term lang="gk">&#x03B9;&#x03C3;&#x03BC;&#x03B1;</term> in <f type="i"><term lang="en">ism</term><f type="r">, as <f type="i"><term lang="en"><emend err="Syllo&shy;">Syllogism, </emend></term>
</page>

<page sig="c1v">
<emend err="gism, "></emend><term lang="en">Sophism</term><f type="r">; also their verbs in <term lang="gk">&#x03B9;&#x03B6;&#x03B5;&#x03B9;&#x03BD;</term>, with us end in <f type="i"><term lang="en">ize</term><f type="r">, as <term lang="gk">&#x03BA;&#x03B1;&#x03C5;&#x03C4;&#x03B5;&#x03C1;&#x03AF;&#x03B6;&#x03B5;&#x03B9;&#x03BD;</term> <f type="i"><term lang="en">Cau&shy;
terize</term><f type="r">; in imitation, of which some, out of a pretty Capricchio, have
given common words the same termination, as <f type="i"><term lang="en">enfranchize, spiritualize, 
wantonize</term><f type="r">. The next thing to be observed of Greek words is 
their manner of composition, they are either compounded of these 
following prepositions, as (1) <term lang="gk">&#x1F00;&#x03BD;&#x03B1;</term>, correspondent to the Latin <f type="i"><term lang="en">Re</term><f type="r">, which 
in composition signifieth <f type="i"><term lang="en">again</term><f type="r">, as <f type="i"><term lang="la">Anaphora reductio</term><f type="r">, or a bringing back 
again, 2 <term lang="gk">&#x1F00;&#x03B9;&#x03C4;&#x03B9;</term>, which, compounded with another word, implies an op&shy;
position, as <f type="i"><term lang="en">Antiperistasis</term><f type="r">, an opposing of any quality against its contra&shy;
ry, 3 <term lang="gk">&#x1F00;&#x03BC;&#x03C6;&#x03B9;</term>, <f type="i"><term lang="en">both wayes</term><f type="r">, or <f type="i"><term lang="en">about</term><f type="r">, as <f type="i"><term lang="en">Amphibious</term>, i. e.<f type="r"> living upon ei&shy;
ther element, land, or water, 4 <term lang="gk">&#x1F00;&#x03C0;&#x03BF;</term>, which in composition signifies a con&shy;
trariety, as from <term lang="gk">&#x03BA;&#x03AC;&#x03BB;&#x03C5;&#x03C8;&#x03B9;&#x03C2;</term>, a hiding, <f type="i"><term lang="en">Apocalypsis</term><f type="r">, a revealing, 5 <term lang="gk">&#x0394;&#x03B9;&#x03C2;</term>, im&shy;
plies a <f type="i"><term lang="en">dilating</term><f type="r">, or a dividing, as <f type="i"><term lang="en">Dioeresis</term><f type="r">, a dividing of one syllable 
into two, 6 <term lang="gk">&#x03BA;&#x03B1;&#x03C4;&#x03B1;</term>, answering in composition to the Latin, <f type="i"><term lang="en">De</term><f type="r"> as <f type="i"><term lang="en">Cata&shy;
phora</term><f type="r">, a carrying downward, 7 <term lang="gk">&#x03B5;&#x03C0;&#x03B9;</term>, <f type="i"><term lang="en">in</term><f type="r">, or <f type="i"><term lang="en">upon</term><f type="r">, as <f type="i"><term lang="en">Epitaph</term><f type="r">, an inscrip&shy;
tion upon any ones Tombe, 8 <term lang="gk">&#x03B5;&#x03BA;</term>, or <term lang="gk">&#x03B5;&#x03BE;</term>, <f type="i"><term lang="en">out</term><f type="r">, as <f type="i"><term lang="en">Ectype</term><f type="r">, a thing ta&shy;
ken out of another Copy, 9 <term lang="gk">&#x03B5;&#x03BD;</term>, <f type="i"><term lang="en">in</term><f type="r">, or <f type="i"><term lang="en">inward</term><f type="r">, as <f type="i"><term lang="en">Engastrimyth</term><f type="r">, one that 
speaks inwardly, 10 <term lang="gk">&#x03BC;&#x03B5;&#x03C4;&#x03B1;</term>, which implies a changing, as <f type="i"><term lang="en">Metamorpho&shy;
sis</term><f type="r">, a changing of shapes, 11 <term lang="gk">&#x03C0;&#x03B1;&#x03C1;&#x03B1;</term>, which implies a comparison, as <f type="i"><term lang="en">Pa&shy;
rabola</term><f type="r">, a story brought for a similitude, 12 <term lang="gk">&#x03C0;&#x03B5;&#x03C1;&#x03B9;</term>, <f type="i"><term lang="en">about</term><f type="r">, as <f type="i"><term lang="en">Periphe&shy;
rie</term><f type="r">, a carrying about, 13 <term lang="gk">&#x03C9;&#x03C1;&#x03BF;</term>, <f type="i"><term lang="en">before</term><f type="r">, as <f type="i"><term lang="en">Prodromus</term><f type="r">, a fore-runner, 
14 <term lang="gk">&#x03C0;&#x03C1;&#x03BF;&#x03C2;</term>, <f type="i"><term lang="en">to</term><f type="r">, or <f type="i"><term lang="en">toward</term><f type="r">, as <f type="i"><term lang="en">Prosthesis</term><f type="r">, an adding unto, 15 <term lang="gk">&#x1F50;&#x03C0;&#x03BF;</term>, <f type="i"><term lang="en">under</term><f type="r">, 
as <f type="i"><term lang="en">Hypogastrick</term><f type="r">, the lowermost part of the belly, 16 <term lang="gk">&#x1F7B;&#x03C0;&#x03B5;&#x03C1;</term>, above, as 
<f type="i"><term lang="en">Hyperphysical</term><f type="r">, that which is above nature. Or else of other words, 
as  <term lang="gk">&#x03C0;&#x03C1;&#x1FF6;&#x03C4;&#x03BF;&#x03C3;</term>, first, <term lang="gk">&#x03C0;&#x03BF;&#x03BB;&#x03C5;&#x03C2;</term>, many, <term lang="gk">&#x03C8;&#x03B5;&#x1F7B;&#x03B4;&#x03C5;&#x03C2;</term>, false, and the privative <term lang="gk">&#x03B1;</term>, for 
example, <f type="i"><term lang="en">Prototype</term><f type="r">, an Original, or first Copy, <f type="i"><term lang="en">Polygon</term><f type="r">, a figure that 
hath many angles, or corners; <f type="i"><term lang="en">Pseudomartyr</term><f type="r">, a false witnesse, or con&shy;
terfeit Martyr; <f type="i"><term lang="en">Atrophy</term><f type="r">, a want of the nutritive faculty, these are 
the most material, and all that are in use in our tongue.

But for the Latin words they will require a larger account to be 
given of them; these are the main body of our Army of forraigne 
words, these are so numerous that they may well be thought to e&shy;
qual, if not exceed the number of our ancient words; onely, here 
is the difference, That these are the more essential, those the more re&shy;
mote, and rather the superstructure then the foundation. Of these La&shy;
tin words there are many (as also some of the French, and others be&shy;
fore mentioned) that by long custome are so ingrafted, and natura&shy;
liz'd into our tongue, that now they are become free denizons, with&shy;
out any difference, or distinction between them and the Native words, 
and are familiarly understood by the common sort, and most unlearn&shy;
ed of the people; as <f type="i"><term lang="en">nature, fortune, member, intend, inform, in&shy;
vent</term><f type="r">, and the like, others there are which though frequently written, 
and used in common discourse by the politer sort, and infranchized at
least, if not naturalized, are not yet so very trite as to be understood by 
all, since divers ingenuous persons, addicted to the reading of books, are 
neverthelesse unacquainted with the Latin, and other forraign lan&shy;
guages, and so are at a losse when they meet with unusual words, and
some people if they spy but a hard word, are as much amazed as if they 
had met with a Hobgoblin, and these are they, more especially, the cog&shy;
nizance whereof is one part, though not the greatest, of this designe,
</page>

<page sig="c2r">
but that there are in the book some words ordinary and trite enough, 
for I thought it better in such a case as this, rather to exceed then to 
be too sparing, since an exuberance is easilier cut off then a defect sup&shy;
plied; I had thought once to have omitted this branch of our follow&shy;
ing work, as having been performed by others before, and that not 
without some diligence, but I thought it not enough to have added 
many more things then were yet ever thought on, but also to have 
the quintessence of what ever was offer'd at before, in another cast 
and better method, that it might be a complete work, and not want&shy;
ing in any thing that could be desired in a designe so usefull to the 
Nation; besides, that even of these sorts of words there were many
wanting before, which were requisite to be inserted, many not so 
properly rendred as was convenient, divers cram'd in by the head and 
shoulders without any distinction, but as if they had been as good as the 
best; whereas in works of this nature men ought to fly all Pedantismes, 
and not rashly to use all words alike, that are met with in every English 
Writer, whether Authentick, or not, this is a bad example to the unad&shy;
monish't Reader, and might incourage him to suck in barbarisme as 
soon as Elegance, but by long experience out of a continued course of 
reading the best Authors, and conversation with the better sort of com&shy;
pany to examine throughly what words are natural, and ligitimate, and 
what spurious, and forc'st; nor is it proper to quote an Authour for a 
word that long custome hath sufficiently authoriz'd, but either such as
are grown out of use, or such as are used onely upon special occasions, 
or as terms of Art; and not upon the credit of every one neither, nor 
to quote any modern, or trivial Authour for words used by those more 
ancient, or of greater credit: I do not deny indeed, but that there are 
many words in this book (though fewer then in other books of this 
kinde) which I would not recommend to any for the purity, or reputa&shy;
tion of them, but this I had not done, but to please all humours, know&shy;
ing that such kinde of words are written, &amp; that the undistinguishing sort 
of Readers would take it very ill if they were not explained, but with&shy;
all I have set my mark upon them, that he that studies a natural and un&shy;
affected stile, may take notice of them to beware of them, either in dis&shy;
course, or writing; and if any of them may have chanc't to have escap't 
the Obelisck (as such a thing may happen in spight of deligence) there 
can arise no other inconvenience from it, but an occasion to exercise the 
choice and judgement of the Reader, especially being forewarned, who 
if he have a fancie capable to judge of the harmony of words, and their 
musical cadence, cannot but discern when a word falls naturally from the 
Latin termination, when forc't and torn from it, as Imbellick, which
might indeed come from <f type="i"><term lang="la">Imbellicus</term><f type="r">, if any such word were, but how 
they can handsomely deduce it from <f type="i"><term lang="la">Imbellis</term><f type="r">, is hard to resolve, if this 
be bad <f type="i"><term lang="en">imprescriptible</term><f type="r"> is worse, being derived, neither I nor any body 
else knows how, since <f type="i"><term lang="la">Pr&aelig;scriptus</term><f type="r"> is the nearest they can go: there are al&shy;
so worth the pains of avoiding certain kinde of Mule-words propaga&shy;
ted of a Latin Sire, and a Greek Dam, such as <f type="i"><term lang="en">Acrilogie, Aurigraphy</term><f type="r">, 
and others <f type="i"><term lang="la">ejusdem farin&aelig;</term><f type="r">; but I have also met with some forged, as 
I shrewdly suspect, by such as undertook to explain them; so monstrous&shy;
ly barbarous, and insufferable, that they are not worthy to be mentio&shy;
</page>

<page sig="c2v">
ned nor once thought on, yet that ye may guesse at <f type="i">Hercules<f type="r"> by his 
foot, one of them I shall produce, which is <f type="i"><term lang="en">Suicide</term><f type="r">, a word which I 
had rather should be derived from <f type="i"><term lang="la">Sus</term><f type="r">, a Sow, then from the Pronown
<f type="i"><term lang="la">Sui</term><f type="r">, unlesse there be some mystery in it; as if it were a Swinish part for 
a man to kill himself.

What cautions more to give for the avoiding of such grosse words as 
these I know not, onely this in general, To be ever conversant in the best 
Authours, as Sir <f type="i">Philip Sidny<f type="r">, Sir <f type="i">Thomas More<f type="r">, Sir <f type="i">Water Rawleigh<f type="r">, 
my Lord <f type="i">Verulam, Ben Johnson<f type="r">, happy as well in his prose as verse, and 
for his instructions in well writing excellent; nor is this present age ut&shy;
terly barren: not to mention our late Romances, which for stile are not 
quite to be rejected, neither are they void of delight and some ele&shy;
gancies, onely intermixed with a kinde of grave majestical, and se&shy;
rious folly.

Now for those words that are of a right stamp, and currant among 
us, that they may orderly be dinstinguish't by their Terminations, and 
not be known at randome, meerly, and by chance; I shall shew exact&shy;
ly how they are formed from the Original Latin words, and reduce them
into certain classes, or ranks, where note that the Characteristick of a 
word alwayes consists in the end, or termination.

First, Our Adjectives are formed from the Latins, either by casting 
away the Final <f type="i"><term lang="la">us</term><f type="i">, as from <f type="i"><term lang="la">Promptus</term><f type="i"> <term lang="en">Prompt</term>, from <f type="i"><term lang="la">Justus</term><f type="i"> <term lang="en">Just</term>, or 
changing <f type="i"><term lang="la">us</term><f type="i"> into <f type="i"><term lang="en">ed</term><f type="i">, as <f type="i"><term lang="la">Infatuatus</term><f type="i">, <term lang="en">Infatuated</term>, or into <f type="i"><term lang="en">ous</term><f type="i">, as <f type="i"><term lang="la">Obvius</term><f type="i"> <term lang="en">Obvi&shy;
ous</term>, sometimes into <f type="i"><term lang="en">an</term><f type="i">, as <f type="i"><term lang="la">Plebeius</term><f type="i">, <term lang="en">Plebeian</term>, or by changing <f type="i"><term lang="la">ilis</term><f type="i"> in&shy;
to <f type="i"><term lang="en">ile</term><f type="i">, as from <f type="i"><term lang="la">Agilis</term><f type="i"> comes <term lang="en">Agile</term>, from <f type="i"><term lang="la">facilis</term><f type="i"> <term lang="en">facile</term>, <f type="i"><term lang="la">ax</term><f type="i"> into <f type="i"><term lang="en">acious</term><f type="i">, as 
<f type="i"><term lang="la">efficax</term><f type="i"> <term lang="en">efficacious</term>, <f type="i"><term lang="la">bilis</term><f type="i"> into <f type="i"><term lang="en">ble</term><f type="i">, as <f type="i"><term lang="la">tractabilis</term><f type="i"> <term lang="en">tractable</term>, <f type="i"><term lang="la">Docibilis</term><f type="i"> <term lang="en">Doci&shy;
ble</term>; <f type="i"><term lang="la">alis</term><f type="i"> into <f type="i"><term lang="en">al</term><f type="i">, as <f type="i"><term lang="la">Orientalis</term><f type="i"> <term lang="en">Oriental</term>; <f type="i"><term lang="la">ans</term><f type="i">, or <f type="i"><term lang="la">ens</term><f type="i">, into <f type="i"><term lang="en">ant</term><f type="i">, or <term lang="en">ent</term>, 
as <f type="i"><term lang="la">constans</term><f type="i"> <term lang="en">constant</term>, <f type="i"><term lang="la">eloquens</term><f type="i"> <term lang="en">eloquent</term>, <f type="i"><term lang="la">or</term><f type="i"> into <f type="i"><term lang="en">our</term><f type="i"> as <f type="i"><term lang="la">inferior</term><f type="i"> <term lang="en">inferiour</term>, 
<f type="i"><term lang="la">rius</term><f type="i"> into <f type="i"><term lang="en">ry</term><f type="i">, as <f type="i"><term lang="la">contrarius</term><f type="i"> <term lang="en">contrary</term>, <f type="i"><term lang="la">Transitorius</term><f type="i"> <term lang="en">Transitory</term>.

Secondly, Noun substantives derived from adjectives, participles, verbs; 
or otherwise; of which those that in Latine end in <f type="i"><term lang="la">tas</term><f type="i">, with us end 
in <f type="i"><term lang="en">tie</term><f type="i">, or <f type="i"><term lang="en">ty</term><f type="i">, as <f type="i"><term lang="la">Imbecillitas</term><f type="i">, <term lang="en">Imbecillity</term>, <f type="i"><term lang="la">Probabilitas</term><f type="i">, <term lang="en">Probability</term>, <f type="i"><term lang="la">antia</term><f type="i"> 
into <f type="i"><term lang="en">ance</term><f type="i">, or <f type="i"><term lang="en">ancy</term><f type="i">, as <f type="i"><term lang="la">substantia</term><f type="i"> <term lang="en">substance</term>, <f type="i"><term lang="la">reluctantia</term><f type="i"> <term lang="en">reluctancy</term>, <f type="i"><term lang="la">entia</term><f type="i"> 
into <f type="i"><term lang="en">ence</term><f type="i">, or <f type="i"><term lang="en">ency</term><f type="i">, as <f type="i"><term lang="la">confidentia</term><f type="i"> <term lang="en">confidence</term>, <f type="i"><term lang="la">eminentia</term><f type="i"> <term lang="en">eminencie</term>, <f type="i"><term lang="la">ura</term><f type="i"> into
<f type="i"><term lang="en">ure</term><f type="i">, as <f type="i"><term lang="la">commissura</term><f type="i"> <term lang="en">commissure</term>; <f type="i"><term lang="la">udo</term><f type="i"> into <f type="i"><term lang="en">ude</term><f type="i">, as <f type="i"><term lang="la">magnitudo</term><f type="i"> <term lang="en">magnitude</term>, 
<f type="i"><term lang="la">or</term><f type="i"> into <f type="i"><term lang="en">our</term><f type="i">, as <f type="i"><term lang="la">Author</term><f type="i"> <term lang="en">Authour</term>, words ending in <f type="i"><term lang="la">tio</term><f type="i">, of which there are 
a great number, have <f type="i"><term lang="en">n</term><f type="i"> added at the end, as <f type="i"><term lang="la">separatio</term><f type="i"> <term lang="en">separation</term>,
<f type="i"><term lang="la">repletio</term><f type="i"> <term lang="en">repletion</term>, <f type="i"><term lang="la">instructio</term><f type="i"> <term lang="en">instruction</term>, <f type="i"><term lang="la">ambitio</term><f type="i"> ambition, sometimes 
<f type="i"><term lang="la">us</term><f type="i">, or <f type="i"><term lang="la">um</term><f type="i">, is taken away from the latter end, as <f type="i"><term lang="la">Conventus</term><f type="i"> a <term lang="en">Convent</term>, 
<f type="i"><term lang="la">Argumentum</term><f type="i"> an <term lang="en">Argument</term>, <f type="i"><term lang="la">Articulus</term><f type="i"> an <term lang="en">Article</term>, <f type="i"><term lang="la">Monstrum</term><f type="i"> a <term lang="en">Mon&shy;
ster</term>; to one, or other of these terminations, almost all Nouns whatso&shy;
ever be reduced. 

Thirdly, For our Verbes, some there be that may most aptly, and with 
best ease be formed from the indicative <f type="i">mood<f type="r">, present <f type="i">tence<f type="r"> of the 
active voice, as from <f type="i"><term lang="la">Informo</term><f type="r"> <term lang="en">to Inform</term>, and from <f type="i"><term lang="la">contendo</term><f type="r"> <term lang="en">to contend</term>, 
from <f type="i"><term lang="la">pr&aelig;scribo</term><f type="r"> <term lang="en">to prescribe</term>, from <f type="i"><term lang="la">comtemno</term><f type="r"> <term lang="en">to contemne</term>, from <f type="i"><term lang="la">alludo</term><f type="r"> 
<term lang="en">to allude</term>: Some fall more kindly from the infinitive mood, as from <f type="i"><term lang="la">con&shy;
vincere</term><f type="r"> <term lang="en">to convince</term>, from <f type="i"><term lang="la">reducere</term><f type="r"> <term lang="en">to reduce</term>, because of the melting of 
the <f type="i"><term lang="la">c.</term><f type="r"> but there are other Verbs, such as from <f type="i"><term lang="la">Colligere</term><f type="r"> <term lang="en">Collect</term>, from <f type="i"><term lang="la">in&shy;
struere</term><f type="r"> <term lang="en">instruct</term>, from <f type="i"><term lang="la">consulere</term><f type="r"> <term lang="en">consult</term>, from <f type="i"><term lang="la">invenire</term><f type="r"> <term lang="en">invent</term>, which can&shy;
</page>

<page sig="c3r">
not, without much constraint, be deduced either from the Indicative, 
or Infinitive mood, but seem much more probably, by their near resem&shy;
blance, to be formable from the participle passive, as <f type="i"><term lang="la">Collectus, Instructus, 
Consultus, Inventus</term><f type="r">. In like manner may all those Verbs that come from 
the first conjugation of the Latins (whereof a great multitude are of late 
years grown in use) be formed, as to <f type="i"><term lang="en">coacervate</term><f type="r">, to <f type="i"><term lang="en">consummate</term><f type="r">, to <f type="i"><term lang="en">ag&shy;
gravate</term>, &amp;c.<f type="r"> from <f type="i"><term lang="la">Coacervatus, Consummatus, Aggravatus</term><f type="r">, rather then 
from the Infinitive, <f type="i"><term lang="la">coacervare, consummare, aggravare</term><f type="r">, for as much as 
the final <f type="i"><term lang="la">t</term><f type="r"> seems to be the Characteristick letter; there are also sundry 
other Verbes that appear to have been most anciently received, and
most inured to our language, which, belike, were had from the Latins 
at the second hand, we taking them from the French, as they from the 
Lat. as chiefly those that end in <f type="i"><term lang="fr">y</term><f type="r"> or <f type="i"><term lang="fr">ie</term><f type="r">: for example, to <f type="i"><term lang="en">signifie</term><f type="r">, to <f type="i"><term lang="en">glorifie</term><f type="r">, 
to <f type="i"><term lang="en">mollifie</term><f type="r">, which we borrow from the French, <f type="i"><term lang="fr">signifier, glorifier, mol&shy;
lifier</term><f type="r">, and they from the Latin, <f type="i"><term lang="la">significare, glorificare, mollificare</term><f type="r">; be&shy;
sides, those both Verbes, and Nouns which we borrow from the French
meerly, as to <f type="i"><term lang="en">refresh</term><f type="r">, to <f type="i"><term lang="en">discourage</term><f type="r">, to <f type="i"><term lang="en">discharge</term><f type="r">, to <f type="i"><term lang="en">furnish</term><f type="r">, to <f type="i"><term lang="en">garnish</term><f type="r">, to 
<f type="i"><term lang="en">refrain, despite, distresse, hostage, menace</term>, &amp;c.<f type="r">

Fourthly, Concerning our Adverbs, there needs no more to be said 
but this, that whereas in Latin they most commonly end in <f type="i"><term lang="fr">&egrave;</term><f type="r">, or <f type="i"><term lang="fr">&egrave;r</term><f type="r">, we re&shy;
tain our old termination <f type="i"><term lang="en">ly</term><f type="r">, as for <f type="i"><term lang="fr">successiv&egrave;</term><f type="r">, we use <f type="i"><term lang="en">successively</term><f type="r">, for <f type="i"><term lang="en">dili&shy;
gent&egrave;r, diligently</term><f type="r">, these must be understood to be such onely as are de&shy;
rived from Nown Adjectives, for with the ordinary Adverbs of time, 
place, <f type="i">&amp;c.<f type="r"> our tongue meddles not. As for those in <f type="i"><term lang="fr">t&ugrave;s</term><f type="r">, as <f type="i"><term lang="fr">divinit&ugrave;s</term><f type="r">, 
and in <f type="i"><term lang="la">im</term><f type="r">, as <f type="i"><term lang="la">confertim, viritim</term><f type="r">, &amp;c. we cannot expresse them by one 
word, except <f type="i"><term lang="la">partim</term><f type="r">, i. <term lang="en">partly</term>.

Fifthly, and lastly, there are a sort of words and expressions, which 
we take from the Latins, whole and intire without any diminution, or 
change, either in the same nature as <f type="i">Cicero<f type="r">, and some of the Latin wri&shy;
ters do from the Greeks (as namely when they had not a significant 
word of their own, wherewith handsomely to expresse what they in&shy;
tended) or else when a word falls not naturally into our termination; 
as in the words <f type="i"><term lang="la">elogium</term><f type="r">, and <f type="i"><term lang="la">encomium</term>:<f type="r"> for the first indeed we say indif&shy;
ferently, either an <f type="i"><term lang="la">elogium</term><f type="r">, or an <f type="i"><term lang="fr">elogie</term><f type="r">, but with <f type="i"><term lang="la">encomium</term><f type="r"> we do not 
yet make so bold as to say an <f type="i"><term lang="fr">encomie</term><f type="r">, and to render it in English would 
be too tedious a <f type="i">circumloqution<f type="r">, As to say, a speech made in praise of an 
other man, and therefore it is better to use the very word <f type="i"><term lang="en">encomium</term><f type="r">; so 
<f type="i"><term lang="sp">Privado</term><f type="r"> in Spanish, and <f type="i"><term lang="it">Inamorato</term><f type="r"> in Italian, retain their own termina&shy;
tions with a better grace then any change could bring them, <f type="i"><term lang="un">Privad</term><f type="r"> or 
<f type="i"><term lang="un">Inamorat</term><f type="r">, not sounding so agreeably to the eare; also by a certain odd, 
and strange construction we oftentimes turn a Latin Verb, and sometimes 
a sentence into an English Noun; especially with the help of an Article, 
as to give a <f type="i"><term lang="la">bene discessit</term><f type="r">, to sing <f type="i"><term lang="la">Lachrym&aelig;</term><f type="r">, such a one was charged with 
a <f type="i"><term lang="la">non est inventus</term><f type="r">, and many more of this nature, very acceptable to 
such as delight to have their writings and discourses larded with old 
ends of Latin; this manner of expression comes somewhat near that
Grammar rule, where a whole clause comes before, or followes a
Verb, and many times denotes the beginning of some publick form 
of words, of this sort are the Latin names of divers Writs, consist&shy;
ing of a tedious sentence, which put me in minde of the Spaniard,
</page>

<page sig="c3v">
whose long name made him to be taken for a great company of men 
together.

I shall conclude this discourse of our Latin-derived words, with the 
manner of their composition, as I did before, in my mention of the Greek 
words, and this I do that the Reader may not be puzled at the missing 
of every compound word, so long as he knows of what words they 
are compounded; it is therefore to be noted that they differ not in their 
composition from the Original Latin words; being alwayes joyned with 
one of these following prepositions <f type="i"><term lang="la">a</term><f type="r">, or <f type="i"><term lang="la">ab</term><f type="r">, <term lang="en">from</term>, or <term lang="en">away</term>, as <f type="i"><term lang="en">Version</term><f type="r"> 
being a turning, <f type="i"><term lang="en">Aversion</term><f type="r"> is a turning from, <f type="i"><term lang="en">duction</term><f type="r"> a leading, <f type="i"><term lang="en">abduction</term><f type="r"> 
a leading away, <f type="i"><term lang="en">ad</term><f type="r"> <term lang="en">to</term>, wherein <f type="i"><term lang="en">d</term><f type="r"> is commonly changed into the same 
Letter, that the word to which it joyned begins with, as from <f type="i"><term lang="en">plica&shy;
tion</term><f type="r"> being compounded with <f type="i"><term lang="en">ad</term><f type="r">, ariseth <f type="i"><term lang="en">application</term><f type="r"> an applying, not 
<f type="i"><term lang="un">adplication</term>; <term lang="en">de</term><f type="r"> <term lang="en">from</term>, or <term lang="en">of</term>, as <f type="i"><term lang="en">detruncation</term><f type="r"> a cutting off, the rest are <f type="i"><term lang="en">e, 
ex, extra, in, dis, contra, ob, per, sub, supra &amp; ultra</term><f type="r">. Seldom it is that ac&shy;
cording to the manner of the Greeks, a Noun is joyned in composition 
with a Verb, or one Noun with another, onely the word <f type="i"><term lang="en">semi</term><f type="r"> is often 
used, which, in composition, implies as much as half, as <f type="i"><term lang="en">semicircular</term><f type="r"> being 
in the form of a half Circle.

This is as much as needs to be said of forraign words, in respect of 
their dependence upon our tongue, and their frequent use in speaking 
and writing; I might in the next place proceed to as ample an account 
of the words of Art, which I count the more curious part of the design, 
and that which was most wanting; but in regard that to do this hand&shy;
somely, would require a particular discourse of the Arts, and the divi&shy;
sion of them, and because that a sufficient account of the book is given 
elsewhere, I shall passe them over briefly.

The words which we use in most Arts, are taken from one, or other 
of those languages above mentioned; in those which are commonly 
called the liberal Arts, we borrow a very considerable number from the 
Greek; in Rhetorick all the Tropes and Figures, as <f type="i"><term lang="en">Synecdoche, Ironie, 
Metonymie</term><f type="r">, in Logick, <f type="i"><term lang="en">Enthymeme, Sorites</term><f type="r">, and the word <f type="i"><term lang="en">Logick</term><f type="r"> it 
self; in Physick <f type="i"><term lang="en">Eupepsie, Dyscrasie</term><f type="r">, and the names of most diseases; in 
Astronomie, <f type="i"><term lang="en">Antipodes, Periscians</term><f type="r">, and the word <f type="i"><term lang="en">Astronomie</term><f type="r"> it self, 
and so in divers other Arts. In Astrology many from the <f type="i">Arabicks<f type="r">, as 
the names of the most conspicuous Starres in each constellation, viz.
<f type="i"><term lang="en">Aldebaran, Alnath</term><f type="r">, and some in Astronomy, as <f type="i"><term lang="en">Nadir, Almicantarats</term><f type="r">. 
In sundry of the Mathematical Arts, and the politer sort of <f type="i">Mechanicks<f type="r">, 
we have many words from the <f type="i">French<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Italians<f type="r">, as in Architecture, 
and Fortification, <f type="i"><term lang="en">Pilaster, Foliage, Cupulo, Parapet</term><f type="r">, &amp;c. all our Terms of 
Heraldry, we have chiefly from the <f type="i">French<f type="r">, as <f type="i"><term lang="en">Couchant, Saliant, En&shy;
grailled</term><f type="r">; and as also in Jewelling, Inlaying, Painting, as <f type="i"><term lang="en">Carrat, Naif, 
Boscage, Affinage, Marquetry</term>, &amp;c.<f type="r"> but for the Handycrafts, and seve&shy;
ral of those, which are called <f type="i">Artes Serviles<f type="r">, they have their Terms pe&shy;
culiar onely to themselves, <f type="i">&amp;c.<f type="r"> such as are known to few but the se&shy;
veral Professours, as the names of Tools and Instruments, belonging to 
all kinde of Manufactures, of which to the attaining but of one tenth 
part, the search of an age would scarce suffice, but very many of the 
chiefest are to be found in this book. Of this nature also are the Terms 
used by Sea-man; as <f type="i"><term lang="en">Abast, Afmost, Larboard</term><f type="r">, to <f type="i"><term lang="en">spring a Leak</term><f type="r">; by Hun&shy;

</page>

<page sig="c4r">
ters and Forresters; as <f type="i"><term lang="en">Lappise, Foreloin, Bloudyhand, Dogdraw</term><f type="r">, &amp;c. of 
both which last, there are likewise not a few.

The last consideration of words is our proper names, which have hi&shy;
therto been wanting in <f type="i">English<f type="r">, and under these are comprehended both
Mythology, History, and Geography, to which may be added the expli&shy;
cation of <f type="i">Hebrew<f type="r">, and <f type="i">Saxon<f type="r"> names.

As for Orthography, it will not be requisite to say any more of it, then 
may conduce to the Readers direction in the finding out of words, which 
is that we many times use a single <f type="i"><term lang="en">e</term><f type="r">, where the Latins use an <f type="i"><term lang="la">oe</term><f type="r">, or an <f type="i"><term lang="la">&aelig;</term><f type="r">, 
as <f type="i"><term lang="en">preparation</term><f type="r"> for <f type="i"><term lang="la">pr&aelig;paration</term>, <term lang="en">Amebean</term><f type="r"> for <f type="i"><term lang="la">Am&oelig;b&aelig;an</term><f type="r">; but if the <f type="i"><term lang="la">&aelig;</term><f type="r">, or <f type="i"><term lang="la">&oelig;</term><f type="r"> 
be observed, it is not amisse; some use either indifferently: in the same 
manner <f type="i"><term lang="en">i</term><f type="r"> is oft used for <f type="i"><term lang="en">y</term><f type="r">, as <f type="i"><term lang="en">Limphatick</term><f type="r"> for <f type="i"><term lang="en">Lymphatick, o</term><f type="r"> for <f type="i"><term lang="en">u</term><f type="r">, as 
<f type="i"><term lang="en">secondine</term><f type="r"> for <f type="i"><term lang="en">secundine</term><f type="r">.

Thus I have, in as brief a Method as I could devise, run through the 
whole Oeconomy of our forraign words, and have ranged them all into 
their several orders and distinctions; so that there is scarce any word, 
but may be reduced to one, or other of them, for I thought it in vain to 
publish to the world a <f type="i">Dictionary<f type="r"> of hard Terms, if I did not withall 
lead men the way to the right use of it, that they might inform them&shy;
selves distinctly, and not sit down contented with a confused notion of 
things. In this work, which, for the generality of it, must stand the bront 
of many a curious inquisition; both for the present, and future ages, 
I regard not my own fame equal to the renown and glory of the Na&shy;
tion, which cannot but be much advanced by such like indeavours, and 
as I am not conscious to my self to have been wanting in industry; so I 
shall be ready without any difficulty to acknowledge what ever over&shy;
sight I may be fairly convinced of; Provided, I may scape such censures, 
as have any thing of the Pedant in them; nor shall I think it enough to 
have come off fairly here, without suddenly attempting other things of 
equal concernment with this present design, which I commend to the 
judgement of the learned, the ingenuity of those that are inclined to 
learning, and the fortune of that intertainment, which the World shall 
think fit to give it.

<f type="i">Edward Phillips.<f type="r">
</section>
</page>

<page sig="c4v">
</page>

<page sig="d1r">
<section type="to the reader">
<heading>
A Brief and Familar 
ADVERTISEMENT 
TO THE 
READER.
</heading>

<f type="i">LEarned and Courteous Reader, continual experience con&shy;
firmes that as Science is first derived to us by notions, so 
it is made known to us by words: without our right know&shy;
ledge of the later it is impossible for us but that in our dis&shy;
course, writing, or reading, we must either be gravelled, 
or strangly to seek; and though the knowledge of a prece&shy;
dent sentence in the turning over of an Authour cannot be denyed
sometimes to be a more then ordinary help: yet without our more par&shy;
ticular ingenuity, in respect of the various acceptance of words, there 
will be required a recourse to the Dictionary, as we cannot other&shy;
wise be advised or satisfied. Hence it hath proceeded a Maxim 
from the Learned, That he that is ignorant of words, shall never 
have his minde rightly instated to judge of things; so, true it is, 
That every mans judgement for the chusing of words ought like a 
finger in the Margent of a Book to point for the wisest election, more
especially where Etymologies are not added, and Historical observations 
on antiquitated words are wanting.

Discreet Reader, not to insist on many particulars, I have endea&shy;
voured throughout this Work to be so far thy assistant, as that what 
others have omitted in all their former undertakings I have inserted, 
A large Poeticall, as also a Geographicall Dictionary, the later not 
onely for the most parts of the World, but also diligently reflecting 
and giving useful descriptions of the Antiquities of Cities, Towns, 
and other eminent Places of <f type="i">England, Scotland,<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Ireland,<f type="r"> so that 
for a small expence Strangers as well as our own Countrymen may 
travell in this Dictionary. To include all words, especially those 
that relate to the Mechanicks, is an impossible task.
</page>

<page sig="d1v">
Indeed as I have indeavoured to wave obsolete terms which some
make it their businesse to pick up at any rate, so I hope I have not 
been wanting in useful words, but have so compleated this Volume, 
that he that hath but a competent knowledge of the Greek and La&shy;
tin, the English will quickly surrender it selfe to his interpretation.
Some Critticks perhaps will expect the names of Authours in the tra&shy;
verse of this Worke to be often set down as single testimonies for 
the fantasticalnesse of their own words; such an undertaking I look 
upon as no lesse needlesse, then abusive and ridiculous.

Courteous Reader, I shall not trifle with such niceties and imper&shy;
tinencies as one of our late Writers hath done, taking notice of hard 
words promiscuously as they are scattered in English Bookes. To use
his own words. <f type="i">In the Turkish History I met with Janizaries, Ba&shy;
sh&aelig;s, Seraglios; in the French, in the Spanish, in the Roman, Hi&shy;
stories, in which he likewise instances particulars.<f type="r"> and so in other 
Subjects runnes on to what purpose I know not, wasting so much of 
his Readers time and patience, when he knowes those words to be 
in his Alphabet, which if persons are so learned as to finde out
<f type="i">A, B, C,<f type="r"> they may without his anticipating easily enforme them&shy;
selves of.

To passe by such vanities, the Saxon words, as in reference
to our Lawes, cannot be accounted so obsolete as some would have
them. For my own part, I have made it my businesse with my great&shy;
est care and diligence to consult with ancient Manuscripts; nor have 
I wanted in these scrutinizings the assistance of Grand Persons. As 
touching some of our late Modern Authorizers of words. The Vi&shy;
count of <f type="i">St. Albans,<f type="r"> Sir <f type="i">Kenelme Digby, Mr. Selden, Dr. Brown,<f type="r"> 
and others, whatsoever Termes we have received from them, the 
Learned do acknowledge them to be good Bullion stampt and well 
minted, so that as they have past the censure of the present, they 
will command the test and honour of future Ages; and if we do but
seriously consider how our Language is inricht from forreign words, 
brought home to our doores, from the Greek, Latin, French Ora&shy;
tors and Poets, even from such a distance, we cannot but have 
more inlarged and proper respects to our own Native Laurels; it is 
our happinesse that being a terror to other nations, we are now free 
from invaders that formerly altred our Language, otherwise our 
clothes should not be more varied then our Speech, as the tyranny 
of Strangers if it were possible would apparel our very thoughts. 
Certainly it is a higher prerogative for our Nations to have these 
forreign Languages as it were onely in the Landskip, that though we 
honour the smoothnesse of the French, the neatnesse of the Italian, 
the gravity of the Spaniard, yet still we remain so happy as to be 
our own Dictionary.

Not to dwell longer on this discourse, it is the expression of Mr. 
<f type="i">H. B.<f type="r"> in his endeavours tending this way, <f type="i">That a Dictionary for 
the English Tongue, would require an Encyclopedie of knowledge, 
and the concurrence of many Learned heads<f type="r">. Such an Encyclo&shy;
pedy I present thee Reader with from the Muses, as it was deli&shy;
vered me from the forked top of their <f type="i">Parnassus;<f type="r"> for I shall ever
</page>

<page sig="d2r">
acknowledge such peculiar aides as I received from severall Learned 
Persons, otherwise I can faithfully assert for the building up of this 
Volume, next to the use of grand Dictionaries, I have onely been behold&shy;
ing to the imperfect remaines of a Gentleman who long since begun this 
Work: First his sicknesse impeding, and then impartial death cut&shy;
ting him short of finishing his Design, the best Schollars that then 
perused his Labours, did with one voice render him this honour; 
That his Collections were choice, That he had taken up nothing but 
what was Authentick, and that the Learned themselves, in some re&shy;
spects, might be obliged to him for his Studies.

To conclude, Courteous Reader, this Volume which the so many years 
industry of my self and others hath brought to such a perfection, is for 
thine, and the general good, now at last, made publick; I wish thee all 
happinesse in thy necessary search and use of it. Farewell.
</page>

<page sig="d2v6">
COurteous Reader, faults are usual in the 
printing of Generall Tracts, but in Dicti&shy;
onaries and Works of this kind, I am truly 
sensible that, as they will seem more strange 
to thee, so they reflect more on the Authours credit; 
to purchase thy more favourable construction, I have
collected an Alphabetical Index of the Capital <f type="i">Errata,<f type="r">
which is placed at the end of the Book.<f type="r">
</section>
</page>

<page sig="A1r">
<section type="dictionary">

<heading>
THE NEW WORLD 
Of English Words. 
Or, a General
Dictionary.

Containing the Terms, Etymologies, Definitions, and 
perfect Interpretations of the Proper significations of hard English 
words, throughout the Arts and Sciences, Liberal; and Mechanick, 
as also all other subjects, that are usefull, or appertain to the Lan&shy;
guage of our Nation.
</heading>

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="aa"><alpha>A. A.</alpha>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Aaron(pn)"><f type="i">AAron<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Amram<f type="r">, and
brother of <f type="i">Moses<f type="r">,
he was the first High-Priest of the Jews, being chosen to
that dignity by the budding of his Rod, <class lang="he" type="etymlang">the word signifies
in Hebr. a Teacher, or Mountain
of fortitude</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Aaron(pn)"><f type="i">Aaron<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a great Emperour of the
<f type="i">Saracens<f type="r">, who
leading into <f type="i">Asia<f type="r"> an Army of 300000. men,
compelled <f type="i">Nicephorus<f type="r"> the Greek Emperour, to make
peace with him, on Ignominions, and dishonourable
terms.</xpln></wordentry>

</wordgroup1>
<wordgroup1 type="a" object="ab"><alpha>A. B.</alpha>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Aba(pn)"><f type="i">Aba<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Tyrant of <f type="i">Hungaria<f type="r">, who
being slain by his own subjects, and buried in the next
Church, not long after was digged out of the earth again,
where being found with his winding-sheet, and other
cloathes uncorrupted,
and unchanged, and all his wounds cured, he was honoured
with a nobler burial, and
his bones translated to a Monastery, built by himself, and
there interred.</xpln></wordentry>

forcing away.</xpln>

</lemenote>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Aberconwey(pn)"><f type="i">Aberconwey</form>, <xpln>q.<f type="r"> the mouth of
