<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Abergevenny(pn)" lexeme="abergenny(n)"><f type="i">Abergevenny<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Abergenny<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>so
called, because it is
situate at the very meeting of the Rivers <f type="i">Vsk<f type="r">,
and <f type="i">Gebenny<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Gobanny<f type="r">, it is called in
Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Gobanium<f type="r"></term>, and is fortified with a very
strong Castle, which hath been the seat of many great
Lords and Earles.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="abessed(a)"><f type="i">Abessed<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="old word">(old word)</class> cast down,
humbled.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Academia(pn)"><f type="i">Academia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Wooddy place, about a mile from
<f type="i">Athens<f type="r">, built by <f type="i">Academus<f type="r">, where
<f type="i">Plato<f type="r"> was born and taught Philosophy, whence
the word <f type="i">Academy<f type="r"> is taken for any publick
Shool, or University.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Acadinus(pn)"><f type="i">Acadinus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Fountain in <f type="i">Sicily<f type="r">, in
which they used to try the truth of an Oath, by writing
the words of him that swore upon a Table of wood, and if
the wood did swim, they took the words for truth, but if
it sunk, they took it to be a false Oath.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Acarnar(pn)"><f type="i">Acarnar<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the bright Starre of <f type="i">Eridanus,

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Acastus(pn)"><f type="i">Acastus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Peleus<f type="r">, King
of <f type="i">Thessaly<f type="r">, a
famous Hunter with Bow and Arrows, he married
<f type="i">Hippolita<f type="r">, who loving <f type="i">Pelius<f type="r">,
because he yielded not to
her love, accused him to her husband, for having offered
violence to her, wherefore <f type="i">Acastus<f type="r"> threw him to
be devoured of wilde beasts, but Mercury coming in the
interim, freed <f type="i">Pelius<f type="r">
with Vulcans sword, who returning slew <f type="i">Acastus<f type="r">
and <f type="i">Hippolita<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Achelous(pn)"><f type="i">Achelous<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Oceanus<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Terra<f type="r">, he fought a single Combat with <f type="i">Hercules<f type="r"> for
<f type="i">Deianira<f type="r">, he first changed himself into a Serpent, then into a Bull, one of whose Horns
<f type="i">Hercules<f type="r"> cut, and dedicated it to plenty the Companion of Fortune, but afterward
<f type="i">Achetous<f type="r"> giving him <f type="i">Amalthea's<f type="r"> Horn
received his own again, also the name of a River in <f type="i">Epirus<f type="r"> rising from the
Mountain <f type="i">Pindus<f type="r">, and is said to be the first River that broke out, after
the general Deluge.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Acheron(pn)"><f type="i">Acheron<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Ceres<f type="r">, without
a father, whom, when she
had brought forth in a dark cave in <f type="i">Sicily<f type="r">, not
daring to behold the light
he was sent to <f type="i">Tartarus<f type="r">, and there turned into a
River over which the Souls of men are carried, it is
commonly taken for Hell.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Achilles(pn)"><f type="i">Achilles<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Peleus<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Thesis<f type="r">, whom his mother while he was an infant,
dipt all over in the river <f type="i">Styx<f type="r">, so that he
became invulnerable all
over, save in that part of his heel, by which she held
him, he was put to the <f type="i">Centaur Chiron<f type="r">, to be
instructed
</page>

<page sig="A3r">
in warlike affairs and musick; and being grown to age,
his Mother hearing he should die in the Trojan wars put
him into Womans apparel
and hid him among the Daughters of <f type="i">Lycomede<f type="r">
where he ravish't <f type="i">Deidamia<f type="r">, and begot
<f type="i">Pyrrhus<f type="r">, being seduced from thence by the craft
of <f type="i">Vlisses<f type="r">, he fought against the Trojans, slew
<f type="i">Hector<f type="r">, and performed many other great exploits
in that war.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Aeacus(pn)"><f type="i">Aeacus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> by
<f type="i">Aegina<f type="r">, he was said to be so just, that, when he
was dead, he was chosen one of the infernal Judges, with
<f type="i">Minos<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Rhadamanthus<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Aedone(pn)"><f type="i">Aedone<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the Wife of <f type="i">Zethus<f type="r"> the
Brother of <f type="i">Amphion<f type="r">, she slew her son
<f type="i">Itylus<f type="r"> in the night thinking him to have been
<f type="i">Amaneus<f type="r"> the son of <f type="i">Amphion<f type="r">, but
afterwards acknowledging her error, she desired to die,
and was changed into a Thistle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Aeeta(pn)"><f type="i">Aeeta<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the King of <f type="i">Colchos<f type="r"> the son
of <f type="i">Sol<f type="r"> by <f type="i">Persa<f type="r"> the daughter of
<f type="i">Oceanus<f type="r">, he begat
<f type="i">Medea, Absyrtus<f type="r">, and <f type="i">Calciope<f type="r">, to him
<f type="i">Phryxus<f type="r"> brought the golden Fleece, which, with
the help of <f type="i">Medea<f type="r"> was won from him by
<f type="i">Jason<f type="r"> and the Argonaut's and he
deposed from his
Kingdom.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Aega(pn)"><f type="i">Aega<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Nymph, the Daughter of

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Aeg&aelig;on(pn)"><f type="i">Aeg&aelig;on<f type="r"></form> <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Titan<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Terra<f type="r">, who at one lift threw a hundred Rocks
against <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">, but being overcome, was bound by
<f type="i">Neptune<f type="r"> to a Rock in the <f type="i">Aeg&aelig;an<f type="r">-Sea.

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Aegeus(pn)"><f type="i">Aegeus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Neptune<f type="r">, King
of <f type="i">Athens<f type="r">, who had by his Wife <f type="i">Aetha<f type="r"> the
daughter of <f type="i">Pitheus<f type="r">, a son named
<f type="i">Theseus<f type="r">, the greatest Hero of that time, whom he
thinking to have been slain when he returned from
<f type="i">Crete<f type="r"> threw himself into the Sea, and was by the
Athenians made one of the Sea-Gods.</xpln></wordentry>

continued while he lived.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Aegyptus(pn)"><f type="i">Aegyptus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Belus<f type="r">, the
brother of <f type="i">Danais<f type="r">. He having fifty daughters,
gave them in marriage to his brothers fifty sons, but they
having receiv'd instructions from their father
<f type="i">Danaus<f type="r">, each one killed their Husband, the first
night of their marriage,
except <f type="i">Hypermnestra<f type="r"> who saved her Husband
<f type="i">Lynceus<f type="r">, who afterwards driving out
<f type="i">Danaus<f type="r">, possest the Kingdome of <f type="i">Argos<f type="r">;
also a famous Country of <f type="i">Lybia<f type="r">, once a great
Kingdome, now a Province under the Turks dominion.</xpln></wordentry>

ty years after his Father-in-law's death.

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="era(n)"><f type="i">Aera<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="history">a Term in Chronologie</class> signifying the

from which people compute
the number of years, as the Jews reckn'd from
<f type="i">Abraham<f type="r">'s journey out of <f type="i">Chaldea<f type="r">, or
from their deliverance out of <f type="i">Egypt<f type="r">, &amp;c. the

from the birth of Christ.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Aesacus(pn)"><f type="i">Aesacus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Priamus<f type="r">, who
being in love with a beautiful Virgin call'd
<f type="i">Hesperia<f type="r">, never
left following her in the Woods, but she flying from him
was at length kill'd by the bite of a Serpent, he
impatient of his loss threw himself from a high Rock into
the Sea, where <f type="i">Thetis<f type="r"> taking compassion on him,
transform'd him into a Dive-dapper.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Aesculapius(pn)"><f type="i">Aesculapius<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Apollo<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Coronis<f type="r">, he, being taught by <f type="i">Chiron<f type="r"> the
art of Physick, restor'd
<f type="i">Hippolitus<f type="r"> the son of <f type="i">Theseus<f type="r"> to life,
who, because the had refus'd the
embraces of
<f type="i">Ph&aelig;dra<f type="r"> his Mother-in-law, was by her meanes torn
in pieces by wild Horses, but <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> was so
incens't at this cure that he slew <f type="i">Aesculapius<f type="r">
with a thunderbolt.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Aesica(n)"><f type="i">Aesica<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an ancient City of
<f type="i">Cumberland<f type="r"> (upon the River <f type="i">Esk<f type="r">) where
the Tribune of the <f type="i">Austures<f type="r"> in old time kept
watch and ward against the Northern enemies.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Aesia(n)"><f type="i">Aesia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a River in <f type="i">France<f type="r"> now
call'd <f type="i">Oyse<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="aestuate(v)">To <f type="i">Aestuate<f type="r"><f type="r"></form> <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> to burn; to rage like

he first gave himself to robbing, but afterwards by his
stoutnesse and eloquence, he was advanced to the Kingdom,

but seeking to inlarge his Dominions, he was betrayed, and
died for grief.</xpln></wordentry>

<f type="i">Athenians<f type="r"> and

<f type="i">Athenian<f type="r">, and brother of <f type="i">Themistocles<f type="r">;
he being judged to be sacrificed at the Altar of the Sun,
for killing <f type="i">Mardonius<f type="r">, held his hand a good while
in the fire without changing his countenance, and affirmed
that all the <f type="i">Athenians<f type="r"> were such as himself,
whereupon he was set free.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Ajax(pn)"><f type="i">Ajax<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Telamon<f type="r">, and
<f type="i">Hesione<f type="r"> daughter of <f type="i">Laomedon<f type="r">, he was one
of the stoutest of all the <f type="i">Greeks<f type="r"> that went to
the <f type="i">Trojan<f type="r"> War, he fought with <f type="i">Hector<f type="r">,
and had a contest with <f type="i">Vlisses<f type="r">, for the armes of
<f type="i">Achilles<f type="r">, but <f type="i">Vlisses<f type="r"> having gain'd them
by his eloquence, <f type="i">Ajax<f type="r"> run mad, and made a huge
slaughter among a flock of sheep, thinking
<f type="i">Vlisses<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Atrides<f type="r"> to have been among
them, also the name of the son of <f type="i">Oileus<f type="r"> King of
the <f type="i">Locri<f type="r">, who for vitiating <f type="i">Cassandra<f type="r">
in the Temple of <f type="i">Pallas<f type="r">, was slain with Thunder
by the Goddesse, whose Priestesse she was.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="aid(n)"><f type="i">Aide<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> help, also a subsidy, or

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Aidoneus(pn)"><f type="i">Aidoneus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>King of the <f type="i">Molossi<f type="r">, he
sent <f type="i">Theseus<f type="r"> to prison, because he, and
<f type="i">Pirithous<f type="r"> would have taken away his daughter
<f type="i">Proserpina<f type="r">,
not far from the River <f type="i">Acheron<f type="r">, which gave
occasion to the fable, to say that he descended into Hell
to fetch away <f type="i">Proserpina<f type="r">, the daughter of
<f type="i">Dis<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Ailesbury(n)"><f type="i">Ailesbury<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town situate not far from the

<f type="i">Cutwulph<f type="r"> the <f type="i">Saxon<f type="r">, in the year 572. and
hath been famous in times past, by
being the habitation of St.
<f type="i">Edith<f type="r">, the daughter
of <f type="i">Frewald<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Ailesford(pn)"><f type="i">Ailesford<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town in <f type="i">Kent<f type="r">, not far

the <f type="i">British<f type="r"> tongue <f type="i">Saissen&aelig;g-haibal<f type="r">,

<f type="i">Vortimer<f type="r"> the <f type="i">Brittain<f type="r">, son of
<f type="i">Vortigern<f type="r"> to <f type="i">Hengist<f type="r">, and his

<f type="i">Amphiaraus<f type="r">, and afterwards runne mad; but being
cured by <f type="i">Phlegias<f type="r">, he married
his daughter <f type="i">Olph&aelig;stb&aelig;a<f type="r">,
giving her a Bracelet of his mothers, but afterwards
falling in love with one of <f type="i">Achetous<f type="r"> his
daughters, called <f type="i">Callirhoe<f type="r">, he promised her the
Bracelet which he had given his former wife, on condition
she would marry him, but going to fetch it, he was slain
by <f type="i">Temon<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Axion, Alphesib&aelig;as<f type="r">
brothers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Amalthea(pn)"><f type="i">Amalthea<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the Nurse of
<f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">, she fed him with Goats milk, and he
afterwards as a reward gave her the horn of a Goat, which
had this faculty, that whatsoever she desired she should
have it, whence <f type="i">Amalthean<f type="r">
horn hath been taken for an embleme of plenty.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Amazon(pn)"><f type="i">Amazons<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>certain warlike women of
<f type="i">Asia<f type="r">, that dwelt near the River
<f type="i">Thermodoon<f type="r">, who burnt off their right paps, and
killed all their Male Children, that they might have no
man among them, their most renowned Queens were
<f type="i">Mathesia, Orithya, Penthesilea<f type="r">, whom
<f type="i">Achilles<f type="r"> slew, coming to help the <f type="i">Trojans,
Menalippe<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Hippolyta<f type="r">, whom
<f type="i">Hercules<f type="r"> overcame, and gave <f type="i">Theseus<f type="r"> to
wife.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="ambacti(n)"><f type="i">Ambacti<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>among the ancient Gauls, were
those servants and dependants, which
belonged to their chief Nobility.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="amber(n)"><f type="i">Amber<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a hard yellow Gum, of which they

Poplar Trees, others the juyce of a certain stone that
grows like Corral.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="ambergris(n)"><f type="i">Ambergreece<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a sweet perfume, or
Aromatick juyce, which
some hold to be a kinde of bitumen, rising from Fountains
in the bottom of the Sea, and becoming hard by floating
upon the water.</xpln></wordentry>

<f type="i">Wiltshire<f type="r">, built by <f type="i">Ambrose Aurelian<f type="r">,

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Amphiaraus(pn)"><f type="i">Amphiaraus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Oileus<f type="r">, he
was a great Prophet, who was desired by
<f type="i">Adrastus<f type="r">, to go
to the War of <f type="i">Thebes<f type="r">, but he knowing he should
not return, kept himself private, till being betrayed by
his wife <f type="i">Eriphile<f type="r">,
who was bribed with a golden bracelet,
he was forced to go, but the first day he came to
<f type="i">Thebes<f type="r">, he was swallowed up alive by the
earth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="amphibious(a)"><f type="i">Amphibious<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> living indifferently

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="amphictyons(n)"><f type="i">Amphictions<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> the Councel of
<f type="i">Greece<f type="r">, consisting of men chosen out of the
twelve chief Cities, for the making of laws, and deciding

<f type="i">Amphyction<f type="r"> the son of <f type="i">Hellen<f type="r">, or as
others say by <f type="i">Acrisius<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Amphion(pn)"><f type="i">Amphion<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Antiope<f type="r">,
who being married to <f type="i">Lycus<f type="r">, and after vitiated by
<f type="i">Epaphus<f type="r">, was imprisoned by <f type="i">Dirce Lycus<f type="r">'s
2. wife, but being set at liberty by <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">, she
fled to the Hill <f type="i">Cytheron<f type="r">, where she brought
forth Twins, <f type="i">Zethus<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Amphion<f type="r">, who to
revenge their mothers injuries,
tormented <f type="i">Dirce<f type="r"> by tying her to a wilde Bull's
tale, but <f type="i">Bacchus<f type="r"> pitying her, changed her to a
Fountain, <f type="i">Amphion<f type="r"> became
so rare a Musician, that he was said to build the
<f type="i">Theban<f type="r"> Walls, by playing upon <f type="i">Mercuries<f type="r">
Harp.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Amphiscian(pn)"><f type="i">Amphiscians<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> those people that live
under the Equator, where the shadow's are cast both wayes,
North and South.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="amphitheater(n)"><f type="i">Amphitheater<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a place made for the
acting of stage-playes, and
publick spectacles differing from a common Theater, as
being more perfect, and built in a full circle, the other
onely in a semicircle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Amphitrite(pn)"><f type="i">Amphitrite<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of <f type="i">Nereus<f type="r">
and <f type="i">Doris<f type="r">, the wife of Neptune, she sitting at
the foot of <f type="i">Atlas<f type="r">, was brought to him by a
<f type="i">Dolphin<f type="r">, and made Queen of the Sea.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Amphitryo(pn)"><f type="i">Amphitryo<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Alceus<f type="r">
Prince of <f type="i">Thebes<f type="r">, who married <f type="i">Alcmena<f type="r">,
daughter of <f type="i">Electryon<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Lysidice<f type="r">, upon
that condition that he should revenge the death of her
brothers upon the <f type="i">Teleboans<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Taphians<f type="r">, but while he was in the War,
<f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> coming to
her in the likenesse of her husband,
and lying with her, she brought forth Twins,
<f type="i">Hercules<f type="r"> son to <f type="i">Jupiter, Iphiclus<f type="r"> to
<f type="i">Amphitryo<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Amsanctus(pn)"><f type="i">Amsanctus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a place in the midst of

inclosed round about with Woods, which gave occasion to
the Poets to faign that the infernal Ghosts had their
abode there.</xpln></wordentry>

preserveth from the plague, poyson, or inchantment.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Amulius(pn)"><f type="i">Amulius<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>King of the <f type="i">Latin's<f type="r">, he
disposest his brother <f type="i">Numitor<f type="r"> of the Kingdom, and
made a Vestal of his <f type="i">Neece Rhea Silvia<f type="r">, but she
being got with Childe by <f type="i">Mars<f type="r"> (as it was
reported) brought forth <f type="i">Romulus<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Remus<f type="r">, who afterwards reigned.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Amycus(pn)"><f type="i">Amycus<f type="r"></form> <xpln>King of the
<f type="i">Bebrycii<f type="r">,
the son of Neptune and <f type="i">Melie<f type="r">, who challenging all
strangers to fight with him with whirlebats, was at length
slain by <f type="i">Pollux<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Amymone(pn)"><f type="i">Amymone<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>one of the fifty daughters of
<f type="i">Dan&aelig;<f type="r">, she was ravish't by Neptune, and brought
forth <f type="i">Nauplius<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Amyris(pn)"><f type="i">Amyris<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an inhabitant of <f type="i">Sybaris<f type="r">,
who foretelling the ruine of his Countrey fled away with
all his goods.</xpln></wordentry>

</wordgroup1>
<wordgroup1 type="a" object="an"><alpha>A N</alpha>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="ana(adv)"><f type="i">Ana<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">a Greek adverb</class>, used by
Physitians in their
bills to signifie the like quantity
of each, also a kind of <f type="i">Indian<f type="r"> beasts with long
teeth, and sharp nails.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="B4v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Anabaptists(pn)"><f type="i">Anabaptists<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Sect of Hereticks first
begun in <f type="i">Germany<f type="r">,
as some say, by one <f type="i">Nicholas
Stork<f type="r">, in the year 1521. their chief
Tenet is that men ought
not be baptized, till they are able to render an account
of their faith.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="anabathrum(n)"><class type="unknown">&dagger;</class> <f type="i">Anabathrum<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a place
whereunto we ascend by
steps.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="anacardium(n)"><f type="i">Anacardium<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a kinde of bean growing
in <f type="i">Malaga<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="anachorite(n)"><f type="i">Anachorite<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a kinde of religious
person that gives himself up to a religious life.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Anacreon(pn)"><f type="i">Anacreon<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous Lyrick Poet of
<f type="i">Teus<f type="r"> in <f type="i">Jonia<f type="r">, who was choaked with the
husk of a raison.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="anacrisis(n)"><class type="unknown">&dagger;</class> <f type="i">Anacrisis<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> question of the
guilty, either by torment, or by
interrogation.</xpln></wordentry>

Chronology</class>, signifying a false collection of time.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="anadesm(n)"><f type="i">Anadesme<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a swath, a cloath, to tie

Rhetorick</class>, <f type="i">i.
e.<f type="r"> when one verse begins with the same word the last
ended with.</xpln></wordentry>

so as to make another word
of it, which art some say was invented
by Lycophron.</xpln></wordentry>

repetition of the same sound, in the
beginning of several
sentences, or verses, also the ascention of the signs,
from the East by the dayly course of the firmament.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Anaxarete(pn)"><f type="i">Anaxarete<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a beautifull Virgin of
<f type="i">Salamis<f type="r">, who
disdaining the love of <f type="i">Iphis<f type="r">, was the cause that
he hang'd himself before the her door, and was afterwards,
for her hard heartednesse turned into a stone.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Anaximander(pn)"><f type="i">Anaximander<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a great <f type="i">Milesian<f type="r">
Philosopher, the
Successour of <f type="i">Thales<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Ancoeus(pn)"><f type="i">Ancoeus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of Neptune, he being much
given to <f type="i">Agriculture<f type="r">, and going to drive a wilde
Boar out of a Vineyard he had planted, was slain by the
Boar.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Ancaster(pn)"><f type="i">Ancaster<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town, or long street in
<f type="i">Lincolnshire<f type="r">,
by <f type="i">Antoninus<f type="r"> called <f type="i">Crocolana<f type="r">, in which
the memory of Antiquity is continued
by the Roman Coines, and Vaults under ground oftentimes
discovered.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Anchises(pn)"><f type="i">Anchises<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Capys<f type="r">, he was
carried by his son <f type="i">Aeneas<f type="r"> from the sack of
<f type="i">Troy<f type="r">, but died in his journy toward
<f type="i">Italy<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Anchurus(pn)"><f type="i">Anchurus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Midas<f type="r">, he
after <f type="i">Midas<f type="r"> was
warned by the Oracle to throw what he had most precious
into a great gap of the earth, about <f type="i">Celenon<f type="r"> in
<f type="i">Phrygia<f type="r">, &amp; had thrown in his gold in vain,
her rode into the <f type="i">Abysse<f type="r">, which had swallowed
many men, and afterwards it closed up.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Ancus Martius(pn)"><f type="i">Ancus Martius<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the fourth King of the
Romans.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="ancil(n)"><f type="i">Ancil<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(Lat.)</class> a kinde of sheild, or
buckler, made after the
fashion of a decrescent Moon, the first of this form was
reported to fall from heaven into the hands of
<f type="i">Pompilius,
Numa<f type="r">, in the time of a great plague, who by the
instinct of the Goddesse <f type="i">Ege&shy;
</page>

<page sig="C1r">
ria<f type="r"> caused eleven more to be made, and committed them to the
keeping of the 12.  <f type="i">Salii<f type="r">.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Andradswald(pn)"><f type="i">Andradswald<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Wood in <f type="i">Sussex<f type="r">,
<emend err="aciently">anciently</emend> 120 miles in length, memorable for the death of
<f type="i">Sigebert<f type="r">, King of the West <f type="i">Saxons<f type="r">, who

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="angelical(a)"><f type="i">Angelical<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> belonging to an
Angel, <f type="i">i.<f type="r"> a
messenger, the Angels are also taken
in holy Scripture for those immortal spirits, which wait
upon Almighty God in the highest heavens, they are divided
by Saint <f type="i">Paul<f type="r">, into nine several orders,
<f type="i">Seraphim, Cherubim,
Thrones, Dominations, Virtues, Powers, Principates,
Arch-Angel<f type="r">, and <f type="i">Angel<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="angle(n)"><f type="i">Angle<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a corner, also <class type="register" subject="mathematics">a Term in
Geometry</class>, being the
concurse of two lines meeting
together, so as that they do not make one line.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="angle(n)"><f type="i">Angles<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>also are the most powerfull
houses; for a Planet
therein hath more power, and efficacy then another (in any
other house) that is but equally dignified. The Angles are
these, <f type="i">viz.<f type="r"> The first house, or the East Angle,
the tenth, or the South Angle, the seventh house, or the
West Angle, and the fourth, or the North
Angle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="anglia(n)"><f type="i">Anglia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a part of great <f type="i">Brittain<f type="r">,

<f type="i">England<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Anglesey(pn)"><f type="i">Anglesey<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an Island lying over against
<f type="i">C&aelig;rnarvon<f type="r"> in <f type="i">Wales<f type="r">, it was anciently
the seat of the <f type="i">Druides<f type="r">, and was called by the
<f type="i">Brittains, <term lang="br">Ynis Dowil</term><f type="r">, and the land of
<f type="i"><term lang="br">Mon</term><f type="r">, in Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Mona</term><f type="r">. It was first
attempted by <f type="i">Paulinus Swetonius<f type="r">, and afterwards
brought under the <f type="i">Roman<f type="r"> Empire by <f type="i">Julius
Agricola<f type="r">, many ages
after it was Conquered by the <f type="i">English-men<f type="r">, and
thence derived this name as it were the
<f type="i">English-mens<f type="r"> Island.</xpln></wordentry>

Tropicks, so much on the other side the Tropick shall the
Antiscion of the Planet fall, and shall give virtue to any
Star, or Planet that is in the same
degree, or casteth any
Aspect thereto.</xpln></wordentry>

<f type="i"><term lang="la">Aoristus primus</term><f type="r">,

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Aornus(pn)"><f type="i">Aornus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Lake in <f type="i">Italy<f type="r">, near the
River <f type="i">Po<f type="r">, whose waters are infected with a deadly
noysomnesse: into this Lake, the Poets feign that
<f type="i">Ph&aelig;ton<f type="r"> fell being struck with
thunder, and that his
sisters weeping for him were changed into poplars dropping
<f type="i">Amber<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Apollo(pn)"><f type="i">Apollo<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Latona<f type="r">, born in <f type="i">Delos<f type="r">, at one birth with
<f type="i">Diana<f type="r">, coming to
age, he slew the Serpent <f type="i">Pytho<f type="r">, and afterwards
the <f type="i">Cyclops<f type="r">, for which he was deprived of his
Divinity, and kept the sheep of <f type="i">Admetus<f type="r">, King of
<f type="i">Thessaly<f type="r">, upon the banks of <f type="i">Amphrysus<f type="r">,
he loved <f type="i">Daphne<f type="r">, who flying from him was turned
into a Lawrel-Tree, also he loved <f type="i">Hyacynthus<f type="r">, a
boy of a rare feature, whom killing by mischance, he
turned into a flowr; he was called the God of physick, of
Musick and Archery, and guided the Chariot of the
day.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Arion(pn)"><f type="i">Arion<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous Musician of the Isle of
<f type="i">Lesbos<f type="r">, he was in great favour with
<f type="i">Periander<f type="r">
Tyrant of <f type="i">Corinth<f type="r">, as he was sayling from
<f type="i">Italy<f type="r">, the Mariners conspired to kill him for his
riches, but he casting himself into the Sea, was carried
by a Dolphin to <f type="i">T&aelig;narus<f type="r">; a Town of
<f type="i">Laconia<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<f type="i">Ceres<f type="r">, he was King of <f type="i">Arcadia<f type="r">, and found
out the use of Bees, but because <f type="i">Euridice<f type="r"> flying
from him, was slain by the bite of a
Serpent, the Nymphes
destroyed his Bees, to appease, whom he having sacrificed
four Oxen, and four Heifers, a multitude of Bees sprung
from the dead Oxen.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Atalanta(pn)"><f type="i">Atalanta<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of
<f type="i">Schoeneus<f type="r"> King of <f type="i">Scyrus<f type="r">, she being
swift of foot, it was proposed
among her suiters, that he, who could out-run her, should
have her for his wife, but many of them being overcome, at
length <f type="i">Hippomenes<f type="r"> the son of <f type="i">Megacles<f type="r">,
who had received three golden Apples of <f type="i">Venus<f type="r">,
that had been gathered in the <f type="i">Hesperian<f type="r"> Garden,
let them fall in the midst of the Race, and by that means
arrived at the end before her, also the name of a great
Huntresse of <f type="i">Arcadia<f type="r">, who gave the first wound to
the <f type="i">Caledonian<f type="r"> Boar, and was
afterwards married to
<f type="i">Meleager<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="average(n)"><f type="i">Average<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="etymlang" lang="la">from the old <f type="i">Latin<f type="r"> word
<f type="i"><term lang="la">Averia</term><f type="r"></class>, which
signifies a beast; it being a service,
which a Tenant does unto the Lord by horse, or carriage of
horse, and so the Kings <f type="i">Averages<f type="r"> are
the Kings carriages by
horse, or cart, it is also a contribution that <class type="register" subject="merchanise">Merchants</class> 
and others make, towards the losses of those, who have
their goods cast into the Sea for the safeguard of the
ship.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="avoirdupois(n)"><f type="i">Averdupois<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> it signifies <class type="register" subject="law">in
Common-law</class>, a weight
of 16 Ounces, whereas Troy-weight hath but 12. also <class type="register" subject="merchandise">such
Merchandizes</class> as are
weighed by this weight.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Avernus(pn)"><f type="i">Avernus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Lake in <f type="i">Campania<f type="r"> near
<f type="i">Bai&aelig;<f type="r">, whose vapours were so deadly, that birds
were kill'd as they flew over, which made the ancients

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Augeas(pn)"><f type="i">Augeas<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>King of <f type="i">Elis<f type="r">, the son of
<f type="i">Sol<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Nauphridame<f type="r">, he had a stable
which held 3000 Oxen, which <f type="i">Hercules<f type="r"> cleansed
by bringing in the River <f type="i">Alpheus<f type="r">, but being
denied his pay, he killed <f type="i">Augeas<f type="r">, and made his
son <f type="i">Phileus<f type="r"> King.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="augmentation(n)"><f type="i">Augmentation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(Lat.)</class> an increasing, the

erected by <f type="i">Henry<f type="r">
the eighth, for the increase of the Revenues of the Crown,
by the suppression of
Abbies and religious houses.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Auses(pn)"><f type="i">Auses<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a people of <f type="i">Africa<f type="r">, among

<f type="i">Tritonis<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Ausones(pn)"><f type="i">Ausones<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a very ancient people of

<f type="i">Circeii<f type="r">,

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Austrasia(pn)"><f type="i">Austrasia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>that part which contains
<f type="i">Brabant<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Lorrain<f type="r">, it was anciently
reckoned a part of <f type="i">France<f type="r">, and was a Kingdom of it self, having
<f type="i">Mets<f type="r"> for its chief seat, there being anciently in
<f type="i">France<f type="r"> four Kingdoms,
<f type="i">Austrasie, Soissons, Orleans<f type="r">, and
<f type="i">Paris<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<f type="i">Pannonia<f type="r">,

daughter of <f type="i">Lucifer<f type="r">, he received this gift from

being deprehended, he
ravish't <f type="i">Anticlia<f type="r">, the daughter of
<f type="i">Sisyphus<f type="r">, who being with childe was given to
<f type="i">L&aelig;rtes<f type="r">, and brought forth
<f type="i">Vlisses<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

which was there caused, it

situate upon the River <f type="i">Isis<f type="r">, where Sir <f type="i">R.
Vere<f type="r">, Earle of <f type="i">Oxford<f type="r">, Marquesse of
<f type="i">Dublin<f type="r">, and Duke of <f type="i">Ireland<f type="r">, being in
great favour and Authority with King <f type="i">Richard<f type="r"> the
second, was defeated by the Nobles, forced to swim over
the River, and to fly his Countrey.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Bacchus(pn)"><f type="i">Bacchus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the
inventour of wine, he was the son of <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Semele<f type="r">, who desiring to lye with <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">
in all his glory was burnt up with Thunder, and
<f type="i">Bacchus<f type="r"> being cut out of her Womb, was inserted
into <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">'s Thigh, untill the birth were
mature, he is also called <f type="i">Dionysius, Liber Pater<f type="r">,
and <f type="i">Osiris<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

scituate upon the River
<f type="i">Rhene<f type="r">, called <f type="i">Holland<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Bath(pn)"><f type="i">Bath<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous Citie in
<f type="i">Sommersetshire<f type="r">, so called from the hot Baths of
Medicinal waters, which are there by <f type="i">Antoninus<f type="r">
called <f type="i">Aqu&aelig;
solis<f type="r">, by <f type="i">Ptolomy<f type="r"> <term lang="gk">&#x1F59;&#x03B4;&#x03B1;&#x03C4;&#x03B1; &#x03B8;&#x03AD;&#x03C1;&#x03BC;&#x03B1;</term>, some
report them to have been found out by <f type="i">Bleyden<f type="r"> a
Magician, others by <f type="i">Julius C&aelig;sar<f type="r">, others by an
ancient <f type="i">Brittish<f type="r"> King.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Battail-field(pn)"><f type="i">Battail-field<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a place near
<f type="i">Shrewsbury<f type="r">, so called from the great battail
fought there between King <f type="i">Henry<f type="r"> the fourth, and
<f type="i">Edmund Mortimer<f type="r">,
Earle of <f type="i">March<f type="r">, where Sir <f type="i">Henry Piercy<f type="r">,
called <f type="i">Hotsspur<f type="r"> was slain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="battalion(n)"><f type="i">Battalion<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> the main battle of an
Army.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Battle-bridge(pn)"><f type="i">Battle-bridge<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a place in

called <f type="i">Stanford-bridge<f type="r">, where <f type="i">Harald<f type="r">

flat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="battology(n)"><f type="i">Battology<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a vain repetition of words.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Battus(pn)"><f type="i">Battus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain keeper of Mares, to whom
Mercury delivered several Oxen, which he had stollen from
<f type="i">Apollo<f type="r">, keeping <f type="i">Admetus<f type="r"> his heards, and
coming to him afterwards
in another shape,
he corrupted him with gifts to deliver the Oxen, but
seeing his perfidiousnesse,
he turned him into a stone, called <f type="i">Index<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="batoon(n)"><f type="i">Batune<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="heraldry">a Term in Heraldry</class>, and seemeth to
be the fourth part of a bend Sinister onely, it toucheth
not the chief, nor the base point.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Bavaria(pn)"><f type="i">Bavaria<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a great Dukedom in

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="beacon(n)"><f type="i">Beacon<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="etymlang" lang="du">from the Dutch word <term lang="du">Bekennen</term> to
give notice</class>, a light fastened upon a high pole to give
warning of an enemies approach.</xpln></wordentry>

Beacons.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="beads(n)"><f type="i">Beads<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="etymlang" lang="du">from the Dutch word <term lang="du">beden</term> to pray</class>, a
certain number of prayers, at the end of which it is the
custome to drop a bead.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="beadle(n)"><f type="i">Beadle<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="du" type="etymlang">(from the Dutch word <term lang="du">Bedel</term>, a
Cryer)</class> one that waites upon a Magistrate with a white wand
to make any Summons, an Officer, especially belonging to a
University, also an
Officer of the Forrest, that makes all manner of
garnishments for the Court of the Forrest, and makes all
manner of Proclamations, as
well within the Court of the Forrest as without.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="bead-roll(n)"><f type="i">A Beadroll<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="sx" type="etymlang">(Saxon)</class> a list of such as
Priests use to pray for in the Church.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="beak-head(n)"><f type="i">Beakehead<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="navigation">in Navigation</class>, is that which is
fastened to the stem of the ship, and is supported with a
knee which is fastened into the stem.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="beam(n)"><f type="i">Beam<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="hawking and hunting">in hunting</class>, is that whereon the
starts of a Stags head grow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="bear's-foot(n)"><f type="i">Bearesfoot<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an Herb otherwise called Brank

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="bearer(n)"><f type="i">Bearers<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="law">a term in Law</class> signifying

abettors; also <class type="register" subject="heraldry">a term in Heraldry</class>,

distinguisht from others by tincture
and differences.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="bear in(v)"><f type="i">Bear in<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>is when a ship sailes before, or
with a large wind into a harbour, or
channel, she is said to
bear in with the harbour or channel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Beauchamp(pn)"><f type="i">Beauchamp<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a name of great honour and
eminency from the time of King <f type="i">Henry<f type="r"> the second,
especially since <f type="i">Cicily de Fortibus<f type="r">
descended from the Earles <f type="i">de
Ferrariis<f type="r"> matcht
into their Family of this name were anciently the Earles
of Warwick, the Barons of Kidderminster, and of Powick. Of
late ages, the Title of Vicount
Beauchamp, hath been
conferred upon the Family
of Seimours. In old Records it is written <f type="i">de Bello
Campo<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Beaumont(pn)"><f type="i">Beaumont<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the name of one of the

Nation, descended from John County of <f type="i">Brene<f type="r"> in
<f type="i">France<f type="r">, who for his valour was preferred to the
kingdom of <f type="i">Jerusalem<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="bec(n)"><f type="i">Bec<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="etymlang" lang="pr">a Phrygian word, signifying bread,</class>

whom <f type="i">Psammeticus<f type="r"> the Egyptian King caused to be
brought up in a forrest, by which he concluded the
Phrygians to be the most ancient people.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Belgia(pn)"><f type="i">Belgia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the Country of the <f type="i">Belg&aelig;<f type="r">,
or Low-countrymen, lying between the
River <f type="i">Sequana<f type="r">, and
the <f type="i">Rhene<f type="r">. It is divided into 17 Provinces, also
the people anciently
inhabiting that part of England now called
<f type="i">Sommersetshire, Hantshire<f type="r">, and
<f type="i">Wiltshire<f type="r">, were
called <f type="i">Belg&aelig;<f type="r">, in regard they came thither
originally out of <f type="i">Gallia Belgica<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Belides(pn)"><f type="i">Belides<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the fifty daughters of
<f type="i">Danaus<f type="r">, who married the fifty sons of
<f type="i">Aegyptus<f type="r">, who all killed their husbands except
one.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Belizarius(pn)"><f type="i">Belizarius<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>Captain of the Emperour
Justinians armies, who overthrew the
Persians in the East, the
Vandals in <f type="i">Africa<f type="r">, the Goths in <f type="i">Italy<f type="r">,
and at last had his eyes put out by Justinian, and was
forc't to beg his bread in a poor cottage.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="bell(n)"><f type="i">Bell<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="etymlang" lang="cl">in the Chald&aelig;an language

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="bellatrix(n)"><f type="i">Bellatrix<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the left shoulder of

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Bellerophon(pn)"><f type="i">Bellerophon<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Glaucus<f type="r">
King of <f type="i">Epire<f type="r">, against whom <f type="i">Sthenob&aelig;a<f type="r">
the wife of <f type="i">Pr&aelig;tus<f type="r"> King of <f type="i">Argos<f type="r">
conspired, because he refused her inticements; but he
having overcome all
difficulties, was commanded
at last to kill the Chim&aelig;ra, which he did with the help
of <f type="i">Neptune<f type="r">, who sent him a flying horse called
pegasus, which was afterwards plac't among the celestial
Signs.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Belus(pn)"><f type="i">Belus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the second, or, as some say, the
first King of <f type="i">Assyria<f type="r">, who when he died, was
worshipped as a god. Also the son of <f type="i">Epaphus<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Lybia<f type="r">, was called <f type="i">Belus Priscus<f type="r">, who
married <f type="i">Isis<f type="r">, and had two sons,
<f type="i">Aegyptus<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Danaus, Belus<f type="r"> hath also been taken for
<f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">, as <f type="i">Nimrod<f type="r"> for
<f type="i">Saturn<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Belzebub(pn)"><f type="i">Belzebub<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="etymlang" lang="he">an Hebrew word, signifying the
god of flyes</class>, and is used in Scripture for the prince of
the Devils.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Benan(pn)"><f type="i">Benan<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Star in the taile of

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="bend(n)"><f type="i">Bend<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>used by <f type="i">Chaucer<f type="r"> for a
muffler, a caul, a kercher. Also <class type="register" subject="heraldry">a term in
Heraldry</class>, being an
ordinary extended between two opposite points of the
Escutcheon: <f type="i">viz.<f type="r"> the dexter chief, and the
sinister base.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="bendlet(n)"><f type="i">Bendlet<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>is also <class type="register" subject="heraldry">a term in Heraldry</class>,

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Berenice(pn)"><f type="i">Berenice<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of <f type="i">Ptolem&aelig;us
Philadelphus<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Arsinoe<f type="r">, whom <f type="i">Ptolem&aelig;us
Lagus<f type="r"> her brother
married. She when her husband made an Expedition, vowed to
dedicate her hair to
<f type="i">Venus<f type="r"> if he returned safe, which afterwards not
being to be found, <f type="i">Conon<f type="r"> the Mathematician
feigned to have been translated to heaven and plac't
among the Stars.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Beris(pn)"><f type="i">Beris<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a high hill in <f type="i">America<f type="r">, on

thereabouts; They are
also called Claik-geese, and Soland-geese.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="besant(n)"><f type="i">Besant<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an ancient coin of Gold,
otherwise called
<f type="i">Bisantine<f type="r">, from <f type="i">Byzantium:<f type="r"> i. e.
<f type="i">Constantinople<f type="r">, where it used to be coined. It is
uncertain what value it is of; some attribute to it the
value of a Ducket. <class type="register" subject="heraldry">It is also a term in Heraldry</class>, by which
they understand plates of Gold,
containing 104 pound
and two ounces of Troy weight, in value 3750 pound ster.
They were round and smooth, without any representation on
them.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Biton(pn)" lexeme="Cleobis(pn)"><f type="i">Biton<f type="r">, and <f type="i">Cleobis<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the two sons

<f type="i">Dorcetshire<f type="r">,
called also the Forrest of <f type="i">Whitehart<f type="r"> from a very
beautifull <f type="i">Whitehart<f type="r">, which King <f type="i">Henry<f type="r">
the third, going thither a hunting, and taking great care
to spare, was killed by <f type="i">T. de la Linde<f type="r">, which so
incensed the King, that
he set a perpetual Fine upon the Land, which at this day
is called <f type="i">Whitehart<f type="r"> silver.</xpln></wordentry>

<f type="i">Brigidia<f type="r">, there was also an <f type="i">Irish<f type="r"> woman
famous for sanctity, who was called St. <f type="i">Brigit<f type="r">,
or <f type="i">Bride<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="brimstone(n)"><f type="i">Brimstone<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain Mineral, being the fat
of the earth, decocted unto his
hardnesse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="bryony(n)"><f type="i">Brionie<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a plant, called otherwise white

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Briseis(pn)"><f type="i">Briseis<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of <f type="i">Brises<f type="r">,

<f type="i">Lyrnessus<f type="r">, and
being afterwards taken from him by <f type="i">Agamemnon<f type="r">, was
the cause of his defection from the Grecian Army for a
great while.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Britannia(pn)"><f type="i">Britannia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the name of this whole Island,

so called from the ancient name <f type="i"><term lang="un">Brith</term><f type="r">, i. painted
and <class type="etymlang" lang="gk"><f type="i">Tania<f type="r">, which among the old Greeks signified a

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Bristow(pn)"><f type="i">Bristow<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the name of a pleasant Citie,

<f type="i">Gloster-shire<f type="r">, it is so called as it were
<f type="i"><term lang="sx">Brightstow</term><f type="r">, which <class type="etymlang" lang="sx">in the <f type="i">Saxon<f type="r">
signifieth a bright, or shining place</class>, <class type="etymlang" lang="br">in <f type="i">British<f type="r">
it was called <f type="i"><term lang="br">C&aelig;r Oder Nant Badon</term><f type="r">, i. e. the
Citie <f type="i">Oder<f type="r"> in the
Vale of <f type="i">Badon<f type="r"></class>, it was fortified
by <f type="i">Robert<f type="r"> Bishop of <f type="i">Constance<f type="r">, against
King <f type="i">William Rufus<f type="r">, with a Wall, which this day
is in part standing.</xpln></wordentry>

<f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Charme<f type="r">, she was the first

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Byzantium(pn)"><f type="i">Byzantium<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a City of <f type="i">Thrace<f type="r">, built

<f type="i">Pausanias<f type="r">. It
was afterwards called <f type="i">Nova Roma<f type="r">:
But <f type="i">Constantine<f type="r"> the Great, making it the chief
Seat of his Empire, it was called
<f type="i">Constantinople<f type="r">, and is at this day the chief Seat
of the Turkish Empire.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Cacus(pn)"><f type="i">Cacus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a shepherd of <f type="i">Aventinium<f type="r"> in
<f type="i">Italy<f type="r">, who stealing
some of the oxen which <f type="i">Hercules Recaranus<f type="r"> had
taken from <f type="i">Gorgon<f type="r">,
drew them backward by the taile to his cave, that they
might seem by their foot-steps to have gone an other way;
but the theft being discovered, <f type="i">Hercules<f type="r"> slew him
with his club, and recovered his oxen.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Cadmus(pn)"><f type="i">Cadmus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the King of the Phoenicians, the
son of <f type="i">Agenor<f type="r"> and brother of <f type="i">Europa<f type="r">, he
brought the Greek letters out of
Phoenicia; he killed a
serpent which had slain some of his companions, sowing the
teeth of it in the Earth, out of which there sprung up
armed men. He built <f type="i">Thebes<f type="r">, in the Country of
<f type="i">Aonia<f type="r">, which was afterwards
called <f type="i">Boeotia<f type="r">; but being driven thence with his
wife <f type="i">Hermione<f type="r">, by <f type="i">Zethus<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Amphion<f type="r">, he was changed into a serpent.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Cadrou(pn)" lexeme="Cadzou(pn)"><f type="i">Cadrou<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Cadzou<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>a Barony in
<f type="i">Scotland<f type="r">, out of
which was paid a yearly pension
of 26 pounds 13 shillings and 4 pence to the Kings
Exchequer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="caduce(n)"><f type="i">Caduce<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the snaky staffe which
<f type="i">Apollo<f type="r"> gave to <f type="i">Mercury<f type="r"> in recompence of
his harp. This staff had such vertue, that with it he
could kill or make alive. It was also a rod among the
Romans which was carried by their Heraulds in sign of
peace; whence an Embassadour is called Caduceator.</xpln></wordentry>

and called <f type="i">C&aelig;neus<f type="r">, was made

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="C&aelig;rdiff(pn)"><f type="i">C&aelig;rdiff<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town in
<f type="i">Glamorganshire<f type="r">, fortified
by <f type="i">Robert Fitz-Hamon<f type="r">, whose Grandchild
<f type="i">William<f type="r"> Earle of <f type="i">Glocester<f type="r">, was
afterwards besieged in the Castle, and taken prisoner by
<f type="i">Yvor-Bach<f type="r">, a Brittish Mountaineir. In this
Castle, <f type="i">Robert Curthose<f type="r">,
son of <f type="i">William<f type="r"> the Conqueror,
after he was bereft of his eyes, lived till he was very old.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="calends(n)"><f type="i">Calends<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(Lat.)</class> <class type="etymlang" lang="la">a word used among the

<f type="i">Phocus<f type="r">, King of <f type="i">Boeotia<f type="r">, she complaining
to her Countrey-men
against her thirty suiters, who had killed her father,
they fled to <f type="i">Hippote<f type="r">,
a Town of <f type="i">Thebes<f type="r">, but being pursued by the
<f type="i">Boeotians<f type="r">, the Town was taken, and the murtherers
burnt to death.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Cambridge(pn)"><f type="i">Cambridge<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the chief Town of
<f type="i">Cambridge-shire<f type="r">,
so called from a Bridge built over the River
<f type="i">Cam<f type="r">: In this Town hath flourished for many
ages, a famous University,
consisting of sixteen Colledges, it hath been anciently
reported that this Academy was founded by
<f type="i">Cantabar<f type="r"> a <f type="i">Spaniard<f type="r">, 375 years before
<f type="i">Christ<f type="r">, and repaired
by <f type="i">Sebert<f type="r">, King of the East Angles, in the year
of our Lord 630. afterwards it was defaced by the
<f type="i">Danes<f type="r"> under <f type="i">Sueno<f type="r">, but being restored
again by the <f type="i">Normans<f type="r">, it hath stood unviolated
by War to this day.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Camelot(pn)"><f type="i">Camelot<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town in the Shriefdom of
<f type="i">Stirling<f type="r"> in <f type="i">Scotland<f type="r">, which seems to be
the same with that, which was called <f type="i"><term lang="la">Corta
Damniorum</term><f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Cambyses(pn)"><f type="i">Cambyses<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>King of <f type="i">Persia<f type="r">, the son
of <f type="i">Cyrus<f type="r">, he added
<f type="i">Aegypt<f type="r"> to his Dominions, he died of a wound,
which he gave himself as
he was getting up to horse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Canterbury(pn)"><f type="i">Canterbury<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the chief City of

called in Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Dorobernia</term><f type="r">, now
<f type="i">Cantuaria<f type="r">. In the time of the <f type="i">Saxon<f type="r">
Heptarchy, it was the
Royal Seat of the Kings of <f type="i">Kent<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="capias(n)"><f type="i">Capias<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a writ, of which there be two
sorts, the one before judgement, which is called
<f type="i"><term lang="la">Capias ad respondendum</term><f type="r">, where an exigent is to be
proclaimed 5 times, and if the party appear not, he is to
be outlaw'd. The other is called a writ of execution
after judgement, which is of divers
kinds, <f type="i"><term lang="la">Capias ad faciendum, Capias pro fine, Capias ut
lagatum, &amp;
inquiras de bonis &amp; catallis</term><f type="r">: of which see a book
called <f type="i">Natura
Brevium<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Carlyle(pn)"><f type="i">Carlile<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an ancient City in
Cumberland, almost
encompast with the Rivers Eden, Peteril, and Cand, it was
called by the Romans Luguballia, by the ancient Brittains
C&aelig;rlnalid, Egfrid, King of Northumberland, made a deed of
gift of it to St. Cuthbert: this City being
depopulated by the
Danes, and lying buried in Rubbish for 2000 years, began
to flourish again in the
time of William Rufus, by whom it was first
repaired.</xpln></wordentry>
