<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="carnivorous(a)"><f type="i">Carnivorous<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(Lat.)</class> Flesh-devouring.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="carnoggin(n)"><f type="i">Carnogan<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="etymlang" lang="br">an old Brittish word,
signifying a kind of
wodden dish, a Piggin</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="carnouse(n)"><f type="i">Carnoose<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the base ring in a great
gun.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="carnocity(n)"><f type="i">Carnocity<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> corpulency, fulnesse of
flesh.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Carodunum(pn)"><f type="i">Carodunum<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the chief City of Poland, called
Cracovia.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="carol(n)"><f type="i">Caroll<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Christmasse song, or hymn, sung
at Christmasse, in honour of our
Saviours birth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="carove(n)"><f type="i">Carove<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kind of fruit, also a root
called St. Johns
bread.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="carouse(v)"><f type="i">Carouse<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a lusty drinking, a drinking all
out, <class type="etymlang" lang="du">from the dutch words, <term lang="du">Gar</term>,
altogether, and, <term lang="du">ausz</term>,
out</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Carpathus(pn)"><f type="i">Carpathus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an Island in the
Mediterranean sea,
between Rhodes and Crete, now called Scarpanto.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Carpocratians(pn)"><f type="i">Carpocratians<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a sort of Hereticks, that
held a very dangerous opinion.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="carp stone(n)"><f type="i">The Carp stone<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a triangular stone, found
in the chap of a Carp, white without, and yellow
within.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="carrack(n)" lexeme="carrick(n)"><f type="i">Carrack<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Carrick<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>a great ship,
<class type="etymlang" lang="it">from the Italian word, <term lang="it">Carico</term>, a
burthen</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="carat(n)"><f type="i">Carrat<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> <class type="register" subject="jeweling">a term used by
mintmen, Goldsmiths, and
Jewellers</class>: in gold and silver it signifies the third part
of an ounce, in Jewels the 192<expan type="^d">d</expan> part.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Carricta(pn)" lexeme="Carrict(pn)"><f type="i">Carricta<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Carrict<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>a province
of the South part of Scotland, standing upon Dunbritain
Frith.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="career(n)"><f type="i">Carriere<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French<emend err="">)</emend></class>, a running of horses in
their full speed; also a circle where horses run.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cartel(n)"><f type="i">Cartel<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> a challenge, or letter of
defiance.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Carthage(pn)"><f type="i">Carthage<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the chief City of Africa,
anciently called
<f type="i">Carthedon<f type="r">: it was built by Dido, and grew at
length to that power and greatnesse, that it waged war
with the Romans, for a long while, with equal advantage.
There is also a City of Hispania
Tarraconensis, formerly called Carthago
Vetus, now Villa Franca.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Carthismandua(pn)"><f type="i">Carthismandua<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous Brittish Lady, Queen of
the Brigantes, who casting off
</page>

<page sig="G1v">
her husband Venusius, married Vellocatus
his Harnesse-bearer, and crowned him King, being
countenanced by the Romans, and aided by their forces;
yet Venusius making war against her, drove her to great
straights, and recovered the Kingdom.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Carthusian(n)"><f type="i">Carthusians<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an order of Monks,
instituted by St.
Bruno, a native of Cullen 1101, who first led a
Hermeticall life upon the Carthusian Mountains.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cartilagineous(a)"><f type="i">Cartilagineous<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(latine)</class> full of
gristles.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="carucata terr&aelig;(n)"><f type="i">Carucata terr&aelig;<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="etymlang" lang="fr">from the French word
<f type="i"><term lang="fr">Charrue</term><f type="r">, a Plough</class>: it signifies in the ancient
charters, as much land as can be ploughed in a year by one
Plough. <class type="register" subject="law">In the ancient laws</class> it is called <f type="i"><term lang="la">Hilda
terr&aelig;</term><f type="r">, which we call
a hide of land.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cartilagineous(a)"><f type="i"><emend err="Cartilagindous" source="errata">Cartilagineous</emend><f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> of a gristly
substance.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cartouche(n)"><f type="i">Cartouch<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> <class type="register" subject="architecture">a word used in
Architecture</class>,
signifying a roll, with which they adorn the Cornish of a
pillar, also a charge of powder and shot, made ready in a
paper, called also a Carthrage.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="carvage(n)"><f type="i">Carvage<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>is to be quit, if the King should
tax his land by <f type="i">Carves<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="carve of land(n)"><f type="i">Carve<f type="r"> of land</form>, <xpln>see <xref target="carucata"><f type="i">Carrucata
terr&aelig;<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="casemate(n)"><f type="i">Casemate<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="it" type="etymlang">(Ital.)</class> <class type="register" subject="architecture">a term in fortification</class>,
a loop-hole in a wall to shoot out at.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cashier(v)"><f type="i">Cashire<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> to break up a
company of
souldiers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Caspian sea(pn)"><f type="i">Caspian sea<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a sea between the Caspian and
Hircanian Mountains.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Cassandra(pn)"><f type="i">Cassandra<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of Priam and
Hecuba, she being beloved of Apollo,
received the gift of
prophesie from him at the sack of Troy, she was ravisht in
the Temple by Ajax Oileus, and afterwards in the dividing
the spoil, she fell to Agamemnons
lot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cassation(n)"><f type="i">Cassation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a nulling or making
void.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cassia fistula(n)"><f type="i">Cassia<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Cassia fistula<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>a kind
of Reed or shrub, growning in Egypt, it is also called
Canell, from the French word <term lang="fr">Canelle</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cassia lignea(n)"><f type="i">Cassia lignea<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a sweet wood like to
Cinnamon.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Cassiope(pn)"><f type="i">Cassiope<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>or Cassiopea, the daughter of
Cepheus, King of Ethiopia, and mother of Andromeda, who
for her mothers pride, in boasting her self fairer than
the Nereides, was exposed to the fury of a sea-monster,
they were afterwards placed both among the stars. see <xref><f type="i">Andromeda<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Cassivellaunus(pn)" lexeme="Cassibellinus(pn)"><f type="i">Cassivellaunus<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Cassibellinus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>
an ancient King of the
Brittains, under whose conduct they defended themselves
with great courage against the Romans for a long time,
when they invaded this Island, but at last he was
constrained to surrender himself to Julius C&aelig;sar.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="castaldy(n)"><f type="i">Castaldie<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Stewardship, <class type="etymlang" lang="la">from the Latin
word <f type="i"><term lang="la">Gastaldius</term><f type="r"></class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Castalia(pn)"><f type="i">Castalia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain Nymph, as some think,
the daughter of Achelous, who flying from Apollo, was
turned into a Fountain near Parnassus, called the
Castalian Fountain, by some the Cabailine
Fountain, sacred to the Muses.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="castanet(n)"><f type="i">Castanetts<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain sort of snappers,
which dancers tying about their fingers, keep time with
them as they dance; they are so called from their
resemblance of a a Chesnut, <class type="etymlang" lang="la">called in Latin
<f type="i"><term lang="la">Castanea</term><f type="r"></class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="castellan(n)"><f type="i">Castellain<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an officer called the
Constable of a Castle,
which some think to be the same with Gnastaldus, also <class type="register" subject="law">in
the Forrest laws</class>, it signifies an Officer of the
Forrest.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="castigate(v)"><f type="i">Castigate<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> to punish, to
chastize.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="castlesteed(n)"><f type="i">Castlesteed<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="old word">a word anciently used</class> for any
Fortresse or Bulwark.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="castleward(n)"><f type="i">Castleward<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an Imposition upon such as
dwell within a certain compasse of any Castle, toward the
maintenance of such as watch and ward the Castle: it is
taken also for the circuit it self, which is
inhabited by such as are
subject to this service.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Castor and Pollux(pn)"><f type="i">Castor and Pollux<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the sons of Jupiter and Leda, whom he lay with in the
shape of a Swan, they being grown to age, freed the sea of
Pirates, and were therefore counted gods of the sea; they
went with <f type="i">Jason<f type="r"> to <f type="i">Colchos<f type="r">, and coming
home, they recovered their sister from <f type="i">Theseus<f type="r">,
and won the Town <f type="i">Aphydna<f type="r">, wherein <f type="i">Castor<f type="r">
died, <f type="i">Pollux<f type="r">, who was born in the same Egge with
<f type="i">Helena<f type="r">, and so became immortal,
desired of <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> that his brother might partake
of immortality with him, whereupon they were both reported
to live and die by turns.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="castrated(a)"><f type="i">Castrated<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(Lat.)</class> gelded, cut away.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="casual(a)"><f type="i">Casual<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(Lat.)</class> accidental, hapning by
chance.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="casu consimili(n)"><f type="i">Casu consimili<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Writ of Entry granted
where a Tenant in courtesie, or for Term of life doth
Alienate in Fee, or in Tail.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="casu proviso(n)"><f type="i">Casu proviso<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Writ of Entry granted by
the Statute of <f type="i">Glocester<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="casuist(n)"><f type="i"><emend err="Casuit" source="errata">Casuist</emend><f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a writer of Cases of
conscience.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="casule(n)"><f type="i">Casule<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kinde of vestment, in which the
Priest sayes Masse, resembling the
purple Robe of derision,
which was put upon our Saviour.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="catabaptist(n)"><f type="i">Catabaptist<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> an enemy, or
a&shy; 
</page>

<page sig="G2r">
buser of the Sacrament of baptisme.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="catachresis(n)"><f type="i">Catachresis<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> <class type="register" subject="rhetoric">a Rhetorical
figure</class>, the using of
another word, in stead of the proper word.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cataclysm(n)"><f type="i">Cataclysme<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> an inundation, or
deluge.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="catadrome(n)"><f type="i">Catadrome<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> an Engin like a Crane,
which builders use, also a Tiltyard,
or place where horses run for prizes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cataglottism(n)"><f type="i">Cataglottisme<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a thrusting out the
tongue in kissing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="catagraph(n)"><f type="i">Catagraph<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> the first draught of a
picture.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Catalia(pn)"><f type="i">Catalia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>see <xref><f type="i">Chattels<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="catalepsy(n)"><f type="i">A Catalepsie<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> occupation, also a
disease in the head, which causeth a
deprehension of the
spirits.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="catalogue(n)"><f type="i">Catalogue<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a roul of names.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Catalonia(pn)"><f type="i">Catalonia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Province in
<f type="i">Spain<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="catamidiate(v)"><f type="i">Catamidiate<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>to put one to open shame, for
some notorious offence.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="catamite(n)"><f type="i">A Catamite<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(Lat.)</class> an Ingle, a boy kept for
Sodomy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cataphora(n)"><f type="i">Cataphora<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a kinde of disease in
the head, which causeth heavinesse, and deep sleep.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cataplasm(n)"><f type="i">Cataplasme<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> an unctuous, and moist
composition made of Meal and Herbs like a Pultis, but of a
thicker substance.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Cataphrygians(pn)"><f type="i">Cataphrygians<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Sect of Hereticks, who
baptized their dead, forbid second
marriage, and had other
erroneous opinions, they were broached by
<f type="i">Montanus<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Apelles<f type="r">
(who were of the Countrey of <f type="i">Phrygia<f type="r">)
in the year 181.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="catapuce(n)"><f type="i">Catapuce<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an Herb called Spurge.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="catapult(n)"><f type="i">Catapult<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(Lat.)</class> the same as
<f type="i">Balista<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cataract(n)"><f type="i">Catarract<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a great fall of
waters from a high place, a
flood-gate, a post-cullis, also a disease in the eyes
caused by a coagulation of
flegme, between the Uveous
Tunicle and the Christalline humour, hindring the egresse
and ingresse of the visual spirits.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Catarractonium(pn)"><f type="i">Catarractonium<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>or <f type="i">Caturactonium<f type="r">,
the name of a Town near <f type="i">Richmond<f type="r">,
anciently very famous,
so called from a great waterfall near unto it, in the year
769. it was burnt by the Tyrant <f type="i">Beanred<f type="r">, but
afterwards it
flourish't again in the time of King <f type="i">Ethelred<f type="r">,
who solemnised his marriage
with King <f type="i">Offa's<f type="r"> daughter in this Town, it is now
called <f type="i">Catarrick-bridge<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="catarrh(n)"><f type="i">Catarrh<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a Rheum, a
distillation of
humours out of the head into the mouth, or throat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="catastasis(n)"><f type="i">Catastasis<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> the third Act of a
Comedy, or Tragedy, wherein things are brought to a full
perfection and ripenesse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="catastrophe(n)"><f type="i">Catastrophe<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the conclusion of a
businesse, also the
last Act of a Comedy, or Tragedy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="catechize(v)"><f type="i">Catechize<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> to instruct, or
inform.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="catechumen(n)"><f type="i">A Catechumen<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> one that is
Catechiz'd for the
receiving of the Communion.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="category(n)"><f type="i">Category<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> an accusation, also a
Predicament, which is <class type="register" subject="logic">a Term in
Logick</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="catenate(v)"><f type="i">Catenate<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(Lat.)</class> to chain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Caterlogh(pn)" lexeme="Carlogh(pn)"><f type="i">Caterlogh<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Carlogh<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>a Countrey
of <f type="i">Ireland<f type="r">, joyning on the East to the
County of
<f type="i">Kilkenny<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Cathanesse(pn)" lexeme="Cathness(pn)"><f type="i">Cathanesse<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Cathnesse<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>a
Province of the South-part of <f type="i">Scotland<f type="r">, the
people were called by <f type="i">Ptolomy, Catini<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cath&aelig;a(pn)"><f type="i">Cath&aelig;a<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Countrey in <f type="i">India<f type="r">,
where beauty is so much regarded, that they choose the
hansomest man for their King.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Catharine(pn)"><f type="i">Catharine<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> pure, chaste, a
proper name of
women.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Catharians(pn)"><f type="i">Catharians<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Sect of Hereticks, who held
themselves pure from sin, rejected baptisme, and denied
original sin.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Catharists(pn)"><f type="i">Catharists<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>another sort of Hereticks, who
were counted a branch of the <f type="i">Manichees<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cathartic(n)"><f type="i">Catharticks<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> <class type="register" subject="medicine">the general name in
Physick</class> for all purging Medicines.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Cathay(pn)"><f type="i">Cathay<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a great Country Eastward
divided into 9 Realmes
under the great Cham. It was formerly called
<f type="i">Scythia<f type="r">, now <f type="i">Sinarum Regio<f type="r">; the chief
City is <f type="i">Issedon<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cathedral(n)"><f type="i">Cathedral<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(Lat.)</class> belonging to a chair,
also a Cathedral Church is the chief Church in a Bishops See.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Cathelaunum(pn)" lexeme="Catalaunum(pn)"><f type="i">Cathelaunum<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Catalaunum<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>a
Citie of <f type="i">Champagne<f type="r"> in <f type="i">France<f type="r">, now called

of <f type="i">Spain<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cathorius(n)"><f type="i">Cathorius<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="law">a Term used in the practick of

being a penalty set upon him who
</page>

<page sig="G2v">
breaks the Kings peace, to give to the King 22 Kine, and
3 Cathores, or for every Cathorius 9 Kine.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Cefala(pn)"><f type="i">Cefala<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an Island of <f type="i">Africa<f type="r">, found out
by the <f type="i">Portugals<f type="r">, in the year 1500. being three
miles in length, and one in breadth.
</page>

<page sig="G3r">
It hath two Villages and one strong Castle. In the year
1505 the Ilanders rebelled, but were quickly subdued by
the Portugall's,
who killed the King; they had chosen among themselves,
and set up another King,
as Deputy to the King of <f type="i">Portugal<f type="r">.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Centaur(n)"><f type="i">Centaures<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a people of <f type="i">Thessaly<f type="r">,
who waged war with the
<f type="i">Lapith&aelig;<f type="r">, they descended as the Poets feign from
<f type="i">Ixion<f type="r">, who falling in love with <f type="i">Juno<f type="r">,
lay with a cloud which was formed into her shape. They
were thought to be half men and half horses; because
riding their horses to water, while their horses held down
their heads to drink, they seemed to those who beheld them
a far off, like a strange kind of monster, whose former
part resembled a man, the hinder part a horse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="centaury(n)"><f type="i">Centaury<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kind of herb, which some call

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Cephalus(pn)"><f type="i">Cephalus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Eion<f type="r">, he married
<f type="i">Procris<f type="r">, the daughter of <f type="i">Erichtheus<f type="r">
King of <f type="i">Athens<f type="r">, and being loved of
<f type="i">Aurora<f type="r">, would not answer her love: one morning
after he had been a hunting with a dart which
<f type="i">Procris<f type="r"> gave him, and a dog called Lelaps, he
sate down and called upon <f type="i">Aura<f type="r"> to refresh him;
but his wife having followed
him out of jealousie, had hid her self in a bush.
<f type="i">Cephalus<f type="r"> perceiving the
</page>

<page sig="G3v">
bush to move, thought it had been a wild beast, and shot
his wife, and afterwards was turned into a stone.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cepi corpus(n)"><f type="i">Cepi Corpus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a return made by the Sheriff,
that upon an exigent, he hath taken
the body of a man.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="ceramite(n)"><f type="i">Ceramite<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kind of precious stone.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="ceratine(a)"><f type="i">Ceratine<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> made of wax,

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Cerberus(pn)"><f type="i">Cerberus</form>, <xpln>quasi creoborus<f type="r"> or flesh
devouring, a
three-headed dog, said
to watch constantly at the gates of Hell, whom
<f type="i">Hercules<f type="r"> overcame and carried
away in a chain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cerebrosity(n)"><f type="i">Cerebrosity<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a being cock brain'd,
or brainsick.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Cerdonists(pn)"><f type="i">Cerdonists<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a sect of Hereticks, who held
that there were two contrary principles in the cause of
every thing, a good God and a bad; they were instituted by
one <f type="i">Cerdo<f type="r"> in the year 150.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="ceremony(n)"><f type="i">Ceremonies<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>rites of the Church, <class type="etymlang" lang="la">from the
ancient Latin word <f type="i"><term lang="la">Cerus</term><f type="r"></class>, which signifieth
<f type="i">holy<f type="r">, or else from the <f type="i">C&aelig;rites<f type="r">, a
people of <f type="i">Hetruria<f type="r">, who chearfully
entertained all the
sacred things of the Romans,
which were brought to them by the Vestals when
<f type="i">Rome<f type="r"> was taken by the <f type="i">Gaules<f type="r">: whereupon
the Romans out of gratitude, ordered that all things
belonging to Religious
Worship, should be called
Ceremonies.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Ceres(pn)"><f type="i">Ceres<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of <f type="i">Saturn<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Ops<f type="r">, by whom <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> had
<f type="i">Proserpina<f type="r">, and being
snatcht away by <f type="i">Pluto; Ceres<f type="r">
wandered through the
world to seek her, and came to the Court of
<f type="i">Eleusius<f type="r"> King of <f type="i">Attica<f type="r">, whose son
<f type="i">Triptolomus<f type="r"> she made immortal; and seating him in
a Chariot drawn with winged Dragons through the air, she
sent him to teach mortals the use of corn, whence she was
adored as the Godesse of <f type="i">Agriculture<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Cerinthians(pn)"><f type="i">Cerinthians<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a sort of Hereticks, who held
that Christ at his second coming should give to his people
all carnal delights and
pleasures: they had their original
in the year 97 from one <f type="i">Cerinthus<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Cerna(pn)"><f type="i">Cerna<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an Island in the <f type="i">Aethiopick<f type="r">
Sea, where the North Pole is not seen, by some thought to
be the same with <f type="i">Madagascar<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

that the party seeking the said Writ hath
received hard dealing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="chancellor(n)"><f type="i">Chancellour<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="etymlang" lang="la">from the Latin word
<f type="i"><term lang="la">Cancelli</term><f type="r"></class>,
Latices, with which in former time the judgement seats
were compassed; it is a title
of honour given unto him, who is the chief man next unto
the Prince for matter of justice in civil affairs, having
power to moderate, and temper the written Law, according
to equity, also the Chancellour of the Exchequer is a
supream Officer, appointed to moderate the extreamities in
Exchequer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Chancery(n)"><f type="i">Chancery<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the Court of Equity &amp;
Conscience, moderating
the severity of other Courts that are more strictly tied
to the rigour of the Law, the Officers belonging to this
Court, are the Lord Chancelour, who is chief Judge, twelve
masters of the Chancery, whereof the master of the Roll's
is chief, the Clerk of the Crown, the six Clerks, with
many others.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Charing Cross(pn)"><f type="i">Charing-crosse<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous monument which
stood not long since at the end of the strand towards
<f type="i">Westminster<f type="r">, it was erected
by King <f type="i">Edward<f type="r">, the first in memory of his Queen
<f type="i">Eleanor<f type="r">, who accompanying him to the holy war,
suck't the poyson out of his eye, when it had been
wounded by a <f type="i">More<f type="r">
with an envenom'd sword, this crosse was utterly
demolish't not many years
since.</xpln></wordentry>

attractions and allurements. <f type="i">Artamenes<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="charnel-house(n)"><f type="i">A Charnel-house<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a place where dead bones
are laid.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Charon(pn)"><f type="i">Charon<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Erebus<f type="r">, and
night, whom the Poets faign to be the ferryman of Hell,
and to carry the Souls of those that die over the stygian
Lake in a Boat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Charterhouse(pn)"><f type="i">Charter-house<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous Hospital in
<f type="i">London<f type="r">, founded by
Sir <f type="i">Waltermany<f type="r"> of Henault,
who served under King <f type="i">Edward<f type="r"> the third, in the
<f type="i">French<f type="r"> wars, this place was anciently a very
noted C&aelig;mitery, or place of burial.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="charter(n)"><f type="i">Charters<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> written Evidences of

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Charybdis(pn)"><f type="i">Charybdis<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Gulph in the Bay of
<f type="i">Sicily<f type="r">, near the <f type="i">Tauromitanian<f type="r"> shore,
which is feign'd to have been a woman of
prodigious greedinesse,
who for stealing <f type="i">Hercules<f type="r">
his Oxen, was struck with Thunder by <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">, and
turned into this Gulf.</xpln></wordentry>

a Gentle-woman of a great house.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="chasuble(n)"><f type="i">Chasuble<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> a kinde of Cope, which

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="chattels(n)"><f type="i">Chattels<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> <class type="register" subject="law">a Term in

all goods moveable, and immoveable, but such as are in the

</page>

<page sig="H1r">
family of <f type="i">Ailesbury<f type="r"> in
<f type="i">Buckinghamshire<f type="r">, they were so called as

<f type="i">Querce<f type="r"> a Province of <f type="i">France<f type="r">, in Latin

</xpln></wordentry>

the bordure consisteth
of three panes of checquer-work, wherein it differs from
counter-pany, which never exceeds two panes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Chelmerford(pn)"><f type="i">Chelmerford<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town in <f type="i">Essex<f type="r">, so
called from the River <f type="i">Chelmer<f type="r">; it is commonly
known by the name of <f type="i">Chensford<f type="r">. In the reign of
King <f type="i">Henry<f type="r"> the first it belonged to
<f type="i">Maurice<f type="r"> Bishop of <f type="i">London<f type="r">, who built here
two bridges. Some think it to be the same with that which
was anciently called <f type="i">Canonium<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Chelonophagi(pn)"><f type="i">Chelonophagi<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain people bordering
upon <f type="i">Carmania<f type="r">, who feed onely upon Tortoises,

large that one of them will serve to make a ship.</xpln></wordentry>

the City of <f type="i">Cissa<f type="r">, because it was built by

Rufus<f type="r">, the Bishops See was translated from
<f type="i">Selsey<f type="r"> hither.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Chim&aelig;ra(pn)"><f type="i">Chim&aelig;ra<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Hill of <f type="i">Lycia<f type="r">, on the top
whereof were many Lions, in the midst fed Goates, and at
the bottom were Serpents,
which <f type="i">Bellerophon<f type="r"> made habitable. Whence the
Poets feigned that <f type="i">Bellerophon<f type="r">
</page>

<page sig="H1v">
killed the Monster <f type="i">Chim&aelig;ra<f type="r">, who had the head
of a Lion, the belly of a Goat, and the tail of a
Dragon. Whence <f type="i">Chim&aelig;ra's<f type="r">
are taken for idle conceits.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="chimb(n)"><f type="i">Chimbe<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the uttermost part of a barrel.

also called Palmestry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Chiron(pn)"><f type="i">Chiron<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Saturn<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Philyra<f type="r">, who by reason that <f type="i">Saturn<f type="r"> lay
with <f type="i">Philyra<f type="r"> in the shape of a horse, had his
upper parts like a man, his lower parts like a horse: he
grew famous for physick, brought up <f type="i">Achilles<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Aesculapius<f type="r">, and at length was placed among the
Stars, and called <f type="i">Sagittarius<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="chirrichote(n)"><f type="i">Chirrichote<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="sp" type="etymlang">a Spanish word</class> used in

</wordentry>

the ancient orders of the Clergy was admitted to serve God
in the quire.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="circumferentor(n)"><f type="i">Circumferentor<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="mathematics">a Mathematical
instrument</class>, used by
Geometricians and Surveyors,
it is made of wood, eight inches in length, and four
broad, three quarters of an inch thick, about the middle
of the upper-side is a
round hole, three inches and a half about, and half an
inch deep, in which is placed a
Card, divided into
120 equal parts, in
which Card is drawn a Dyal, to know the hour of the
Sun.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="climacterical(a)"><f type="i">Climacterical<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">from the Greek word
<f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Climax</term><f type="r"></class>, a scale,
or ladder, every seventh, and ninth year is counted a
climacterical year: wherein, if any misfortune, or
sicknesse happen, it is accounted most dangerous, as
likewise those years, which are compounded of
7<expan type="^ths">ths</expan>. &amp; 9<expan type="^ths">ths</expan>. up to the
63<expan type="^d">d</expan>. which is held most dangerous of
all.</xpln></wordentry>

in the length of the day.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Clytemnestra(pn)"><f type="i">Clytemnestra<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of
<f type="i">Tyndarus<f type="r">, and <f type="i">Leda<f type="r">, the wife of
<f type="i">Agamemnon<f type="r">, she lived
in Adultery with <f type="i">Aegystus<f type="r">, and with his help
killed her husband <f type="i">Agamemnon<f type="r">, but his son
<f type="i">Orestes<f type="r"> revenged his death upon his mother and
<f type="i">Aegysthus<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="clytia(pn)"><f type="i">Clytia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>one of the daughters of
<f type="i">Oceanus<f type="r">, who discovering that <f type="i">Apollo<f type="r"> lay
with <f type="i">Leucothoe<f type="r">,
the daughter of <f type="i">Orchamus<f type="r"> was slighted by him, and
pining her self away was turned into a flower, called a
<f type="i">Heliotrope<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Clyto(pn)"><f type="i">Clyto<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Title of Honour, anciently used in
this Nation, and peculiarly ascribed to the Kings sons, it
comes <class lang="gk" type="etymlang">from the Greek word <term lang="gk">&#x03BA;&#x03BB;&#x03C5;&#x03C4;&#x03BF;&#x03C3;</term>, <f type="i">i.
e.<f type="r"> glorious, or excellent</class>, in the same sense was <class lang="sx" type="etymlang">the
<f type="i">Saxon<f type="r"> word <f type="i"><term lang="sx">Aetheling</term><f type="r"> used</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Cnidus(pn)"><f type="i">Cnidus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Citie of <f type="i">Caria<f type="r">, where

called <f type="i">Cabocrio</xpln>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cnossus(n)" lexeme="Gnossus(pn)">Cnossus<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Gnossus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a
Citie of <f type="i">Crete<f type="r">, where <f type="i">Minas<f type="r"> anciently
kept his Court. It was anciently called
<f type="i">Ceratus<f type="r">, from a River of that name, which ran hard by.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Canute's delf(n)"><f type="i">Cnouts delf<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>otherwise called <f type="i">Steeds
dike<f type="r">, a certain Ditch, which <f type="i">Canute<f type="r"> the
<f type="i">Dane<f type="r"> caused to be made between <f type="i">Ramsey<f type="r">
and <f type="i">Whitlesey<f type="r">, to abate the fury of the Sea
thereabout, where in a great storm his sons and servants
had like to have been cast away, it was also called
<f type="i">Swerdes delf<f type="r">, because it was marked out with
their swords.</xpln></wordentry>

<f type="i">Peloponesians<f type="r"> should overcome, if they did not
kill the <f type="i">Athenian<f type="r"> King, he disguised himself like

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cognisance(n)"><f type="i">Cognisance<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> a badge in armes, also
an acknowledging of a Fine, also a hearing a thing
judicially; moreover, a Cognisance of a Plea is a
priviledge that a Citie, or Town hath of the Kings Grant,
to hold a Plea of all Contracts, and of Lands, within the
Precincts of the Franchise,
and that when any man is impleaded for any such thing at
the Kings Court, the Mayor, or Bayliffs of such Franchises
may ask Cognisance of the Plea, that is, that the matter
be determined before them.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cognisee(n)"><f type="i">Cognisee<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>is he, to whom a Fine is

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="collateral(n)"><f type="i">Collateral<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> equal with either side,
Collateral relations or kindred, are brothers or sisters
children, or those that descend from them. Collateral

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="collation(n)"><f type="i">Collation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a joyning or
comparing together, also
a Banquet; also Collation
of a benefice is the bestowing of a benefice by the Bishop
who hath it in his own gift or patronage; whereas the
institution into a
benefice is performed by the Bishop at the presentation of
another who is Patron of the place, or hath a
Patrons right. It is
moreover a term used by Booksellers, and signifies a
looking upon the letters at the bottom of every page to
see that the book be perfect.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="collative(a)"><f type="i">Collative<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a unanimous contribution of the
people toward any publick work.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="collaud(v)"><f type="i">To Collaud<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> to joyn with others in

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="colleague(n)"><f type="i">A Colleague<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a fellow or

office.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="collection(n)"><f type="i">A Collection<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a gathering or levie.
<f type="i">Collection<f type="r"> is when two principal significates do
not behold one another, but both of them cast several
aspects to a more weighty Planet than themselves, and they
both receive him in some of their essential dignities,
then shall the Planet which thus collects both their
lights, bring the thing demanded to
perfection.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Colran(pn)"><f type="i">Colran<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Country of <f type="i">Ireland<f type="r">,
anciently called <f type="i">Krine<f type="r">, bordering south upon
<f type="i">Tir Oen<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

Latin word <f type="i"><term lang="la">Coluber</term><f type="r">, a snake</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Coludum(pn)"><f type="i">Coludum<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the ancient name of a Town of the
Province of <f type="i">Merch<f type="r"> in <f type="i">Scotland<f type="r">,
called also <f type="i">Coldana<f type="r"> by <f type="i">Ptolomy Colania<f type="r">, now
<f type="i">Coldingham<f type="r">, where there was a famous Monastery,
the Nuns whereof with their Prioresse <f type="i">Ebba<f type="r">, cut
off their lips and noses to avoid the lustful violence of
the <f type="i">Danes<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Column&aelig; Herculis(pn)" lexeme="Hercules' Pillars(pn)"><f type="i">Column&aelig; Herculis<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Hercules<f type="r"> 
pillars,</form> <xpln>two mountains in the West, the one in
<f type="i">Europe<f type="r"> called <f type="i">Calpe<f type="r">, the other in
<f type="i">Africa<f type="r"> called <f type="i">Abyla<f type="r">, which
<f type="i">Hercules<f type="r"> separated the one from the other. Others
say they were two pillars of Brasse in the Isles of
<f type="i">Cades<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="colure(n)"><f type="i">Colures<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>two great circles in the Globe of
the World, which passing through the Poles and the 4
principal points of the Zodiack, cut themselves
equally, and divide the
Glob into equal parts.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="colus(n)"><f type="i">Colus<f type="r"></form> <xpln>a beast of whitish colour that hath a

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="combat(n)"><f type="i">Combat<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="law">in the Common law</class> signifies a
formal trial of a doubtful cause by the sword or bastons
of two Champions, wherein if the defendant can defend
himself till the stars be
seen in the firmament, and demand judgement if he ought to
fight any longer, then judgement is to be given on the
defendants side.</xpln></wordentry>

remains under the Sun, until he is fully elongated 17
degrees.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="commissary(n)"><f type="i">Commissary<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>according to the acception of
the Cananists, is
he who exerciseth Ecclesiastical
jurisdiction in places of the Diocesse so far distant from
the chief City, that the
Chancelour cannot call the subjects to the Bishops
principal Consistory
without their great molestation; also an Officer in war,
is he who is to look to the distribution of victuals,
provided for the Army and Garrisons.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Common Pleas(pn)"><f type="i">Common-pleas<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>is one of the Courts in
<f type="i">Westminster<f type="r">, but in ancient time moveable. It was
erected in <f type="i">Henry<f type="r"> the thirds time, for the trying
of all civil causes, both reall and personal. The cheif
Judge whereof is called Lord cheif Justice of the
Common-pleas: the rest of the Officers are <f type="i">Custos
brevium<f type="r">; four Exigenters, fourteen
Filazers, a Clark of the warrants, a Clark of the jurata
writs, Clark of the Treasury, Clark of the Kings Silver,
Clark of the Essoynes, and Clark of the Outlawries.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Congersbury(pn)"><f type="i">Congersbury<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town in

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="conquest(n)"><f type="i">Conquest<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="law">a Term used in the practick of
<f type="i">Scotland<f type="r"></class>, and differs from heritage in this,
that heritage
signifies Lands &amp; Goods pertaining to any person, as
general Suc&shy;
</page>

<page sig="I3v">
cessour to his father, or any other predecessour.
Conquest signifies those which any one possesseth by his
own private Title, or by gift, or by any other single
contract.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="consideration(n)"><f type="i">Consideration<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> an advising or

Common law</class>, signifying the material part of a contract,
without which no contract standeth or bindeth.
Consideration is either expressed,
as when a man bargaineth to give a certain sum for any
thing, or else imply'd as when the law inforceth a
consideration.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="conspiracy(n)"><f type="i">Conspiracy<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a plotting or secret
consultation; but <class type="register" subject="law">in Common law</class> it is alwayes taken in the
evil part, and signifieth
an agreement of such as bind themselves
by covenant or other allyance, that each of them shall
assist the other malitiously
to indite, or falsely to move and maintain pleas; also
such as cause children
within age to appeal men of felony, and such as receive
men in the Countries, with liveries and fees to maintain
their malitious enterprises.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="constable, quasi comes stabuli(n)" lexeme="Master of the King's Horse(n)"><f type="i">Constable, quasi comes stabuli<f type="r">, or Master of
the Kings horse, or as others say,
<class lang="du" type="etymlang">derived from the Dutch
word <f type="i"><term lang="du">Konnin-Stable</term><f type="r"></class>, i. e. prop and stay of the
King.</form> <xpln>This
</page>

<page sig="I4r">

word is diversly taken <class type="register" subject="law">in Common law</class>, either for the
Constable of <f type="i">England<f type="r">, a place formerly of great
Dignity, or for an office belonging heretofore to the
Lords of certain Mannours, and at length there came to
be ordained others of an inferiour rank, as Constables
of Hundreds, or Franchises
who were appointed for the conservation
of the peace, and called high Constables; and under
these the Constables
of every Town or Parish, who are called pety-constables.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="consul(n)"><f type="i">Consul<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">from the Latin word
<f type="i"><term lang="la">Consulere</term><f type="r">, to give counsel</class>; it was a place of
highest dignity among the Romans, brought in
after the expulsion of their
Kings, and at this present day the chief Governours of
divers Cities, are called Consuls.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="consultation(n)"><f type="i">Consultation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(Lat.)</class> a taking counsel, also

Court, is returned thither again.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="contemporal(a)" lexeme="contemporary(n)"><f type="i">Contemporal<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Contemporary<f type="r">,</form>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="controller(n)"><f type="i">Controller<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an officer who keepeth a Roll
of other officers accounts. Controller
of the Hamper, an officer in Chancery, who takes all
things sealed from the Clark of the Hamper inclosed in
leather bags, and takes a special charge of them.
Controller of the pipe, an officer in the Exchequer, who
writes summons to the Sheriffs to levie the debts of the
pipe. Controller of the Pell, an officer of the Exchequer
who keeps a controlment of the Pell of receipts and goings
out.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Corin&aelig;us(pn)"><f type="i">Corin&aelig;us<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>one of the companions of

<f type="i">Cornwall<f type="r"> is said to have

being in old time called <f type="i">Corin&aelig;a<f type="r">, it is
fabulously reported of him that he fought with a Gyant,
called <f type="i">Gogmagog<f type="r">,
and threw him down a steep Rock.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Corinth(pn)"><f type="i">Corinth<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Citie of <f type="i">Achaia<f type="r"> in

<f type="i">Pelops<f type="r">, and by him called
<f type="i">Corinth<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Corinthian order(n)"><f type="i">Corinthian<f type="r"> order</form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="architecture">a Term in

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cornage(n)"><f type="i">Cornage<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>is <class type="register" subject="law">in Common-law</class> a certain Tenure,
whereby in the North, men used to hold their Lands, which
was to blow a horn when any invasion of a Northern enemy
was perceived.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cornalin(n)"><f type="i">Cornalin<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kinde of precious stone, which
some think to be the same with <f type="i">Corneol<f type="r">.</xpln>
<lemenote>
OED "cornelian"?
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Cornavii(pn)"><f type="i">Cornavii<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the name of a certain people, who
in ancient times possessed that part of this Island,
containing those Counties which are at present called
<f type="i">Warwick-shire, Worcestershire, Stafford-shire,
Shrop-shire, Cheshire<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cornflowwr(n)"><f type="i">Corn-flowr<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kinde of flowr, called
blue-bottle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cornelian(n)"><f type="i">Cornelian<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the same as Corneol,
</page>

<page sig="K1v">
a kinde of precious stone, also Cornelian Law, was a Law
made by <f type="i">Cornelius Sylla<f type="r">, that any who would
follow him in, should be capable of Office before they
had attained their full years.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Cornelius(pn)"><f type="i">Cornelius<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a proper name of men,
from <f type="i">Cornu<f type="r">, a horn.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cornel(n)"><f type="i">Cornel<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="old word">an old word</class>, signifying a
corner, also the fore-part
of a house.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="corneole(n)"><f type="i">Corneol<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kinde of precious stone, apt to
be ingraven, and therefore much used for the making of
seals: It is also called a Sardy, or Onyx.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="corneous(a)"><f type="i">Corneous<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> of a horny
substance.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cornet(n)"><f type="i">Cornet<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> a kinde of black
Taffata, which Doctors of
Physick, or Law used to wear on the collar of their robes
as an Ensign, or badge of their degree,
also the Ensign of a Troup of
horse, so called because it was used to be made of that
kinde of Taffata.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cornice(n)"><f type="i">Cornice<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="architecture">a Term in Architecture</class>,
signifying the crests,
or flourishing work at the upper end of a pillar, it is
also called a frize.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cornigerous(a)"><f type="i">Cornigerous<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> wearing horns, an
Epithet of Bacchus.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cornel-tree(n)"><f type="i">Cornil-tree<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Tree called a Horn-tree,
because its branches are hard like a horn.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cornemuse(n)"><f type="i">Cornimuse<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> <class type="register" subject="music">a kinde of musical
in&shy;
<emend err="instrument">strument</emend></class>, which
some take for a kind of Bag-pipe.</xpln></wordentry>

<f type="i">Corneol<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cornucopy(n)"><f type="i">Cornucopy<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a horn which <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">
gave to <f type="i">Amalthea<f type="r">, whereby she injoyed plenty of
all things, it is Metaphorically taken for plenty.</xpln>

</lemenote>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="corody(n)"><f type="i">Corody<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">from the Latin word
<f type="i"><term lang="la">Corrodo</term><f type="r"></class>, it signifieth <class type="register" subject="law">in Common-law</class>, a summe of
money, or allowance of meat and drink, toward the
maintenance of any of the Kings servants out of an Abby,
or religious house,
whereof the King is the founder.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="corollary(n)"><f type="i">Corollary<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an advantage above the
ordinary measure, also a
gift bestowed on the people at publick feasts.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="corona(n)"><f type="i">Corona<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>by the Greeks called <f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Halo</term><f type="r">,
that is to say a clear Circle appearing in a Cloud about
the Sun, or any other bright Star, but especially about
the Moon, also a coelestial constellation upon the
shoulder of Bootes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="coronal suture(n)"><f type="i">Coronal Suture<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="medicine">this is by Chirurgons
called the formost seam of the skull</class>,
passing from one bone of
the Temples to the other.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="coronation(n)"><f type="i">Coronation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a Crowning.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="coroner(n)"><f type="i">Coroner<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an ancient Officer belonging to
the Crown, and Common-wealth of
<f type="i">England<f type="r">, his
Office, is to enquire of every man that is slain, or
cometh to an untimely end, and what Corn, Cattel, or
freehold, the Felon had
at the time of the fact committed, and to seize them to
the use of the King, or State, there are four of these
Officers in every County.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="coronet(n)"><f type="i">Coronet<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a little Crown, or Chaplet.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="corporal(n)"><f type="i">Corporal<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to the body,
also <emend err="" source="errata">of</emend> a Commander, or band of ten
Souldiers, also the
fine linnen wherein the Sacrament
is put.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="corporation(n)"><f type="i">Corporation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> <class type="register" subject="law">in the Civil Law</class>,
signifieth a body politick, authorised by the Kings
Charter, to have a Common Seal, one, or more head
Officers, and Members able by their common consent to
grant, or receive in Law any thing within the compasse of
their Charter.</xpln></wordentry>

of fee at the day of his death, of certain lands and
tenements, and he dying, a stranger entereth and
intrudeth. Then shall
his heir have this Writ of Cosenage.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Coventry(pn)"><f type="i">Coventry<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous City in
<f type="i">Warwickshire<f type="r">,
so called from a Covent of Monks
</page>

<page sig="K2v">
that was anciently there. The first Lord of this City is
said to be one <f type="i">Leofric<f type="r">, who imposing heavy
taxes upon the Citizens, remitted them at last at the
earnest intercession
of his wife <f type="i">Godiva<f type="r">, upon condition she would
ride naked thorough the chief street of the City, which
she performed, but so covered with her long hair, that
no body could discern her.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="covercle(n)"><f type="i">Covercle<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Coverkill<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class type="old word">(old word)</class>
a lid or cover.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="covert(n)"><f type="i">Covert<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> an ombrage or
shady place for Deer or
other beasts.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="coverture(n)"><f type="i">Coverture<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="law">in Common law</class> is the
condition of a married
woman, who by the Laws of <f type="i">England<f type="r">, is under
Covertbaron, and so disabled to make any bargain
without her husbands
consent.</xpln></wordentry>

general, if he have a childe by her, which cometh alive
into the world, though she and the childe die immediately,
yet if she were in possession he shall hold the land
during his life, and is called Tenant <f type="i">per legem
Angli&aelig;<f type="r">, or the courtesie of
<f type="i">England<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Creon(pn)"><f type="i">Creon<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Menatius<f type="r"> King of
<f type="i">Thebes<f type="r">, he was
brother to <f type="i">Jocasta<f type="r">, the wife of <f type="i">Laius<f type="r">,
and mother of <f type="i">Oedipus<f type="r">, who
unfolded the riddle of
<f type="i">Sphinx<f type="r">, and married <f type="i">Jocasta<f type="r">,
not knowing her to be his mother, and by her had
<f type="i">Eteocles<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Polynices<f type="r">, who succeeded in
the Kingdom, and were to reign by turns every other year,
but they having killed one another in civil Wars,
<f type="i">Creon<f type="r"> regained the Kingdom, but
behaving himself with
much cruelty, he was overcome by <f type="i">Theseus<f type="r">, and
slain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Creusa(pn)"><f type="i">Creusa<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of <f type="i">Priamus<f type="r">
and <f type="i">Hecuba<f type="r">, and wife of <f type="i">Aeneas<f type="r">, by whom
he had <f type="i">Ascanius<f type="r">; she following her husband out of
<f type="i">Troy<f type="r"> when it was set on fire, was not minded by
him till he came out of the City, by reason that he led
his son in his hand, and carried his father on his
shoulders through the
flames, but going back to seek her, he could never hear
what was become of her.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Crinisus(pn)"><f type="i">Crinisus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a River of <f type="i">Sicily<f type="r">, near
to the City <f type="i">Segesta<f type="r">, of which it is related, that
when the <f type="i">Trojan<f type="r"> Virgins were to be
exposed to the fury of a
Monster, whom <f type="i">Neptune<f type="r"> sent to destroy the Country
because of <f type="i">Laomedons<f type="r"> perfidiousnesse,
<f type="i">Hippotes<f type="r"> a noble
<f type="i">Trojan<f type="r"> committed his daughter
<f type="i">Hegesta<f type="r"> to the wide Sea, and she
being by fortune carried
into <f type="i">Sicily, Crinisus<f type="r">
fell in love with her, and turning
himself into a Bear,
ravisht her, whereupon she became with child and brought
forth <f type="i">Acestes<f type="r">,
who was afterwards King of <f type="i">Sicily<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="criplings(n)"><f type="i">Criplings<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="architecture">(a term in building)</class> short spars
on the side of a house.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

discerning into any
thing; also <class type="register" subject="medicine">a term in Physick</class> denoting the sudden change

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="critical(a)"><f type="i">Critical<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> of a nice judgement, apt
to censure. Also Critical dayes in a disease, are those
dayes wherein a disease comes to its Crisis, and they are
the odde dayes as the third, fifth, seventh, and so on;
but the most critical are counted
the fourteenth. The Crisis in acute diseases is judged by
the Moon, but in Chronick diseases, the Crisis is judged
by the Sun</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="criticism(n)"><f type="i">Criticisme<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a playing the Critick,
a learning which consists in the curious and nice
examining of Authors.</xpln></wordentry>

in case he minister not
justice as he should do.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Croesus(pn)"><f type="i">Croesus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a King of the <f type="i">Lydians<f type="r">,
who abounded in riches; he was overcome in war by
<f type="i">Cyrus<f type="r">, and put upon a pile to be burnt, and
calling out <f type="i">Solon, Solon, Cyrus<f type="r"> demanding the
reason, he acquainted him how that <f type="i">Solon<f type="r"> having
formerly been asked of him who was the happiest man, told
him none could be happy till his death, and that the
greatest riches could not keep a man from misery;
whereupon he was freed and made one of <f type="i">Cyrus<f type="r"> his
Counsellers.</xpln></wordentry>

one should put out their fire and light, at the ringing of
the eight a clock-bell, which was called <f type="i">Couvrir le

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="custom(n)"><f type="i">Custome<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>both <class type="register" subject="law">in Common and Civil Law</class>,
signifieth a Law, or Rite not written,
which being established by long use and the consent of
our Ancestours hath been, and is dayly practised.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="custos brevium(n)"><f type="i">Custos brevium<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Clerk belonging to the

all the Writs, and put them upon files, every return by it

receive of the prothonotaries, all the Records
of <f type="i">nisi prius<f type="r">, called the <f type="i">postea<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

called in Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Sepia</term><f type="r">, which throwing a black
juyce like ink into the water, becomes hid in that
obscurity, and so escapes the fisher.</xpln></wordentry>

of Saturn, she is otherwise
called <f type="i">Ops, Rhea, Vesta, Magna Mater<f type="r">, or

&amp; <f type="i">Berecynthia<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cycle(n)"><f type="i">Cycle<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> <class type="register" subject="astrology and astronomy">a Term in Astronomy</class>,
<f type="i">Cycle<f type="r"> of the Sun is the revolution of 28 years,
<f type="i">Cycle<f type="r"> of the Moon the revolution of 19 years, in
which time both of their motions
recur to the same point.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cyclop&aelig;dia(n)"><f type="i">Cyclop&aelig;die<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> the whole Circle of

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cyclops(n)"><f type="i">Cyclops<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the sons of Neptune and <f type="i">Amphitrite<f type="r">,
or as <f type="i">Apollodorus Atheniensis<f type="r"> saith of
<f type="i">Coelus<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Terra<f type="r">, they were the servants
of <f type="i">Vulcan<f type="r">, and made Thunder-bolts for
<f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">, having each of them one great eye in
their forehead, their names were <f type="i">Bronte, <emend err="Serope" source="errata">Sterope</emend><f type="r">
and <f type="i">Pyracmon<f type="r">, whom <f type="i">Apollodorus<f type="r">
calleth <f type="i">Harpe<f type="r">, others say they were a very
ancient people of <f type="i">Sicily<f type="r"> of a very Gyantly
stature.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Cycnus(pn)"><f type="i">Cycnus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Mars<f type="r">, who was
kill'd in a Combate with <f type="i">Hercules<f type="r">, whom
<f type="i">Mars<f type="r"> to revenge his sons death resolved to fight
with, but before they came to blows,
<f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> parted them with a clap of Thunder,
there was another <f type="i">Cycnus<f type="r">, the son of
<f type="i">Neptune<f type="r">, who being invulnerable fought with
<f type="i">Achilles<f type="r">, and could not be killed, till
<f type="i">Achilles<f type="r"> throwing him upon the ground, kneel'd
upon his neck and stiffled him.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cylinder(n)"><f type="i">Cylinder<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> <class type="register" subject="mathematics">a Geometrical
body</class>, being long, flat at
both ends, and equally
round from one end to the other, also a rolling stone to
smooth Garden allies, being just of that figure, <class type="register" subject="war">in the
art of Gunnery</class> it signifies that part of the bore of a
piece, which remains empty when the piece is laden.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cymaise(n)"><f type="i">Cymace<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">from the Greek word <f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Cyma</term><f type="r">,

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Cyrus(pn)"><f type="i">Cyrus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Cambyses<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Mandana<f type="r">, he was
King of <f type="i">Persia<f type="r">, overthrew the <f type="i">Assyrian<f type="r">
Monarchy, conquered all <f type="i">Asia<f type="r">, but was at length
overcome and slain by <f type="i">Thomyris<f type="r">, Queen of
<f type="i">Scythia<f type="r">, who causing his head to be cut off, and
cast into a tub of bloud, cried out, now satisfie thy self
with bloud, after which thou hast alwayes thirsted.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cystic(a)"><f type="i">Cystick<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> belonging to the bag of
Gall, which is call'd <f type="i">Cystis, Cystick<f type="r"> vein
signifieth <class type="register" subject="medicine">in Anatomy</class> a branch of the Port vein, which
ascendeth up to the neck of the Gall, and there divideth
it self.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="D&aelig;dalus(pn)"><f type="i">D&aelig;dalus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous Artist, who made the

up himself with his son <f type="i">Icarus<f type="r">, for having made a
woodden Heifer, in which <f type="i">Pasiph&aelig;<f type="r"> was injoyed by
<f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> in the shape of a Bull, but he making
artificial wings for himself and his son, flew out of
<f type="i">Crete<f type="r"> into <f type="i">Sardinia<f type="r">, but <f type="i">Icarus<f type="r">
soaring too high, melted the wax and fell into the

Captain, who conquered those parts.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Damascus(pn)"><f type="i">Damascus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the chief Citie of

man taketh in his estate, also a part of that the Jurors

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="damage-fesant(n)"><f type="i">Dammage fesant<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="law">in Common-law</class>, is, when a
strangers beasts are in another mans ground, and there
feed without Licence of
the Tenant, spoiling the Grasse, or Corn, in which case
the Tenant may impound them.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Damocrita(pn)"><f type="i">Damocrita<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Roman Matron, whose husband
<f type="i">Alcippus<f type="r"> being banish't, and she forbid to follow
him, and her daughters prohibited marriage that his race
might be extinct, she in revenge when the chief women of
the Citie were met in a house to sacrifice, set fire on
the house, and when she saw people run to their aid, she
first killed her daughters, then her self.</xpln></wordentry>

Earth, whom they worshipped as a

farmed the Priors aliens
lands of the King.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="decener(n)" lexeme="dozener(n)"><f type="i">Deciners<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Doziners<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>such as
were wont to have the check of ten Friburgs for the
maintenance of the peace, the limits
of whose jurisdiction was called
Decenna.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="declension(n)" lexeme="declination(n)"><f type="i">Declension<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Declination<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class>
a declining or bowing
down; also <class type="register" subject="grammar">in Grammar</class>, it
signifieth the varying of Cases and Tenses in Nounes and
Verbs. <class type="register" subject="astrology and astronomy">In <emend err="Astrology" source="errata">Astronomy</emend></class>,
the declination of a Planet is his
distance from the
equator, and as he declines
from thence, either northward or southward, so is his
declination nominated
either north or south.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Deianira(pn)"><f type="i">Deianira<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of <f type="i">Oeneus<f type="r">,
King of <f type="i">Etolia<f type="r">, she was first espoused to
<f type="i">Achelous<f type="r">,
afterwards to <f type="i">Hercules<f type="r">, and being to passe over
the River <f type="i">Evenus, Nessus<f type="r"> the Centaure offered his
service to carry her over, but as soon as he was on the
farther side, he attempted to ravish her,
whereupon <f type="i">Hercules<f type="r"> shot at him with a
poysoned arrow; <f type="i">Nessus<f type="r"> perceiving he had
received his deaths wound, he to be revenged
presented <f type="i">Deianira<f type="r"> with a shirt dipt in his own
bloud, telling her, that if her husband wore it, it would
draw his affections from all other women, which she
believing gave it to <f type="i">Hercules<f type="r">, but the shirt
sticking to his body so burnt his flesh that to avoide the
torment, he threw himself into a flaming pyle, and
<f type="i">Deianira<f type="r"> for grief slew her self.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="dejeration(n)"><f type="i">Dejeration<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a taking a solemn
oath.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Delamere(pn)"><f type="i">Delamere<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Forrest in <f type="i">Cheshire<f type="r">,
whereof the Dawns of <f type="i">Vskinton<f type="r"> were, by the gift
of <f type="i">Ranulph<f type="r"> the first Earle of <f type="i">Chester<f type="r">,
made Forresters by Hereditary succession; in this Forrest
<f type="i">Aedelfleda<f type="r"> the <f type="i">Mercian<f type="r"> Lady built a Town
called <f type="i">Eadelbury<f type="r">, i. e. the happy Town, which now
being nothing but a heap of rubbish, is called the Chamber
in the Forrest.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="demand(n)"><f type="i">Demand<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="law">in Common-law</class>, is opposite to

actions, the pursuer is called demandant, if personal,

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="demesne(n)"><f type="i">Demeasne<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Demain<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> by
the <f type="i">Civilians<f type="r"> called <f type="i"><term lang="la">Dominicum</term><f type="r">, is that
land, which a man holdeth originally of
himself, whereas
<f type="i"><term lang="la">feodum</term><f type="r"> are those, which he holdeth by the benefit
of a Superiour.</xpln></wordentry>
