<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Demetrius(pn)"><f type="i">Demetrius<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the name of several famous Kings in
<f type="i">Asia<f type="r">, who succeeded <f type="i">Alexander<f type="r">, the
word signifieth belonging to <f type="i">Ceres<f type="r">, who in
Greek is called <f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Demeter</term><f type="r">.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="demi(a)"><f type="i">Demi<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> joyned with another word,
signifieth half as <f type="i">Demi-God<f type="r">, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="demin(n)"><f type="i">Demin<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="old word">(old word)</class> a Judge.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="demise(n)"><f type="i">Demise<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> to farm, or let.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="demission(n)"><f type="i">Demission<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a casting down, or
abasement.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="democracy(n)"><f type="i">Democracy<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a Government wherein the
Magistrates are chosen from among the people, and by the
people.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Democritus(pn)"><f type="i">Democritus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous Philosopher born at
<f type="i">Abdera<f type="r">, he thought the world to be composed of
Atomes, and that he might the better contemplate upon
natural causes, and not be
taken off with any outward
objects, he put out his eyes with a burning bason, his
father was a man of so great riches, that he feasted
<f type="i">Xerxes<f type="r"> and all his Army.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="demolition(n)"><f type="i">Demolition<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a casting down, or
ruinating.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="demonachation(n)"><class type="unknown">&dagger;</class> <f type="i">Demonachation<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> an
expelling from the
Monkish order, also a forsaking
of the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="demoniac(n)"><f type="i">Demoniack<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>see <xref><f type="i">D&aelig;moniack<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="demonstration(n)"><f type="i">Demonstration<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a shewing, or
making plain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Demophon(pn)"><f type="i">Demophon<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Theseus<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Ph&aelig;dra<f type="r">, he was
driven by Tempest upon the shore of <f type="i">Thrace<f type="r">, and
married <f type="i">Phillis<f type="r">, the daughter of
<f type="i">Lycurgus<f type="r">, but <f type="i">Theseus<f type="r"> dying, he took the
government of <f type="i">Athens<f type="r"> upon him, and forgetting
<f type="i">Phillis<f type="r">, she for grief hanged her self upon an
Almond-tree.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Demosthenes(pn)"><f type="i">Demosthenes<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous Oratour among the
Greeks, who was banish't by <f type="i">Philip<f type="r"> of
<f type="i">Macedon<f type="r">, and at last poysoned himself to avoid
the fury of <f type="i">Antipater<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="demur(n)"><f type="i">Demur<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>signifieth in Common-law a kinde of
pause upon any point of difficulty.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="denariata terr&aelig;(n)"><f type="i">Denariata terr&aelig;<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the fourth part of an
Acre of Land, it is also called farding-deal, or a
farundel of Land.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="denary(n)"><f type="i">Denary<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> the number of 10. also the
same as Deneer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Denbigh(pn)"><f type="i">Denbigh<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the chief Town of
<f type="i">Denbighshire<f type="r">,
called by the <f type="i">Britains Cled Fryn-yn Rosse<f type="r">, i. e.
a rough Hill in <f type="i">Rosse<f type="r">, for so that part of
<f type="i">Wales<f type="r"> was anciently named.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="denier(n)"><f type="i">Deneer<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kinde of Coper Coyn, which values
about the tenth part of a penny.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Dane-law(n)"><f type="i">Denelage<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the Law of the Danes, by which a
third part of <f type="i">England<f type="r"> was
governed before the
Conquest.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Denis(pn)"><f type="i">Denis<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a proper name, contracted from
<f type="i">Dionysius<f type="r">, which some fetch from <f type="i">Dios
nous<f type="r">, i. e. Divine minde, the chief of this name was
St. <f type="i">Denis<f type="r">, the great Saint of <f type="i">France<f type="r">, it
is also a womans name contracted
from <f type="i">Diana<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="deneck(n)"><f type="i">Deneck<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="ar" type="etymlang">(Arab.)</class> the tayl of the
Swan.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="deneck elected(a)"><f type="i">Deneck elected<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="ar" type="etymlang">(Arab.)</class> the tayl of the
Lion.</xpln>
<lemenote>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="deneck alihedi(n)"><f type="i">Deneck Alihedi<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="ar" type="etymlang">(Arab.)</class> the bowing of the
back, or doubling of the tayl of the Goat.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not in OED.
</lemenote>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="denizen(n)"><f type="i">Denizon</form>, <xpln>quasi<f type="r"> Danes son, or <class lang="fr" type="etymlang">from the
French word <f type="i"><term lang="fr">donaison</term><f type="r">, an endowing</class>, and signifieth
in Common-law an Alien that is Infranchised by the Princes
Charter, whereby he is made capable of any
Office, or of purchasing
Land, but it cometh short of Naturalization, because a
stranger naturalised may
inherit by descent.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Dennington(pn)"><f type="i">Dennington<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Castle in
<f type="i">Bark-shire<f type="r">, built by Sir <f type="i">Richard de
Aberbury<f type="r">, it was once the Residence of the Poet
<f type="i">Chaucer<f type="r">, afterwards
of <f type="i">Charles Brandon<f type="r"> Duke of
<f type="i">Suffolk<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="denomination(n)"><f type="i">Denomination<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a giving a name, from
any occasion.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="dense(a)"><f type="i">Dense<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>thick, opposed to rare by the
Philosopher, and that body is said to be dense, where the
substance is more, and the quantity lesse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="density(n)"><f type="i">Density<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> thicknesse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="dent(n)"><f type="i">Dent<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="heraldry">a Term in Blazon</class>, as a bordure dent,
or indented is, when the line of which the border is made
is indented in, and out like the teeth of a saw.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="dentifrice(n)"><f type="i">Dentifrice<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat)</class> a certain powder made up
into a consistence, wherewith to rub the teeth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="dentiscalp(n)"><f type="i">Dentisscalp<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a tooth-picker, or
tooth-scraper.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="dentition(n)"><f type="i">Dentition<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a putting forth, or

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="denudation(n)"><f type="i">Denudation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a making bare, or

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="denuntiation(n)"><f type="i">Denuntiation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a proclaiming, or

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="deodand(n)"><f type="i">Deodand<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a thing devoted, and consecrated
to the service of God, to expiate some eminent hurt, or
mischief it hath done.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="de deoneranda pro rato portionis(n)"><f type="i">De Deoneranda pro rato portionis<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Writ
that lieth where a man is distrained for Rent that ought
to be paid by others, proportionably with himself.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="deosculation(n)"><f type="i">Deosculation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a kissing with
eagernesse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="departer(n)"><f type="i">Departer<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="law">a Term in Law</class>, signifying, he
</page>

<page sig="L4v">
that pleading one thing at first in barre of an action,
and being replied thereunto, doth in his rejoynder, shew
another matter contrary
to his first plea; also departers
of Gold or Silver, are those that purifie, and part
those mettals from the courser sort: they are also
called parters and finers.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="departure in despite of the court(n)"><f type="i">Departure in despite of the Court<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>is when
the Tenet or Defendant appeareth to the action brought
against him, and hath a day over in the same term and does
not appear but makes default; it is called a departure in
spight of the Court.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="depauperation(n)"><f type="i">Depauperation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a making poor.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="depeculation(n)"><f type="i">Depeculation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a publick theevery, or
stealing from the Common-wealth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="depend(v)"><f type="i">Depend<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> to stay or rely upon.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Deptford(pn)"><f type="i">Depford<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous shipdock in
<f type="i">Kent<f type="r">, where the ships for the Kings Navy use to
be built. It was anciently called <f type="i">West-Greenwich<f type="r">,
and at the Conquest of <f type="i">England<f type="r">
was given to <f type="i">Cislebert Mammignot<f type="r">, one of
<f type="i">William<f type="r"> the Conquerours
Souldiers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="depilation(n)"><f type="i">Depilation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a making bare of hairs,
a making bald.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="deploration(n)"><f type="i">Deploration<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a mourning for, or

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="deplume(v)"><f type="i">Deplume<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> to strip off

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="deponent(n)"><f type="i">Deponent<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="grammar">in Grammar</class>, signifieth a Verb
which hath a passive termination, and an active
signification; also <class type="register" subject="law">in Common law</class> it is he who deposeth or
layeth down any matter upon oath.</xpln></wordentry>

calamity.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="depulsion(n)"><f type="i">Depulsion<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a driving from.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="derein(n)"><f type="i">Derein<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">from the French word
<f type="i"><term lang="fr">Desranger</term><f type="r"></class>, or
<class lang="no" type="etymlang">the Norman word <f type="i"><term lang="no">Desrene</term><f type="r"></class>,
signifieth the proof of
an action which a man affirmeth that he hath done, and his
adversary denies.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Derham(pn)"><f type="i">Derham<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="sx" type="etymlang">in the Saxon tongue
<f type="i"><term lang="sx">Deorham</term><f type="r"></class>, a Town in <f type="i">Glostershire<f type="r">, where
<f type="i">Ceaulin<f type="r"> the Saxon King slew 3 Princes of the
Britains, <f type="i">Commeail, Condidan<f type="r">, and
<f type="i">Fariemeiol<f type="r">, and utterly subdued the
Nation.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Deric(pn)"><f type="i">Deric<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a proper name of a man, it being a
word contracted from <f type="i">Theoderic<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="derision(n)"><f type="i">Derision<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a scorning or laughing
at.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="derivation(n)"><f type="i">Derivation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a drawing or taking, it
is used <class type="register" subject="grammar">in Grammar</class> for the deriving of any word from its
original; also <class type="register" subject="medicine">in Physick</class>
it is taken for a drawing of the
humour from one part of the
body to another.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Dartmouth(pn)"><f type="i">Dertmouth<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Port Town in
<f type="i">Devonshire<f type="r">, which in former times Mounsieur
<f type="i">de Castel<f type="r"> a French Pirate going about to invade,
was by the Country people intercepted and slain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="derogation(n)"><f type="i">Derogation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a lessening or
detracting from the
worth of any thing, or any person.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="deruncination(n)"><f type="i">Deruncination<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a taking away weeds,
or any thing that molesteth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Derbices(pn)"><f type="i">Derbices<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a people of <f type="i">Asia<f type="r">,
inhabiting near the mountain <f type="i">Caucasus<f type="r">, who
strangle their kindred as soon as they arrive at the age
of 70 years, and eat their flesh,
inviting their neighbours
to the Feast. And this they hold to be the most noble kind
of burial.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Derceto(pn)"><f type="i">Derceto<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the name of a certain Goddesse
anciently worshipped at <f type="i">Askalon<f type="r">, her
forepart representing the
shape of a woman, her hinder part the shape of a
fish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Dercyllidas(pn)"><f type="i">Dercyllidas<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous <f type="i">Lacedemonian<f type="r">
Commander, who succeeded <f type="i">Thymbron<f type="r">, he took
<f type="i">Larissa, Amaxitos<f type="r">, and <f type="i">Colona<f type="r">, and
gained divers victories over the <f type="i">Persians<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Dervises(pn)"><f type="i">Dervises<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an Order of religious persons
among the <f type="i">Turks<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Descalsas(pn)"><f type="i">Descalsas<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="sp" type="etymlang">(Spanish)</class> a sort of Fryars in
<f type="i">Spain<f type="r"> that go barelegged.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="descant(n)"><f type="i">Descant<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>called in Latin
<f type="i"><term lang="la">frequentamentum
vocis</term><f type="r">, in French <f type="i"><term lang="fr">fredon</term><f type="r">, is <class type="register" subject="music">a term in
Musick</class>, signifying the answering of quick notes in one
part, unto a slower measure in the other <emend err="parti">part.</emend>
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="descent(n)"><f type="i">Descent<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a coming down, also a
deriving ones pedigree.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="description(n)"><f type="i">Description<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a setting forth the
nature or property of any thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="descry(v)"><f type="i">Descry<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">from the French word <term lang="fr">cry</term> or
<term lang="fr">clamour</term></class>, to discover afar off.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="desection(n)"><f type="i">Desection<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a cutting or mowing
down.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="desert(n)"><f type="i">Desert<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Wildernesse or solitary place,
<class lang="la" type="etymlang">from the Latin word <f type="i"><term lang="la">deserere</term><f type="r">, to forsake</class>, but
with the accent in the last syllable, it signifieth merit
<class lang="fr" type="etymlang">from the French word <f type="i"><term lang="fr">deservir</term><f type="r"></class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Deucalion(pn)"><f type="i">Deucalion<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Prometheus<f type="r">,
he with his wife <f type="i">Pyrrha<f type="r"> the daughter of
<f type="i">Epimetheus<f type="r">,
were saved in the universal Deluge, being carried in a
ship to the top of <f type="i">Pernassus<f type="r">
and consulting the Oracle of <f type="i">Themis<f type="r"> what way they
should take to restore mankind, and being told they should
throw the bones of their first mother
behind them, they took
stones out of the earth, and cast them behind them. Those
which <f type="i">Deucalion<f type="r"> cast became men, and those <emend err="whic">which</emend>
<f type="i">Pyrrha<f type="r"> cast became women.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="devils-bit(n)"><f type="i">Devils-bit<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kind of plant whose root looks as
if it were, and is fain'd to have been, bitten by the
Devil out of envy,
</page>

<page sig="M1v">
because of the many excellent virtues and properties it
hath, wherewith mankinde is benefitted.
</xpln></wordentry>

after his decease, and he, to whom the lands, or goods are
bequeathed, is called
the devisee, devise also

Picture, and is also called an Imprese.</xpln></wordentry>

in the air; but when he withdrawes himself from our
Hemisphear, it falleth down again in round drops, and is
by the coldnesse of the air congealed resolved into
water.</xpln></wordentry>

forth at one birth with <f type="i">Apollo<f type="r">,

hunting, whereupon she was called the Goddesse of the

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="diaphoretic(n)"><f type="i">Diaphoretick<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> easily piercing

signifies a Medicine
that discusses any humour
by concoction, or transpiration.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="diaphragm(n)"><f type="i">Diaphragme<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a fence, or hedge, <class type="register" subject="medicine">in
Anatomy</class> it signifieth a skin, or muscle which passeth
overthwart the body, seperating
the breast, or middle region from the stomack, or lower
region.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="diarrh&aelig;a(n)"><f type="i">Diarrh&aelig;a<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a flux of the belly
without any inflammation of the
Entrailes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="diastole(n)"><f type="i">Diastole<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a figure whereby a
syllable short by nature is made long, also <class type="register" subject="medicine">in physick</class>, it
is taken for that motion of the pulses, which dilates the
heart and the arteries, being contrary to Systole, which
contracts them.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="diary(n)"><f type="i">Diarie<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Diurnal, or Day-book,
wherein the passages of
every day are written.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="diatesseron(n)"><f type="i">Diatesseron<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> one of the chief
Chords <class type="register" subject="music">in Musick</class>, called a fourth, also a plaister that
consists but of foure ingredients.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="diatribe(n)"><f type="i">Diatribe<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a place where

or Disputations are held.</xpln>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="dictator(n)"><f type="i">Dictator<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a great Commander
among the Romans, who had
the chief authority for
the time being, both in war and peace; he was never chosen
but upon some great occasion,
and his command was to last but half a year.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Dictynna(pn)"><f type="i">Dictynna<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a name attributed to
<f type="i">Diana<f type="r">, who flying from <f type="i">Minos<f type="r">, she cast
her self into certain nets which are called Dictya.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="didapper(n)"><f type="i">Didapper<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kind of bird, so called <class lang="gk" type="etymlang">from
the Greek word <f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Diadyptein</term><f type="r">, to duck under
water</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Dido(pn)"><f type="i">Dido<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of <f type="i">Belus<f type="r">, King
of the <f type="i">Tyrians<f type="r">, she was married to
<f type="i">Sich&aelig;us<f type="r"> Priest of <f type="i">Hercules<f type="r">, whom
<f type="i">Pygmalion<f type="r"> slew that he might obtain his riches;
but she gathering all the wealth she could together, fled into
<f type="i">Africa<f type="r">, and there built a City which was first
called <f type="i">Byrsa<f type="r">, afterwards
<f type="i">Carthage<f type="r">, and refusing to marry <f type="i">Iarbas<f type="r">
King of <f type="i">Getulia<f type="r">, because he went about to force
her by war, she killed her self. Others say, it was
because falling in love with <f type="i">Aeneas<f type="r"> who was
driven by tempest on her
coast, he refused to marry her.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="didrachm(n)"><f type="i">Didram<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an ancient coin valueing
fifteen pence.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="diem clausit extremum(n)"><f type="i">Diem clausit extremum<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Writ that lieth
for the Heir of him that holdeth land of the Crown, either
by Knights service, or in Soccage and dieth. It is
directed to the Eschetour
to inquire of what estate he was seized, and who is next
Heir; and this inquisition is to be
returned into the
Chancery.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="dies datus(n)"><f type="i">Dies datus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a respite given to the
Tenent or Defendant before
the Court.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="diennial(a)"><f type="i">Diennial<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> of two years

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="diminutive(a)"><f type="i">Diminutive<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> little, small; <class type="register" subject="grammar">in
Grammar</class> it is taken
substantively for a word whose termination implies a
littlenesse in respect of another thing that is bigger, as
from <f type="i">tabula<f type="r"> a table, comes <f type="i">tabella<f type="r"> a
little table or tablet. <class type="register" subject="heraldry">In Heraldry</class> it is a
blemishing or defacing
of some particular point of the Escocheon by the
imposition of some stain and colour thereon. <class type="register" subject="architecture">In
Architecture</class> it
signifies the lessening of a pillar by little and little,
from the base to the top.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="diocese(n)"><f type="i">Dioces<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>from the Greek word <f type="i"><term lang="gkt">dioecesis</term><f type="r">
a governing, signifieth the Ecclesiastical jurisdiction

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Diogenes(pn)"><f type="i">Diogenes<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous Philosopher, who lived
in a tub which he rolled up and down from place to place;
he was for his churlish disposition and clownish
conversation called
the <f type="i">Cynic<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Diomedes(pn)"><f type="i">Diomedes<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Tydeus<f type="r">, and
<f type="i">Deiphile<f type="r">, and
King of <f type="i">Aetolia<f type="r">, he was
accounted one of the
chiefest Hero's at the wars of <f type="i">Troy<f type="r">; he brought
away <f type="i">Rhesus<f type="r"> his horses and the
<f type="i">Palladium<f type="r">, he wounded <f type="i">Mars<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Venus<f type="r">, fought with <f type="i">Hector<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Aeneas<f type="r">, whom his mother <f type="i">Venus<f type="r"> protected;
at length being ashamed to return home because of the
whorish pranks of his wife <f type="i">Aegiale<f type="r">, he went into
<f type="i">Apulia<f type="r"> and had that Kingdom given him by
<f type="i">Daunus<f type="r">. There was also another <f type="i">Diomed<f type="r">
King of <f type="i">Thrace<f type="r">, who used to feed his horses with
mans flesh; but at last <f type="i">Hercules<f type="r"> overcoming him,
gave him to be devoured by his own horses.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="dioptic art(n)"><f type="i">Dioptic art<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="art">that part of perspective</class> which
belongs <class type="register" subject="astrology and astronomy">to Astronomy</class>, and by instruments
searcheth out the distance of the Sun and other Stars,
comprehending <emend err="Neniter capedines" source="errata">the Intercapedines</emend> of Sun, 
Moon, and Stars.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="dirge(n)"><f type="i">Dirge<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">from the Latin word

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="districation(n)"><f type="i">Districation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a ridding out of trouble,
from the latin words <f type="i"><term lang="la">dis</term><f type="r"> a preposition, and
<f type="i"><term lang="la">Tric&aelig;</term><f type="r"> small threads about chickens legs, which
hinder them from going; but metaphorically
any kind of incumbrance.</xpln></wordentry>

within which a man may be
compelled to appear.</xpln>

Term not in OED as headword but see entry for "district."

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Dodona(pn)"><f type="i">Dodona<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Citie of <f type="i">Chaonia<f type="r">, a
Countrey of Greece, near to which there was a Temple and
Oracle of <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">, within a Wood, sacred to the
same Deity, of which Wood it was fain'd that the Trees
were vocal, and returned the answers of the Oracle, also
the name of a Fountain, whose water had a property, both
to quench and kindle fire.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="dog-draw(n)"><f type="i">Dogdraw<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="law">(a Term used in Forrest law,)</class> is
when any man is found drawing after a Deer by the scent of
a hound, which he leadeth in his hand, being one of the
four circumstances, wherein a Forrester may arrest the
body of an offender against Vert, or Venison in the
Forrest, the other three being Stablestand, Back berond,
and Bloudy-hand.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Donatists(pn)"><f type="i">Donatists<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Sect of Hereticks, whereof the
more rigid sort are called Circumcellians,
they held the son to be lesse then the father, and the
holy Ghost lesse then the son, and affirm'd the true
Church to be onely in <f type="i">Africa<f type="r">, they were
instituted by <f type="i">Donatus<f type="r">, Bishop of
<f type="i">Carthage<f type="r">, in the year 358. the more moderate sort
were called Rogatists.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="donative(a)"><f type="i">Donative<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> apt to give, it is

for a benefice meerly given
by a Patron to any man, also a Princes gift.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Dorchester(pn)"><f type="i">Dorchester<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the chief Town in
<f type="i">Dorcetshire<f type="r">,
it was in old time called <f type="i">Durnovaria,
i. e.<f type="r"> the River passage, it was
miserably harrass't by
<f type="i">Sueno<f type="r"> the <f type="i">Dane<f type="r">, and
afterwards by
<f type="i">Hush<f type="r"> the <f type="i">Norman<f type="r">, but flourish't again in
King <f type="i">Edwards<f type="r"> dayes; there is
also another Town of this
name in <f type="i">Oxfordshire<f type="r">,
by <f type="i">Leland<f type="r">, called <f type="i">Hydropolis. <class lang="br" type="etymlang">Dour<f type="r">
signifying in the ancient <f type="i">Brittish<f type="r"> tongue,
water.</class></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Doris(pn)"><f type="i">Doris<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of <f type="i">Oceanus<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Thetis<f type="r">, she being
married to <f type="i">Nereus<f type="r">, brought forth a great number
of <f type="i">Sea-nymphs<f type="r">, called
<f type="i">Nereides<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="dormant(a)"><f type="i">Dormant<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="heraldry">in Heraldry</class> signifieth lying in a
sleeping posture, also <class type="register" subject="law">in Law</class> a writing Dormant is, that,
which hath a blank to put in the name of any one, also a
Dormant-tree is a
great beam, which lieth crosse the house which some call a
Summer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="dormer(n)"><f type="i">Dormers<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>window's made in the roof of a

<page sig="N1v">

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="dragon's head(n)"><f type="i">Dragons Head<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>called in the Greek
<term lang="gk">&#x1F00;&#x03BD;&#x03B1;&#x03B2;&#x03B9;&#x03B2;&#x03AC;&#x03B6;&#x03C9;&#x03BD;</term>}, a node or place in the
Eccliptick line, which
the Moon cutteth and ascendes from the aust'ral part of
the node into the Septentrional, it hath no aspect to any
Planet, but it may be aspected
by them; its motion is according to the motion of the
Sun.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="dragon's tail(n)"><f type="i">Dragons taile<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>called in Greek

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Dublin(pn)"><f type="i">Dublin<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the chief City of <f type="i">Ireland<f type="r">,
situate in the Province of
<f type="i">Leimster<f type="r">, it was antiently called <f type="i">Bala
cleigh<f type="r">, i. a Town upon
<f type="i">Hurdles<f type="r">. Some say it was built by <f type="i">Harold<f type="r">
King of <f type="i">Norway<f type="r">, (when he conquered
<f type="i">Ireland<f type="r">) from whom descended in a direct line
<f type="i">Griffith ap Conan<f type="r">, borne at <f type="i">Dublin<f type="r">, in
the reign of <f type="i">Tyrlough<f type="r">. This City was bravely
defended by the <f type="i">English<f type="r"> against <f type="i">Asculph<f type="r">
Prince of the <f type="i">Dublinians<f type="r">, and <f type="i">Gottred<f type="r">
King of the Isles, and in the time of King <f type="i">Henry<f type="r">
the second, was given to a Colony of
<f type="i">Bristowmen<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Dubris(pn)"><f type="i">Dubris<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the ancient name of a Port-Town in
<f type="i">Kent<f type="r">, now called <f type="i">Dover<f type="r">, having a very
fair and strong Castle, built as some say by <f type="i">Julius
C&aelig;sar<f type="r">, and afterwards fortified
by King <f type="i">Arviragus<f type="r"> against the
<f type="i">Romans<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="ducal(a)"><f type="i">Ducal<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to a Duke.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="ducket(n)"><f type="i">Ducket<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain golden coin, valueing

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="dulcarnon(n)"><f type="i">Dulcarnon<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a proportion found out by <f type="i">Pythagoras<f type="r">, for which
happy invention, he sacrified an Oxe to the gods in
thankfulness, which
sacrifice he called <f type="i">Dulcarnon<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Durham(pn)"><f type="i">Durham<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the chief City of the
Bishoprick of
<f type="i">Durham<f type="r">, built by Bishop <f type="i">Aldwin<f type="r">, with the

<f type="i">Northumberland<f type="r">.

the fury of the <f type="i">Danes<f type="r">. It was anciently called

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Easter(n)"><f type="i">Easter<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the time of the celebration of
Christs Resurrection, <class lang="du" type="etymlang">contracted from the Dutch word
<f type="i"><term lang="du">Aufferstand</term>, i. e.<f type="r"> Resurrection</class>, or <class lang="sx" type="etymlang">from
<f type="i"><term lang="sx">Eoster</term><f type="r">, an ancient Goddesse of the Saxons</class>, whose
Feast they kept about the same time, namely, about
<f type="i">April<f type="r">, which was thence called
<f type="i"><term lang="sx">Eoster-monath</term><f type="r">. It is also
called <f type="i">Pasca<f type="r">, <class lang="he" type="etymlang">from the <f type="i">Hebrew<f type="r">, word
<f type="i"><term lang="he">Pasach</term><f type="r">, to passe over</class>, because about this time,
the Jews celebrated the Feast of the Passeover.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Easterlings(pn)"><f type="i">Easterlings<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>people inhabiting the East
part of <f type="i">Germany<f type="r">, also Easterling money, is that
which we call Sterling, or Currant money, from a certain
coin which <f type="i">Richard<f type="r"> the first caused to be coined
in those parts, being held in great request for its
purity.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Edinton(pn)"><f type="i">Edinton<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="sx" type="etymlang">(called in old time

overthrew the <f type="i">Danes<f type="r"> in a
memorable battle, here also <f type="i">William de Edinton<f type="r">, Bishop of
<f type="i">Winchester<f type="r">, erected a Colledge for an Order of
men, called <f type="i">bon hommes, i. e.<f type="r"> good men.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="edition(n)"><f type="i">Edition<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a setting forth of any
thing, but commonly it is taken for the impression of a
book.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Edmund(pn)"><f type="i">Edmund<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the proper name of a man
signifying <class lang="sx" type="etymlang">in the
<f type="i">Saxon<f type="r"> tongue happy peace</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Edmundsbury, St.(pn)">St. <f type="i">Edmundsbury<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town in
<f type="i">Suffolk<f type="r">, anciently called <f type="i">Bederick's gueord,
i. e.<f type="r"> the Court, or Mansion-house of
<f type="i">Bederick<f type="r">, and seems to have been the same Town
with that, which <f type="i">Antonine<f type="r"> calleth <f type="i">Villa
Faustini<f type="r">. It derived
its present name from King <f type="i">Edmund<f type="r">, who was
cruelly put to death by the <f type="i">Danes<f type="r">, and his body
translated hither, a
stately Church being also erected to his memory, which
being demolished by
<f type="i">Suenus<f type="r"> the <f type="i">Dane<f type="r">, was built anew by his
son <f type="i">Canutus<f type="r"> to expiate his
fathers sacriledge.</xpln></wordentry>

as Manumission to servants, <class type="register" subject="law">according to the Civil Law</class>,
namely a legal, setting them free from the power of their
fathers, before the Magistrate.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="ember-week(n)"><f type="i">Emberweek<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>in Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Cineralia</term><f type="r">, the
week before Lent, wherein by the
ancient institution of the
Church people were to fast, and the Bishop used to
sprinkle ashes upon their heads; saying, Remember, O man,
that thou art ashes, and to ashes shalt thou return.
<f type="i"><term lang="sx">Imber</term><f type="r">, signifying <class lang="sx" type="etymlang">in the <f type="i">Saxon<f type="r"> tongue
ashes</class>, whence our word embers cometh, some say ember week,
is derived <class lang="gk" type="etymlang">from the Greek word <f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Hemerai</term>, i.<f type="r">
dayes</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="faces, decury(n)" lexeme="faces, deconate(n)"><f type="i">Faces, Decury<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Deconate<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">from
the Greek word <f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Deka</term><f type="r"></class>, signifying ten, because in
every Sign there are three Faces, every Face consisting of
ten degrees. They are called Faces for that they are
equivalent to Signs, Formes, and shapes, by reason they
shew the nature and inclination of the Planets in them as
in their own houses.</xpln>
<lemenote>
The term "deconate" is not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="felony(n)"><f type="i">Felony<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="law">in Common Law</class>, is any offence which is
next to petty treason, as murder, theft, rapes, burning
of houses, <f type="i">&amp;c.<f type="r">
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="fence-month(n)"><f type="i">Fencemonth<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the month wherein Deer begin to
fawn, which is about midsummer,
wherein it is unlawful to hunt in the Forrest.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="fend(n)"><f type="i">Fends<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>things hung over a ships side to
keep another ship from rubbing against it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="fennel(n)"><f type="i">Fennel<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kind of herb so called.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="fenugreek(n)"><f type="i">Fenugreec<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an herb which hath been found
growing in great abundance, in several parts of
Greece.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="feodary(n)" lexeme="feudatary(n)"><f type="i">Feodary<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Feudatary<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>an officer
belonging to the Court
of Wards and Liveries,
who is to be present with the Escheatour
at the finding of any office, and also to survay and value
the land of the Ward.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="feofment(n)"><f type="i">Feofment<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="law">in Common Law</class>, is the gift or
grant of any Honours, Castles, Manors, <f type="i">&amp;c.<f type="r">
unto another in fee simple, by delivery
of seisin, either by word or writing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="feminine(a)"><f type="i">Foeminine<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to the
Femal Sex.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="feneration(n)"><f type="i">Foeneration<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a putting out money to
use.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="feracity(n)"><f type="i">Feracity<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> fruitfulnesse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="feral(a)"><f type="i">Feral<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> dangerous or deadly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="feral sign(n)"><f type="i">Feral<f type="r"> Signs,</form> <xpln>are <f type="i">Leo<f type="r">, and the last
part of <f type="i">Scorpio<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="farcost(n)"><f type="i">Fercost<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="it" type="etymlang">(Ital.)</class> a kind of ship or
boat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="fere(n)"><f type="i">Fere<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="old word">(old word)</class> a companion.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="ferd-fare(n)"><f type="i">Ferdfare<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an acquitment of a man to go into
the wars.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Ferdinando(pn)"><f type="i">Ferdinando<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a proper name of men,
called by the Spaniards
<f type="i"><term lang="sp">Hernando</term><f type="r">, by the Italians <f type="i"><term lang="it">Ferando</term><f type="r">, by
the French <f type="i"><term lang="fr">Ferrant</term><f type="r">. Some think it derived <class lang="sx" type="etymlang">from
the Saxon words <f type="i"><term lang="sx">Fred rand</term>, i.<f type="r"> pure peace</class>. Others
think that <class lang="sp" type="etymlang">the Spaniards have for the sweeter sound drawn
it from <f type="i">Bertrand, i.<f type="r"> fair and pure</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="ferd-wite(n)"><f type="i">Ferdwit<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an acquitment of a murderer in the
army.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Feretrius(pn)"><f type="i">Feretrius</form>, <xpln>Jupiter<f type="r"> so called <f type="i">a ferendis
spoliis<f type="r">, i. from spoiles taken in war.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="feriation(n)"><f type="i">Feriation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a keeping holiday, a
ceasing from work, idlenesse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="ferm(n)" lexeme="farm(n)"><f type="i">Ferm<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Farm<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>a house, or land,

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Fermanagh(pn)"><f type="i">Fermanagh<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a County of <f type="i">Ireland<f type="r"> in

anciently called <f type="i">Erdini<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="ferret(n)"><f type="i">Ferret<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">from <f type="i">Forare<f type="r">, to pierce, or
<f type="i">Furari<f type="r">, to steal</class>;
a little beast <class lang="la" type="etymlang">called in Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Viverra</term><f type="r"></class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="ferry(n)"><f type="i">Ferry<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a passage over the water, <class lang="gk" type="etymlang">from the
Greek word <f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Phero</term><f type="r">, to carry</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="ferruginous(a)"><f type="i">Ferruginous<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> like rust of iron, of

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Feversham(pn)"><f type="i">Feversham<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a flourishing Town in
<f type="i">Kent<f type="r">, where King <f type="i">Althestane<f type="r"> assembled
the Nobles and learned men
of his Kingdom to make Laws, and where King
<f type="i">Stephen<f type="r"> founded
an Abby for the Monks of <f type="i">Clugny<f type="r">, in which he
himself, <f type="i">Maude<f type="r"> his wife, and <f type="i">Eustach<f type="r"> his
son, were entombed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="firmament(n)"><f type="i">Firmament<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(from the Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Firmus</term><f type="r">,
i. e. <f type="i">solid<f type="r">.)</class> the starry Heaven, it is turned
about the Chrystalline Heaven, being both of an uniform
motion, &amp; finish their course in 250000 years, which
motion appears not, but by the observation of sundry ages.
For 430 years before Christs time, the first star in
<f type="i">Aries<f type="r"> was in the vernal intersection, which
still keeps that name, though now removed almost 29
degrees, so that in more then two thousand years the fixed
stars have not travelled from West to East, so much as
one whole sign of the Zodiack.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Firmus(pn)"><f type="i">Firmus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Roman Emperour of that vast strength,
that bearing himself up from any place with his arms,
and bearing an Anvil upon his breast, he could endure
the smiths
</page>

<page sig="P3r">
beating upon it for a long time.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="first fruits(n)"><f type="i">First fruits<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the profits of every
spiritual living for one
year, in ancient time given to the Pope, afterwards to the
Prince.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="fiscal(a)"><f type="i">Fiscal<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to a fisque,
<f type="i">i. e.<f type="r"> a Treasury, or Exchequer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="fishing(n)" lexeme="splicing(n)"><f type="i">Fishing<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Splicing<f type="r">,</form> <xpln> <class type="register" subject="architecture">a Term used
in Masts, Cables, or in any Timber</class>, cut like wedges at one
end, and fastned together.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="fissure(n)"><f type="i">Fissure<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a cleft, or
division.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="fistulary(a)"><f type="i">Fistulary<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to a pipe, or
to a disease called Fistula, which is a kind of Ulcer

several great families of

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="galactite(n)"><f type="i">Galactite<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a kind of pretious stone, so

</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Galanthis(pn)"><f type="i">Galanthis<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the servant maid of

sought to hinder the birth of <f type="i">Hercules<f type="r">, was
turned into a Weasel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Galathea(pn)"><f type="i">Galathea<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Sea Nimph, the Daughter of
<f type="i">Nereus<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Doris<f type="r">, who being beloved of
<f type="i">Polypheme<f type="r">, and prefering <f type="i">Acis<f type="r"> before
him, <f type="i">Polypheme<f type="r"> killed his rival with a great
stone which he pluckt out of a rock: whereupon
<f type="i">Acis<f type="r"> was turned into a River of the same
name.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Galatia(pn)"><f type="i">Galatia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a region of <f type="i">Asia<f type="r"> the
Less, called also
<f type="i">Gallogrecia<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="galaxy(n)"><f type="i">Galaxy<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a broad white circle in the

reflected from a great
company of little Stars. It is called the milky
way.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="galbanum(n)"><f type="i">Galbanum<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kind of gum, issuing out of a

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="gale(n)"><f type="i">Gale<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>when the wind bloweth gently, so that
a ship may bear her top-sailes a trip, it is called a loom
gall; when it is much wind, a fresh or stiff gale.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="galosh(n)"><f type="i">Galege<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Galage<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(in French

weather, which hath been anciently in use among the
<f type="i">Gaules<f type="r"> from whence the word is derived.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Gallus(pn)"><f type="i">Gallus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a River in <f type="i">Phrygia<f type="r">, of

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="gauntlet, run the(n)">To run the <f type="i">Gantlope<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a punishment used

naked through the whole Regiment, and to receive a lash
from every souldier. It comes <class lang="du" type="etymlang">from <f type="i">Gant<f type="r">, a Town
in <f type="i">Flanders<f type="r">, where it was invented, and the Dutch
word <f type="i"><term lang="du">Lope</term><f type="r">, which signifies running</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Ganymede(pn)"><f type="i">Ganymed<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Tros<f type="r">, whom for
his excellent form, <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> fell in love with,
and causing him to be brought up to
Heaven upon an Eagles back,
made him his Cup-bearer instead of
<f type="i">Hebe<f type="r"> the
daughter of <f type="i">Juno<f type="r">. Also it is metaphorically taken
for an ingle or boy hired to commit Sodomy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="gavelkind(n)"><f type="i">Gavelkind<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="sx" type="etymlang">from the three Saxon words,
<f type="i"><term lang="sx">Gife, Eal, Cyn</term><f type="r">, i. e. given to all the kind</class>,

</xpln></wordentry>

word <f type="i">Gebal<f type="r"> a Mountain, and <f type="i">Tareck<f type="r"> the
son of <f type="i">Abdalla<f type="r">, who brought his Army over those

Metaphorically
taken for Hell.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Gelo(pn)"><f type="i">Gelo<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a young boy of <f type="i">Sicily<f type="r">, who
sitting upon the threshold of a School, and
making an out-cry after a
Wolf that had snatched his book out of his hand, the
master and Scholars making
a sudden tumult, were all killed by the fall of the
School-house.</xpln></wordentry>

nature, that the waters of
one make women fruitfull, the other barren.</xpln></wordentry>

<f type="i">Cappadocia<f type="r">, a Tribune under

Champion.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Georgians(pn)"><f type="i">Georgians<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a people inhabiting
<f type="i">Albania<f type="r">, now called <f type="i">Georgia<f type="r">, professing
themselves Christians, though differing in many points
from us, and honouring St. <f type="i">George<f type="r"> as their chief
Patron, also a Sect of Hereticks;
instituted at <f type="i">Delft<f type="r"> by <f type="i">David George<f type="r">,
whose Doctrine was, that both the Law and the Gospel were
unprofitable for salvation.</xpln></wordentry>

grew a Wallnut-tree, which as some have

Feast.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="gorbelly(n)"><f type="i">Gorbelly<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>one who is all panch or
belly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="gorcrow(n)"><f type="i">Gorcrow<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Raven.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Gordieus(pn)"><f type="i">Gordieus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Mountain of <f type="i">Armenia<f type="r">, where the Ark of
<f type="i">Noah<f type="r"> was said to rest.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Gordius(pn)"><f type="i">Gordius<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a King of <f type="i">Phrygia<f type="r">, who
being raised from the plough to the Throne, hung up the
furniture of his oxen in the Temple, as a memorial, which
being tied in a very intricate knot, and the
Monarchy of the World
being promised to him that could untie it,
<f type="i">Alexander<f type="r"> the Great after he had long tried in
vain, at length cut it in two with his sword, whence the
Gordian knot came to be a proverb, being taken for any
thing which is difficult to be expounded.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="gore(n)"><f type="i">Gore<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="heraldry">a term in Blazon</class>, and consists of two
Arch lines drawn from the sinister chief and bottom of the
Escutcheon, and meeting in a sharp angle in the
fesspoint.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="gorgeous(a)"><f type="i">Gorgious<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>gallant, sumptuous, some think
<class lang="gk" type="etymlang">from the Greek word <f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Gargairo</term><f type="r">, i. e. to
shine</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Gorgon(pn)"><f type="i">Gorgons<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the three daughters of <f type="i">Phorcys
Medusa, Sthenio<f type="r">, and <f type="i">Euriale<f type="r">, with
<f type="i">Medusa Perseus<f type="r"> fought, and cutting off her head,
turned it into a stone. Also particularly taken for the
head of <f type="i">Medusa<f type="r"> in Astrology.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Gorlois(pn)"><f type="i">Gorlois<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Prince of <f type="i">Cornwall<f type="r">,
whose wife <f type="i">Vther Pendragon<f type="r"> fell in love with, and
injoying her by the means of his Magical delusions, he
begat King <f type="i">Arthur<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="gormandize(v)"><f type="i">Gormandize<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> to play the
gourmand, <f type="i">i.<f type="r"> a
glutton or great devourer. Some derive it <class lang="la" type="etymlang">from the Latin
words <f type="i"><term lang="la">gulose mandere</term>, i.<f type="r"> to eat
greedily</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Gormoncester(pn)"><f type="i">Gormoncester<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town in
<f type="i">Huntingtonshire<f type="r">,
the same with <f type="i">Goodmanchester<f type="r">
above mentioned, it was called <f type="i">Gormoncester<f type="r">, from
<f type="i">Gormon<f type="r">, the Dane, unto whom, after an agreement
of peace, King <f type="i">Alfred<f type="r"> granted this Town with the
adjoyning Territories, it is thought to have been the same
Town with that which was called in old times
<f type="i">Durosiponte<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="gospel(n)"><f type="i">Gospel<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="sx" type="etymlang">a Saxon word, signifying good
saying, or Gods word</class>; it is commonly taken for one of the
four Evangelists in the New Testament.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="goshawk(n)"><f type="i">Gossehauke, <term lang="la">quasi</term> Grossehauke<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kind of
Hauke called in Greek <f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Asterias</term><f type="r">, because of its
spots, which are like little Stars.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="gossip(n)"><f type="i">Gossip<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>one that undertakes for a child in
Baptism, the word signifieth <class lang="sx" type="etymlang">in the Saxon tongue,
spiritually of kin</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="gossamer(n)"><f type="i">Gossomor<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Gossymear<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="sx" type="etymlang">(Saxon)</class> a
kind of thin Cobweb-like exhalation, which hovers abroad
in the air in hot weather.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Gothia(pn)"><f type="i">Gothia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Country of <f type="i">Europe<f type="r">,
bordering upon <f type="i">Denmark<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Norway<f type="r">, 
the people are called <f type="i">Gothi<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Gothes<f type="r">,
who in former times overrun the greatest part of
<f type="i">Europe<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="gowl(n)"><f type="i">Goule<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="old word">(old word)</class> Usury, <class lang="la" type="etymlang">from the Latin
<f type="i"><term lang="la">Gula</term><f type="r">, i. the throat</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="gourd(n)"><f type="i">Gourd<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kind of plant, somewhat like a
coucumber, also used by <f type="i">Chaucer<f type="r"> for a
bottel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="gout(n)"><f type="i">Gowtes<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a word used in
<f type="i">Sommersetshire<f type="r">, common sewes or sinks that run
under ground.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="gaure(v)"><f type="i">Gowreth<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="old word">(old word)</class> stareth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Gracchus Sempronius(pn)"><f type="i">Gracchus Sempronius<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a great Captain of the
Romans, who subdued the <f type="i">Celtiberians<f type="r">
a people of <f type="i">Spain<f type="r">, and repaired their chief City
<f type="i">Illurcis<f type="r">, calling it by his own name
<f type="i">Gracchuris<f type="r">: he had two sons by his wife
<f type="i">Cornelia, Caius<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Tiberius<f type="r">, who were
both slain in a popular sedition,
seeking to re-establish
the <f type="i">Agrarian<f type="r"> Laws.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Graces(pn)"><f type="i">Graces<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the three daughters of

and <f type="i">Thalia<f type="r">, the Goddesses of Elegance, and
handsome conversation.</xpln></wordentry>

signification well known.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="grand sergeanty(n)"><f type="i">Grand Sergeanty<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain kinde of
service, whereby the
Lords of <f type="i">Scrivelby<f type="r">, in <f type="i">Cheshire<f type="r"> held
their Land, which was to come well armed and mounted into
the Kings presence upon the day of his
Coronation, and by
publick Proclamation to offer himself to maintain the
Kings right by open Combat, against whosoever should dare
to oppose it, this Tenure belonged by Hereditary
succession to the Family of the <f type="i">Dimmocks<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Greenwich(pn)"><f type="i">Greenwich</form>, <xpln>(q. Green Creek)<f type="r"> a Town in
<f type="i">Kent<f type="r">, where in old times there lay at
<f type="i">Rode<f type="r"> a great Fleet of the <f type="i">Danes<f type="r"> under
<f type="i">Thurkill<f type="r"> their Captain, who put to a cruel death
<f type="i">Ealpheg<f type="r"> Arch-Bishop of <f type="i">Canterbury<f type="r">; this
place is also famous for a Royal Palace, built by
<f type="i">Humphry<f type="r"> Duke of <f type="i">Glocester<f type="r">, and by him
named <f type="i">Placence<f type="r">, he also built here upon a high
Hill, a pleasant Town famous in <f type="i">Spanish<f type="r">
fables.</xpln></wordentry>

<f type="i">Gregorian<f type="r">
account, a correction of the Calender
by Pope <f type="i">Gregorie<f type="r"> the 13<expan type="^th">th</expan>. making the
year to consist of 365 dayes, 5 hours, 49 minutes, and 12
seconds, whereas before
according to the <f type="i">Julian<f type="r"> account, it consisted of
365 dayes, and 6 hours.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Gresham College(pn)"><f type="i">Gresham Colledge<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a fair house in the Citie
of <f type="i">London<f type="r">, once the habitation of Sir <f type="i">Thomas
Gresham<f type="r">, who constituted it a Colledge, and endowed
it with Revenues for the maintaining of Professours of
Divinity, Law, Physick,
Astronomy, Geometry, and
Musick; the said Sir <f type="i">Thomas
Gresham<f type="r"> built also
that stately Fabrick, commonly
called the Royal Exchange.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="grave(n)"><f type="i">Greve<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Grave<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>a word of
authority among the Low Dutch, signifying as much as Lord,
or Governour.</xpln></wordentry>

Mansion in times past of the English <f type="i">Saxon<f type="r"> Kings,
who had 75 <f type="i">Hages, i. e.<f type="r"> houses wherein remained
175 men, here <f type="i">Elfrid<f type="r"> the son of King
<f type="i">Ethelred<f type="r"> was most barbarously betrayed by
<f type="i">Goodwin<f type="r">, Earle of
<f type="i">Kent<f type="r">, who contrary to his faithfull promise
delivered him into the hands of <f type="i">Harold<f type="r"> the
<f type="i">Dane<f type="r">, and by a cruel decimation slew almost all
his men that came with him out of
<f type="i">Normandy<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<f type="i">Rome<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="halcyon(n)"><f type="i">Halcyon<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a bird, called a King-fisher, which
builds its Nest, and breeds upon the Sea-shore, about
the winter solstice,
for the space of fourteen dayes, wherein the weather
useth to be very calm, whence by Metaphor peaceable and
quiet times,
</page>

<page sig="R3v">
are called Halcyon dayes, the Poets feign that
<f type="i">Halcyon<f type="r"> the wife of <f type="i">C&aelig;yx<f type="r">, was turned
into this bird. see <xref><f type="i">Alcyon<f type="r">.</xref>
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Haledon(pn)"><f type="i">Haledon<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a place in
<f type="i">Northumberland<f type="r">, where <f type="i">Oswald<f type="r"> King of
that County, in a great pitcht feild against the Brittish
King <f type="i">Cedwall<f type="r">, having erected a cross unto
<f type="i">Christ<f type="r">, obtained the victory, and afterwards
became a devout Christian.
This place was in old times called
<f type="i">Heavenfeild<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

hair, a Town in <f type="i">Yorkshire<f type="r">, so called from a
Maides head, that had been cut off by a Priest of that
place, which being hung upon
a yew-tree as a holy matter, was had in great veneration
by the people, who gathering of the sprigs of the tree,
took it for her hair.</xpln></wordentry>

first invention of Musical Harmony.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Harmonides(pn)"><f type="i">Harmonides<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a <f type="i">Trojan<f type="r"> whom
<f type="i">Minerva<f type="r"> inspired
with all kind of manufacture.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Harpalice(pn)"><f type="i">Harpalice<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of

that her father was taken prisoner by the <f type="i">Getans<f type="r">,

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Harpe(pn)"><f type="i">Harpe<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the name of the Fauchion

<f type="i">Serapis<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Isis<f type="r">, made with one hand
upon his mouth, and called by the <f type="i">Aegyptians<f type="r">, the

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="harpy(n)"><f type="i">Harpyes<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the three daughters of
<f type="i">Pontus<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Terra, Aello, Cel&aelig;no<f type="r">, and
<f type="i">Ocypete<f type="r">, they were part women, and part birds,
having claws like vultures. <f type="i">Homer<f type="r"> saith, that
upon <f type="i">Cel&aelig;no<f type="r">, whom he calls <f type="i">Podarges,
Zephyrus<f type="r"> begat <f type="i">Balius<f type="r">, and <f type="i">Xanthus<f type="r">,
the horses of <f type="i">Achilles<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="hart(n)"><f type="i">Hart<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="law">in the Forrest Laws</class>, is a Stag of 5
years old, if having been hunted by the King or Queen, he
escape alive, he is called
a Hart royal.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Hart Hall(pn)"><f type="i">Hart-hall<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a place for Students in the
University of <f type="i">Oxford<f type="r">, built by <f type="i">Water
Stapleton<f type="r"> Bishop of <f type="i">Exceter<f type="r">, together with
<f type="i">Exceter<f type="r"> Colledge, in the time of King
<f type="i">Edward<f type="r"> the second, who in imitation of him, built
<f type="i">Oriall<f type="r"> Colledge and St. <f type="i">Mary<f type="r">

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="hatch of a ship(n)"><f type="i">Hatches<f type="r"> of a ship</form>, <xpln>are trap-doors to let

scutles.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Havelock(pn)"><f type="i">Havelock<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain Danish foundling of the

<f type="i">Grime<f type="r"> a Merchant, and from a skullen in the Kings
kitchin, was for his valour and conduct in Military
affairs, promoted to the marriage
of the Kings daughter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Havering(pn)"><f type="i">Havering<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town in <f type="i">Essex<f type="r">, an

so called from the fabulous conceit of a ring delivered by
a Pilgrim, as sent from St. <f type="i">John Baptist<f type="r">, to King
<f type="i">Edward<f type="r"> the Confessour.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Helena(pn)"><f type="i">Helena<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">
and <f type="i">L&aelig;da<f type="r">, she was married to <f type="i">Menelaus<f type="r">,
and brought forth <f type="i">Hermione<f type="r">, afterwards being
stole away by <f type="i">Paris<f type="r">, and being demanded of
<f type="i">Priamus<f type="r"> by the Greeks, the Trojans refused to
send her back, which was the occasion of a very great war,
and of the destruction of <f type="i">Troy<f type="r">. The word
signifieth <class lang="gk" type="etymlang">in Greek pittiful</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="heliacal(a)"><f type="i">Heliacal<f type="r"></form> <xpln>rising of a Star, is when a Star
which was at first hid by the light of the Sun, afterwards
appears; <class lang="gk" type="etymlang">from the Greek word <f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Helios</term><f type="r">, i. the
Sun</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Heliades(pn)"><f type="i">Heliades<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughters of the Sun, and
sisters of <f type="i">Ph&aelig;ton<f type="r">, who wept themselves
into Poplar-trees for the
death of their brother, and their teares became Amber;
their names were <f type="i">Pha&aelig;thusa, Lampelusa<f type="r">, and
<f type="i">Lampetia<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Heliconian(a)"><f type="i">Heliconian<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>belonging to <f type="i">Helicon<f type="r">,

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Helle(pn)"><f type="i">Helle<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of <f type="i">Athamas<f type="r">
King of <f type="i">Thebes<f type="r">, she with her brother
<f type="i">Phryxus<f type="r">, crossing over the <f type="i">Pontick<f type="r"> Sea
upon a golden Ram, being
frighted with the danger, fell into the sea, from which
accident, that sea was ever after called
Hellespont.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="hellebore(n)"><f type="i">Hellebore<f type="r"></form>. <xpln>the name of a certain

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Helvetia(pn)"><f type="i">Helvetia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Country invironed by the
<f type="i">Alps<f type="r"> and the Hill <f type="i">Jura<f type="r">, the Rivers
<f type="i">Rhene<f type="r">, and <f type="i">Rhone<f type="r">, it is now called
<f type="i">Swizzerland<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="hemerology(n)"><f type="i">Hemerology<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a Calender, or Book
wherein are registred the passages of every day.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="hemicrany(n)"><f type="i">Hemicranie<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a disease in the head
called the Meagrim.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="hemicycle(n)"><f type="i">Hemicycle<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a half circle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Hemingstone(pn)"><f type="i">Hemingstone<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town in <f type="i">Suffolk<f type="r">,
which one <f type="i">Baldwin le Pettour<f type="r"> held of the King,
<f type="i">per Saltum, sufflatum, &amp; Bumbulum seu Pettum<f type="r">, i. e. by this
Tenure, that on every Christmasse Day before the King, he
should dance, puff up his cheekes, and fart.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="hemisphere(n)"><f type="i">Hemisphere<f type="r"></form> <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> half the compass of the
heavens, or so much as is visible
above the Horison.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="hemlock(n)"><f type="i">Hemlock<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain plant, called in Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Cicuta</term><f type="r">, whose juice being poison used to be given
to capital offenders.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Henares(pn)"><f type="i">Henares<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a River in <f type="i">Spain<f type="r">, near to
which stands a Town called <f type="i">Alcala di
Henares<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="henbane(n)"><f type="i">Henbane<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>in Greek <f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Hyoscyamus</term><f type="r">, an
herb which is counted rank poison.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="henchman(n)"><f type="i">Henchman<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Heinsman<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="gr" type="etymlang">a German
word</class>, signifying a domestick servant. It is taken among us
for a page of honour.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="hend(a)"><f type="i">Hend<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="old word">(old word)</class> neat, fine, gentle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Hengston Hill(pn)"><f type="i">Hengston hill<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a hill in <f type="i">Cornwall<f type="r">,
where the Brittish <f type="i">Danmonii<f type="r"> calling the Danes to
assist them to drive the English out of
<f type="i">Devonshire<f type="r">, were by King <f type="i">Egbert<f type="r"> totally
defeated and ruined.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="hangwite(n)"><f type="i">Hengwit<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>see <xref><f type="i">Hankwit<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Hengest(pn)"><f type="i">Hengest<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the name of him who led the first
English men into this Isle, <class type="etymlang" lang="sx">the word signifies in the
Saxon Horseman</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Heniochus(pn)"><f type="i">Heniochus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>vide <xref><f type="i">Auriga<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Henry(pn)"><f type="i">Henry<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the name of seven Emperours of
<f type="i">Germany<f type="r">, eight Kings of <f type="i">England<f type="r">, four
Kings of <f type="i">France<f type="r">, four Kings of <f type="i">Castile<f type="r">:
the word comes from the German <f type="i"><term lang="gr">Einric</term>, i.<f type="r"> rich
and powerful, or <f type="i"><term lang="gr">Herric</term>, i.<f type="r"> rich Lord, or else is
contracted from <f type="i">Honoricus<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Hephaestian mountains(pn)"><f type="i">Heph&aelig;stian<f type="r"> mountains</form>, <xpln>certain burning

</xpln></wordentry>

in <f type="i">England<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

the liberty that a man hath to feed his cattel in another
mans ground, or in the Forrest.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="herbalist(n)" lexeme="herbary(n)"><f type="i">Herbalist<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Herbary<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> one

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Hercinia(pn)"><f type="i">Hercinia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a great Wood in <f type="i">Germany<f type="r">,
