breadth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Herculean(a)"><f type="i">Herculean<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>belonging to <f type="i">Hercules<f type="r">,
the cheif of which name was <f type="i">Hercules<f type="r"> the son of
<f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Alcmena<f type="r">, he being hated by
<f type="i">Juno<f type="r"> because he was born of a Concubine, was by her
ingaged in 12 very dangerous enterprises, which are called
<f type="i">Hercules<f type="r"> his 12 labours, all which he overcame to
his great renown; whence every great atcheivment came to
be called a <f type="i">Herculean labour<f type="r">. He is said to have built two pillars on Mount
<f type="i">Calpe<f type="r">, and Mount <f type="i">Avila<f type="r">, as the utmost
bounds of the Western World, with the inscription of
<f type="i">Nil ultra<f type="r">, and at this day those places are
called <f type="i">Hercules<f type="r"> pillars. This name
<f type="i">Hercules<f type="r"> signifieth in Greek, Glory or Illumination
of the Air.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="here de Caesar(n)"><f type="i">Here de C&aelig;sar<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain Epoch or
Account, from which the
<f type="i">Saracens<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Arabians<f type="r">
used to compute their number of yeares, as we do from the
year of our Lord. It was also used in <f type="i">Spain<f type="r"> for a
great while, the word signifieth as much as the Monarcy of
<f type="i">C&aelig;sar<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="hereditary(a)"><f type="i">Hereditary<f type="r">, or <f type="i">H&aelig;reditary<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class>
coming by
Inheritance.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="hereditament(n)"><f type="i">Hereditaments<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>signifie <class type="register" subject="law">in Common Law</class>, all
such things as descend to a man and his heirs by way of
Inheritance, and fall not within the compasse of an
Executor as Chattels do.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Hereford(pn)"><f type="i">Hereford<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the cheif City of
<f type="i">Herefordshire<f type="r">,
anciently called <f type="i">Tresawith<f type="r">, from the Beech-trees
growing thereabout. It was built as some say by King
<f type="i">Edward<f type="r"> the Elder, in that tract of the Country
called of old <f type="i">Ereinuc<f type="r"> or <f type="i">Archenfeild<f type="r">,
out of the ruines of the ancient <f type="i">Ariconium<f type="r">; the
fame of this City was augmented by the
Martyrdom of
<f type="i">Ethelbert<f type="r"> King of <f type="i">East England<f type="r">, who
going to wooe the daughter of <f type="i">Offa<f type="r"> King of the
<f type="i">Mercians<f type="r">, was here forelaid and murthered by the
procurement of <f type="i">Quendred Offa's<f type="r"> wife.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="hermitage(n)"><f type="i">Heremitage<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Ermitage<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class>
a solitary place, a dwelling for <f type="i">Hermites, i.<f type="r">
persons that devote themselves to a religious
solitude.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="heresy(n)"><f type="i">Heresie<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>see <xref><f type="i">H&aelig;resie<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="heresiarch(n)"><f type="i">Heresiarch<f type="r">, or <f type="i">H&aelig;resiarch<f type="r">,</form>
<xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> the principall Author of any Heresie or Sect.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="heretoga(n)"><f type="i">Heretog<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Hertogh<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>a Leader of
an Army, or a Duke, <class lang="sx" type="etymlang">from the Saxon words <f type="i"><term lang="sx">Here</term><f type="r"> an
Army, and <f type="i"><term lang="sx">Toga</term><f type="r">, to draw out</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="herility(n)"><f type="i">Herility<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> Masterly Authority.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="heriot(n)"><f type="i">Heriot<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Hariot<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>hath formerly
been used to signifie a tribute given by a
Tenant to the Lord of the
Mannour for his better preparation toward war;
<class lang="sx" type="etymlang"><f type="i">Here<f type="r"> in the Saxon tongue</class> signifying an Army; but
now it is taken for the best chattel that a Tenant hath at
the hour of his death, which is due unto the Lord by
custom.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Herlaxton(pn)"><f type="i">Herlaxton<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town in <f type="i">Lincolnshire<f type="r">,
near which was ploughed up a brazen vessel, wherein a
Golden Helmet beset with pretious
Stones (which was given as a present
to <f type="i">Catherine<f type="r"> of <f type="i">Spain<f type="r">, wife to King
<f type="i">Henry<f type="r"> the eighth) was found.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Herman(pn)"><f type="i">Herman<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>see <xref><f type="i">Harman<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="hermaphrodite(n)"><f type="i">Hermaphrodite<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a word
compounded of
<f type="i">Hermes<f type="r">, i. <f type="i">Mercury<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Aphrodite<f type="r">, i. <f type="i">Venus<f type="r">, and signifieth one of both Sexes, Man and
Woman. See the story of <f type="i">Hermaphroditus<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Salmacis<f type="r">, elegantly described in the fourth Book
of <f type="i">Ovids Metamorphosis<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="hermetical(a)"><f type="i">Hermetical<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> belonging to
<f type="i">Mercury<f type="r"> the messenger of the gods, who is called
in Greek <f type="i">Hermes<f type="r">, or to <f type="i">Hermes
Trismegistus<f type="r">, the great <f type="i">Aegyptian<f type="r"> Philosopher.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Hermione(pn)"><f type="i">Hermione<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of
<f type="i">Menelaus<f type="r">, she was betrothed by her father, after
the end of the <f type="i">Trojan<f type="r"> war, to <f type="i">Pyrrhus<f type="r">
the son of <f type="i">Achilles<f type="r">, which <f type="i">Orestes<f type="r"> (to
whom she had been before espoused by her Grandfather
<f type="i">Tyndarus<f type="r">) taking ill, he slew
<f type="i">Pirrhus<f type="r"> in the
Temple of <f type="i">Apollo<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="hermitage(n)" lexeme="hermit(n)"><f type="i">Hermitage, Hermite<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>see <xref><f type="i">Heremitage<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Hermotimus(pn)"><f type="i">Hermotimus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain man of
<f type="i">Clazomena<f type="r">,
whose Soul used to leave his body, and wander up and down,
bringing him news of things that were done a great way
off, his body lying in the mean while as it were asleep,
but at length his enemies finding
his body, burnt it, so that his Soul had no habitation
left to return to.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="hernious(a)"><f type="i">Hernious<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> bursten bellied.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Herod(pn)"><f type="i">Herod<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>sirnamed <f type="i">Antipater<f type="r">, a King
of the Jews, created by the Roman Senate, he destroyed the
Temple, built by <f type="i">Zorobabel<f type="r">,
and erected another more magnificient
in its place, he put his wife <f type="i">Mariamne<f type="r">
to death, and his two sons, <f type="i">Aristobulus<f type="r">
and <f type="i">Alexander<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="heroic(a)" lexeme="heroical(a)"><f type="i">Heroick<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Heroical<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class>
noble, lofty, becoming a <f type="i">Heroe<f type="r">, whence
<f type="i">Heroick<f type="r"> Poem, is a Poem treating of
<f type="i">Heroic<f type="r"> actions, or persons.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="heroine(n)"><f type="i">Heroine<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a woman of a noble spirit, and
excellent virtues.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="heron(n)"><f type="i">A Heron<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kinde of bird, called in
Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Ardea, ab ardendo</term><f type="r">, because its dung burns whatsoever it
touches.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Herophila(pn)"><f type="i">Herophila<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the name of the <f type="i">Erythr&aelig;an
Sibil<f type="r">, who having asked <f type="i">Tarquin<f type="r"> a very great
price for her three books of Prophesies,
and being refused it, she burnt 2. and afterwards received
as much for that one that was left, as she demanded for
all the three.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Herostratus(pn)"><f type="i">Herostratus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>one that to purchace
himself fame, burnt the Temple of <f type="i">Diana<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Hersilia(pn)"><f type="i">Hersilia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the wife of <f type="i">Romulus<f type="r">, who
after her death was worshipp'd by the name of
<f type="i">Hora<f type="r">, or the goddesse of youth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Hertford(pn)"><f type="i">Hertford</form>, <xpln>i. e.<f type="r"> the Ford of Harts, the
chief Town of <f type="i">Hertford-shire<f type="r">, having a Castle
upon the River <f type="i">Lea<f type="r">, built as some say, by King
<f type="i">Edward<f type="r"> the Elder, and augmented
by <f type="i">Gislebert de Clare<f type="r">, who was Earle of this Town
in King <f type="i">Henry<f type="r"> the seconds
dayes, <f type="i">Bede<f type="r"> treating of the Synode that was held
here in the year 670. calleth
it <f type="i">Herudford<f type="r">, i. e. <f type="i">Redford<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Herthus(pn)"><f type="i">Herthus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a goddesse worshipt by the
ancient <f type="i">Saxons<f type="r">,
in the same nature as <f type="i">Tellus<f type="r"> by the
<f type="i">Latins<f type="r">, some think the word earth to be thence
derived.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Hesione(pn)"><f type="i">Hesione<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of <f type="i">Laomedon<f type="r">,
King of <f type="i">Troy<f type="r">, whom <f type="i">Hercules<f type="r">, having
freed her from a great Whale, gave in marriage to his
friend <f type="i">Telamon<f type="r">, after he had ransack't
<f type="i">Troy<f type="r">, because her father <f type="i">Laomedon<f type="r">
performed not his
promise to him.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Hesperus(pn)"><f type="i">Hesperus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Japetus<f type="r">, and
brother of <f type="i">Atlas<f type="r">, who flying from his Countrey,
went and inhabited in <f type="i">Italy<f type="r">, whence that Countrey
came to be called <f type="i">Hesperia<f type="r">,
he had three daughters, <f type="i">Aegle, Arethusa<f type="r">, and
<f type="i">Hesperethusa<f type="r">, called the <f type="i">Hesperides<f type="r">, who
lived in the <f type="i">Hesperian<f type="r"> Garden, whose Trees bare
golden Apples, that were kept by a watchfull Dragon, whom
<f type="i">Hercules<f type="r"> slew; it is also faigned of
<f type="i">Hesperus<f type="r">, that after his death he was changed
into the Evening Star.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="hest(n)"><f type="i">Hests<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="old word">(old word)</class> commands, or
decrees.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="hete(n)"><f type="i">Hete<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="old word">(old word)</class> a vow, offer, or

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="hide of land(n)"><f type="i">Hide<f type="r"> of Land</form>, <xpln><class lang="du" type="etymlang">from the Dutch word <f type="i"><term lang="du">Heyd</term>,
i. e.<f type="r"> a wide field, also Heath and Broom</class>, signifieth
<class type="register" subject="law">in Law</class>, such a quantity of Land as may be plough'd with
one plough in a year, which according to some mens
accounts is about a hundred Acres, eight Hides, being a
Knights fee.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Hippolytus(pn)"><f type="i">Hippolytus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Theseus<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Hippolyte<f type="r">, he
addicted himself wholly to hunting,
but being accused of adultery by <f type="i">Phoedra<f type="r"> his
mother in Law, because he had denied her, when she
sollicited him to lye with her, he fled away and was
torn in pieces by
the wilde horses that drew his
</page>

<page sig="S3r">
Chariot, afterwards his limbs being gathered up, and he
restored to life by <f type="i">Aesculapius<f type="r">, at the request
of <f type="i">Diana<f type="r">, he went into <f type="i">Italy<f type="r"> and was
called <f type="i">Virbius<f type="r">, and built a Citie, which from
his wives name was called <f type="i">Ancia<f type="r">.

<f type="i">Atalanta<f type="r">, the daughter of <f type="i">Sich&aelig;neus<f type="r">, by

could not abstain from lying with his wife in the Temple
of <f type="i">Cybele<f type="r">, he was turned into a Lion, and she

night, after which he is accounted one of the
family.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="hogo(n)"><f type="i">Hogoo<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a word vulgarly used for a high-

<f type="i"><term lang="fr">Hautgoust</term><f type="r"></class>.</xpln></wordentry>

part of a Tun.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="hoggaster(n)"><f type="i">A Hogsteer<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a wilde Boar of three years

<f type="i">Holland<f type="r"> deriveth his Title, the other two are

wood</class>, it is a Countrey of Germany

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Homer(pn)"><f type="i">Homer<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous Greek Poet, called at first
<f type="i">Melesigenes<f type="r">, because he was born by the River
<f type="i">Melete<f type="r">, he writ a Poem concerning the wars of
<f type="i">Troy<f type="r">, which was called <f type="i">Ilias<f type="r">, and
another of the Travels of <f type="i">Vlisses<f type="r">,
called <f type="i">Odysseis<f type="r">.
He is called by some the <f type="i">Moeonian<f type="r">
Prophet.</xpln></wordentry>

violently, and without Licence; it cometh <class lang="du" type="etymlang">from the Dutch

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Horatius Cocles(pn)"><f type="i">Horatius Cocles<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous Roman, who
fighting against <f type="i">Porsenna<f type="r">,
King of the <f type="i">Hetrurians<f type="r">,
defended a bridge himself against
all the enemies forces, untill the bridge was cut down,
and after that he leapt into <f type="i">Tyber<f type="r">, and swomme to
his own people, also <f type="i">Horatius Flaccus<f type="r">, a famous
<f type="i">Lyrick<f type="r"> Poet of <f type="i">Venusium<f type="r">, who was in high
favour with <f type="i">Augustus<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Mec&aelig;nas<f type="r">:
whence <f type="i">Horatio<f type="r"> is a proper name frequent now
adayes, derived as some think <class lang="gk" type="etymlang">from the Greek
<term lang="gk">&#x1F41;&#x03C1;&#x03B1;&#x03C4;&#x1F78;&#x03C2;</term>, <f type="i">i. e.<f type="r"> of good
eye-sight</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="hord(n)"><f type="i">Hord<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(Lat.)</class> a Cow great with Calf.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="horizontal(a)"><f type="i">Horizontal<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> belonging to the

upper Hemisphear, or so much of the Heavens as we can see round about us from the lower Hemisphear, or so much of

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="hornet(n)"><f type="i">A Hornet<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kinde of insect, called in

other creatures, and is ingendred of the carcases of dead

committed felony by the highway, by describing the party,
and giving notice to several Constables from one Town to
another.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Hugh(pn)"><f type="i">Hugh<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the proper name of a man,
signifying comfort.
Others derive it <class lang="du" type="etymlang">from the Dutch word <f type="i"><term lang="du">Hougen</term><f type="r">, to
cut</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Huguenots(pn)"><f type="i">Huguenots<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">a name which used to be given in
derision to those of the reformed Religion in
<f type="i">France<f type="r">, from a gate in <f type="i">Tours<f type="r"> called
<f type="i">Hugon<f type="r"></class>. Others derive it from these words <class lang="la" type="etymlang"><f type="i"><term lang="la">Huc
nos venimus</term><f type="r">, Hither we are come</class>, wherewith they begin
their protestation.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Hull(pn)"><f type="i">Hull<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town in <f type="i">Yorkshire<f type="r">, situate
upon the River <f type="i">Hull<f type="r">, anciently called
<f type="i">Kingston<f type="r"> (q. Kings Town) upon <f type="i">Hull<f type="r">. It
being built by King <f type="i">Edward<f type="r"> the first, and beautified with fair
buildings by <f type="i">Mich&aelig;l de la Pool<f type="r"> Earle of
<f type="i">Suffolk<f type="r">. This Town is very well accomodated for
Ships and Merchandize.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="hull(n)"><f type="i">Hull<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="navigation">in Navigation</class>, is taken for the body
of a ship without masts, sailes, or yards.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Humiliates(pn)"><f type="i">Humiliates<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain religious Order of

-peace</term></class>.</xpln></wordentry>

any controversie of land, dwelling within the Hundred
where the land lieth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="hundred-law(n)"><f type="i">Hundrelagh<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the Hundred Court, from which

<page sig="S4v">
time of the Emperour <f type="i">Valentinian<f type="r"> overrun all

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Huntington(pn)"><f type="i">Huntington<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the chief Town of
<f type="i">Huntintonshire<f type="r">,
in the publick seale called <f type="i">Huntersdune,
i.<f type="r"> the hill of Hunters, alluding to which name
<f type="i">Leland<f type="r"> calls it in Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Venantodunum</term><f type="r">:
near unto the bridge is to be seen yet the plot of a
Castle built by K. <f type="i">Edward<f type="r"> the Elder, in the year
917, and by K. <f type="i">Henry<f type="r"> the second demolished, to
put an end to the contention which the <f type="i">Scottish<f type="r">
men and the St. <f type="i">Lizes<f type="r"> had so often had about
it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Hyacynthus(pn)"><f type="i">Hyacynthus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a youth who being
beloved of
<f type="i">Apollo<f type="r">, and playing with him at a play called
Discus, <f type="i">Zephyrus<f type="r"> who was slighted by
<f type="i">Hyacinthus<f type="r">, blew the Discus thrown by
<f type="i">Apollo<f type="r">, full upon <f type="i">Hyacinthus<f type="r"> his head,
and killed him, which mischance <f type="i">Apollo<f type="r"> lamenting,
turned him into a flower called a Jacinth, vulgarly
Crowtoes. There is also a pretious stone called a Hyacinth
or Jacinth, being of a waterish colour.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Hyades(pn)"><f type="i">Hyades<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the seven daughters of

called <f type="i">Ambrosia,

<f type="i">Tyche<f type="r">, who lamenting their brother <f type="i">Hyas<f type="r">
devoured by a Lion, were taken up into Heaven by
<f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> and changed into Stars.</xpln></wordentry>

<f type="i">Caria<f type="r">, but when <f type="i">Labienus<f type="r">

<f type="i">Hercules<f type="r"> going on

River <f type="i">Ascanius<f type="r">, and the Nimphs of the River being
in love with him, pulled him in, so that <f type="i">Hercules<f type="r">
long expected him, and hearing no news of him, left the
Argonauts and wandred up and down the Wood for a long time
in quest of him.</xpln></wordentry>

who desiring of <f type="i">Jupiter, Mercury<f type="r">, and
<f type="i">Neptune<f type="r">, whom he had intertained at his house,

expired, was borne <f type="i">Orion<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<f type="i">Tyre<f type="r">, he was a great opposer

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Janthe(pn)"><f type="i">Janthe<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain Virgin, the daughter of
<f type="i">Telessa<f type="r">, who the first day of her
marriage was transformed
into a man.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Janus(pn)"><f type="i">Janus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the name of an ancient King of
<f type="i">Italy<f type="r">, who intertained <f type="i">Saturn<f type="r"> (when he
was banish't out of <f type="i">Creet<f type="r">, by his son
<f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">) and of
him learn't husbandry, and the use of the Vine, he built a
Citie called <f type="i">Janiculum<f type="r">, from which all
<f type="i">Italy<f type="r"> was also called <f type="i">Janicula<f type="r">, he is
pictured with two faces, and from him the first moneth of
the year is called <f type="i">January<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Iapetus(pn)"><f type="i">Iapetus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Titan<f type="r"> and

and <f type="i">Epimetheus<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Japygia(pn)"><f type="i">Japygia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Countrey upon the Borders of

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="jar of oil(n)"><f type="i">Jarre<f type="r"> of Oile</form>, <xpln>an earthen pitcher,

instituted by <f type="i">Don Garcia<f type="r">, King of
<f type="i">Navarre<f type="r">, who riding one day on hunting, and
entring into a Cave, he saw an Altar with the image of the
Virgin <f type="i">Marie<f type="r">, and a Pitcher of Lillies, at which
sight being moved with devotion,
he founded this order.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Jason(pn)"><f type="i">Iason<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Aeson<f type="r">, King of

<f type="i">Pelias<f type="r"> to <f type="i">Colchos<f type="r">, to fetch the Golden

of <f type="i">Medea<f type="r">, who was in love with him, he brought
her away with him, and married her, but afterwards falling
in love with <f type="i">Creusa<f type="r">, the daughter of
<f type="i">Creon<f type="r">, he left <f type="i">Medea<f type="r">,
who in anger burnt <f type="i">Creusa<f type="r">, and her Palace
together.</xpln></wordentry>

<f type="i"><term lang="fr">Iaulne</term>, i. e.<f type="r"> yellow</class>, because it maketh the skin

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Idas(pn)"><f type="i">Idas<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of Neptune, he seeing
<f type="i">Marpesia<f type="r">, the daughter of <f type="i">Mars<f type="r">, dancing
in a wood, which was sacred to <f type="i">Diana<f type="r">, carried her
away by force, his father <f type="i">Neptune<f type="r">
having given him very swift horses, whereat <f type="i">Mars<f type="r">
was so inraged that he threw himself into the River <f type="i">Lycorma<f type="r">,
but <f type="i">Apollo<f type="r"> meeting <f type="i">Idas<f type="r">, and fighting
with him for <f type="i">Marpesia, Iupiter<f type="r"> sent
<f type="i">Mercury<f type="r"> to part them, and <f type="i">Marpesia<f type="r"> being
left to her own freedom, which of them she would choose
made choice of <f type="i">Idas<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

every moneth, as in March,
May, July, and October, from the fifteenth to the eight,
being reckoned backward in other moneths from the
thirteenth to the sixth, it comes <class lang="la" type="etymlang">from the old Latin word
<f type="i"><term lang="la">Iduo</term><f type="r">, to divide</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="idiotical(a)"><f type="i">Idiotical<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> private, also

<f type="i">i. e.<f type="r"> one born of so weak an understanding, that
the King by his prerogative, hath the government and

substance, and to that purpose, a Writ <f type="i">de Idiota
Inquirendo<f type="r"> is to be directed to the Sheriff, to

<f type="i">Idiotisme<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Idomeneus(pn)"><f type="i">Idomeneus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Deucalion<f type="r">

and arriving in the Countrey of <f type="i">Calabria<f type="r">, he
built the Citie of <f type="i">Salentinum<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<f type="i">Ignatius Loyola<f type="r">, they had to the three vows of
Chastity, Poverty, and Obedience,
the vow of Mission annexed, which bound them to go
whithersoever the Roman Bishop should send them for the
propagation of the
Faith, and to execute whatsoever he should command

to wander out of their way. It is metaphorically taken for

men of shallow understandings are apt to be
seduced.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="ignoramus(n)"><f type="i">Ignoramus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>is a word used by the grand
Inquest empanelled in the inquisition of causes criminal
and publick, when they mislike their evidence as
defective, or too weak to make good the presentment, which
word being written upon the Bill, all farther inquiry upon
that party is stopped. It is also taken substantively for
a foolish and ignorant person.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="ignoscible(a)"><class type="unknown">&dagger;</class> <f type="i">Ignoscible<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> fit to be
pardoned or forgiven.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="J N S(pr)"><f type="i">J H S<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain character whereby hath
anciently been expressed <f type="i">Jesus<f type="r">, the proper name
of our Saviour, the middle letter being taken for a Greek
E, but more likely the three initial letters of these
words <f type="i"><term lang="la">Jesus Hominum Salvator</term><f type="r">, i. Jesus the
Saviour of man, have been commonly
used for brevities sake.</xpln></wordentry>

</wordgroup1>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Ikenild Street(pn)"><f type="i">Ikenild street<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>one of the 4 famous ways,
that the Romans anciently made in
<f type="i">England<f type="r">: It
taketh its name from the <f type="i">Iceni<f type="r">, (so the people
inhabiting <f type="i">Norfolk, Suffolk<f type="r">, and
<f type="i">Cambridgeshire<f type="r">, are called) the other three wayes
were termed <f type="i">Foss, Erminstreet<f type="r">, and
<f type="i">Watlingstreet<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="imp(v)"><f type="i">Impe<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="hawking and hunting">a term in Falconry</class>, signifieth to
insert a feather into the wing of a Hawk, instead of one
which was broken. It comes <class lang="sx" type="etymlang">from the Saxon word
<f type="i"><term lang="sx">imp</term><f type="r"> or <f type="i"><term lang="sx">himp</term>, i.<f type="r"> to graff or inoculate</class>,
and is metaphorically taken for to fill up any vacancies.
<class type="register" subject="agriculture">It is taken also for a kind of graffing used by
Gardeners</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

hinder; also to accuse one
as guilty of the same crime whereof he which impeacheth is

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="inborrow(n)" lexeme="outborrow(n)"><f type="i">Inborow<f type="r">, and <f type="i">Outborow<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>in ancient
times, was the office of him that was to allow free
liberty of Ingress and Egress to those that travelled
between the two Realmes of <f type="i">England<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Scotland<f type="r">. This office belonged
in King <f type="i">Henry<f type="r"> the thirds time, to

Damask Rose.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="incensory(n)"><f type="i">Incensory<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> a <f type="i">censing-pan<f type="r">,
or <f type="i">Church-vessel<f type="r">, wherein they use to burn

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="incentor(n)"><f type="i">Incentor<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> the same as
<f type="i">Incendiary<f type="r">, also Incentor, Accentor, and
Succentor, are three sorts of Singers in parts.</xpln></wordentry>

businesse: whence Inceptour,
he that hath newly taken his degree
in the University.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="incestuous(a)"><f type="i">Incestuous<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> unchast, committing

but it is commonly taken for a defiling one that is near

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="incident(n)"><f type="i">Incident<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> hapning to, or falling out
of necessity: It is also substantively taken in Common
Law, for a thing necessarily
depending upon another, as more principal; as a
Court-Baron is so incident
to a Manor that it cannot be separated.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="incineration(n)"><f type="i">Incineration<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a reducing to ashes or

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="incubus(n)"><f type="i">Incubus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a certain disease called
the night-mare, which is caused by the ascending of raw
humours up into the brain, and obstructing the animal
spirits; it oppresseth people in their sleep, and causeth
them to imagin that some great weight is lying upon them.
There is also mention made in some Stories of certain
spirits, that having taken upon them
humane shapes, have mixed
in carnal copulation
with mortal persons, the male spirit is called
<f type="i">Incubus<f type="r">, the female <f type="i">Succubus<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="inculcation(n)"><f type="i">Inculcation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> an often repeating and
insisting upon the same thing, that it may the more deeply
be imprinted in ones mind.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="inculpable(a)"><f type="i">Inculpable<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> unreproveable, not to be
blamed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="incumbent(n)"><f type="i">Incumbent<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> lying or leaning upon,
also it is substantively taken for him that is preferred
to any spiritual living, and is in possession of it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Indacus(pn)"><f type="i">Indacus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a servant to the Emperour

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="inde(n)"><f type="i">Inde<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> a certain Mineral

paint or die of a blew colour, called also Indico, because
it is brought out of <f type="i">India<f type="r">. It is of two sorts,
<f type="i">English<f type="r"> Inde, and Inde <f type="i">Baunias<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="independency(n)"><f type="i">Independency<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a not depending upon
another, absoluteness of ones self; but it is commonly
taken for that profession
or sect of men who manage all things belonging to
Church-discipline within their own Congregations, and
allow not of a dependance upon a national Church.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="index(n)"><f type="i">Index<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a token or mark to shew or

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="India(pn)"><f type="i">India<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous and vast Country, lying
very far toward the East, and extreamly abounding in
riches. It is denominated from the River <f type="i">Indus.
America<f type="r"> or the New World is also called the <f type="i">West
Indies<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Indian mouse(n)"><f type="i">Indian mouse<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a little beast called in
Greek <f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Ichneumon</term><f type="r">, which creeping in at the mouths
of Crocodiles, eates up their entrailes, and kills
them.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="indication(n)"><f type="i">Indication<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a shewing or making
manifest; also <class type="register" subject="medicine">a term in Physick</class>,
signifying the right
way which prescribeth what is to be done in relation to
the restoring of health.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="indicative mood(n)"><f type="i">Indicative mood<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="grammar">in Grammar</class> is that mood
which barely affirms and no more.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="indicavit(n)"><f type="i">Indicavit<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the name of a writ, by which the
patron of a Church may remove a suit commenced against his
Clerk, from the Court Christian, to the Kings Court.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="indigo(n)"><f type="i">Indico<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the same as <f type="i">Inde<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="indiction(n)"><f type="i">Indiction<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a certain computation of
time, which came in place of the
Olympiads, every
Indiction is the space of 15 years, by which compute all
publick writings were
dated at <f type="i">Rome<f type="r">; it signifieth
also a tribute, or tax.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="indifference(n)"><f type="i">Indifference<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a carelesse, general,
and unconcerned affection. <f type="i">Cassandra.<f type="r"></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="indigence(n)"><f type="i">Indigence<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> need, penurie, or

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="individual(a)"><f type="i">Individual<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> not to be divided or
separated, an individual, or individuum <class type="register" subject="philosophy">in Philosophy</class> is
taken for a small particle or body, so minute, that it
cannot be divided, and is by some called an Atome: also <class type="register" subject="logic">in
Logick</class> it signifies that which cannot be divided into more
of the same name or nature, and is by <emend err="somd">some</emend> called
<f type="i">Singulare<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

collected out of the Individuals, the

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="infangtheft(n)"><f type="i">Infangtheft<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="law">a word used in the practic of
<f type="i">Scotland<f type="r"></class>, signifying a liberty to sit and decide
upon any theft committed within a mans own jurisdiction,
by his own servant;
<f type="i">Out-fangtheft<f type="r"> being the like liberty, when a
theft is committed by a stranger.</xpln>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="informatus non sum(n)"><f type="i">Informatus non sum<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a formal answer, made
by an Atturny, that is commanded by the Court to say what
he thinks good in defence of his Client, whereby he is
deemed to leave his Client undefended, and so judgement
passeth for the adverse party.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="informer(n)"><f type="i">Informers<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>certain Officers belonging to
the Kings bench, who complain of those that offend against
any penal statutes; they are also called Promoters, and by
the <f type="i">Civilians,
Delatores<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="informity(n)"><f type="i">Informity<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> unhandsomenesse,
uglynesse, a being out of shape or form.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="infrangible(a)"><f type="i">Infrangible<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> not to be broken or
discouraged.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="infriction(n)" lexeme="infrication(n)"><f type="i">Infriction<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Infrication<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class>
a rubbing or
chafing in.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="infusion(n)"><f type="i">Infusion<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a powring, in, it is used <class type="register" subject="medicine">in Physick</class>, for a
steeping of roots or leaves, or <class type="register" subject="medicine">any kind of medicine</class>, in
some liquid substance for a certain time, till the
chiefest of their virtue be drawn out.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="ingeniosity(n)" lexeme="ingenuity(n)"><class type="unknown">&dagger;</class> <f type="i">Ingeniosity<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Ingenuity<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="inhibition(n)"><f type="i">Inhibition<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a forbiding, <class type="register" subject="law">in Common
law</class>, it is taken, for a writ, forbidding a Judge to
proceed farther in the cause depending
before him, but inhibition is a writ issuing out of a
higher Court, Christian
to an inferiour, whereas prohibition issues out of the
Kings, to a Court Christian,
or to an inferiour temporall Court.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="inhonestation(n)"><f type="i">Inhonestation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a shaming or

upon any one, also a decree out of Chancery, to give

of the law is against equity.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="inkling of a matter(n)"><f type="i">An Inkling of a matter<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a small rumour or

others say, from <f type="i">Inclinare<f type="r">, because by it the ear
is somewhat inclined.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="inlagary(n)"><f type="i">Inlagary<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="law">in Common Law</class>, is a restitution
or restoring of one outlaw'd, to the
benefit or estate of a
subject; <class lang="sx" type="etymlang">the word <f type="i">Inlawgh<f type="r"> signifying in the Saxon
tongue</class>, one that is in <f type="i">franco plegio<f type="r">,
that is, under a certain law; and in Decenna, for till a
man be 12 years of age, he is not accounted under
law.</xpln></wordentry>

man in his house, passing in and out by one door, and not

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Inns of Chancery(pn)"><f type="i">Innes of Chancery<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>eight houses
appointed for young
Students in the elements of law, namely, <f type="i">Thavies
Inne<f type="r">, anciently the mansion house of <f type="i">J.
Thavie<f type="r">, Armourer of <f type="i">London<f type="r">. 2.
<f type="i">Furnivalls Inne<f type="r">, once the mansion of Sr. <f type="i">Rich.
Furnival<f type="r">, afterwards of the <f type="i">Talbots<f type="r">, Earls
of <f type="i">Shrewsbury<f type="r">. 3. <f type="i">Bernards
Inne<f type="r">, once belonging to <f type="i">J. Macworth<f type="r">, Dean of
the Cathedral of <f type="i">Lincoln<f type="r">, and in the holding of
<f type="i">Lionel Bernard<f type="r">. 4. <f type="i">Staple Inne<f type="r">, once
belonging to the <f type="i">English<f type="r"> Merchants of the
<f type="i">Staple<f type="r">. 5. <f type="i">Cliffords Inne<f type="r">, once the
dwelling house of <f type="i">Malcolm de hersey<f type="r">, afterwards
of the <f type="i">Cliffords<f type="r">, Earls of <f type="i">Cumberland<f type="r">,
of whom it is now rented. 6. <f type="i">Clements Inne<f type="r">, once
a Messuage belonging to
the Parish Church of St. <f type="i">Clement Danes<f type="r">. 7.
<f type="i">New Inne<f type="r">, once the dwelling house of Sr. <f type="i">J.
Tyncaulxe<f type="r">, it hath been also called our <f type="i">Lady's
Inne<f type="r">. 8. <f type="i">Lyons Inne<f type="r">, once a dwelling house,
known by the name of the <f type="i">Black Lyon<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Inns of Court(pn)"><f type="i">Innes of Court<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>4 houses or Celledges, for
the intertainment of Students of the law, namly, the two
Temples, Inner and Middle, which were anciently the
habitations of the
Templars, or Knights of <f type="i">Jerusalem<f type="r">,
(to which was added the outward Temple, which is now

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Ino(pn)"><f type="i">Ino<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of <f type="i">Cadmus<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Harmonia<f type="r">, and
nurse to <f type="i">Bacchus<f type="r">, she was second wife to
<f type="i">Athamas<f type="r">, King of <f type="i">Thebes<f type="r">, and for causing
<f type="i">Phryxus<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Helle<f type="r">, whom he had by his
first wife <f type="i">Nephele<f type="r">,
to be banisht, she was punished by <f type="i">Juno<f type="r">, who
possest her husband, with such a raving madnesse, that he
took her for a lionesse, and forced her with her son
<f type="i">Melicerta<f type="r">, to cast her self into the sea, where,
by the compassion of the gods, they were changed into sea
Deities.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="inquisition(n)"><f type="i">Inquisition<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a searching into, or
inquiring after; also the name of a grand councel,
instituted by <f type="i">Ferdinand<f type="r">, the
Catholick King of
<f type="i">Spain<f type="r">, who having subdued
the Empire of the <f type="i">Moors<f type="r"> in that
kingdom, ordered, that no
<f type="i">Moors<f type="r"> should be suffered to stay in
<f type="i">Spain<f type="r">, but such as should be baptized; and for
inquiry into those matters: this Councel was erected, and
called the Sacred Councel of the inquisition, whereof the
Arch-bishop of <f type="i">Toledo<f type="r">, or the Arch-Bishop of
<f type="i">Sevil<f type="r"> was President, assisted by 12 other
Councellours.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="enrolment(n)"><f type="i">Inrolement<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a registering or recording any
lawful act in the Roules of the
Chancerie.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="interdict(n)" lexeme="interdiction(n)"><f type="i">Interdict<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Interdiction<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class>
a forbidding or

Law</class>, interdiction is
particularly taken for an Ecclesiastical censure
prohibiting the use of Divine rites to the person
condemned, also such persons whom all men are
forbidden to receive
into their house, are said to be interdicted of fire and

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="interfector(n)"><f type="i">Interfectour<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an interficient or
destroying Planet, and
which is placed in the eighth house (in a Nativity) either
five degrees before the cusp of the house, or 25 after.
Secondly, the Lord of the eighth house. Thirdly the Planet
that is joyned to the Lord of the eighth house. Fourthly
the Planet that disposeth of the Lord of the eighth house
when he is not therein.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="interjection(n)"><f type="i">Interjection<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a casting between: It

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="interim(n)"><f type="i">Interim<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an Adverb signifying <class lang="la" type="etymlang">in Latin, in
the mean while</class>; but we commonly use it substantively for
the time passing between.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="jo"><alpha>J O</alpha>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Io(pn)"><f type="i">Io<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of <f type="i">Inachus<f type="r">, King
of the <f type="i">Argives<f type="r">, she being beloved of
<f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> was transformed into a Cow, that she
might not be known of <f type="i">Juno<f type="r">, who neverthelesse
suspecting, caused her to be watch't by <f type="i">Argus<f type="r">,
who had many eyes, but <f type="i">Argus<f type="r">
being slain by <f type="i">Mercury,
Juno<f type="r"> sent a Gadfly to sting her, which made her run
up and down restlesse, till at length she arrived at
<f type="i">Aegypt<f type="r">, where being restored to her former shape,
she was married to <f type="i">Osiris<f type="r">, and called
<f type="i">Isis<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Joab(pn)"><f type="i">Joab<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="he" type="etymlang">(Hebr.)</class> Fatherhood.</xpln></wordentry>

signifying preparation
of the Lord.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Joan(pn)"><f type="i">Joan<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a proper name of women,
answerable to that of <f type="i">John<f type="r"> in men, it was the name of several great
Queens, as those of <f type="i">Aragon<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Naples<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

that wear the figure of a Chalice upon their

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="John(pn)"><f type="i">John<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a proper name, signifying <class lang="he" type="etymlang">in
Hebrew gracious</class>, there have
been divers great Kings, and other famous men of this
name, as Kings of <f type="i">England, Scotland, Spain<f type="r">, and
<f type="i">Portugal<f type="r">, 23 Popes of <f type="i">Rome<f type="r">, also
<f type="i">Joannes Hircanus<f type="r">, a famous Captain of the
<f type="i">Jews<f type="r">, who conquered <f type="i">Samaria,
Idum&aelig;a<f type="r">, and a great
part of <f type="i">Syria; Joannes Acutus<f type="r">, or
<f type="i">Hackwood<f type="r">, an English-man, who performed several
great martial exploits in <f type="i">Italy<f type="r">, under the Dukes
of <f type="i">Milain; Joannes
Guttenberg<f type="r">, a German, who invented the Art of
printing, this name was anciently
pronounced <f type="i">Juon<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Iphianassa(pn)" lexeme="Iphinoe(pn)" lexeme="Lysippe(pn)"><f type="i">Iphianassa, Iphinoe<f type="r">, and <f type="i">Lysippe<f type="r">,</form>, 
<xpln>the daughters of <f type="i">Proetus<f type="r">, King of <f type="i">Argos<f type="r">,
who for despising the goddesse <f type="i">Juno<f type="r">, &amp;
equalling their own
beauties to hers, were struck with such a Phrensie, that
they imagined themselves
transformed to Cowes, but <f type="i">Melampus<f type="r"> being sent
for, &amp; offered for the cure of them half the Kingdom,
and which of the daughters he lik't best, soon brought
them to their former estate, and married
<f type="i">Iphianassa<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Iphiclus(pn)"><f type="i">Iphiclus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Amphitryo<f type="r"> by
<f type="i">Alckmena<f type="r">, he was
born at the same time with <f type="i">Hercules<f type="r">, who was
begot by <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Iphicrates(pn)"><f type="i">Iphicrates<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Captain of the
<f type="i">Athenians<f type="r">, famous for many great victories.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Iphigenia(pn)"><f type="i">Iphigenia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of
<f type="i">Agamemnon<f type="r">, and <f type="i">Clytemnestra<f type="r">, she was
adjudged to be sacrificed to <f type="i">Diana<f type="r">, because that
goddesse being incensed against <f type="i">Agamemnon<f type="r"> for
killing one of her harts,
kept the Navy of the Greeks by contrary windes from their
intended course, but after that <f type="i">Vlisses<f type="r"> had by
craft obtained her of her mother, and all things in a
readinesse for the sacrifice,
<f type="i">Diana<f type="r"> accepted of a Hart, so that
<f type="i">Iphigenia<f type="r"> was set free and sent to
<f type="i">Taurica<f type="r">, where she was made Over-seer of the
rites of that goddesse, (which were performed by the
sacrificing of men) by <f type="i">Thoas<f type="r"> the King of that
place, who was afterwards slain by <f type="i">Orestes<f type="r">, who
was designed to be offered for a sacrifice.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Iphimedia(pn)"><f type="i">Iphimedia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the wife of <f type="i">Aloeus<f type="r">, who
being ravish't by Neptune, brought forth Twins,
<f type="i">Othus<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Ephialtes<f type="r">, who grew every
moneth nine fingers in talnesse, till they came to be of a
very vast stature, they helpt the Gyants against the Gods,
and were at length slain by the Arrows of <f type="i">Apollo<f type="r">
and <f type="i">Diana<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Iphinoe(pn)"><f type="i">Iphinoe<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>see <xref><f type="i">Iphianassa<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Iphis(pn)"><f type="i">Iphis<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a young man of a great beauty, who
fell in love with <f type="i">Anaxarete<f type="r">, see <xref><f type="i">Anaxarete<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Iphis(pn)"><f type="i">Iphis<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>is also the name of a <f type="i">Cretan<f type="r"> Vir&shy;
</page>

<page sig="X2v">
gin the daughter of <f type="i">Lygdus<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Theletusa<f type="r">,
she was by her mothers prayers to the goddesse
<f type="i">Isis<f type="r"> changed into a man, least <f type="i">Lygdus<f type="r">
finding himself deceived should be incensed, for he
going to travel, and giving
a strict charge to <f type="i">Theletusa<f type="r">, whom he left with
Childe, that if she brought forth a Female Childe, she
should put her out from her, he was made to believe that
it was a Boy, and as soon as his supposed Son came of
age, he provided him a wife named <f type="i">Janthe<f type="r">, for
whom as it hapned, <f type="i">Iphis<f type="r"> proved a real husband.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Ipswich(pn)"><f type="i">Ipswich<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the chief Town of
<f type="i">Suffolk<f type="r">, it was sacked by the <f type="i">Danes<f type="r"> in
the year 991. this Town is famous for the birth of
Cardinal <f type="i">Wolsey<f type="r">
who was a Butcher's son of this place, and who began to
build here a very magnificent Colledge. here is yet
to be seen the ruines of the old Town, which was called
<f type="i">Gipwich<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Irene(pn)"><f type="i">Irene<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the mother of <f type="i">Constantine<f type="r">
the 7<expan type="^th">th</expan>. she reigned at <f type="i">Constantinople<f type="r">
joyntly with her son called a Councel at <f type="i">Nice<f type="r">,
consisting of above 300 Bishops, wherein the setting up of
images in churches was confirmed by a decree, being
expelled from the Empire by her son, who reigned alone
for  seven years, she at length took him by craft,
put out his eyes, and cast him into prison where he
died.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Iris(pn)"><f type="i">Iris<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of <f type="i">Thaumas<f type="r">,

gods, there is a kinde of watry
<f type="i">Meteor<f type="r">, <class lang="gk" type="etymlang">so called
in Greek</class>, appearing in the Clouds of divers colours, which
we call the Rain-bow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Irus(pn)"><f type="i">Irus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a poor man of <f type="i">Ithaca<f type="r">, who
was a continual messenger between <f type="i">Penelope<f type="r"> and
those that came to court her in her
husbands absence, for
which <f type="i">Vlisses<f type="r">, when he came home, killed him with
his fist.</xpln></wordentry>

<f type="i">Theseus<f type="r">, in honour of <f type="i">Neptune<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Isurium Brigantum(pn)"><f type="i">Isurium Brigantum<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the name of an
ancient City in
<f type="i">York-shire<f type="r">, so called from the River <f type="i">Vre<f type="r">
running by it: It was many ages since, rased to the
ground, but out of the ruines of it was built a Town, now
called <f type="i">Ealdburgh<f type="r"> or <f type="i">Aldborow<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Italy(pn)"><f type="i">Italia<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Italie<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>one of the most
famous Countries of <f type="i">Europe<f type="r">, so called from
<f type="i">Italus<f type="r">, otherwise called <f type="i">Atlas<f type="r">, an
ancient King thereof, who had two daughters,
<f type="i">Electra<f type="r">, whom he marryed to <f type="i">Camboblasco<f type="r">,
King of the <f type="i">Janigen&aelig;<f type="r">, and <f type="i">Roma<f type="r">, whom he
made Queen of the <f type="i">Aborigenes<f type="r">, she is said to have
laid the foundation of the City <f type="i">Rome<f type="r">, which was
afterwards finished by <f type="i">Romulus<f type="r">, others derive
<f type="i">Italy<f type="r"> <class lang="gk" type="etymlang">from the Greek word <f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Italos</term><f type="r">, an Ox</class>,
because that Country abounded with Oxen, it was
anciently called
<f type="i">Hesperia<f type="r">, from <f type="i">Hesperus<f type="r">, the brother of
<f type="i">Atlas<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Italianize(v)">To <f type="i">Italianize<f type="r"><f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="neologism">a made word</class>, signifying to
speak or do like an <f type="i">Italian<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Ithaca(pn)"><f type="i">Ithaca<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an Island in the <f type="i">Ionian<f type="r">
sea, where <f type="i">Vlisses<f type="r"> was born, it is full of Goats,
but no Hare can live there.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Itylus(pn)"><f type="i">Itylus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Zethus<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Aedon<f type="r">, <xref><f type="i">See Aedon<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Itys(pn)"><f type="i">Itys<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Tereus<f type="r">, King of
<f type="i">Thrace<f type="r">, by <f type="i">Progne<f type="r">, the daughter of
<f type="i">Pandion<f type="r">, King of <f type="i">Athens<f type="r">, he was slain by
his mother, and set before <f type="i">Tereus<f type="r">, to eat at a
banquet, (because he had deflowred her sister
<f type="i">Philomel<f type="r">, who
after her hands and tongue were cut off, wrought the
relation of it with her needle) but <f type="i">Tereus<f type="r">
discovering in the midst of the banquet, the slaughter of
<f type="i">Itys<f type="r">, by seeing the head of the child, he pursued
<f type="i">Progne<f type="r"> and her sister, with his sword drawn, who
running from him, <f type="i">Progne<f type="r"> was changed into a
swallow, <f type="i">Philomell<f type="r">,
into a Nighingale, and <f type="i">Itys<f type="r"> into a
Pheasant.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Juba(pn)"><f type="i">Juba<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a King of <f type="i">Mauritania<f type="r">, he was a
constant friend to <f type="i">Pompey<f type="r">'s party, he overthrew
<f type="i">Curio<f type="r">, and all his forces sent into
<f type="i">Africa<f type="r">, by <f type="i">C&aelig;sar<f type="r">: when
<f type="i">Pompey<f type="r"> was over&shy;
</page>

<page sig="X3v">
come, he joyned his forces with <f type="i">Scipio<f type="r">, and dyed
fighting with <f type="i">Petreius<f type="r">.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="jubarb(n)"><f type="i">Jubarb, q. barba jovis<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>because of its

called <f type="i">Housleek<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="jubeb(n)"><f type="i">Jubeb<f type="r"></form>. <xpln>fruit or <f type="i">Jujubes<f type="r">,
(Arab. <f type="i">zufalzef<f type="r">) a kind of Pruan, <class type="register" subject="medicine">used much in
Physick</class>, and sold by Apothecaries; it was a fruit known
among the <f type="i">Seres<f type="r">, a people of <f type="i">Scythia<f type="r">,
and therefore called in Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Sericum</term><f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="jubilation(n)"><f type="i">Jubilation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a solemn rejoycing, a
shouting for joy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="jubilee, year of(n)"><f type="i">A year of Jubile<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a great festival, or time
of rejoycing, celebrated every 50th year by the Jews, in
remembrance of their deliverance from <f type="i">Egypt<f type="r">, it
came at length to be solemnized among the
Christians, being
first instituted by Pope <f type="i">Boniface<f type="r">,
the eighth in the year 1300, who ordained it to be kept
every hundred years, <class lang="he" type="etymlang">it comes from the Hebrew word
<f type="i"><term lang="he">Jocel</term><f type="r">, rejoycing</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="jucundity(n)"><f type="i">Jucundity<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> pleasantnesse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Judea(pn)"><f type="i">Judea<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Country of Syria, in <f type="i">Asia<f type="r">
the greater, bordering eastward upon the dead sea, it is
also called <f type="i">Chanan&aelig;a<f type="r">, or the land of
Promise.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Judaism(pn)"><f type="i">Judaisme<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> the faith or religion of

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Ivetot(pn)"><f type="i">Ivetot<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town of lower <f type="i">Normandy<f type="r">
in <f type="i">France<f type="r">, which hath in former times been
governed by a titular King; whence a man of a great Title,
and a small inheritance,
is in derision called a King of <f type="i">Ivetot<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>
