<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="jugular(a)" lexeme="jugulary(a)"><f type="i">Jugular<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Jugularie<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class>
belonging to the throat, whence the jugular veins are
those veins which ascend along the sides of the neck, to
the bottom of the head.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="jugulation(n)"><f type="i">Jugulation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a cutting the throat of
any one, a killing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Jugurth(pn)"><f type="i">Jugurth<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Manostabales<f type="r">,
brother of <f type="i">Micipsa<f type="r">, King of <f type="i">Numidia<f type="r">;
whom his Uncle, dying, constituted heir of his
kingdom, together with
his two sons, <f type="i">Adherbal<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Hiemsal<f type="r">, but
<f type="i">Jugurth<f type="r">, that he might possesse the Kingdom to
himself, slew them both: whereupon the <f type="i">Romans<f type="r">
made war upon him for a long time, wherein at length being
overthrown by <f type="i">Marius<f type="r">, he fled to Bocchus, King of
<f type="i">Mauritania<f type="r">, by whom he was betrayed to
<f type="i">Sylla<f type="r">, and being brought to Rome, dyed in
prison.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="jujube(n)"><f type="i">Jujubes<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>see Jubeb fruit.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="jouk(v)"><f type="i">To Juke<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>to pearch or roost as a
Hawk.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="julep(n)"><f type="i">Julep<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="medicine">a kind of physical medecine</class>, to open
the inward parts, and prepare for purgation, being a
decoction mingled with sirrups, or sweetned with
sugar.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Jullaber(pn)"><f type="i">Jullaber<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain hillock in
<f type="i">Kent<f type="r">, so called from one <f type="i">Jullaber<f type="r">, a
Giant, or as some say, a Witch, who was here enterred, but
<f type="i">Cambden<f type="r"> rather thinks it so named from
<f type="i">Laberius Durus<f type="r">, a Captain of <f type="i">Julius
C&aelig;sars<f type="r">, who was here slain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Julian(pn)"><f type="i">Julian<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>sirnamed the Apostate, because that
being brought up in the Christian religion, he fell back
to Heathenisme: he was the son of <f type="i">Constantius<f type="r">,
and by his valour came to
be made <f type="i">Roman Emperour<f type="r">, he prohibited to the
Christians all kind of learning, that through their
ignorance, they might become uncapable to defend their
religion: at last, in an expedition against the
<f type="i">Persians<f type="r">, being mortally
wounded, he cryed out,
<f type="i">vicisti Galil&aelig;e<f type="r">, Thou hast overcome, O
<f type="i">Galil&aelig;an<f type="r">, meaning <f type="i">Christ<f type="r">; and soon
after dyed: also, a proper name of women, contracted
<f type="i">Juliana<f type="r">, some write it <f type="i">Gilian<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Julian account(n)"><f type="i">Julian account<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>see <f type="i">Gregorian
account<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="julio(n)"><f type="i">Julio<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="it" type="etymlang">a kind of <f type="i">Italian<f type="r"> coin</class>,
made by Pope <f type="i">Julius<f type="r">, valuing about six pence of
our mony.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Julius C&aelig;sar(pn)"><f type="i">Julius C&aelig;sar<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the first of the <f type="i">Roman
Emperours<f type="r">, he subdued <f type="i">France, Spain,
Brittain<f type="r">, the <f type="i">Low Countries<f type="r">, and the greatest part of
<f type="i">Germany<f type="r">, afterwards he entred into a civil war
with <f type="i">Pompey<f type="r">, whom he utterly
defeated at the battle of <f type="i">Pharsalia<f type="r">, and his two
sons, <f type="i">Cneus<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Sextus Pompeius<f type="r"> in
<f type="i">Spain<f type="r">; and having reigned three years in
<f type="i">Rome<f type="r">, as absolute Emperour, he was at length
slain in the Senate house, by <f type="i">Brutus<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Cassius<f type="r">, <class lang="gk" type="etymlang">the word signifies in Greek
softhaired</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Julius(pn)"><f type="i">Julius<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the sirname of <f type="i">Ascanius<f type="r">, the
son of <f type="i">Aeneas<f type="r">, and his first wife
<f type="i">Creusa<f type="r">, he came along with his father into
<f type="i">Italy<f type="r">, and built the City <f type="i">Alba<f type="r"> in the
place, where he found the white Sow with the 30 Pigs:
also the son of <f type="i">Ascanius<f type="r">, who stood in
competition for the kingdom of <f type="i">Alba<f type="r">, with
</page>

<page sig="X4r">
<f type="i">Silvius Posthumus<f type="r"> the son of <f type="i">Aeneas<f type="r"> by
his second wife <f type="i">Lavinia<f type="r">; the word signifieth in
Greek, the soft down appearing on the chin of a young
man, before he comes to have a perfect beard.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="July(pn)"><f type="i">July<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the name of the fifth moneth from
<f type="i">March<f type="r">, which was heretofore accounted the first
moneth of the year, it was so named
from <f type="i">Julius C&aelig;sar<f type="r">, being in former time called
<f type="i">Quintilis<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="jumentarious(a)"><f type="i">Jumentarious<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to a horse,
or any kind of labouring beast,
called <class lang="la" type="etymlang">in Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">jumentum</term><f type="r"></class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="juncture(n)"><f type="i">Juncture<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a joyning together, also a
joynt, also juncture of time, the very nick or moment of
time.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="June(pn)"><f type="i">June<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the fourth moneth of the year from
<f type="i">March<f type="r"> the first. Some say it was so called from
<f type="i">Juno<f type="r">, as it were <f type="i">junonian<f type="r"> moneth. Others
from <f type="i">Junius Brutus<f type="r">, who begun his Consulship in
that moneth: it is called in Greek <f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Hecatomb&aelig;on</term><f type="r">,
from the <f type="i">Hecatombs<f type="r"> or <f type="i">Sacrifices<f type="r"> of a
hundred Oxen which used to be offered to <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">
in this moneth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="junk(n)"><f type="i">Junke<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="navigation">in Navigation</class>, is any piece of an
old cable.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Juno(pn)"><f type="i">Juno<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of <f type="i">Saturn<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Ops<f type="r">, and both wife and sister to
<f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">, to whom she brought forth
<f type="i">Vulcan<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Mars<f type="r">, and a daughter called
<f type="i">Hebe<f type="r">, whom she conceived by eating of green
Lettice: she is called <f type="i">Juno a juvando<f type="r">, i. from
giving help, also <f type="i">Lucina<f type="r">, from causing men to see the light of the World, being said to be present at the
birth of all children that come into the World, and to sit
crosse-legged when any miscarry. She is also called
<f type="i">Sospita a Sospitando, i. e.<f type="r"> keeping in
safety.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Juno's tears(n)"><f type="i">Juno's teares<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kind of plant otherwise
called <f type="i">Vervain<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="junto(n)" lexeme="junta(n)"><f type="i">Junto<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Junta<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="sp" type="etymlang">(Span.)</class> a meeting
together of men to
sit in council.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="ivory(n)"><f type="i">Ivory<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> the Elephants tooth being
the finest and whitest kind of bone, of which boxes and
several sorts of things are made.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Jupiter(pn)"><f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Saturn<f type="r"> by his
wife <f type="i">Ops<f type="r">, born at the same birth with
<f type="i">Juno<f type="r">, and hid in the mountain <f type="i">Ida<f type="r"> in
<f type="i">Creet<f type="r">, where he was bred up by the
<f type="i">Curetes<f type="r"> unknown to his father <f type="i">Saturn<f type="r">,
who intending to devoure
all his male children, his wife <f type="i">Ops<f type="r"> gave him a
great stone wrapt up in swadling
clouts, to eat instead of his son <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">, who
coming to age and understanding his fathers designs
against him, conspired against
him, and cast him out of his dominions,
and divided the government of the World between himself
and his two brothers;
the Heavens he reserved to himself,
to <f type="i">Neptune<f type="r"> he gave the Empire of the Sea, and to
<f type="i">Pluto<f type="r"> the lower Regions of the Earth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Jupiter Belus(pn)"><f type="i">Jupiter Belus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the second King of
<f type="i">Babylon<f type="r">, or as
some say the first, he was the son of <f type="i">Nimrod<f type="r">,
called also <f type="i">Saturn<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="juration(n)"><f type="i">Juration<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a swearing, or taking an
oath.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="jurat(n)"><f type="i">Jurats<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> certain officers
otherwise called
<f type="i"><term lang="fr">Eschevins</term><f type="r">, or <f type="i">Sheriffs<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="jordan(n)"><f type="i">Jurden<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Jordon<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>a kind of
Urinal or Chamberpot, also <f type="i">Jordan<f type="r"> is the name of
a River dividing <f type="i">Perea<f type="r"> from the rest of
<f type="i">Jud&aelig;a<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="juridical(a)"><f type="i">Juridical<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to the Law,
judicial, or which will bear an action.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="jury(n)"><f type="i">Jury<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(in lat. <f type="i">Jurati<f type="r">)</class> signifieth
<class type="register" subject="law">in Common Law</class>, a company
consisting of 24 or 12 men empanelled, and sworn to
deliver a truth upon such evidence as shall be
delivered them touching the matter in question,
there being three sorts of trials, either by Assize or
Jury, by Battel, or by Parliament. In every general
Assize, there is both a Grand Jury consisting of 24
substantial men,
chosen indifferently out of the whole County, and others
called Petit Juries, consisting of 12, to whom are
referred such things concerning life and death, as the
Grand Jury have approved
of.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="jurisdiction(n)"><f type="i">Jurisdiction<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> authority to make or
execute Laws. Also it is used for any kind of power or
authority.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="jurist(n)">A <f type="i">Jurist<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Lawyer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="jurisprudence(n)"><f type="i">Jurisprudence<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> knowledge or skil in
the Laws.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="jarn(n)" lexeme="jarn-chopper(n)"><f type="i">Jurn<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Journchoppers<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>the
regraters or changers of yarn.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="juror(n)"><f type="i">Juror<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>one of the twelve men in a
Jury.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="jury-mast(n)"><f type="i">Jury-mast<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>is one made at sea in case of
necessity, by fastning several pieces
together.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="jussel(n)"><f type="i">Jussel<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a minutal from <f type="i">jus<f type="r">,
signifying a dish made of several meats minced together.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="jussulent(a)"><f type="i">Jussulent<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> full of broth or
pottage.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="joust(n)"><f type="i">Justes<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> tikings or combats on
horseback with Speares and Lances.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="justice(n)" lexeme="justicer(n)"><f type="i">Justice<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Justicer<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> an
officer deputed by the King or Common-wealth, to act by
way of judgement.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="X4v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Justice of the King's Bench(pn)"><f type="i">Justice of the Kings Bench<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>is the capital or
chief Justice of <f type="i">England<f type="r">, he is a Lord by his
office, which is most especially to hear and determine
all pleas of the Crown, that is such as concern offences
committed against the Crown, Dignity, and Peace, of the
King; as Treasons, Mayhems, and the like.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Justice of the Common Pleas(pn)"><f type="i">Justice of Common pleas<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>is he who hears
and determines all causes at the Common Law, that is, all
civil causes between common persons, as well personal as
reall. He is also a Lord by his office.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Justice of the Forest(pn)"><f type="i">Justice of the Forrest<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>or Justice in eyre
of the Forrest, is he that hath the hearing and
determining of all offences within the Kings Forrest
committed against Venison
or Vert, and is also a Lord by his office.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Justice of Assise(pn)"><f type="i">Justices of Assises<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>such as were wont by
special commission to be sent into this or that County to
take Assises for the ease of the subjects.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Justice of Oyer and Terminer(pn)"><f type="i">Justices of oyer and terminer<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>are
Justices deputed upon
some special and extraordinary
occasions, to hear and determine
causes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Justice in Eyre(pn)"><f type="i">Justices in eyre<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>those that were wont to
be sent with commissions into divers
Counties, to hear such
causes as were termed the Pleas of the Crown, and were for
the case of the
subjects who must have come to the Kings Bench, if the
cause were too high for the County-Court, from the French
word <f type="i"><term lang="fr">Erre</term><f type="r">, a journey.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Justice of Gaol Delivery(pn)"><f type="i">Justices of Goale delivery<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>are such as are
sent with commission to hear and
determine all causes
appertaining to such as for any offence are cast into
Goale.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Justice of Nisi Prius(pn)"><f type="i">Justices of Nisi prius<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the same now
adayes with Justices of
Assises.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Justice of Trial Baston(pn)"><f type="i">Justices of tryal baston<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>or <f type="i">trayl
baston<f type="r">, were certain Justices appointed by
<f type="i">Edward<f type="r"> the first
to make inquisition through the Realme, upon all Officers,
as Mayors, Sheriffs, Escheatours, <f type="i">&amp;c.<f type="r">
touching extortion, briberies, intrusion into other mens lands, and Barratours
that used to take money for beating of men, and they had
power either to punish by death, or to exact a ransome.
<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">This term comes from two French words, <f type="i"><term lang="fr">treille</term><f type="r"> an
arbour or form, and <f type="i"><term lang="fr">baston</term><f type="r"> a staff or pole, to
note that the Justices imployed in this
commission, had authority to proceed without any solemn Judgement-seat,
but wheresoever they could apprehend the malefactours.</class></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Justice of the Peace(pn)"><f type="i">Justices of peace<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>are such as are
appointed by the Kings
commission to attend the peace in the County where they
dwell, whereof such whose commission begins <f type="i">Quorum vos
unum esse volumus<f type="r">, are called Justices of the
<f type="i">Quorum<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="justicies(n)"><f type="i">Justicies<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Writ directed to the Sheriff
for the dispatch of justice in some
especial cause wherewith
of his own authority he cannot deal in his
County-Court.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="justiciable(a)"><f type="i">Justiciable<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> subject to Law, under
authority.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Justicians(pn)"><f type="i">Justicians<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain religious Order
instituted in the year
1412 in the Abby of St. <f type="i">Justine<f type="r"> at
<f type="i">Padua<f type="r">, by one <f type="i">Lewise Balus<f type="r"> a
Venetian.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="justification(n)"><f type="i">Justification<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a clearing,
justifying, or making
good; <class type="register" subject="law">in Common Law</class> it is a shewing a good reason why a
man did such a thing as he is called to
answer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Justinianus(pn)"><f type="i">Justinianus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a name by which two of the
Roman Emperours were called. The first was famous for
causing the Civil Law to be reduced into the Pandects and
the Code; whence Students of the Civil Law are called
<f type="i">Justinianists:<f type="r"> the second for the great wars he
had with the Saracens and Bulgarians.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Justinopolis(pn)"><f type="i">Justinopolis<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a City of <f type="i">Istria<f type="r">,
built upon the Sea side by the Emperour <f type="i">Justine<f type="r">:
it is now called <f type="i">Cabo d' Istria<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="jutties of houses(n)"><f type="i">Jutties of houses<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>are certain parts of a
building, which jut or stand out farther than the rest.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Juturna(pn)"><f type="i">Juturna<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of <f type="i">Daunus<f type="r">,
and sister of <f type="i">Turnus<f type="r"> King of the <f type="i">Rutuli<f type="r">,
she was by <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> in recompence of the losse of
her maiden-head immortalized, and made Nimph of the River
<f type="i">Numicus<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="juvenility(n)"><f type="i">Juvenility<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> youthfulnesse,
lustinesse, or vigour.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Juventas(pn)"><f type="i">Juventas<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the Goddesse of Youth, the same
with <f type="i">Hebe<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Juverna(pn)"><f type="i">Juverna<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an ancient name of
<f type="i">Ireland<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="i-wimpled(a)"><f type="i">Iwimpled<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="old word">(old word)</class> muffled.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Ixion(pn)"><f type="i">Ixion<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Phlegyas<f type="r">, he having
slain his son in law <f type="i">Erioneus<f type="r">, after he had
long wandered up and down, and could not be absolved
either by gods or men; at length <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">
pitying him, took him up into Heaven and expiated him; but he
</page>

<page sig="Y1r">
after his purgation remaining among the gods, fell in
love with <f type="i">Juno<f type="r"> and sollicited her to
unchastity, which she making known to <f type="i">Jove<f type="r">, he
formed a cloud in the shape of <f type="i">Juno<f type="r">, and
<f type="i">Ixion<f type="r"> thinking it to have been the goddesse,
begat a race of <f type="i">Centaurs<f type="r">, and being soon after
sent down to the earth, he boasted every where that he
lay with <f type="i">Juno<f type="r">, for which being struck down to
Hell with a Thunderbolt, he was condemned to be alwayes
rowled on a wheele.
</xpln></wordentry>

</wordgroup1>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cab(n)"><f type="i">KAb<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Cab<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>an <class lang="he" type="etymlang">Hebrew</class> measure
containing three pints
of our measure.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="keel(n)"><f type="i">Keel<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the lowest and first timber laid in a

beer or ale in.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="keen(a)"><f type="i">Keen<f type="r"> or <f type="i">Kene<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="old word">(old word)</class> sharp,
some think it comes <class lang="gk" type="etymlang">from the Greek word <f type="i"><term lang="gkt">a cone</term><f type="r">, a

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Keeper of the Great Seal of England(pn)"><f type="i">Keeper of the great Seal of England<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>is he
under whose hands passe all Charters, Commissions, and
grants of the King, strengthned by the Great or Broad
Seal, without which they are of no effect. He is a Lord by
his office, and one of the Kings privy Council.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Keeper of the Privy Seal(pn)"><f type="i">Keeper of the privy Seal<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>is also a Lord by
his office, and one of the privy
Council; under his hands
passe all Charters signed by the King, before they come to
the Broad Seal.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Keeper of the Forest(pn)"><f type="i">Keeper of the Forrest<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>is he who hath the
principal government of all things
belonging to the
Forrest: he is also called chief Warden of the
Forrest.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="keel(v)"><f type="i">Kele<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="old word">(old word)</class> to coole.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="ken, within(n)">Within <f type="i">Ken<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>within sight or view, <class type="register" subject="navigation">a term in
Navigation</class>, and <class type="etymlang" lang="sx">comes from the Saxon word <f type="i"><term lang="sx">Kenne</term>, i.
e.<f type="r"> to know or discover</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Kenchester(pn)"><f type="i">Kenchester<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town in
<f type="i">Herefordshire<f type="r">, built as some think out of the
ruines of old <f type="i">Ariconium<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Kenhelm(pn)"><f type="i">Kenhelm<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the proper name of a man,
signifying <class lang="sx" type="etymlang">in Saxon, defence of his
kindred</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="kennel(v)"><f type="i">Kenneleth<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>(applyed to a Fox) when he is in
his hole. <class type="register" subject="hawking and hunting">A term in hunting.</class></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="kerchief(n)"><f type="i">Kerchief<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="kern(n)"><f type="i">Kern<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kind of light-armed foot
souldier among the <f type="i">Irish<f type="r">; we use it also for an ordinary Country
farmer, also to <f type="i">Kern<f type="r">, signifieth to powder or to
salt.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="kernel(v)"><f type="i">Kernel<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat. <f type="i">Kernellare<f type="r">)</class> <class type="old word">an old

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="cress(n)"><f type="i">Kers<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Cresses<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>a kind of plant

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="kersy(n)"><f type="i">Kersie<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> a kind of cloth or stuff
much used.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Kesar(pn)"><f type="i">Kesar<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a word which the Brittains used
instead of <f type="i">C&aelig;sar<f type="r">, and is taken in the same sense
at this day, when they say, King nor Kesar.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Kesteven(pn)"><f type="i">Kesteven<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>see <xref><f type="i">Holland<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="key of a river or haven(n)"><f type="i">Key of a River or Haven<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a place where
ships ride, and are as it were lock't in. Some deduce it a
<f type="i">quiescendo, i.<f type="r"> from resting,
or <class lang="la" type="etymlang">from the old Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Casare</term>, i.<f type="r"> to
restrain</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="keynard(n)"><f type="i">Keynard<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="old word">(old word)</class> a micher.</xpln>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="kichel(n)"><f type="i">Kichel<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="old word">(old word)</class> a kind of cake, the same
which is called in Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Libum</term><f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="kilderkin(n)"><f type="i">Kilderkin<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="du" type="etymlang">(in Dutch
<f type="i"><term lang="du">Kindekin</term><f type="r">)</class>
a kind of liquid measure, being the eighth part of a
hogshead, it contains about eleven or twelve
gallons.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="kayles(n)"><f type="i">Kiles<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="du" type="etymlang">from the Dutch word <f type="i"><term lang="du">keghel</term><f type="r">
an <f type="i">Isicle<f type="r"></class>, certain pins to play withal,
commonly called Nine-pins.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Kildare(pn)"><f type="i">Kildare<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>two Counties of <f type="i">Ireland<f type="r">
in the Province of <f type="i">Leimster<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Kilkenny(pn)"><f type="i">Kilkenny<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>two Counties of <f type="i">Ireland<f type="r">
in the Province of <f type="i">Leimster<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Kinburgh(pn)"><f type="i">Kinburgh<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="sx" type="etymlang">(Sax.)</class> strength and defence of
kindred, a proper name of women.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="king(n)"><f type="i">King<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="du" type="etymlang">(from the Dutch word <f type="i"><term lang="du">koning</term>,</class> i.<f type="r">
to
</page>

<page sig="Y1v">
know, because he ought to be the most knowing of men, or
from <f type="i">Konnen<f type="r">, to be powerful) the supream Ruler
of a Nation.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="King of Heralds(pn)"><f type="i">King of Harolds<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>or <f type="i">King of Arms<f type="r">,
he is called <f type="i">Garter<f type="r">, and is the same with
<f type="i">Pater patratus<f type="r">, among the Romans. see in
<xref target="Harald"><f type="i">Harald<f type="r">.</xref></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="King's Bench(pn)"><f type="i">Kingsbench<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the Court or Judgement-seat
where the King was wont to sit in his own person, and
therefore it was moveable
with the Court or Kings houshold, and was called <f type="i">Curia
domini Regis<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Aula Regia<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="King's silver(n)"><f type="i">Kings Silver<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>that money which is due to
the King in the Court of Common-pleas, in respect of a
license there granted to any man for passing of a
fine.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="King's Silver, Clerk of the(pn)">Clark of the <f type="i">Kings Silver<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>is an officer of
the Common pleas, unto whom every fine is brought, after
it hath been with the <f type="i">custos Brevium<f type="r">, and by whom
the effect of the Writ of covenant is entred into a paper
book.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Kingston upon Thames(pn)"><f type="i">Kingston upon Thames<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town in
<f type="i">Surry<f type="r">, so called because <f type="i">Athelstane,
Edwin<f type="r">, and <f type="i">Etheldred<f type="r">, were here Crowned
Kings in the open Market-place.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="kintal(n)"><f type="i">Kintal<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>see <xref><f type="i">Quintal<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

</wordgroup1>
<wordgroup1 type="a" object="kn"><alpha>K N</alpha>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="knap of ground(n)"><f type="i">Knap of ground<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a little rising
hillock.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="knave(n)"><f type="i">Knave<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="sx" type="etymlang">(Sax. <f type="i">Canapa<f type="r">)</class> signifieth
originally a Lacquey or
Waiting-man, and cometh originally <class lang="he" type="etymlang">from the Hebrew word
<f type="i"><term lang="he">Gnavadh</term><f type="r">, to serve</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="knee(n)"><f type="i">Knees<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="navigation">in Navigation</class>, are certain
crooked pieces of timber
used in Ships to fasten the beames unto the sides.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="knight(n)"><f type="i">Knight<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="sx" type="etymlang">(Sax. <f type="i">Cnicht<f type="r">)</class> hath been
taken originally for a souldier or horseman in war; those
that were wont to accompany and wait upon the Emperour in
the wars, were called in Dutch <f type="i"><term lang="du">Knechts</term>, i. e.<f type="r">
servitours or lusty young men. It is also taken
for a client or vassal, but more
especially one that holds his land by serving his Lord on horseback; it is now
grown to be a Title of great Dignity and
Honour. Of Knight-hoods
there are many sorts, but the most usual in this Nation
are these.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Knight Bachelor(pn)"><f type="i">Knight Bachelour<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the lowest, but
ancientest Order of
Knight-hood, and cometh from the Germans, among whom it
was an ancient custom, that as soon as the State judged
any of their young men fit to manage armes and weapons,
and allowed him sufficient
for martial exercises, then in the very assembly and
council, either one of the
Princes, the father, or son of the kinsfolk of the young
man, did furnish him with a shield and a javelin, as the
Romans did the <f type="i">toga virilis<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Virile
gown<f type="r">, to those whom they thought capable of publick
imployment, and thenceforth from a part of a private
house, he was accounted a member of the Common-wealth. It
was also an ancient ceremony to honour men with the Girdle
of Knighthood, which he who received, was solemnly to go
to Church, and offerring
his sword upon the Altar, to vow himself to the service of
God; afterwards it came to be usual for Kings to send
their sons to the neighbour Princes, to receive Knighthood
at their hands; Then it was also that besides the Sword
and Girdle, Gilt-Spurs were also added for more
ornament, whence in Latin they are called <f type="i"><term lang="la">Equites
aurati</term><f type="r">; the word Bachelours some derive from the
French <f type="i"><term lang="fr">Baschevaliers</term><f type="r">,
as it were Knights of the lowest degree; others from
<f type="i"><term lang="fr">Batailler</term><f type="r"> to battel or fight: they are also
simply and without any addition called Knights.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Knight Banneret(pn)"><f type="i">Knight Banneret<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="du" type="etymlang">from the Dutch word
<f type="i"><term lang="du">Bannerherr</term><f type="r">, Lord or Master of the Banner</class>, is a
Knight made in the field, with the ceremonies of cutting
the point of his Standard, and making it as it were a
Banner, and is allowed to
display his arms in the Kings army. This Dignity was given
at first by the Kings of <f type="i">England<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">France<f type="r">, to such Gentlemen as valiantly carried
themselves in two Royal Battels, or to such as had ten
vassals and means to maintain
a Troop of Horses at their own charge. Some say the first
original of it was from <f type="i">Edward<f type="r"> the third.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Knight Baronet(pn)"><f type="i">Knight Baronet<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>is a new distinct Order erected
by King <f type="i">James<f type="r">, who for certain disbursements
toward the Plantation in <f type="i">Vlster<f type="r">, created divers
into this Dignity, and made it hereditary by his Letters
Patents to be seen in the Rolles, whereas before
that time there were Baronets who were not Knights, and
these Knight Baronets
were to have precedency in all Writings, Sessions, and
Salutations, before all
Knights of the Bath, and Knights Bachelours, and
Bannerets, except those created under the Kings Standard
in an Army Royal, the King being personally present, and
the King was not to create any person into that degree of Baronet
</page>

<page sig="Y2r">
within the Kingdom of <f type="i">England<f type="r">, above the number
of two hundred.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Knight of the Bath(pn)"><f type="i">Knight<f type="r"> of the Bath</form>, <xpln>an Order of Knights
created within the lists of the Bath, and girded with a
sword in the Ceremonies of their Creation, these Knights
were wont to be created with a great many religious
solemnities, which usually belong to
Hermites, and other holy Orders.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Knight of the Carpet(pn)"><f type="i">Knights<f type="r"> of the Carpet</form>, <xpln>are another sort of
Knights made out of the field, and are so called, because
in receiving their order they commonly kneel upon a Carpet.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Knight of the Garter(pn)"><f type="i">Knights<f type="r"> of the Garter</form>, <xpln>an order of
Knighthood, instituted by King <f type="i">Edward<f type="r"> the 3d.
some say upon occasion of good successe in a skirmish,
wherein the Kings Garter was used for a token, others
affirm that the King after his great successes abroad and
at home, dancing one night with the Queen and other
Ladies, took up a Garter that hapned to fall from one of
them, whereat some of the Lords smiling, the King said
that ere long he would make that Garter to be of high
reputation, and shortly after he erected this order of the
blue Garter, which consists of 26 martial Nobles, whereof
the King of <f type="i">England<f type="r">
used to be the chief, and the rest be either of the Realm,
or Princes of other Countreys, there are also depending
upon this order 26 poor Knights, who have no other
sustenance, but the allowance of this house, and are also
called poor Knights of <f type="i">Windsor<f type="r">, the site of this
Colledge being the Castle of
<f type="i">Windsor<f type="r">, with the Chappel
of St. <f type="i">George<f type="r">, the Officers belonging to this
Order, are, the Prelate of the Garter, which Office
belongeth to the Bishop of
<f type="i">Winchester<f type="r">, the Chancelour of the Garter, the
Register of the Garter, who was alwayes <f type="i">Dean<f type="r"> of
<f type="i">Windsor<f type="r">, the principal
King of Arms, called Garter, and the Usher of the Garter,
which Office belonged to
the Usher of the Princes Chamber,
called <f type="i">Black-rod<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Knight of the Order of St. John of Jerusalem(pn)"><f type="i">Knights<f type="r"> of the Order of St. <f type="i">John<f type="r">
of <f type="i">Jerusalem<f type="r">,</form>
<xpln>an Order of Knighthood erected in the year 1120. and had
their first foundation
and abode in <f type="i">Jerusalem<f type="r">, afterwards they had their
residence at <f type="i">Rhodes<f type="r">, whence they were expelled by
<f type="i">Solyman<f type="r">, and ever since their chief seat hath
been at <f type="i">Malta<f type="r">, where they have done great
exploits against the
<f type="i">Turk<f type="r">, there was one general Prior that had the
government of the whole Order in <f type="i">England<f type="r">, and
<f type="i">Scotland<f type="r"> but toward the end of <f type="i">Harry<f type="r"> the
eights reign, they were suppressed in <f type="i">England<f type="r"> for
adhering to the Pope.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Knight of the Temple(pn)"><f type="i">Knights<f type="r"> of the Temple</form>, <xpln>or Knights
Templars, an Order of
Knighthood erected by Pope <f type="i">Gelasius<f type="r">, about the
year of our Lord 1117. these Knights in the beginning
dwelling not far from the Sepulchre of Christ, intertained
Christian strangers and Pilgrims charitably, and in their
Armour led them through the holy land, to view such things
as there were to be seen, and to defend them from the
Infidels, but because at
the last they abounded in many Vices, and many of them
fell away from Christianity to the <f type="i">Saracens<f type="r">, the
whole Order was suppressed by Pope <f type="i">Clement<f type="r"> the
fifth, and their substance given to the Knights of
<f type="i">Rhodes<f type="r">, and other Religious Orders.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Knight of the Shire(pn)"><f type="i">Knights<f type="r"> of the Shire</form>, <xpln>two Knights, or other
Gentlemen of worth, that are chosen by the freeholders of
every County, that can dispend fourty shillings <f type="i">per
annum<f type="r">, and be resident in the Shire; formerly none
but Knights were chosen to that Office (<f type="i">Milites gladio
cincti<f type="r">, for so runneth
the Tenour of the Writ) when every one that had a Knights
fee was constrained to
be a Knight, but now custome alloweth
that Esquires may be chosen, so that they be resident in
the County.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Knight Marshal(pn)"><f type="i">Knight Marshal<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an Officer of the Kings
house, who hath the Jurisdiction and Cognisance of any
transgression; as also of all Contracts made within the
Kings house and verge.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Knight of Calatrava in Spain(pn)"><f type="i">Knights<f type="r"> of <f type="i">Calatrava<f type="r"> in
<f type="i">Spain<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>an Order created by <f type="i">Alonzo<f type="r">, the
ninth King of <f type="i">Spain<f type="r">, conferred upon certain
<f type="i">Cavallero's<f type="r">, who went in Devotion to succour
<f type="i">Calatrava<f type="r">
against the <f type="i">Moors<f type="r">, their badge was a red crosse
on the left side of their breast.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Knight of the Jar(pn)"><f type="i">Knights<f type="r"> of the <f type="i">Jar<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>see <xref target="Jarre"><f type="i">Jar<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="knight's fee(n)"><f type="i">Knights fee<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>so much inheritance as is
sufficient to maintain a Knight with
convenient Revenue,
which was in ancient time about 800 Acres, it is also
taken for the Rent that a Knight payes for his fee to the
Lord of whom he holds.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="knight's service(n)" lexeme="chivalry(n)"><f type="i">Knights service<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Chevalry<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>a
certain ancient Tenure of
Lands, by which a man was obliged to bear Arms in defence
of his Countrey.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Knighten Guild(pn)"><f type="i">Knighten Guild<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain Guild, or
Company in
<f type="i">London<f type="r">, consisting of 19 Knights, it was
founded by King <f type="i">Edgar<f type="r">, who gave them a portion
of void ground, lying
</page>

<page sig="Y2v">
without the Citie, now called Portsoken Ward.
</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Knipperdollings(pn)"><f type="i">Knipperdollings<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain Sect of
Hereticks, who lived in
<f type="i">Germany<f type="r">, about the time of <f type="i">John<f type="r"> of
<f type="i">Leyden<f type="r">, they were so called
from one <f type="i">Knipperdolling<f type="r">, who was the first
founder of that Sect.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Knolls of the Peace(pn)"><f type="i">Knolls<f type="r"> of Peace</form>, <xpln>certain Mounts cast up by
mans hand, in the Sherifdom of <f type="i">Sterling<f type="r">
in <f type="i">Scotland<f type="r">, called in Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Duni
Pacis</term><f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

</wordgroup1>
<wordgroup1 type="a" object="ku"><alpha>K U</alpha>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Kunigunda(pn)" lexeme="Cunigunda(pn)"><f type="i">Kunigunda<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Cunigunda<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>the wife
of <f type="i">Henry<f type="r"> the second, Duke of <f type="i">Bavaria<f type="r">,
and Emperour of <f type="i">Germany<f type="r">, she to free her self
from the aspersion of inchastity that was cast upon her,
caused certain Plough-shares to be heated red hot, and
placed at a little distance one from the other, and went
over them blindfold without receiving any harm, whereby
she cleared her self from all suspition, the like was
reported of <f type="i">Edward<f type="r"> the Confessours wife, and this tryal
afterwards became oftentimes
in use upon such like occasions, and was called the tryal
of fire Ordeal.</xpln></wordentry>

</wordgroup1>
<wordgroup1 type="a" object="ky"><alpha>K Y</alpha>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Kyle(pn)"><f type="i">Kyle<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a County in the South part of
<f type="i">Scotland<f type="r">, by <f type="i">Bede<f type="r">, called <f type="i">Campus
Cyel<f type="r">, i. e. the field <f type="i">Ciel<f type="r">; this with other
Territories <f type="i">Eadbert<f type="r"> King of
<f type="i">Northumberland<f type="r"> annexed to his Kingdom.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="kyrie eleison(n)"><f type="i">Kyrie Eleison<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a form of solemne
invocation, used in
the Liturgy, or Service book, and signifieth in the Greek
tongue, Lord have mercy upon us.</xpln></wordentry>

</wordgroup1>
<wordgroup1 type="a" object="la"><alpha>L A</alpha>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="labarum(n)"><f type="i">LAbarum<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a military streamer, or
flag, also a Church Banner, or Ensigne.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Labda(pn)"><f type="i">Labda<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of <f type="i">Amphion<f type="r"> of
the Race of the <f type="i">Bacchid&aelig;<f type="r">, she being lame and
despised by the rest of the <f type="i">Bacchid&aelig;<f type="r">
married <f type="i">Aetion<f type="r">,
to whom she brought forth <f type="i">Cypselus<f type="r">, so called
from a certain Corn measure, wherein his mother hid him
from the ten men, whom the <f type="i">Corinthians<f type="r"> by a
publick decree ordained to kill him, because it had been
foretold by the Oracle that
a son of <f type="i">Labda<f type="r"> should invade the Tyranny of
<f type="i">Corinth<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="labdacism(n)"><f type="i">Labdacisme<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>see <xref><f type="i">Lambdacisme<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="labdanum(n)" lexeme="ladanum(n)"><f type="i">Labdanum<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Ladanum<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>a kinde of
sweet Gumme, taken from the leaves of a certain small
shrub, called <f type="i">Cistus Ledon<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="labefaction(n)"><f type="i">Labefaction<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> an enfeebling, or
making weak.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="label(n)"><f type="i">Labels<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>Ribbands hanging down upon
Garlands, or Crowns, made of flowrs, also little pieces of
parchment cut out longwayes,
and hanging upon Indentures, or other kinde of writings,
also <class type="register" subject="heraldry">in Heraldry</class> they are those lines, which hang down
from the file in an Escutcheon.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="labeon(n)"><f type="i">Labeons<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> blaber-lipped
persons.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Labienus(pn)"><f type="i">Labienus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>one of <f type="i">C&aelig;sars<f type="r"> Captains,
who did very famous actions under him in
<f type="i">Gallia<f type="r">, but when
the Civil wars broke out, fled from him to
<f type="i">Pompey<f type="r">'s party.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="labile(a)"><f type="i">Labile<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> slippery, apt to slip, or
fall.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="laborariis(n)"><f type="i">Laborariis<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the name of a Writ that lieth
against such as having not wherewith to live, do refuse to
serve.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="laboriosity(n)"><class type="unknown">&dagger;</class> <f type="i">Laboriosity<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> laboriousnesse, painfulnesse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="labour(n)"><f type="i">Labour<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a ship is said to <f type="i">Labour<f type="r">
in the Sea, when she rowles and tumbles very much, either
a Hull, or under Sail.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="labyrinth(n)"><f type="i">Labyrinth<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a Maze, or place made
with so many turnings and windings that a man once entered
in, cannot finde the way out, whereof the two most
famous were, that built by
<f type="i">Miris<f type="r"> King of <f type="i">Egypt<f type="r">, and that which
<f type="i">D&aelig;dalus<f type="r"> built for <f type="i">Minos<f type="r">, King of
<f type="i">Crete<f type="r">, it is also by <f type="i">Metaphor<f type="r">
used for any kinde of intanglement, or intricate
businesse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lac(n)"><f type="i">Lacca<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kinde of red Gumme, issuing from
certain Trees in <f type="i">Arabia<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="laceration(n)"><f type="i">Laceration<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a tearing, or

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lacert(n)"><f type="i">Lacert<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(Latin)</class> from <f type="i"><term lang="la">Lacerta</term><f type="r">, a

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="laches(n)"><f type="i">Laches<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="law">in Common-law</class>, signifieth

<f type="i">French<f type="r"> word <f type="i"><term lang="fr">Lasche</term><f type="r">, i. carelesse, or

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lachrymation(n)"><f type="i">Lachrymation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a weeping, or

not be discerned in the sand.</xpln></wordentry>

into a Reed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lashlite(n)"><f type="i">Laghslite<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="etymlang" lang="sx">a <f type="i">Saxon<f type="r"> word from

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="laical(a)"><f type="i">Laical<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to Lay-men, or such as have not to do in

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lair(n)"><f type="i">Laire<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="hawking and hunting">(a Term in hunting)</class> the place where

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lais(pn)"><f type="i">Lais<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a woman of <f type="i">Sicily<f type="r">, who going
to dwell at <f type="i">Corinth<f type="r">, became a very famous
strumpet, and exacted excessive rates for the prostitution
of her body, afterwards removing to <f type="i">Thessaly<f type="r">, she
was in such high request among the men of
<f type="i">Thessaly<f type="r">,
that the women out of envy killed her in the Temple of
<f type="i">Venus<f type="r">, it was by her instigation that
<f type="i">Alexander<f type="r"> the Great caused <f type="i">Persepo&shy;
lis<f type="r"> to be burnt.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Laius(pn)"><f type="i">Laius<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Labdacus<f type="r">, King
of <f type="i">Thebes<f type="r">, and the
father of <f type="i">Oedipus<f type="r">, see <xref target="Jocasta"><f type="i">Jocasta<f type="r">, or
<f type="i">Oedipus<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lake(n)"><f type="i">Lake<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kinde of red colour, <class type="register" subject="art">used in
painting</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lambeth(pn)"><f type="i">Lambith, q. Lomehith<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>i. e. a Lomy, or
Clayish rode, a Town in <f type="i">Surry<f type="r">, famous for a
stately Palace, belonging to the Arch-bishops of
<f type="i">Canterbury<f type="r">, first built by Arch-bishop
<f type="i">Baldwin<f type="r">, in the year 1183. in this place
<f type="i">Hardy-Canute<f type="r">, the <f type="i">Danish<f type="r"> King of
<f type="i">England<f type="r">, giving up himself wholy to luxurious
banquettings, &amp; costly intertainments
expired suddenly, in the midst of his debauchery, and
excessive Cups.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lambdacism(n)"><f type="i">Lambdacisme<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a pronouncing the

<f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Lambda</term><f type="r">, with greater force then it should
be.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lambdoid(n)"><f type="i">Lamdoides<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the hindermost seam of the

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lamia(pn)"><f type="i">Lami&aelig;<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> certain Female spirits, or

<f type="i">Lamia<f type="r">, a Concubine of <f type="i">Demetrius<f type="r">,

name of <f type="i">Lamia<f type="r"> Venus.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lammas Day(pn)"><f type="i">Lammas day<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the first of <f type="i">August<f type="r">,
so called, as some say, because the Priests, on this day,
were wont to gather their Tithe-Lambs, others take it <class lang="sx" type="etymlang">from
the <f type="i">Saxon<f type="r"> word <f type="i"><term lang="sx">Laffmess</term><f type="r">, i.
<f type="i">Breadmass<f type="r"></class>, it being kept as a feast of
Thanks-giving for the first fruits of the Corn, it is also
called Gule, or Yule of <f type="i">August<f type="r">, see <xref><f type="i">Gule<f type="r">
of <f type="i">August<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lampadios(pn)"><f type="i">Lampadios<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a constellation in the head of
<f type="i">Taurus<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lampas(n)"><f type="i">Lampasse<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>vulgarly called the Lampreys, a
disease in the mouth of a Horse, so named, because it is
cured by burning with a Lamp, or a hot Iron.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lampetia(pn)"><f type="i">Lampetia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>see <xref><f type="i">Ne&aelig;ra<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lampoon(n)"><f type="i">Lampoon<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kinde of Drolling Poem, or

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lanner(n)" lexeme="lanneret(n)"><f type="i">Lanner<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Lanneret<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>a kind of

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lantscape(n)" lexeme="paysage(n)"><f type="i">Lantskip, Landskip<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Paisage<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>a
description of Land as
far as may be seen above the Horison, by hills, valleys,
cities, woods, rivers, <f type="i">&amp;c.<f type="r"> in a mixt picture
which contains both persons, and the
description of a
Country, or any part of a Country; the persons are called
the Argument, the
Landskip the Parergon or By-work.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lanuginous(a)"><f type="i">Lanuginous<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> covered with Lanuge,
which is a soft thin down or cotten-like substance, which
groweth upon some kinds of fruit, also that which
appeareth upon the chins of young men before they come to
have perfect beards.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Laocoon(pn)"><f type="i">Laocoon<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Priamus<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Hecuba<f type="r">, and
Priest to <f type="i">Apollo<f type="r">, he was the first that disswaded
the <f type="i">Trojans<f type="r"> from receiving the great horse into
the walls, and strook his Spear so hard against it, that
the sound of the armes was heard within; whereupon it hath
been affirmed, that for his despising the gift of
<f type="i">Minerva<f type="r">, there came immediately
two great Serpents, and first devoured
his two children, afterwards himself.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Laodamia(pn)"><f type="i">Laodamia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of
<f type="i">Bellerophon<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Achemone<f type="r">,
she brought forth <f type="i">Sarpedon<f type="r"> King of <f type="i">Lycia<f type="r">
to <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">, who was inamoured
of her; at length having displeased
<f type="i">Diana<f type="r">, the goddesse shot her with her own
arrows.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Laodicea(pn)"><f type="i">Laodicea<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a City in <f type="i">Asia<f type="r"> the
Lesse, which became very wealthy by the great gifts of
divers rich Citizens, as <f type="i">Jeronymus<f type="r">, (who died
worth two thousand talents) <f type="i">Zeno<f type="r"> the Orator, and
his son <f type="i">Polemo<f type="r">, whom <f type="i">Augustus<f type="r"> advanced
to be a King.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Laodoche(pn)"><f type="i">Laodoche<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the wife of <f type="i">Protesilaus<f type="r">,
she died imbracing the dead body of her husband slain by
<f type="i">Hector<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Laodocus(pn)"><f type="i">Laodocus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Antenor<f type="r">, in
his shape <f type="i">Minerva<f type="r"> came into the Army of the
<f type="i">Trojans<f type="r">, and perswaded <f type="i">Pandarus<f type="r"> by
shooting at <f type="i">Menelaus<f type="r"> to break the league.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Laomedon(pn)"><f type="i">Laomedon<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a King of the <f type="i">Trojans<f type="r">,
he was the son of <f type="i">Ilus<f type="r">, and the father of
<f type="i">Priamus<f type="r">, to
divert a great pestilence which was sent upon the City,
because he had defrauded <f type="i">Neptune<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Apollo<f type="r"> of the wages he had promised them for
building the City walls, he was constrained to expose his
daughter <f type="i">Hesione<f type="r"> to be devoured by a Sea-monster,
promising <f type="i">Hercules<f type="r"> to give him his horses which
were of sacred race, on condition he would undertake to
free his daughter, which he having performed, and
<f type="i">Laomedon<f type="r"> going back from his word,
<f type="i">Hercules<f type="r"> made war against him, and took the City,
slew <f type="i">Laomedon<f type="r">, took <f type="i">Priamus<f type="r"> captive, and
gave <f type="i">Hesione<f type="r"> to <f type="i">Telamon<f type="r">, who was the
first man that skalled the walls.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lapicide(n)"><f type="i">Lapicide<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a stone-cutter, a hewer of
stones out of the quarry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lapidary(n)"><f type="i">Lapidary<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> one that pollisheth or
works in stones, a jeweller.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lapidation(n)"><f type="i">Lapidation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a stoning or putting to
death with stones hurled or slung.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lapidescence(n)"><f type="i">Lapidescence<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a waxing hard like
stone, or of a stony substance.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lapithae(pn)"><f type="i">Lapith&aelig;<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a people of <f type="i">Thessalie<f type="r">,
inhabiting the mountains <f type="i">Pindus<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Othrys<f type="r">, they were
governed by <f type="i">Pirithous<f type="r">, had great conflicts with
the <f type="i">Centaurs<f type="r">, and were the first that invented
bridles and saddles.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lapwing(n)"><f type="i">Lappewing<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kind of bird, so called from
the often clapping of its wings; it is also called a Houp,
and in French <f type="i"><term lang="fr">Lapouin</term><f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lapise(v)"><f type="i">Lappise<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>is when Greyhounds open their
mouths in their course, or Hounds in the liam or string, <class type="register" subject="hawking and hunting">a
term in Hunting</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lapse(n)"><f type="i">Lapse<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a slip or fall; It is also when
an original Patron departeth from the right of
presenting to a void. Benefice,
</page>

<page sig="Y4r">
by neglecting to present within 6 moneths unto the
ordinary.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="laqueary(n)"><f type="i">Laqueary<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> the roof of a chamber
vaulted.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lara(pn)"><f type="i">Lara<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the name of one of the Nimphs called
<f type="i">Naiades<f type="r">, the daughter of the
River <f type="i">Almon<f type="r">: she
was delivered to <f type="i">Mercury<f type="r"> to be carried to Hell
for revealing to <f type="i">Juno<f type="r"> the love of
<f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> to the Nimph <f type="i">Juturna<f type="r"> the sister
of <f type="i">Turnus<f type="r">; but <f type="i">Mercury<f type="r"> falling in love
with her by the way, lay with her, and begat twins called
<f type="i">Lares<f type="r"> or Household-gods,
who are also named <f type="i">Penates<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="larboard(n)"><f type="i">Larboard<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="navigation">a term in Navigation</class>, the left
side of a boat or ship.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="larceny(n)"><f type="i">Larcenie<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(from the French word
<f type="i"><term lang="fr">Larrecin</term>, i.<f type="r">
theft)</class> <class type="register" subject="law">a word used in Common-Law</class>, and is either great
larcenie, namely, when the
things stollen exceed the value of 12 pence, or <f type="i">petit
larcenie<f type="r">, when the things stollen exceed not such a
value.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="larch-tree(n)">The <f type="i">Larch-tree<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a tree so called from
<f type="i">Larissa<f type="r">, a City of <f type="i">Thessalie<f type="r"> where it
was first known. It hath leaves like the Pine-tree, and
beareth a kind of drug called Agaricum, which is of an
exhilarating nature.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="larew(n)"><f type="i">Lareow<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="sx" type="etymlang">(Sax.)</class> a Master.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lares(pn)"><f type="i">Lares<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>see <xref><f type="i">Lara<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="largesse(n)"><f type="i">Largesse<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> a free gift bestowed
upon any one; also liberality.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="largitional(n)"><f type="i">Largitional<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an officer that oversees the
bestowing of gifts.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Larius(pn)"><f type="i">Larius<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the greatest Lake in <f type="i">Italy<f type="r">,
vulgarly called <f type="i"><term lang="it">Lago
di Como</term><f type="r">, containing 60 miles from North to
South.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="larvated(a)"><f type="i">Larvated<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> masqued or visarded for

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lascivious(a)"><f type="i">Lascivious<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> of a wanton carriage,

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lask(n)"><f type="i">Lask<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a disease called in Greek

causing an immoderate loosenesse of the belly, and cometh
<class lang="la" type="etymlang">from the Latin word <f type="i"><term lang="la">Laxitas</term>, i.<f type="r">

wearinesse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lastage(n)"><f type="i">Lastage<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Lestage<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>a custom
challenged in Markets or Faires for carrying of things,
also the ballast of a ship; it cometh
<class lang="sx" type="etymlang">from the Saxon word <f type="i"><term lang="sx">Last</term><f type="r"></class>, which
signifieth a certain
kind of weight, also a burthen in general.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="latebrous(a)"><f type="i">Latebrous<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> full of <f type="i">Latebr&aelig;,
i.<f type="r"> dens, or hiding-holes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="latent(a)"><f type="i">Latent<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> lying hid.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lateral(a)"><f type="i">Lateral<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to the sides of
any thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lateranus(pn)"><f type="i">Lateranus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Patrician of <f type="i">Rome<f type="r">, so
called because he used to
skulk and hide himself, for the taking of his ease and
pleasure; he being designed Consul was slain by the
command of <f type="i">Nero<f type="r">, and many Ages after his houses
being very large and stately, were given by the
Emperour <f type="i">Constantine<f type="r">
to the Pope, and ever since it hath been called the
Laterane Palace.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="latericious(a)"><f type="i">Latericious<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> made of brick or
tile.</xpln></wordentry>

place.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="laticlave(n)"><f type="i">Laticlave<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>or cloak of the broad
nail, a kind of broad purple garment, which used to be a
badge of the Senatorian Order: a cloak of the narrow nail
was of the Equestrian or Knightly Order.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="latifolious(a)"><f type="i">Latifolious<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> having broad
leaves.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Latimer(pn)"><f type="i">Latimer<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the name of a Town and
Barony in <f type="i">Bucchinghamshire<f type="r">, as also of several great
Families in this Nation. This word, according as
<f type="i">Cambden<f type="r"> observes, signifying
as much as <f type="i">Truchman<f type="r">, or
<f type="i">Interpreter<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="latinity(n)"><f type="i">Latinity<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> an incorrupt speaking or
pronouncing of the Latin tongue.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Latinus(pn)"><f type="i">Latinus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an ancient King of <f type="i">Italy<f type="r">,
the son of <f type="i">Faunus<f type="r">
and <f type="i">Marita<f type="r">, he married his daughter
<f type="i">Lavinia<f type="r"> whom he had by
<f type="i">Amata<f type="r"> sister of <f type="i">Faunus<f type="r"> King of the <f type="i">Rutuli<f type="r">, to
<f type="i">Aeneas<f type="r"> when he came into <f type="i">Italy<f type="r">;
whereupon <f type="i">Turnus<f type="r"> to whom she had formerly been betrothed,
waged war against his Rival, and was slain in single
combat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lation(n)"><f type="i">Lation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a bearing or
carrying.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="latitancy(n)" lexeme="latitation(n)"><f type="i">Latitancy<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Latitation<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a
lurking or lying hid.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="latitat(n)"><f type="i">Latitat<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the name of a Writ, whereby all
men in personal actions are called
originally to the Kings
Bench, because a man is supposed <f type="i">latitare, i.<f type="r"> to
lie hid.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="latitude(n)"><f type="i">Latitude<f type="r"></form>. <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> breadth or
widenesse, <class type="register" subject="astrology and astronomy">in Astronomy</class> the latitude of a star is, the
Arch of a great Circle made by the Poles of the Ecliptick,
intercepted between the star and the Ecliptick. The
latitude of a place is the Arch of the Meridian
intercepted between the Equinoctial and the Zenith of the place given.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="latomy(n)"><f type="i">Latomy<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a Quarry or place whence
they hew out stones for building.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Latona(pn)"><f type="i">Latona<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of <f type="i">C&aelig;us<f type="r">,
one of the <f type="i">Titans<f type="r">, she was got with child by
<f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">, which thing so incensed <f type="i">Juno<f type="r">, that
</page>

<page sig="Y4v">
she sent the Serpent <f type="i">Pytho<f type="r"> to slay her;
whereupon she fled to her sister <f type="i">Asteria<f type="r">, where
she was delivered of twins, <f type="i">Apollo<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Diana<f type="r">; but <f type="i">Diana<f type="r"> being first brought
forth, she immediately served her mother instead of a
Midwife, and helped to bring her to bed of her brother
<f type="i">Apollo<f type="r">, who as soon as he was come to age,
killed the Serpent
<f type="i">Pytho; Apollo<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Diana<f type="r"> being
commonly taken for the
Sun and Moon, are called Latonian Lights.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="latration(n)"><f type="i">Latration<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a barking.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="latria(n)"><f type="i">Latrie<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> Divine-worship or
service of God.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="latrocination(n)"><f type="i">Latrocination<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a committing of

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lavacre(n)"><f type="i">Lavacre<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a washing vessel, also a

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lavatrine(n)"><f type="i">Lavatrine<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a square stone in a

a sinke.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="laudable(a)"><f type="i">Laudable<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> worthy of praise or

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lauds(n)"><f type="i">Lauds<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> commendations or praises,
also certain Psalms of <f type="i">David<f type="r">, beginning with
these words <f type="i"><term lang="la">Laudate dominum</term><f type="r">, which use to be
recited by the Roman Catholicks
between the Nocturns and the Howres, which are certain
other prayers or psalms so called.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lauden(pn)" lexeme="Lothien(pn)"><f type="i">Lauden<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Lothien<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>a Country in

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lavedan(n)"><f type="i">Lavedan<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an iron-grey Gennet, so
called because it is bred
on Lavedon, one of the <f type="i">Pyrenean<f type="r"> Mountains,
whereon the best horses of <f type="i">France<f type="r"> are
bred.</xpln>

Not found in OED.

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lavender(n)"><f type="i">Lavender<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kind of plant, otherwise called

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="laver(n)" lexeme="ewer(n)"><f type="i">Laver<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Ewer<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><emend err="or" source="errata">a</emend> vessel to wash
in, <class lang="la" type="etymlang">from the Latin word <f type="i"><term lang="la">Lavare</term>, i.<f type="r"> to
