<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lord(n)"><f type="i">Laverd<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Loverd<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class type="old word">(old word)</class>
Lord.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Laverna(pn)"><f type="i">Laverna<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain goddesse worshipped by
the ancient Romans, accounted the Patronesse of Theeves,
who were thence called <f type="i">Laverniones<f type="r">; to her they
built a Temple called <f type="i">Lavernium<f type="r">, from whence one
of the gates of <f type="i">Rome<f type="r"> near which it stood, was
called <f type="i">Por a Lavernalis<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lavinia(pn)"><f type="i">Lavinia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the wife of <f type="i">Aeneas<f type="r">, from
whose name the City <f type="i">Lavinium<f type="r"> had its
denomination. see more in <xref target="Latinus"><f type="i">Latinus<f type="r">, and <f type="i">Tyrrheus<f type="r">.</xref></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lancelet(n)" lexeme="Lancelot(pn)"><f type="i">Launcelot<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="medicine">a Chirurgians Instrument</class> used in
letting blood, otherwise called a Fleam, and in Italian
<f type="i"><term lang="it">Lancetta</term><f type="r">; also a proper name. see <xref><f type="i">Lancelot<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lancepesade(n)"><f type="i">Launcepesado<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Lancepresado<f type="r">,</form>
<xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> the lowest officer in a Foot-company, or he that
commands over a maniple, which is a Band of 10
souldiers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="laund(n)" lexeme="lawn in a park(n)"><f type="i">Laund<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Lawn<f type="r"> in a Park,</form> <xpln><class lang="it" type="etymlang"> (Ital.)</class>
plain untilled ground.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lavolta(n)"><f type="i">Lavolta<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="it" type="etymlang">(Ital.)</class> a course held in sailing,
also a kind of dance.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="laureate(a)"><f type="i">Laureat<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> crowned with Laurel, or the
bay-tree, which used to be worn by Conquerours in token of
Triumph, also laureated letters, were letters wrapt up in
Laurel or Bay-leaves, which the Roman Captains were wont
to send unto the Senate, to give them notice of their
Victories. This plant is said to be proof against thunder
and lightning.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="laurels(n)"><f type="i">Laurells<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>by a <class type="register" subject="rhetoric">figure</class> called Metonymy, is
ofttimes used for Triumph or Victory.
<f type="i">Cleop.<f type="r"></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Laurence, St.(pn)">St. <f type="i">Laurence<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the name of a famous Martyr,
who being a Deacon and Questor of the Roman church, and
being commanded by
<f type="i">Valerian<f type="r"> the Prefect of the City to produce the
Treasures of the Church which <f type="i">Sextus<f type="r"> committed to
his charge, he assembled together the poor, the lame, and
the sick, and told the officers
those were the Treasures of the Church; whereupon the
Prefect thinking he was
deluded, commanded he should be broiled upon a Gridiron,
and <f type="i">Laurence<f type="r"> as soon as he was almost ready to
give up the ghost, said to the Prefect standing by, now
turn me on the other side, this is broiled enough. This
name is derived <class lang="la" type="etymlang">from the Latin word <f type="i"><term lang="la">Laurus</term>, i.<f type="r"> a
Laurel or Bay-tree</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Laurentia, Acca(pn)">Acca <f type="i">Laurentia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the wife of <f type="i">Faustulus<f type="r">,
Shepherd of <f type="i">Amulius<f type="r"> King of the
<f type="i">Latins<f type="r">, she took <f type="i">Romulus<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Remus<f type="r"> (the grandchildren
of <f type="i">Numitor<f type="r">, whom his brother <f type="i">Amulius<f type="r">
had expelled the Kingdom) and nursed them up secretly as
her own, they being brought to her by her husband
<f type="i">Faustulus<f type="r">,
who found them sucking of a Wolf at the root of a
Fig-tree from thence called
<f type="i">Ruminalis<f type="r">, upon the banks of <f type="i">Tyber<f type="r">,
into which they had been cast by the command of
<f type="i">Amulius<f type="r">. Others say that the story of their
being fostered by a Wolf ariseth from hence, namely that
this woman from the gain
she made by the prostitution
of her body, was called <f type="i">Lupa<f type="r">, who dying very
rich, had divine honours
</page>

<page sig="Z1r">
given her by the people of <f type="i">Rome<f type="r">, and
festival dayes kept,
which were called <f type="i">Laurentalia<f type="r">;
and from her other name <f type="i">Lupa<f type="r"> those houses of
intertainment are called <f type="i">Lupanaria<f type="r">.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lauriferous(a)"><f type="i">Lauriferous<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> bearing Laurel, or Bays.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lausus(pn)"><f type="i">Lausus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Numitor<f type="r">, and brother of <f type="i">Rhea
Silvia<f type="r">, he was slain by his Uncle <f type="i">Amulius<f type="r">,
after his father had been banisht the Kingdom, also the
son of <f type="i">Mezentius<f type="r">, King of the
<f type="i">Hetrurians<f type="r">, was so called, whom <f type="i">Aeneas<f type="r">
slew, as he went about to rescue his father, he was a
famous hunter of wilde beasts.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="law of arms(n)"><f type="i">Law<f type="r"> of Arms</form>, <xpln>a Law that giveth
precepts how rightly to
proclaim war, to make and observe leagues, to set upon the
enemy, to punish offenders in the camp,
<f type="i">&amp;c.<f type="r"></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="law of marque(n)"><f type="i">Law<f type="r"> of Marque</form>, <xpln>Mart, or reprisal, is that
whereby men take the goods of that
people of whom they have
received wrong, and cannot get ordinary Justice, when ever
they can catch them within their own Territories, or
limits.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

Common-law of <f type="i">England<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="leach(n)"><f type="i">Leach<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="old word">(old word)</class> a Physitian.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="league(n)"><f type="i">A league<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain proportion of ground in
length onely, consisting of about two, or three miles, it
is called in Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Leuco</term><f type="r">, <class lang="gk" type="etymlang">from the Greek word
<f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Leucos</term><f type="r">, i. e. white</class>, because formerly the end of
every league used to be noted with a white stone, whence
<f type="i"><term lang="la">ad primum aut secundum lapidem ab urbe</term><f type="r">, at the
first, or second stone from the Citie, was as much as to
say, one, or two leagues from the Citie. League is also
derived <class lang="la" type="etymlang">from the Latin word <f type="i"><term lang="la">Ligare</term><f type="r">, and
signifieth an agreement, Pact, or Covenant</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lady(n)"><f type="i">Leafdian<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Hleafdian<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="sx" type="etymlang">(Sax.)</class> a
Lady.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="leam(n)"><f type="i">Leam<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a line to hold a Dogge in, it is also
called a <f type="i">Leash<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Leander(pn)"><f type="i">Leander<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a noble youth of <f type="i">Abydos<f type="r">,
a Town in <f type="i">Asia<f type="r">, situated upon the shore of the
<f type="i">Hellespont<f type="r">, he being in love with <f type="i">Hero<f type="r">,
one of <f type="i">Venus<f type="r"> Nuns, who dwelt in <f type="i">Sestos<f type="r">,
a Town of the opposite bank, used to swim over to her in
the night time, which having done several times without
danger, at length in his
passage over, he was orewhelmed by a storm, and drowned in
the <f type="i">Hellespont<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Learchus(pn)"><f type="i">Learchus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Athamas<f type="r">, King
of <f type="i">Thebes<f type="r">,
and <f type="i">Ino<f type="r">, the daughter of <f type="i">Cadmus<f type="r">, he was
slain by his father, who in a raging madnesse, took him
for a Lyons whelp, whereupon <f type="i">Ino<f type="r"> fled with her
other son <f type="i">Melicerta<f type="r">, &amp; both of them cast themselves into the Sea, and were
changed into Sea gods, and called by the Greeks
<f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Leucothea</term><f type="r"> &amp; <f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Paloemon</term><f type="r">,
by the Latins <f type="i"><term lang="la">Matuta</term><f type="r"> &amp;
<f type="i"><term lang="la">Portumnus</term><f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lease(n)"><f type="i">Lease<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="law">a word used in Common-law</class>, and
signifieth a demising, or letting of Lands, or Tenements,
or right of a Rent, unto another for term of years, or of
life, or for a Rent reserved, if it be in writing it is
called a Lease by indenture, if by word of mouth, a Lease
Parole, the party that letteth
the Lease, is called the <f type="i">Leassour<f type="r">, the party that
taketh it, the <f type="i">Leassee<f type="r">, <class lang="fr" type="etymlang">being derived from the
French word <f type="i"><term lang="fr">Laisser</term><f type="r">, i. to leave, or
permit</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<f type="i">Laconia<f type="r">, she being got with Childe by
<f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">, (who to deceive her transformed himself

other <f type="i">Castor<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Clytemnestra<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<f type="i">Bartho&shy;
lomew<f type="r"> Lord <f type="i">Baldismer<f type="r"> fortified against King
<f type="i">Edward<f type="r"> the second, who had freely
given it him, whereupon he
lost his life; also a place in <f type="i">York-shire<f type="r">, where

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="leet(n)"><f type="i">Leet<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="sx" type="etymlang">(Sax.)</class> a Law-day whence Court
<f type="i">Leet<f type="r">, is a Court, or Jurisdiction,
containing the third
part of a Shire, and comprehending
three, or four wapen-takes, or hundreds, the
<f type="i">Leets<f type="r"> were called by the Romans <f type="i">Fasti<f type="r">,
wherein the <f type="i">Pr&aelig;tor<f type="r">
might lawfully keep Court, and administer
Justice, which was not
done without the speaking of these three words, <f type="i"><term lang="la">Do,
Dico, Addico</term><f type="r">,
i. e. I give, <f type="i">viz.<f type="r"> way to actions and suites. I
speak, <f type="i">viz.<f type="r"> the Law. I Judge, <f type="i">viz.<f type="r">
matters and men.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="legion(n)"><f type="i">Legion<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a Company of Souldiers,
among the ancient <f type="i">Romans<f type="r">, consisting of three, or
four thousand foot, and three, or four hundred horse,
afterwards being increased
to six thousand foot, and six hundred
horse, every ordinary foot Legion consisting of ten
Cohorts, every Cohort of three Maniples, every Maniple of
two Centuries, &amp; each Century of a 100 men, likewise
every horse Legion contained six <f type="i">Turm&aelig;<f type="r">, or
Troupes, every Troup ten <f type="i">Decuries<f type="r">, and every
<f type="i">Decury<f type="r"> ten
men; also there are in every Legion four Orders of
Souldiers, the <f type="i">Triarii<f type="r">,
the <f type="i">Principes<f type="r">, the <f type="i">Hastati<f type="r">, or Spearmen,
the <f type="i">Velites<f type="r">, or light-armed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="legionary(a)"><f type="i">Legionary<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to a

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Leicester(pn)"><f type="i">Leicester<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the chief Citie of
<f type="i">Leicestershire<f type="r">,
called also <f type="i">Legeocester, Leogora<f type="r">, and
<f type="i">Legecestria<f type="r">,
this Citie was besieged by King <f type="i">Henry<f type="r"> the third,
(when Earle <f type="i">Robert<f type="r"> rebelled
against him) and the Wall round about it utterly
demolish't.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Leinster(pn)"><f type="i">Leinster<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Province in <f type="i">Ireland<f type="r">,

Weshford, Dublin<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="leman(n)"><f type="i">Leman<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Concubine, or Catamite,
(<f type="i"><term lang="la">Pullus Jovis</term><f type="r"> Latin) some say it comes <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">from the
French word <f type="i"><term lang="fr">Le mignon</term><f type="r">, or Leyman, as
it were ly by man</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lemannus(pn)"><f type="i">Lemannus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the Lake <f type="i">Leman<f type="r">, upon
which stands the Citie of <f type="i">Geneva<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lemnos(pn)"><f type="i">Lemnos<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an Island in the <f type="i">Aegean<f type="r">
Sea, famous for the fall of
<f type="i">Vulcan<f type="r">, who by reason
of his deformity, being thrown down from heaven, as soon
as he was born, hapned to
light in this place, whence he was called the
<f type="i">Lemnian<f type="r"> God, this Island was originally known by
the name of <f type="i">Hipsipyl&aelig;a<f type="r">,
from a daughter of <f type="i">Thoas<f type="r"> of that name, who was
Queen thereof.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lemster(pn)"><f type="i">Lemster<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town of <f type="i">Herefordshire<f type="r">,
so called <f type="i">q. Leonminster<f type="r">, from a Lyon that
appeared to a certain religious man as some have fabled,
others more probably derive it from a Church of Nuns built
by <f type="i">Merwalck<f type="r">, a King of the
<f type="i">Mercians<f type="r">; for those which we call Nuns, the ancient
<f type="i">Brittains<f type="r"> termed <f type="i">Leans<f type="r">, some there are
that derive it from <f type="i">Line<f type="r">, whereof the best sort
groweth there, this Town is now adayes very famous for
Wool, which is called <f type="i">Lemster Ore<f type="r">; it was defaced
by <f type="i">W. de Breosa<f type="r">, Lord of <f type="i">Brecknock<f type="r">, when
he revolted from King <f type="i">John<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lemur(n)"><f type="i">Lemures<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> certain spirits, or
apparitions, vulgarly
called <f type="i">Hobgoblins<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lentigenous(a)"><f type="i">Lentigenous<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to
Lentills which are a kind
of round and flat pulse growing in hot Countries, also
full of little pimples or freckles resembling
Lentills.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lentisk(n)"><f type="i">Lentisk<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a kind of tree called the
Mastick-tree, from which there is taken a Gum of very
great vertue.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lentitude(n)"><f type="i">Lentitude<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> slacknesse, slownesse, or
negligence.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lentor(n)"><f type="i">Lentour<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> stiffnesse, or
clammynesse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lent season(pn)"><f type="i">Lent-season<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(in Lat.
<f type="i">Quadragesima<f type="r">)</class> a Fast of fourty dayes, instituted
by the Church, and first appointed to be kept in
<f type="i">England<f type="r"> by <f type="i">Ercombert<f type="r"> a King of
<f type="i">Kent<f type="r">. It comes <class lang="du" type="etymlang">from the Dutch word <f type="i"><term lang="du">Lente</term>,
i.<f type="r"> Spring</class>, because it ever happens to be
about the beginning of the
Spring time, or as others say, from length, because about
this time the dayes begin to lengthen.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Leo(pn)"><f type="i">Leo<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the name of several Roman
Emperours reigning at
<f type="i">Constantinople<f type="r">; also the name of several Popes of
<f type="i">Rome<f type="r">, also one of the 12 Signes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Leocorion(pn)"><f type="i">Leocorion<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Monument erected by the
<f type="i">Athenians<f type="r">, in honour of <f type="i">Leo<f type="r"> the son of
<f type="i">Orpheus<f type="r">, who when no body else would permit their
daughters to be sacrificed to the gods to divert a great
pestilence which then raged in the City, willingly
consented to the offering up of his three daughters,
<f type="i">Pasithea, Theope<f type="r">, and <f type="i">Eubule<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Leodegar(pn)" lexeme="Leger(pn)"><f type="i">Leodegar<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Leger<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class type="etymlang" lang="gr">a German
proper name</class>, signifying a gatherer of the people.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Leodium(pn)"><f type="i">Leodium<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous City of Germany,
anciently called <f type="i"><term lang="un">Ebur num Augusta</term><f type="r">, and is said to
have been built by <f type="i">Ambioriges<f type="r">, a King of
<f type="i">Germany<f type="r">, who also called it <f type="i">Legia<f type="r">, from
the cutting off of a Roman Legion in a valley near unto
it; at this day it is named <f type="i">Luttich<f type="r"> or
<f type="i">Leige<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Leofstan(pn)"><f type="i">Leofstan<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>i. most beloved, <class lang="sx" type="etymlang">a Saxon name
<f type="i"><term lang="sx">Leofwin</term><f type="r">, i. <f type="i">Winlove<f type="r"></class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="leoh(a)"><f type="i">Leoh<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="sx" type="etymlang">(Sax.)</class> light.</xpln>

</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Leonard(pn)"><f type="i">Leonard<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the proper name of a man,
signifying in Dutch
popular disposition as <f type="i">Lipsius<f type="r"> will have it; but
as others say, Lion-like disposition, answering to the
Greek name <f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Thymoleon</term><f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Leonidas(pn)"><f type="i">Leonidas<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous Captain and King of the
<f type="i">Lacedemonians<f type="r">, who defending the Streights of
<f type="i">Thermopyl&aelig;<f type="r"> against the whole Army of
<f type="i">Xerxes<f type="r">, was himself slain,
together with all his men.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="leonine(a)"><f type="i">Leonine<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to, or like a
Lion.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="leopard(n)" lexeme="libberd(n)"><f type="i">Leopard<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Libberd<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>a certain
<f type="i">African<f type="r"> beast, otherwise called a
<f type="i">Panther<f type="r">: this beast is all over full of streakes
or little spots, and is begotten between a Pard and a
Lionesse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Leopold(pn)" lexeme="Leodpold(pn)"><f type="i">Leopold, q. Leodpold<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the proper name of a
man, <class type="etymlang" lang="du">signifying in Dutch</class> Defender of the people, being in
imitation of the Greek names <f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Demochares</term><f type="r">, i.
gracious to the people, and <f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Demophilus</term><f type="r">, i. a
lover of the people, and <f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Laodamus</term><f type="r">, i. tamer of
the people: the chief of this name was
<f type="i">Leopoldus<f type="r">
Arch-Duke of <f type="i">Austria<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="leorning-cniht(n)"><f type="i">Leorning cnight<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="sx" type="etymlang">(Sax.)</class> a disciple or scholar.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lepid(a)"><f type="i">Lepid<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> neat, jocund, pleasant in

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="leporine(a)"><f type="i">Leporine<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to a

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="leprosy(n)"><f type="i">Leprosie<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a kind of disease which
causeth a white scurfe to run all over the body; it is
also termed <f type="i">Elephantiasis<f type="r">,
from the roughnesse of an Elephants skin, which it
resembleth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lerna(pn)"><f type="i">Lerna<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Lake near the City of
<f type="i">Argos<f type="r">, where the Serpent <f type="i">Hydra<f type="r"> was slain
by <f type="i">Hercules<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lesbos(pn)"><f type="i">Lesbos<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an Island in the <f type="i">Aeg&aelig;an<f type="r">
Sea, which in old time obtained the Empire of all
<f type="i">Troas<f type="r">. It is now called <f type="i">Metelin<f type="r">, from
the chief City thereof <f type="i">Mitylene<f type="r">, the rest were
<f type="i">Eressos, Antissa, Portus, Methymna<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lesinage(n)"><f type="i">Lesinage<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="it" type="etymlang">(Ital)</class> thriftinesse,

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lestrigones(pn)"><f type="i">Lestrigones<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>or <f type="i">L&aelig;strigones<f type="r">,
a certain barbarous people, and of a vast Giant-like
stature, that anciently inhabited
<f type="i">Formi&aelig;<f type="r"> a City
of <f type="i">Campania<f type="r">, and were said to live upon Human
flesh, their King <f type="i">Antiphates<f type="r">
oppos'd <f type="i">Vlisses<f type="r"> with all his might when he
landed on that coast, and tore
</page>

<page sig="Z2v">
one of his companions in pieces with his teeth.
</xpln></wordentry>

<f type="i">Lethe<f type="r"> a River of Hell, which the Poets feign to

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="letters of attorney(n)"><f type="i">Letters of Atturney<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>writings whereby an
Atturney or any friend made choice of for that purpose, is
appointed to do a lawful act in anothers stead, from which
warrants of Atturny
differ in this, that besides being sealed and delivered
before sufficient witnesse, they must also be acknowledged
before a Justice or Serjeant.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="letters of mart(n)" lexeme="letters of marque(n)"><f type="i">Letters of Mart<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Marque<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>are
Letters which authorize any one to take by force of armes
those goods which are due by the Law of Marque. see <xref>Law of
Marque.</xref></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="letters patents(n)"><f type="i">Letters Patents<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>are writings sealed open
with the Broad-Seal of <f type="i">England<f type="r">, whereby a man is
authorized to do or injoy any thing which of himself he
could not, <class lang="la" type="etymlang">from the Latin word <f type="i"><term lang="la">patere</term>, i.<f type="r"> to lie
open</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lettice(pn)"><f type="i">Lettice<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Christian name of severall

joyfulnesse,
mirth</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lettuce(n)"><f type="i">Lettice<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kind of plant called in Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Lactuca</term><f type="r">, because in women that eat of it, it
breedeth milk.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="levament(n)" lexeme="levation(n)"><f type="i">Levament<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Levation<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> an

up or causing to rise.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="levant(a)" lexeme="couchant(a)"><f type="i">Levant<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Couchant<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class>
<class type="register" subject="law">terms used in Common Law</class>, when the beasts or cattel of a

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Leucothoe(pn)"><f type="i">Leucothoe<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of
<f type="i">Orchamus<f type="r"> King of the Babylonians, with whom
<f type="i">Apollo<f type="r"> being in
love, transformed himself into the shape of
<f type="i">Eurynome<f type="r"> her mother, &amp; pretending private
businesse with her, he re-assumed his former shape, and
won her by fair speeches to consent to his desires;
whereupon <f type="i">Clytia<f type="r">, who was in love with
<f type="i">Apollo<f type="r">, growing extreamly envious,
declared the whole
businesse to <f type="i">Orchamus<f type="r">, who in a great fury caused
his daughter to be buried alive, whose death
<f type="i">Apollo<f type="r"> grieving
at, transformed her into the Frankincense-tree,
and <f type="i">Clytia<f type="r"> seeing her self contemned of
<f type="i">Apollo<f type="r">, pined her self away, and was turned into
a Marygold.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Leuctra(pn)"><f type="i">Leuctra<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town in <f type="i">Boeotia<f type="r">, where
the <f type="i">Thebans<f type="r"> under <f type="i">Epaminondas<f type="r"> gave the
<f type="i">Lacedemonians<f type="r">
so total an overthrow, that they could never after recover
themselves.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="level-coil(n)"><f type="i">Level-Coil<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> is, when he that hath
lost the game sits out, and gives
another his place, as it
were <f type="i"><term lang="fr">lever le cul</term><f type="r">, i. to lift up or remove the
buttock; it is also called Hitchbuttock.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="levy(n)"><f type="i">Levie<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> signifieth <class type="register" subject="law">in Common Law</class>,

gather money.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="libertas(n)"><f type="i">Libertas<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a priviledge held by grant

some benefit or favour beyond the

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="libertatibus allocandis(n)"><f type="i">Libertatibus allocandis<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Writ that lieth
for a Citizen or Burgesse of a City, who refusing or
deferring to allow his priviledge,
is impleaded before the Kings Justices.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="libertinism(n)"><f type="i">Libertinism<f type="r"></form> <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> the state and
condition of a
Libertine, <f type="i">i. e.<f type="r"> one born or made free, a
freeman; also <f type="i">Libertinism<f type="r">, or
<f type="i">Libertinage<f type="r">, is taken for sensuality,
licentiousnesse,
a dissolute life and conversation.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Libethra(pn)"><f type="i">Libethra<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town seated upon the mountain
<f type="i">Olympus<f type="r">, of which it was
foretold by the Oracle, that all the inhabitants
should be destroyed by a Sow, when the Sun should behold
<f type="i">Orpheus<f type="r"> his bones, which was thus verified; A
great multitude of
people being gathered together to hear a Shepherd sing in
the way which leadeth from <f type="i">Dion<f type="r"> to
<f type="i">Olympus<f type="r">, a large Urn containing <f type="i">Orpheus<f type="r">
his bones, which stood in that place, was overturned and
his bones laid open to view, and the very same day, a
great violent stream called <f type="i">Sys<f type="r"> (which in Greek
signifieth a Sow) overflowing, destroyed the whole Town
with all the people in it. <f type="i">Libethra<f type="r"> is also the
name of a Fountain of <f type="i">Magnesia<f type="r">, sacred to the
Muses who are thence called <f type="i">Libethrides<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="libidinous(a)"><f type="i">Libidinous<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> sensual, incontinent,
full of lustful desires.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Libitina(pn)"><f type="i">Libitina<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an ancient goddesse worshipt by
the Romans, who was the Patronesse of Funerals,
Sepulchres, and all things belonging to the dead.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Libral(a)"><f type="i">Libral<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to a weight or
measure called Libra, which is also the name of one of the
12 Signs of the Zodiack
into which the Sun entring, causeth the <emend err="vernal" source="errata">autumnal</emend> 
Equinoctial.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="library(n)"><f type="i">Library<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a studdy, or place where
Books are kept.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="libration(n)"><f type="i">Libration<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a weighing, or
ballancing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="librata terrae(n)"><f type="i">Librata terr&aelig;<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>see Farding deale of
land.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Libya(pn)"><f type="i">Libya<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the fourth part of the World,
commonly called <f type="i">Africa<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="licence to arise(n)"><f type="i">Licence to arise<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="law">in Common Law</class>, is a
liberty given by the Court to a tenant that is essoynd
<f type="i">de malo lecti<f type="r"> in a reall action, after he hath
been viewed by Knights thereunto appointed, until which
time, if the Demandant can prove that he hath been seen
out of his chamber, or walking up and down his grounds, he
shall be adjudged to be deceitfully
essoyned.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="licentiate(n)"><f type="i">Licentiate<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> one that hath full
licence or authority to practice in any Art; the same with
him that we commonly call Bachelour of Divinity, or of
Physick, or of Civil Law, and in Common Law a
Barrister.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="licentious(a)"><f type="i">Licentious<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> loose, disorderly,
unruly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lichas(pn)"><f type="i">Lichas<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a boy that waited upon
<f type="i">Hercules<f type="r">, by him <f type="i">Deianira<f type="r"> sent the
shirt that was dipt in the <f type="i">Centaurs<f type="r"> blood, which
<f type="i">Hercules<f type="r">
having put on, and perceiving the
</page>

<page sig="Z3v">
venome to seize upon his body, he in a
fury took <f type="i">Lichas<f type="r">
by the hair of the head and flung him into the Sea,
where he was immediately
changed into a Rock.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lichfield(pn)"><f type="i">Lichfield<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town in
<f type="i">Staffordshire<f type="r">, by <f type="i">Bede<f type="r"> called
<f type="i">Licidfield<f type="r">, i. the field of dead bodies, from a
great number of people, who as some say were martyred here
in the time of <f type="i">Dioclesian<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lich-fowl(n)"><f type="i">Lich-fowles<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>ominous, or ill-boding birds,
as the Night-raven, and <f type="i">Lich-owle<f type="r">, commonly
called the <f type="i">Scritch-owle<f type="r">, the word <f type="i"><term lang="sx">Lich</term><f type="r">,
signifying <class lang="sx" type="etymlang">in the <f type="i">Saxon<f type="r">
language</class> a Carcase, or dead body.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lictorian(a)"><f type="i">Lictorian<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to the

Officers among the ancient Romans twelve in number, who
carried the Axes and bundles of rods before the
Magistrate, they are now taken for the same as we commonly

lift.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lincoln(pn)"><f type="i">Lincoln<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the chief Citie of
<f type="i">Lincolnshire<f type="r">, anciently called <f type="i">Lindum<f type="r">,
and by the Brittains <f type="i"><term lang="br">Lindecoit</term><f type="r">, by <f type="i">Bede <term lang="la">Lindecollina
civitas</term><f type="r">, <class type="etymlang" lang="br">from the old Brittish <f type="i"><term lang="br">Lhin</term><f type="r"></class>,
as <f type="i">Cambden<f type="r"> is of opinion, which signifieth a Lake, it
</page>

<page sig="Z4r">
being situate near a Lake, and upon a hill, in this
Citie <f type="i">Vortimer<f type="r">, the scourge of the
<f type="i">Saxons<f type="r"> ended his dayes.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Linus(pn)"><f type="i">Linus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Apollo<f type="r">, and
<f type="i">Psammas<f type="r">, the daughter of <f type="i">Crotopus<f type="r">, King
of <f type="i">Argos<f type="r">, by whom <f type="i">Apollo<f type="r"> being
intertained as he came from slaying the Serpent
<f type="i">Pytho<f type="r">, lay privately with <f type="i">Psammas<f type="r">, who
proving with Childe brought forth <f type="i">Linus<f type="r">, who
having committed some offence, and hiding
himself among certain
bushes, was found out and torn in pieces by the Dogs, also
the son of <f type="i">Apollo<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Terpsichore<f type="r">,
one of the nine Muses, he proved a very famous
Musitian, taught <f type="i">Thamyras, Orpheus<f type="r">, and
<f type="i">Hercules<f type="r">, by
whom, as some say, he was knockt on the head, because he
laught at him for playing unhandsomely.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lynx(n)"><f type="i">Linx<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a kinde of spotted beast,

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lizard(n)"><f type="i">Lisard<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Lizard<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French,</class> <class lang="la" type="etymlang">from
the Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Lacerta</term><f type="r">)</class>
a certain beast, so called because
it hath feet like the brawne, or
sinews of a mans arms, or
thighs, also the <f type="i">Lizard<f type="r"> point, the utmost
Southwest point of <f type="i">Cornwall<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

directed in their
voyages: It is of a rusty-iron colour, and hath the vertue
to attract or draw iron to
it, whereby many admirable secrets are performed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lodeworks and stremeworks(n)"><f type="i">Lodeworkes and Stremeworks<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>certain workes

in the higher grounds by making deep wells which
they call shafts, those in the lower grounds by digging of

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="logarithm(n)"><f type="i">Logarithmes<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> are certain
borrowed numbers which
differ among themselves
by Arithmetical proportion as the numbers which borrow
them differ by Geometrical proportion.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="log-line(n)"><f type="i">Log-line<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="navigation">a term in Navigation</class>, being a
small line with a little piece of board at the end, with a
little lead to it, to keep it edge-long in the water, the
use of which is, by seeing how many fathom this runs in a
minute, to give a judgement how many leagues the ship will
run in a watch.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="logician(n)"><f type="i">Logician<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> one that hath skill <class type="register" subject="logic">in
Logick</class>, <f type="i">i.<f type="r"> the art of disputing
probably in any argument.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="logist(n)"><f type="i">Logist<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> one skilled in the
Logistick Art, <f type="i">i.<f type="r"> the Art of reckoning or casting account; also
Logists were certain Officers among the <f type="i">Athenians<f type="r">
ten in number, to whom all
such as had ended their Magistracy gave an account within
30 dayes of all those affairs whereof they had had the
administration, they also kept an account of the monies,
and of all matters belonging to the publick
Revenue.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="logographer(n)"><f type="i">Logographers<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> those that write
pleas in the Law, or books of account, Lawyers Clerks.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lollards(pn)"><f type="i">Lollards<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Sect of Hereticks that
abounded here in
<f type="i">England<f type="r"> in the dayes of
<f type="i">Edward<f type="r"> the third,
and <f type="i">Henry<f type="r"> the fifth; so called from one
<f type="i">Gualter Lollard<f type="r"> a German the first Author of
them: or as others say, from <f type="i">lolium<f type="r">, because they
were accounted as darnel
or cockle growing among
wheat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lombard(pn)" lexeme="Lombar(pn)"><f type="i">Lombard<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Lombar<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>a Bank for usury

<f type="i">Lombards<f type="r">, a
people inhabiting the hithermost part of <f type="i">Italy<f type="r">,
formerly called <f type="i">Insubria<f type="r">,
</page>

<page sig="Aa1r">
much addicted to usury, whence ofttimes Usurers are
called Lombardeers.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="London(pn)"><f type="i">London<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the chief City of <f type="i">England<f type="r">,
situate in <f type="i">Middlesex<f type="r">, so called as <f type="i">Cambden<f type="r">
conjectureth, either <class type="etymlang" lang="br">from <f type="i"><term lang="br">Lhun</term><f type="r"> (which in the
Brittish tongue signifieth a Grove) or <f type="i"><term lang="br">Lhong</term><f type="r">,
(<f type="i">i.<f type="r"> a ship) and <f type="i"><term lang="br">Dinas</term><f type="r">, i. a City, so
that it may seem to have been anciently termed
<f type="i"><term lang="br">Lhundinas</term>, i.<f type="r"> a City thick of trees, or
<f type="i"><term lang="br">Lhongdinas</term><f type="r">, i. a City of Ships,</class> from whence the
Latins derive the word <f type="i"><term lang="la">Londinum</term><f type="r">.
It was called <f type="i">Augusta<f type="r">, and <f type="i">Troja Nova<f type="r">,
being first founded by <f type="i">Brutus<f type="r">, who sprang of the
<f type="i">Trojan<f type="r"> race, and repaired by King <f type="i">Lud<f type="r">,
and thence called <f type="i">C&aelig;rlud<f type="r">, or
<f type="i">Luds-town<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="longitude(n)"><f type="i">Longitude<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> the length of any thing,
also the Longitude of a Region, City, or Cape, is the
distance of it East, numbred in the Equinoctial by
Meridians, from the first general and fixed Meridian. The
Longitude of a star, is the arch of the
Ecliptick intercepted
between the beginning of
<f type="i">Aries<f type="r">, and the circle of the stars
Latitude.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Long-Meg(pn)"><f type="i">Long-Meg<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the name of a stone 15 foot high,

manner, which the country people call the Daughters of

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="loray-law(n)"><f type="i">Loray-law<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an article found in the
memorials of the chamber
of account in <f type="i">France<f type="r">, which ordaineth, that if a
combat be once accepted, and afterwards taken up, by
consent of the Lord of the Fee, each of the parties is to
pay two shillings six pence, but if it be performed, the
party vanquisht forfeits 112 shillings.</xpln>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lurdan(n)"><f type="i">Lordane<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Lourdane<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>a dull heavy
fellow, a lazy lubber, it
being a proverbial word taken from the tyranny of the
Danes over the English, who were forced to
labour and till the ground
for them, while they sate idle and ate the fruits of their
labours.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lore(n)"><f type="i">Lore<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="sx" type="etymlang">(Sax.)</class> learning or skill.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lotharius(pn)"><f type="i">Lotharius<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Ludovicus
Pius<f type="r">, Emperour of <f type="i">Germany<f type="r">, and King of
<f type="i">France<f type="r">, he succeeded his father in the Empire;
but his brothers <f type="i">Charles<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Lodowic<f type="r">,
not contented with their portions, and raising an army
against their brother, a great battle
was fought at <f type="i">Fontenay<f type="r">, in the borders of
<f type="i">France<f type="r">, where <f type="i">Lotharius<f type="r"> was put to
flight, but at last they came to an
agreement, and
<f type="i">Lotharius<f type="r"> after he had reigned about 15 years
betook himself to the <f type="i">Prumiensian<f type="r">
Monastery. There were also several
Kings of <f type="i">France<f type="r"> and Dukes of
<f type="i">Lorrain<f type="r"> of his
name.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lothbrook(pn)"><f type="i">Lothbrook<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>(i. <f type="i">Leatherbreech<f type="r">) a
certain Dane, whose daughters were so skilful at
needle-work, that the Danes bare in their Ensign a Raven
of their working, with such an opinion of good successe,
that they imagined it would never be won.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lotherwit(n)"><f type="i">Lotherwit<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>see <xref><f type="i">Leyerwit<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="Aa1v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lotion(n)"><f type="i">Lotion<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a washing or cleansing with
water, also <class type="register" subject="medicine">in Physick</class> it is used for the taking away of
any superfluous quality
out of any medicament, or the bringing on of a new one.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lotus(n)"><f type="i">Lotis<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Lotus<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>the daughter of
<f type="i">Neptune<f type="r">, she fleeing from <f type="i">Priapus<f type="r"> (who
made an attempt upon her
chastity) and invoking the help of the gods, was turned
into the Lote-tree.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lotophagi(pn)"><f type="i">Lotophagi<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain people of
<f type="i">Africa<f type="r">, dwelling near the <f type="i">Syrtes<f type="r">, so
called because they feed much upon the Lote-tree, which is
a tree of that nature, that when the companions of
<f type="i">Vlisses<f type="r"> being cast upon the coast of
<f type="i">Africa<f type="r"> had tasted of the fruit of it, they could
hardly be got from thence to return into their own
Country, whence the word is proverbially used for those
that are forgetful of their Parents,
Country and
Kindred.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lovell(pn)"><f type="i">Lovell's<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an ancient Family in
<f type="i">Northamptonshire<f type="r">,
stiled in Latin records, <f type="i"><term lang="la">de
Lupello</term><f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lord(n)"><f type="i">Loverd<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Laverd<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class type="old word">(old word)</class> a
Lord.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lordan(n)"><f type="i">Lourdain<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>see <xref><f type="i">Lordane<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Louvre(pn)"><f type="i">Louvre<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a stately Palace in <f type="i">Paris<f type="r">,
and the chief seat of the Kings of <f type="i">France<f type="r">, built
by <f type="i">Francis<f type="r"> the first, and augmented with a long
stately Gallery by <f type="i">Henry<f type="r"> the fourth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lowbell(n)"><f type="i">Lowbell<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>as it were loud bell, a certain
bell hung about the neck of a weather.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lozenge(n)"><f type="i">Lozenge<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a little square cake made of
preserved herbs, in the form of a Rhomb or a quarrel of
Glasse.</xpln></wordentry>

<f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Phosphorus</term><f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

as she is the Patronesse of Childbirth, or as some say to
<f type="i">Diana<f type="r"> or the Moon.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lucius(pn)"><f type="i">Lucius<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the pr&aelig;nomen of divers famous men
among the Romans; as <f type="i">Lucius Sylla, Lucius Antonius
Commodus<f type="r"> the Emperour, <f type="i">Lucius Septimius
Severus<f type="r">, and many others. The first of this name is
likely to have been so called from being born in the dawn
or first shining of the day.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lucre(n)"><f type="i">Lucre<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> gain or profit, whence
<f type="i">Lucration<f type="r"> a gaining or winning.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lucretia(pn)"><f type="i">Lucretia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of <f type="i">Lucretius
Tricipitinus<f type="r"> Prefect of <f type="i">Rome<f type="r">, and the wife
of <f type="i">Tarquinius Collatinus<f type="r">, she being ravisht by
<f type="i">Sextus<f type="r"> the son of <f type="i">Tarquinius
Superbus<f type="r"> King of the
Romans, slew her self, which was the cause of banishing
both <f type="i">Tarquin<f type="r"> and Kingly Government from
<f type="i">Rome<f type="r"> which was afterwards ruled by Consuls chosen
anew every year, and this act of <f type="i">Lucretia<f type="r"> hath
ever since been so famed, that every chast woman is
proverbially called a
<f type="i">Lucrece<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="luctation(n)"><f type="i">Luctation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a striving or
wrestling.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Luctatius Catulus(pn)"><f type="i">Luctatius Catulus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous Captain of the

600 of the Carthaginians, and made an end of the

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lucullus(pn)"><f type="i">Lucullus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous Roman, being a man of
great eloquence, and ingenuity, he
having been successeful in
the wars against <f type="i">Mithridates<f type="r">, heaped up a mighty
masse of riches, after the war was ended, gave himself up
wholy to ease and delicacy, living
in more state and splendor than any of that Age<emend err="," source="errata"></emend> besides<emend err="" source="errata">,</emend> 
afterwards beginning to grow mad, he was given in charge
to his brother <f type="i">Marcus<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Ludlow(pn)"><f type="i">Ludlow<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town in <f type="i">Shropshire<f type="r">, in

i.<f type="r"> the Princes Palace, it hath a fair Castle built by

<f type="i">Stephen<f type="r">, who valiantly rescued <f type="i">Henry<f type="r"> son
to the King of Scots, who was about to have been pulled
into the Castle with an iron hook.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Ludovicus Pius(pn)"><f type="i">Ludovicus Pius<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Charles<f type="r"> the

</page>

<page sig="Aa2r">
Pope <f type="i">Leo<f type="r">) he succeeded his father in the Empire
and Kingdom of <f type="i">France<f type="r">, also
<f type="i">Ludovicus<f type="r">
hath been the name of several other Emperours and Kings
of <f type="i">France<f type="r">, this name according to <f type="i">Helmoldus
Nigellus<f type="r"> is deriv'd <class lang="du" type="etymlang">from the Dutch words <f type="i"><term lang="du">Hludo
Wiggh</term><f type="r">, i. e. famous Warrier</class>.

beasts, also the space of five years, by which space the
<f type="i">Romans<f type="r"> were wont to compute the time.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lutheranism(pn)"><f type="i">Lutheranisme<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the doctrine and

of it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lutzenburgum(pn)" lexeme="Llutzenburgh(pn)"><f type="i">Lutzenburgum<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Lutzenburgh<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>a

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lycanthropy(n)"><f type="i">Lycanthropy<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a kinde of
melancoly, or phrenzy,
which causeth those that are possest
therewith to think themselves
turned into Wolves, and to fly the company of men.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lycaon(pn)"><f type="i">Lycaon<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Pelasgus<f type="r">, and King of
<f type="i">Arcadia<f type="r">, who when <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> came into
<f type="i">Arcadia<f type="r"> in the likenesse of a mortal man,
resolved to try whether he were a God, or no, as men
reported him to be, and killing one of those, whom the
King of the <f type="i">Molossi<f type="r">
had left with him for pledges, he
caused him to be dressed,
and part rosted, to be set before <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">,
whereat he being highly provoked turned <f type="i">Lycaon<f type="r">
into a Wolf, and burnt his Pallace with
Thunder, others say it
was for sprinkling with the bloud of an Infant, an Altar
which he had erected to <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> upon the Mountain
<f type="i">Lyc&aelig;us<f type="r">, a hill of <f type="i">Arcadia<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="Aa2v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lycaonia(pn)"><f type="i">Lycaonia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Countrey of <f type="i">Asia<f type="r"> the
lesse, near <f type="i">Phrygia<f type="r">, and reaching as far as the
Mountain <f type="i">Taurus<f type="r">; also <f type="i">Arcadia<f type="r"> was
heretofore so called
from <f type="i">Lycaon<f type="r">, the King thereof.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lyceum(pn)"><f type="i">Lyceum<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the name of a School, which
<f type="i">Cicero<f type="r"> erected at his Mannor of
<f type="i">Tusculum<f type="r">, calling it so after the name of
<f type="i">Aristotles<f type="r"> School, near <f type="i">Athens<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lycomedes(pn)"><f type="i">Lycomedes<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a King of the Island
<f type="i">Scyrus<f type="r">, by whom <f type="i">Achilles<f type="r"> being
intertained before he went to the <f type="i">Trojan<f type="r"> War, and
conversing with his
daughters in womans apparel,
he got one of them called <f type="i">Deidamia<f type="r"> with Childe,
and begat <f type="i">Pyrrhus<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lycurgus(pn)"><f type="i">Lycurgus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Polydectes<f type="r">,
and King of <f type="i">Sparta<f type="r">, after the death of his
brother <f type="i">Eunomus<f type="r">, but he soon resigned up the
Crown to <f type="i">Charilaus<f type="r"> his brothers son, and having
made wholesome laws for the good of the Common-wealth,
which were confirmed by
the approbation of the <f type="i">Delphic<f type="r"> Oracle, he
afterwards retired himself to <f type="i">Cyrrha<f type="r">, where at
length he slew himself, and had a Temple built him, and
Divine honours given bim by the <f type="i">Laced&aelig;monians:<f type="r">
also the name of a King of <f type="i">Thrace<f type="r">, who proceeded
so violently against <f type="i">Bacchus<f type="r">, that he forced him
to retire himself to <f type="i">Naxus<f type="r">, and would have caused
all the Vines in his Kingdom to be rooted up, that no
sacrifice might be made to him, but ere he had effected
his design he fell mad, and cut off his own legs.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lycus(pn)"><f type="i">Lycus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a King of <f type="i">Boeotia<f type="r">, who
married <f type="i">Antiope<f type="r">, the daughter of
<f type="i">Nycteus<f type="r">, but she being got with Childe by
<f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> in the form of a Satyr, he put her away
and married <f type="i">Dirce<f type="r">. see more in <xref target="Dirce"><f type="i">Dirce<f type="r">,
and <f type="i">Amphyon<f type="r"></xref>; also a King of <f type="i">Lybia<f type="r">, who
using to sacrifice his Guests, had intended the same thing
towards <f type="i">Diomede<f type="r">, but <f type="i">Callirroe<f type="r"> the
daughter of <f type="i">Lycus<f type="r">, falling in love with him
delivered him out of Chains, and
being afterwards neglected
by him, hanged her self for grief.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lydia(pn)"><f type="i">Lydia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Christian name of divers
women, from the Countrey so
called.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lydia(pn)"><f type="i">Lydia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Kingdom of <f type="i">Asia<f type="r"> the
lesse, so called from <f type="i">Lydus<f type="r">, the son of
<f type="i">Atys<f type="r">, who perceiving the people grow too numerous
for the Countrey, resolved to send out one of his sons, to
whose lot it should fall, to plant a Colony in some other
place, so that it falling to <f type="i">Tyrrenus<f type="r"> his lot, he
went out with a great multitude of <f type="i">Lydians<f type="r">, and
choosing out a part of <f type="i">Italie<f type="r">, which lieth upon
the Sea-side, he called it from his own name
<f type="i">Tyrrhenum<f type="r">, his brother <f type="i">Lydus<f type="r"> tarrying at
home succeeded his father <f type="i">Atys<f type="r">
in the Kingdom, and called it from his own name
<f type="i">Lydia<f type="r">, whereas before it was called
<f type="i">M&aelig;onia<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lydford law(n)"><f type="i">Lydford Law<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain Law, whereby they
first hang a man, and afterwards
indite him.</xpln>
<lemenote>
See OED "law", n. 8c.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>


<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lymphatic(a)"><f type="i">Lymphatick<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> mad, distracted, as it
were by seeing the likenesse of a Nymph in the water, from
<f type="i">Lympha<f type="r">, i. water.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lynceus(pn)"><f type="i">Lynceus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Apareus<f type="r">, and
one of the <f type="i">Argonauts<f type="r">, he was reported to be so
quick-sighted, that he could see through stone walls even
to the very deep it self, and that he could discern the
Moon in her last quarter, and the first, the very same
day, in the signe of <f type="i">Aries<f type="r">; whence a
sharp-sighted man is proverbially called a
<f type="i">Lynceus<f type="r">, also <f type="i">Lynceus<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Idas<f type="r">
were two brothers, who fought with <f type="i">Castor<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Pollux<f type="r">, about the
two daughters of <f type="i">Leucippus, Castor<f type="r"> fell by the
hand of <f type="i">Lynceus, Lynceus<f type="r"> by the hand of
<f type="i">Pollux, Idas<f type="r"> going about to slay <f type="i">Pollux<f type="r">,
was strook with Thunder from Heaven.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lyncus(pn)"><f type="i">Lyncus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a King of <f type="i">Scythia<f type="r">, who
going about to kill <f type="i">Triptolemus<f type="r"> his Guest as he
lay asleep, that he might gain to himself the glory of
inventing the use of Corn, was changed by <f type="i">Ceres<f type="r">
into a beast, called <f type="i">Lynx<f type="r">, or
<f type="i">Ounce<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lyndus(pn)"><f type="i">Lyndus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Citie of <f type="i">Rhodes<f type="r">, famous
for the solemne sacrifices, which in old time were
performed there to <f type="i">Hercules<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lyra(pn)"><f type="i">Lyra<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>one of the celestial
<emend err="Aphorismes" source="errata">Asterism's</emend>, which
the Poets feigned to be <f type="i">Arions<f type="r"> Harp.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="lyric(n)"><f type="i">Lyrick<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>verses, or songs, songs
composed to the Lyre, or
Harp, whence we say vulgarly, playing Leero-way on the
Viol, which is corruptly used for Lyra-way, <f type="i">i. e.<f type="r">
Harp-way.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lysander(pn)"><f type="i">Lysander<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Captain of the
<f type="i">Leced&aelig;monians<f type="r">,
who overcame the <f type="i">Athenians<f type="r"> under the command of
Conon in a very great battel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lysidice(pn)"><f type="i">Lysidice<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of <f type="i">Pelops<f type="r">,
she was married to <f type="i">Electryon<f type="r">, and brought forth
<f type="i">Alckmena<f type="r"> the mother of <f type="i">Hercules<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lysimachus(pn)"><f type="i">Lysimachus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Agathocles<f type="r">, and
one of the chief Captains of <f type="i">Alexander<f type="r"> the
Great, he was thrown to a Lyon to be devoured by
<f type="i">Alexanders<f type="r"> command, for hearing
<f type="i">Callisthenes<f type="r">
the Philosopher after he was in Chains, but he wrapping
his Garment about his
hands, thrust them into the Lyons mouth, and pulling out his
</page>

<page sig="Aa3r">
tongue killed him; after <f type="i">Alexanders<f type="r"> death he
had the Government of <f type="i">Thrace<f type="r">.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lysippe(pn)"><f type="i">Lysippe<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>see <xref><f type="i">Iphianassa<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Lysius(pn)"><f type="i">Lysius<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>one of the sirnames of
<f type="i">Bacchus<f type="r">, to whom under that name the
<f type="i">Boeotians<f type="r"> consecrated a Temple, because by his
help they overcame the <f type="i">Thracians<f type="r">, by whom they
had been set upon before and beaten.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Macareus(pn)"><f type="i">Macareus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Aeolus<f type="r">, who
got his sister <f type="i">Canace<f type="r"> with child, which
<f type="i">Aeolus<f type="r"> coming to discover by hearing the child
cry, sent <f type="i">Canace<f type="r"> a sword privately,

she deserved best, whereupon she killed her self, and
<f type="i">Macareus<f type="r"> fleeing
to <f type="i">Delphos<f type="r">, was made a Priest of
<f type="i">Apollo<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<f type="i">Italians<f type="r">; but here they are commonly compounded

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Macedonia(pn)"><f type="i">Macedonia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a large Country of

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Magdeburgum(pn)" lexeme="Magdeburg(pn)"><f type="i">Magdeburgum<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Magdeburg<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>as it

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="magician(n)"><f type="i">Magician<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> one that professeth the
</page>

<page sig="Aa3v">
Art Magick, which was the same among the
<f type="i">Persians<f type="r">, as Philosophy among the
<f type="i">Grecians<f type="r">, i.
e. the study of the more occult and mysterious Arts;
whence the 3 Wisemen of
the East were called <f type="i">Magi<f type="r">, but
among the vulgar, the word
simply taken, is used in the same signification as
Diabolical Magick,
<f type="i">i. e.<f type="r"> Sorcery or Witchcraft.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="magisterial(a)"><f type="i">Magisterial<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> pertaining to

Mastership, done by or like a Master; <class type="register" subject="medicine">in Physick</class> a pill or

is called Magisterial.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Magnes(pn)"><f type="i">Magnes<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a youth of <f type="i">Smyrna<f type="r">, the

musick and poetry, for
which he was in high esteem with <f type="i">Gyges<f type="r"> King of
<f type="i">Lydia<f type="r">, who because the Parents of <f type="i">Magnes<f type="r">
spoiled his cloths, and cut off his hair, made war

<f type="i">Sardes<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Mago(pn)"><f type="i">Mago<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the first that increased the wealth

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="magonel(n)"><f type="i">Magonel<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>according to <f type="i">Chaucer<f type="r">, is

stones with.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mayhem(n)" lexeme="maim(n)"><f type="i">Mahim<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Maim<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(in Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Mahemium</term><f type="r">)</class> is the hurting or taking away of any
member by the wrongful act of another, whereby the party
so hurt is made unable to fight, it comes from the old
French word <f type="i"><term lang="fr">Mehaighn</term><f type="r">, and is called by the
Canonists, <f type="i"><term lang="la">Mutilatio membri</term><f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Mahumetanism(pn)"><f type="i">Mahumetanisme<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the Religion and Law of the
<f type="i">Turks<f type="r">, founded by <f type="i">Mahomet<f type="r"> the first
Emperour of the <f type="i">Saracens<f type="r">, there was also of this
name a great Emperour of the <f type="i">Turks<f type="r">, who overthrew
the <f type="i">Greek<f type="r"> Empire, took twelve Kingdomes, and two
hundred Cities from the Christians, whereof the chief were
<f type="i">Constantinople<f type="r">, the Island
<f type="i">Chalcis, Scodra, Trapezuntium<f type="r">, and <f type="i">Hydruntum<f type="r">,
in <f type="i">Italie<f type="r">, but at the siedge of
<f type="i">Belgrade<f type="r">, or as
some say of <f type="i">Taurinum<f type="r">, he was overthrown, and put
to flight.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Maia(pn)"><f type="i">Maia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>one of the seven <f type="i">Pleiades<f type="r">,
on whom <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> begat <f type="i">Mercury<f type="r">, she was
the daughter of <f type="i">Atlas<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Pleione<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Maid Marian(pn)"><f type="i">Maid Marrian<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Morion<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>a boy
dressed in womans apparel to dance the <f type="i">Morisco<f type="r">,
or <f type="i">Morrisdance<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="maiden-hair(n)"><f type="i">Maiden-hair<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kinde of plant, called in
Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Adiantum</term><f type="r">, or <f type="i">Capillus
veneris<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="maidenhead(n)"><f type="i">Maidenhead<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town in <f type="i">Bark-shire<f type="r">,
so called from a Maids head that was had in great
reverence, being one of those 11000. who returning from
<f type="i">Rome<f type="r"> with their Leader
<f type="i">Vrsula<f type="r">, were taken by <f type="i">Attila<f type="r">, and
martyred at <f type="i">Colein<f type="r"> in <f type="i">Germany<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Maidstone(pn)"><f type="i">Maidstone<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a pleasant Town in
<f type="i">Kent<f type="r">, situate
upon the River <f type="i">Medway<f type="r">, and
therefore anciently
called <f type="i">Medweg-ston<f type="r">, and thought to be the same
with the old Town <f type="i">Vagniac&aelig;<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="maim(n)"><f type="i">Maim<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>see <xref><f type="i">Mahim<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mainour(n)"><f type="i">Mainour, Manour<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Meinour<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(from
the French word <f type="i"><term lang="fr">Maniere</term><f type="r">)</class> signifieth <class type="register" subject="law">in
Common-law</class>, an apprehending of one that hath stollen any
thing, and is followed with <f type="i">Hue<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Cry<f type="r">,
with the manner, that is, having the thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mainprise(n)"><f type="i">Mainprise<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(from the French words
<f type="i"><term lang="fr">main</term><f type="r">, i. a hand, and <f type="i"><term lang="fr">prins</term><f type="r">, i. taken)</class>
signifieth <class type="register" subject="law">in Common
Law</class>, the receiving a man into friendly custody, that
otherwise might be committed to prison, giving
security for his forth comming at a day assigned; those that do thus undertake
for any, are called <f type="i">Mainpernours<f type="r">, he that is
taken into custody <f type="i">Mainpernable<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="maint(a)"><f type="i">Maint<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="sx" type="etymlang">(Saxon)</class> mingled.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="maintenance(n)"><f type="i">Maintenance<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="law">in Common Law</class>, is,
up&shy;
</page>

<page sig="Aa4r">
holding of a cause depending in suite between
others, either by lending of money, or making of friends
for either party.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Majo(pn)"><f type="i">Majo<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a County of <f type="i">Ireland<f type="r">, in the
Province of
<f type="i">Conaught<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="major(n)"><f type="i">Major<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>signifieth in Latin greater, but
with us it is commonly taken sometimes for a Pr&aelig;tor or
Governour of a City, sometimes for a Military officer;
also <class type="register" subject="logic">in Logick</class> the first part of a Syllogisme is
called the <f type="i">Major<f type="r">
or the proposition, the second
the <f type="i">Minor<f type="r"> or the assumption.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="majoration(n)"><f type="i">Majoration<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a making greater.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Maisnilwarings(pn)"><f type="i">Maisnilwarings<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>and by contraction
<f type="i">Manwarings<f type="r">, the name of a great and ancient Family in
<f type="i">Cheshire<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Master of the Rolls(pn)"><f type="i">Master of the Rolles<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>is an assistant unto
the Lord Chancelour of <f type="i">England<f type="r"> in the high Court
of Chancery, and in his absence heareth causes and giveth orders.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Master of the Chancery(pn)"><f type="i">Maisters of the Chancery<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>are assistants to
the Lord Keeper of the Great Seal in
matters of judgement; of
these there are 12 in number, whereof the chief is the
Master of the Rolles.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Master of the Court of Wards and Liveries(pn)"><f type="i">Masters of the Court of Wards and
Liveries<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the
principal officer of that Court, named and assigned by the
King to whose custody the Seal of the Court is
committed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Master of the Horse(pn)"><f type="i">Master of the Horse<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>is he that hath the
rule and charge of the Kings stable.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="make(v)"><f type="i">Make<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="law">in Common Law</class>, signifieth, to perform
or execute, as, to make his Law, is to perform that Law
which he hath formerly bound himself unto, that is, to
clear himself of an action, commenced against him by his
Oath, and the Oaths of his Neighbours; also to make ones
beard, (an old phrase) to deceive.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Malachias(pn)"><f type="i">Malachias<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="he" type="etymlang">(Hebr.)</class> my messenger.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="malacissation(n)"><f type="i">Malacissation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kneading, a making

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="malacia(n)"><f type="i">Malacy<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a calm on the Sea, also a

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Malaga(pn)"><f type="i">Malaga<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Citie and Port-Town of
<f type="i">Andalusia<f type="r">,
whence we have that sort of wine, which is called
<f type="i">Malago<f type="r"> Sack; it is said to have been so called,
because <f type="i">Cava<f type="r"> the daughter of Count
<f type="i">Julian<f type="r">, after that, her being ravish't by King
<f type="i">Roderigo<f type="r"> had been the occasion of the losse of
<f type="i">Spain<f type="r"> to the <f type="i">Moors<f type="r">, threw her self from
a high Tower, crying out, <f type="i">Malac&agrave;, i.<f type="r">
here's the evil.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mallender(n)"><f type="i">Malanders<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain disease in a horse,

ill</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="malapert(a)"><f type="i">Malapert<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>saucy, impudent, as it were

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Maldon(pn)"><f type="i">Maldon<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town in <f type="i">Essex<f type="r">, anciently
called <f type="i">Camalodunum<f type="r">
from <f type="i">Camulus<f type="r">, whom the old <f type="i">Brittains<f type="r">
worship't here for <f type="i">Mars<f type="r">, the God of war; this
Town being made a Colony of the <f type="i">Romans<f type="r">, was
sacked by Queen <f type="i">Bunduca<f type="r">, or
<f type="i">Boadicia<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mail(n)"><f type="i">A Male<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kinde of sack, or budget <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">from the

made of sheepskins.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Malmesbury(pn)"><f type="i">Malmesbury<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town in <f type="i">Wiltshire<f type="r">,
first built by <f type="i">Mulmutius<f type="r">, a King of the
<f type="i">Brittains<f type="r">, and
by him named <f type="i">C&aelig;r Baldon<f type="r">,
afterwards from one
<f type="i">Maidulph<f type="r"> an <f type="i">Irish-Scot<f type="r">, who here led a
Hermites life, it was called
<f type="i">Maidulphsburgh<f type="r">, and so by contraction
<f type="i">Malmsbury<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Malta(pn)"><f type="i">Malta<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a rocky and barren Island, sixty
</page>

<page sig="Aa4v">
miles distant from <f type="i">Sicilie<f type="r">, called in the New
Testament <f type="i">Melita<f type="r">, this Island was given by
<f type="i">Charls<f type="r"> the fifth, to the Knights of
<f type="i">Rhodes<f type="r">, who have ever since been called Knights
of <f type="i">Malta<f type="r">.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Mamalukes(pn)"><f type="i">Mamalukes<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain Order of

<f type="i">Aegypt<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Mamitus(pn)"><f type="i">Mamitus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the thirteenth King of the

discipline, and was a terrour to the <f type="i">Aegyptians<f type="r">,
and many other Nations.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Mammon(pn)"><f type="i">Mammon<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the God of wealth, the word

wealth, and is derived <class type="etymlang" lang="he">from the Hebrew word
<f type="i"><term lang="he">Hamon</term><f type="r">, i. plenty</class>, having M.
<f type="i">Hemantick<f type="r"> added

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mahmudi(n)"><f type="i">Mammooda<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kinde of East-Indian Coyn,

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Manchester(pn)"><f type="i">Manchester<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a pleasant Town in
<f type="i">Lancashire<f type="r">,
which anciently belonging to the Kings of
<f type="i">Northumberland<f type="r">, and having been destroyed in the
<f type="i">Danish<f type="r"> war, King <f type="i">Edw.<f type="r"> the Elder, sent an
Army of <f type="i">Mercians<f type="r"> into <f type="i">Northumberland<f type="r">, to
re-edifie this Citie; some say, because the inhabitants
behaved themselves valiantly against the <f type="i">Danes<f type="r">,
it was called <f type="i">Manchester<f type="r">, as it were the Citie of
men, others derive it from <f type="i">Main, i.<f type="r"> a stone,
because it standeth upon a stony Hill; it was anciently
called <f type="i">Mancunium<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="manchet(n)"><f type="i">Manchet<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(from the French word <f type="i"><term lang="fr">Main</term>, i.
e.<f type="r"> the hand)</class> the finest, and the smallest sort of
wheaten bread, called in Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">panis
Capituli</term><f type="r">, in Greek <f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Collyris</term><f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="maunche present(n)"><f type="i">Manch present<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="old word">(old word)</class> a bribe.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mancipation(n)"><f type="i">Mancipation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> an ancient manner of

used; it is also used in the same sence as
<f type="i">Emancipation<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="manciple(n)"><f type="i">Manciple<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a Steward, or Caterer, but
chiefly one that buyes the common provisions in a
Colledge, or Hospital.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mancus(n)"><f type="i">Mancuse<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kinde of Coyn, valuing about
thirty of the ancient pence, each of which contains three
pence of our money, some hold a <f type="i">Manca<f type="r">, or
<f type="i">Mancus<f type="r"> of Gold, to be as much as a Mark of
silver.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mandatary(n)"><f type="i">Mandatarie<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> one that comes in to a
Benefice by a <f type="i">Mandamus<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mandate(n)"><f type="i">A Mandate<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a Commandment, or charge,
also <class type="register" subject="law">in Common-law</class>, it is a Judicial
Command of the King, or his Justices,
to have any thing done for the dispatch
of Justice.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Mandevils(pn)"><f type="i">Mandevils<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an ancient family in
