<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mandible(n)"><f type="i">Mandible<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> from
<f type="i">Mandibulum<f type="r">)
a jaw, (from the <f type="i">participiate Mandibilis<f type="r">)
eatable.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mandilion(n)"><f type="i">Mandilion<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Mandilian<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class>
a kinde of military garment, a loose Cassock.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Mandonius(pn)" lexeme="Indibilis(pn)"><f type="i">Mandonius<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Indibilis<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>two
famous <f type="i">Spanish<f type="r"> Captains, who having assisted
<f type="i">Scipio<f type="r">, and the
<f type="i">Romans<f type="r"> against the <f type="i">Carthaginians<f type="r">
began afterwards to revolt, but
because of the memory of
their former good service they were dismissed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mandrake(n)"><f type="i">Mandrake<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kinde of plant, so called <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">from
the Greek word <f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Mandra</term>, i.<f type="r"> a Cave</class>, because it
groweth near unto <f type="i">Den's<f type="r"> and in shady places, it
beareth a fruit called <f type="i">Mandrake<f type="r">, Apples of a cold
and soporiferous quality, it is also called by some
<f type="i">Anthropomorphos<f type="r">,
because its root being divaricated,
something resembleth the shape of a man.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="manducation(n)"><f type="i">Manducation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a chewing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Maundy Thursday(pn)"><f type="i">Mandy thursday<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>as it were <f type="i">dies
Mandati<f type="r">, the day of Commandment, because of that
great charge which our Saviour gave to his Disciples,
concerning the observation of his Supper, being the
Thursday next before Easter day.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="magonel(n)"><f type="i">Mangonels<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the same as
<f type="i">Magonells<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mangonization(n)"><f type="i">Mangonization<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a trimming, or
setting out things to the best advantage for sale.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Manichees(pn)"><f type="i">Manichees<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a sort of Hereticks that
maintained that there was a fatal necessity of sin, which
Doctrine was first broached by one Manes a
<f type="i">Persian<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="manicle(n)"><f type="i">Manicles<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> fetters wherewith the
hands of prisoners are bound, being <class type="etymlang" lang="la">derived originally
from the Latin word <f type="i"><term lang="la">Manus</term><f type="r">, a hand</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="manifesto(n)"><f type="i">Manifesto<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="it" type="etymlang">(Ital.)</class> a Declaration of some
Prince, or Common-wealth, about publick affairs.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="Bb1r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="maniple(n)"><f type="i">Maniple<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a handful, <class type="register" subject="medicine">in physick</class> more
especialy it is taken for such a bundle of herbs or
other things as may be griped with the hand; also a
company consisting of 10 souldiers; some also take it
for a fannel or such a kind of ornament as Priests used
to wear about their wrists when they went to sacrifice.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="manipular(a)"><f type="i">Manipular<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to a
maniple.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Manlius(pn)"><f type="i">Manlius<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the name of divers famous
Romans, whereof the chief
were <f type="i">Marcus Manlius Capitolinus<f type="r">, and <f type="i">Titus
Manlius Torquatus<f type="r">. see <xref><f type="i">Capitolinus</xref><f type="r"> and
<xref><f type="i">Torquatus<f type="r">.</xref></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="manna(n)"><f type="i">Manna<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain delicious food
wherewith God fed the
children of Isr&aelig;l in their journey to <f type="i">Canaan<f type="r">,
being a congealed dew
which fell from Heaven, it comes <class type="etymlang" lang="he">from the Hebrew word
<f type="i"><term lang="he">Manah</term><f type="r">, i. to distribute
or <f type="i"><term lang="he">Mahna</term><f type="r">, i. what is it</class>, because they admired
what it was: there is also at this day a certain sweet
dew, which falling early in the morning upon trees and
herbs, is called <f type="i">Manna<f type="r">, which congealing into a
whitish substance, is of a pleasant taste, and is much
used <class type="register" subject="medicine">in physick</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="manor(n)"><f type="i">Mannour<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(in Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Manerium a
manendo</term><f type="r">, i. remaining
to the heir, or else from the Lords remaining there
himself)</class> it signifieth
<class type="register" subject="law">in common Law</class>, a rule or government
which a man hath over such as hold land within his
fee.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="man of war(n)"><f type="i">Man of War<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="navigation">in Navigation</class>, is taken for a
ship of War, by the figure <f type="i">Metonymia<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="manqueller(n)"><f type="i">Manqueller<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="old word">(old word)</class> a murderer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mansion(n)"><f type="i">Mansion<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a remaining, an abiding,
also a Manor-house, or the Lords chief dwelling house
within his fee.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="manslaughter(n)"><f type="i">Manslaughter<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="law">in Common Law</class>, is the
unlawful killing of a man upon some
sudden occasion, or falling
out, without premeditated
malice.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mansuetude(n)"><f type="i">Mansuetude<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> gentlenesse,
tractablenesse,
meeknesse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mantle(v)"><f type="i">Manteleth<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="hawking and hunting">a term in Faulconry</class>, for when
the Hawk stretcheth one of her wings along after her legs,
and so the other: It is
said she <f type="i">Manteleth<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mathematics(n)"><f type="i">Mathematicks<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>Arts taught by
demonstration which
comprehend four of the liberal Arts, Astronomy,
Arithmetick, Musick, and Geometry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="manticore(n)"><f type="i">Manticore<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="it" type="etymlang">(Ital.)</class> a kind of
<f type="i">Indian<f type="r"> beast, faced like a Man, and bodied like a
Lion, and having three rows of sharp teeth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="manticulation(n)"><f type="i">Manticulation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a doing a thing
slily, a carrying on a businesse closely.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mantle(n)"><f type="i">Mantle<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Mantile<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a kind
of long robe, also <class type="register" subject="heraldry">in Heraldry</class> it is that flourish which
proceeds from the wreath and helm, and descends on each
side the Escutcheon.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Mantua(pn)"><f type="i">Mantua<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a City of <f type="i">Italy<f type="r">, situate
upon the River <f type="i">Po<f type="r">, and built by <f type="i">Ocnus<f type="r">,
who called it so from his
mothers name <f type="i">Manto<f type="r"> a <f type="i">Theban<f type="r"> Prophetesse,
the daughter of <f type="i">Tiresias<f type="r">,
she after the death of her father
fleeing from the tyranny
of <f type="i">Creon<f type="r"> King of <f type="i">Thebes<f type="r">, went first into
<f type="i">Asia<f type="r"> and built the Temple of <f type="i">Apollo
Clarius<f type="r">, afterwards she came into <f type="i">Italy<f type="r">,
where being got with child by <f type="i">Tiberinus<f type="r">, she
brought forth <f type="i">Ocnus<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="manual(n)"><f type="i">Manual<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to the hand,
filling the hand; it is also used
substantively, for
a book of a small volume which may easily be carried in
ones hand.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="manubiary(n)"><f type="i">Manubiary<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to the spoil or
prey.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="manucaption(n)"><f type="i">Manucaption<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a taking by the

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="manufacture(n)"><f type="i">Manufacture<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> handy-work.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="manumission(n)"><f type="i">Manumission<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> an Enfranchising, a

performed with divers ceremonies before a
Magistrate.</xpln></wordentry>

<f type="i"><term lang="fr">Manouurier</term><f type="r"></class>, to
work and labour the earth with the hand.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="manuscript(n)"><f type="i">Manuscript<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a thing onely written
with the hand.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="manutenentia(n)"><f type="i">Manutenentia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Writ used in the case of

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="manutention(n)"><class type="unknown">&dagger;</class> <f type="i">Manutention<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a holding by

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Marria(pn)" lexeme="Mar(pn)"><f type="i">Marria<f type="r"> or <f type="i">Mar<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the name of a
Country in the North part of <f type="i">Scotland<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Marathon(pn)"><f type="i">Marathon<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town of <f type="i">Greece<f type="r">, about
ten miles distant from <f type="i">Athens<f type="r">, famous for the
Victory of <f type="i">Theseus<f type="r"> over the <f type="i">Marathonian<f type="r">
Bull, and of <f type="i">Miltiades<f type="r"> over <f type="i">Darius<f type="r"> his
Army consisting of above 100000. men.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="maravedis(n)"><f type="i">Maravedis<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kind of <class type="etymlang" lang="sp">Spanish</class> coin of very small
value, 34 of them amounting
</page>

<page sig="Bb1v">
but to a Royal, which is about 6 pence of our money.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Marcellus(pn)"><f type="i">Marcellus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a great General of the
Romans, who overcame the
Captain of the Gaules in a single Duel; vanqvisht
<f type="i">Hannibal<f type="r"> after
he had given the Romans several
great overthrows, took <f type="i">Syracuse<f type="r">, and at last was
circumvented by <f type="i">Hannibal<f type="r"> and slain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="marcessible(a)"><f type="i">Marcessible<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> apt to putrifie or
corrupt.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Marcgrave(pn)"><f type="i">Marcgrave<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="du" type="etymlang">(Dutch)</class> a Count or Earl of the
Marches, <f type="i">i. e.<f type="r"> the Frontier of a Country, whence
the title of Marquesse seemeth to be derived; also those
Noblemen which from the
Marches, <f type="i">i.<f type="r"> the limits between <f type="i">England<f type="r">
and <f type="i">Wales<f type="r">, or between <f type="i">England<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Scotland<f type="r">, were heretofore called Marchers, and
injoyed private Laws to themselves which now are worn
out.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="March(pn)"><f type="i">March<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>so called because it was
dedicated to <f type="i">Mars<f type="r"> by his son <f type="i">Romulus<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="marchesite(n)"><f type="i">Marchesite<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Marquesite<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="sp" type="etymlang">(Span.)</class>
a certain kind of stone
intermingled among mettal, and partaking of the nature and
colour of the mettal it is mixt with: it is by some
called a firestone.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="marcheta(n)"><f type="i">Marcheta<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain Law made by
<f type="i">Eugenius<f type="r"> King of
<f type="i">Scotland<f type="r">, which was that the Lord of the land
should have the first nights lodging with every married
woman within his jurisdiction, (the word
signifying, as some think, the first carnal copulation
with a woman) but this law was abrogated by
<f type="i">Malcolm<f type="r"> the third.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="marchpane(n)"><f type="i">Marchpane<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> a kind of Sugered paste
made into little cakes, it is called in Greek
<f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Saccharites</term><f type="r">, in Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Panis
dulciarius</term><f type="r">, also <f type="i">Sagunculus<f type="r">, from <f type="i">Saguntum<f type="r"> a Town in
<f type="i">Spain<f type="r"> where the best are made, or <f type="i">Panis
Martius<f type="r">, because it had wont to be consecrated to
<f type="i">Mars<f type="r">, having towers, castles, and such like on
it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="marcidity(n)" lexeme="marcour(n)"><f type="i">Marcidity<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Marcour<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a
withering away,
rottennesse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Marcionists(pn)"><f type="i">Marcionists<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a sort of ancient Hereticks,
so called from one <f type="i">Marcion<f type="r"> a Stoick, they denied
<f type="i">Christ<f type="r"> to be the Son of God.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Marcus(pn)"><f type="i">Marcus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the pr&aelig;nomen of divers
eminent Romans, as
<f type="i">Marcus Curtius<f type="r">, (who for the publick good,
devoted himself to the infernal powers, and rid compleatly
arm'd into a monstrous gap with which the earth opened)
and others. see <xref target="Regulus"><f type="i">Regulus Salinator<f type="r">,
&amp;c.</xref></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mermaid(n)"><f type="i">Maremaid<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>see <xref target="Sirens"><f type="i">Syren<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Mareotis(pn)"><f type="i">Mareotis<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a great Lake in <f type="i">Aegypt<f type="r">,
on the south side of <f type="i">Alexandria<f type="r">, having a large
and commodious Port.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Margaret(pn)"><f type="i">Margaret<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> pearl, the Christian name
of divers women, contracted <f type="i">Marget<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="margaritiferous(a)"><f type="i">Margaritiferous<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> bringing forth,
<f type="i">Margarites<f type="r">, i. pearles which are found in Oysters
and other kind of shell-fish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Margery(pn)"><f type="i">Margery<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Christian name of divers women;
some think it to be the same with <f type="i">Margaret<f type="r">,
others derive it from <f type="i">Marjora<f type="r">, a kind of
flower.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="marginal(a)"><f type="i">Marginal<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat)</class> belonging to the
margin or margent,
<f type="i">i.<f type="r"> the brink or brim of any thing, also written
in the margin of a book, which is, the extream or
uttermost part of a page, which terminates the
lines.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Mariandunum(pn)"><f type="i">Mariandunum<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Country of <f type="i">Asia<f type="r">,
famous for the
<f type="i">Acherusian<f type="r"> Den, through which the Poets feign
that <f type="i">Hercules<f type="r"> went down into Hell.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mariet(n)"><f type="i">Mariets<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> a sort of violets,
called also <f type="i">Marian<f type="r">
violets; some think from <f type="i">Maria<f type="r"> the name of a
woman who first discovered
them.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="marigold(n)"><f type="i">Marigold<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kind of flower of a yellow or
golden colour, called in Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">herba solaris</term><f type="r">, in
Greek <f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Heliotropium</term><f type="r">, because at night it contracts
it self, and at sun-rising opens and dilates it self.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="marine(a)"><f type="i">Marine<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to the Sea, whence
Mariner, a Sailour, a Seafaringman.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="marital(a)"><f type="i">Marital<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to Wedlock or
Mariage.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="maritime(a)"><f type="i">Maritime<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to the Sea, or
being along the Sea side.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Marius(pn)"><f type="i">Marius<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a stout Roman born at
<f type="i">Arpinas<f type="r">, he overcame <f type="i">Jugurth<f type="r"> King of
<f type="i">Numidia<f type="r">, and led him in Triumph before his
Chariot, after he had had five Consulships together
conferred on him by the Romans, being the sixth time
Consul with <f type="i">Catulus<f type="r">, he overthrew the
<f type="i">Cimbrians<f type="r"> in <f type="i">Gallia<f type="r">, and the
<f type="i">Teutones<f type="r"> in <f type="i">Italy<f type="r">, at length being
overcome by <f type="i">Sylla<f type="r">, he hid himself by the Lake
<f type="i">Minturna<f type="r">, from whence he fled into
<f type="i">Africa<f type="r">, but was
recalled by <f type="i">Cinna<f type="r">, and made Consul the seventh
time.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Mark(pn)"><f type="i">Mark<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="he" type="etymlang">(Hebr.)</class> high, or <class type="etymlang" lang="la">from the Latin
<f type="i"><term lang="la">Marcus</term><f type="r"></class>, which name according to <f type="i">Varrow<f type="r">,
was given to those that were born in the moneth of
<f type="i">March<f type="r">, but according to <f type="i">Festus<f type="r">, it
signifies a hammer or mallet.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mark(n)"><f type="i">Mark<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a sort of coin, or money valueing with us
about thirteen shillings and four pence, but a Mark of
Gold is counted a&shy;
</page>

<page sig="Bb2r">
bout eight ounces, or thirty three shillings
and four pence.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Marcab(pn)"><f type="i">Marcab<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the pinion of the wing of
<f type="i">Pegasus<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Marlborough(pn)"><f type="i">Marleborough<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town in <f type="i">Wiltshire<f type="r">,
seated upon the River
<f type="i">Cunetio<f type="r"> or <f type="i">Kenet<f type="r">, so called from
<f type="i">Marga<f type="r"> or <f type="i">Marle<f type="r">, because it standeth upon
a chalky ground. <f type="i">Alexander
Necham<f type="r"> calleth it <f type="i">Merlebrigia<f type="r">, from the Tomb
of <f type="i">Merlin<f type="r"> the Prophet; this Town is famous for a
Parliament in old times, assembled here, who made a Law
for appeasing tumults, called the Statute of
<f type="i">Marleborow<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="marlin(n)"><f type="i">Marlin<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kind of Hawk called in French
<f type="i"><term lang="fr">Esmerillion</term><f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="marling(n)"><f type="i">Marling<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="navigation">a term in Navigation</class>, being a
small line made of untwisted hemp, to sease the ends of
ropes from farsing out.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Marmaduke(pn)"><f type="i">Marmaduke<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the proper name of a man, <class type="etymlang" lang="du">from
the Dutch <f type="i"><term lang="du">Mermachtig</term><f type="r">, i. more mighty</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="marmalade(n)"><f type="i">Marmalade<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="it" type="etymlang">(Ital.)</class> a kind of conserve made
of quince, which is called by the Italians
<f type="i"><term lang="it">Marmelo</term><f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="marmorean(a)"><f type="i">Marmorean<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> like Marble, or made of
Marble.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="marmoset(n)"><f type="i">Marmoset<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Monky, <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">from the French word
<f type="i"><term lang="fr">Marmotter</term><f type="r">, i. to mutter</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Maronean wine(n)"><f type="i">Maronean wine<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a sort of wine made at the
City <f type="i">Maronea<f type="r">, of great vertue and
strength.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Maronites(pn)"><f type="i">Maronites<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>were a sort of Christians
dwelling in Mount <f type="i">Libanus<f type="r">, they received the
Catholik religion from Pope <f type="i">Clement<f type="r"> the eighth,
and were a branch of the <f type="i">Jacobites<f type="r">
having a Patriarch of their own, who was alwayes called
<f type="i">Peter<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Marpessa(pn)"><f type="i">Marpessa<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>called also <f type="i">Alcyone<f type="r">, the
daughter of <f type="i">Euenus<f type="r">, and wife of <f type="i">Id&aelig;us<f type="r">,
the comliest man of his time, she was so loved of her
husband, that when <f type="i">Apollo<f type="r"> carried her away he
pursued the god with his bow and arrows; he had by her a
very fair daughter called <f type="i">Cleopatra<f type="r">, who was
married to <f type="i">Meleager<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Marque(n)"><f type="i">Marque<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>see <xref target="Letters of Mart">Letters of Mart, or
Marque</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="marqesite(n)"><f type="i">Marquesite<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>see <xref><f type="i">Marchesite<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="marquetry(n)"><f type="i">Marquetry<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kind of chequer'd or
inlaid work, made with wood
of divers sorts or colours, into the shape of knots,
flowers, or other things.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="marquisate(n)"><f type="i">Marquisate<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> the title and
jurisdiction of a
Marquesse who is a Noble man, next in Dignity and account
unto a Duke, <class lang="du" type="etymlang">from the Dutch word <f type="i"><term lang="du">March</term><f type="r">, i. a
bound</class>, because originally they were the Prefects of the
borders of some Countrey.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="marrow(n)">A <f type="i">Marrow<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> a companion or fellow,
also a beggarly rascal.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Mars(pn)"><f type="i">Mars<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Juno<f type="r">, who without
the help of <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">, proved with child by eating
of a flower which grew in the <f type="i">Olenian<f type="r">
fields, according to the advice of <f type="i">Flora<f type="r"> and
brought forth <f type="i">Mars<f type="r">, who was called the god of
War; he being in bed with <f type="i">Venus<f type="r">, was discovered
by <f type="i">Vulcan<f type="r"> her husband, who throwing an iron net
over them exposed them to the view and laughter of all the gods;
but at the suite of <f type="i">Neptune<f type="r"> they were set free.
Also the name of one of the 7 Planets.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="marshal(n)"><f type="i">Marshal<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(in Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Mariscallus</term><f type="r">)</class>
was anciently no other than a Master of Horse, <class type="etymlang" lang="du">from the
Dutch words <f type="i"><term lang="du">Mar</term><f type="r">, i. a horse, and <f type="i"><term lang="du">Scalc</term><f type="r">,
i. a servant</class>, but of late there are several officers of
that name, as the Marshals belonging to the several Courts
of Law, the Marshals of each Regiment in an Army, but the
highest officers that bore this name among us, were the
Lord Marshal of <f type="i">England<f type="r">, whose power consisted chiefly in matters
of war and armes, and Marshals of the Kings House, whose
office was to hear pleas of the Crown, and to punish
faults committed within the verge.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Marshalsea(pn)"><f type="i">Marshalsee<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>as it were <f type="i">Marshals<f type="r">
seat, the Court of the <f type="i">Marshal<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Marsyas(pn)"><f type="i">Marsyas<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain Musitian of
<f type="i">Phrygia<f type="r">, instructed by <f type="i">Minerva<f type="r">, he
provoking <f type="i">Apollo<f type="r">
to a contest in Musick, was overcome and flead for his
presumption, and from his name the River <f type="i">Marsyas<f type="r">
whose streams were augmented by the tears of the Nimphs
that bewailed him, took its denomination.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="martern's sables(n)"><f type="i">Marternes<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Sables<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>a kind of
rich Fur, being the skin of a little beast called a
Marten.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Martia(pn)"><f type="i">Martia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the wife of <f type="i">Cato
Vticensis<f type="r">, whom he gave to his friend
<f type="i">Hortensius<f type="r">, and after he was dead, about the
beginning of the civil wars, took her again.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="martial(a)"><f type="i">Martial<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> born under the Planet of
<f type="i">Mars<f type="r">, also warlike or valiant, whence the Law of
Armes is called Martial Law.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="marticore(n)"><f type="i">Martichore<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>see <xref><f type="i">Manticore<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Martin(pn)"><f type="i">Martin<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the proper name of a man, <class type="etymlang" lang="la">from the
Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Martius</term><f type="r"></class>. The first of this name was St.
<f type="i">Martin<f type="r"> the Military Saint, Bishop of
<f type="i">Tours<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="martinet(n)" lexeme="martlet(n)"><f type="i">Martinet<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Martelet<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>a kind of bird,
called in Greek <f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Apus</term><f type="r">, because it wanteth the use of its feet.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="martingale(n)"><f type="i">Martingale<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>see <xref><f type="i">Cavechin<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="martnet(n)"><f type="i">Martnets<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="navigation">a Term in Navigation</class>, the small
lines which being fastned to the legs on the leetch of a
sayl, come down by the mast to the deck.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="martyrology(n)"><f type="i">Martyrologie<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a discourse,
treating of the lives,
and sufferings of Martyres.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Marullus Pomponius(pn)"><f type="i">Marullus Pomponius<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the greatest
Grammarian and Critick of his age, who reprehended
<f type="i">Tiberius<f type="r"> for speaking improper Latin, and gave
<f type="i">Ateius Capito<f type="r">, the lie for vindicating it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Mary(pn)"><f type="i">Mary<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="he" type="etymlang">(Hebr.)</class> exalted.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mascarade(n)"><f type="i">Mascarade<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> a mask, or
pompous
representation.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mascle(n)"><f type="i">Mascle<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class type="register" subject="heraldry">in blazon</class>, is a short
lozenge, having a square
hole in the midst, <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">from the French word <f type="i"><term lang="fr">Macle</term>, i.
e.<f type="r"> a spot, also the mash, or hole of a Net</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="masculine(a)"><f type="i">Masculine<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> manly, or of the male
kinde.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Massagetae(pn)"><f type="i">Massaget&aelig;<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>see <xref><f type="i">Scythia<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mass(n)"><f type="i">Masse<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(in latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Missa</term><f type="r">)</class> the
Liturgy, or Divine service performed by the Roman
Catholicks, is also called from the Hebrew <f type="i"><term lang="he">Missah</term>,
l.<f type="r"> sacrifice, or oblation.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="massicot(n)"><f type="i">Massicot<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kinde of Oaker, made of Ceruse,
or white Lead.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Massilia(pn)"><f type="i">Massilia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town of <f type="i">Gallia
Narbonensis<f type="r">, which after it had been destroyed, was
rebuilt by the <f type="i">Phocences<f type="r">, who flying from the Tyranny of
<f type="i">Cyrus<f type="r">, seated themselves in this place; the Arts
and Sciences flowrish't
here at that heighth, that it was accounted a second
<f type="i">Athens<f type="r">, it is vulgarly called
<f type="i">Marseilles<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Massinissa(pn)"><f type="i">Massinissa<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a King of <f type="i">Numidia<f type="r">, who
from an inveterate enemy of the Roman name, became a
faithfull friend and allie, he was a man of that strength,
and vigour of body, that at
90 years of age, he begat a son.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Massorets(pn)"><f type="i">Massorets<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a sort of Jews, which
corrected the false
written words of the Scripture,
noting them wit a little o. (for they made a scruple to
blot them out) and setting
down their corrections in the Margin.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mastication(n)"><f type="i">Mastication<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a chewing between
the teeth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mastic(n)"><f type="i">Mastick<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kinde of sweet Gum, distilling out of the
Mastich, or Lentiske Tree.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="masticot(n)"><f type="i">Masticot<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kinde of yellow colour used <class type="register" subject="art">in
painting</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mastigophore(n)"><f type="i">Mastigophore<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> an Usher that with
stripes makes way in a croud.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mastruke(n)"><f type="i">Mastruke<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> a kinde of winter

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mastupration(n)"><f type="i">Mastupration<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> lascivious violence

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="matagot(n)"><f type="i">Matagot<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> a kinde of Ape, or Monky,
also a Hypocrite.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="match(n)"><f type="i">Match<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="hawking and hunting">a Term in Hunting</class>, when a Wolf

his mate.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mateotechny(n)"><f type="i">Mateotechny<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Mat&aelig;otechny<f type="r">,</form>
<xpln><class type="etymlang" lang="gk">(Greek)</class> the vanity of any Art, a vain Science.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mate(a)"><f type="i">Mate<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="sx" type="etymlang">(Saxon)</class> daunted, also
consum'd.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mate(n)" lexeme="checkmate(n)"><f type="i">A Mate<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Checkmate<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class type="register" subject="games">(a Term used
in the Game at Chess)</class> is when the Game is brought to that
passe, that there is no way left for the King to escape,
<class lang="it" type="etymlang">from the Italian word <f type="i"><term lang="it"><emend err="Motto" source="errata">Matto</emend></term>, i.<f type="r"> foolish and
inconsiderate,</class> or
<class lang="sp" type="etymlang">the Spanish <f type="i"><term lang="sp">Matar</term>, i.<f type="r"> to kill</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="matelotage(n)"><f type="i">Matelotage<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the Hire of a Boat, or ship,
<class lang="fr" type="etymlang">from the French word <f type="i"><term lang="fr">Matelot</term><f type="r">, a Saylour, or
Shipman</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="material(a)"><f type="i">Material<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> consisting of matter, or

importance.</xpln></wordentry>

for building.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="maternal(a)"><f type="i">Maternal<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> motherly, on the
mothers side, whence
maternity, motherhood.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mathematician(n)"><f type="i">Mathematician<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> one that is
skilfull in the
Mathematicks, that is, those Sciences which are understood
by demonstration,
of these there are four in all, Arithmetick,
Geometry, Astronomy, and Musick.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Matthew(pn)"><f type="i">Matthew<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="he" type="etymlang">(Hebr.)</class> Gods gift.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Mathurins(pn)"><f type="i">Mathurins<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>certain Fryars of the Order of
the holy Trinity, whose Office is to
redeem Christian Captives out of Turkish slavery.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="matricide(n)"><f type="i">Matricide<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a killing of ones

his mother.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="matrice(n)"><f type="i">Matrice<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> that part of the Womb,

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="matriculation(n)"><f type="i">Matriculation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a Registring of young

learning the University.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="matrimonial(a)"><f type="i">Matrimonial<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mattress(n)"><f type="i">Mattresse<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> a quilt, or flock-bed.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Matura(pn)"><f type="i">Matura<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain goddesse among the
ancient Romans, who was said to be the Patronnesse of
Corn, when the eares began
to ripen, as <f type="i">Patalena<f type="r"> took charge of them when
the cups began to open, and <f type="i">Lactucina<f type="r">, when the
juyce, or milky substance
began to abound.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="maturity(n)"><f type="i">Maturity<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> ripenesse, whence

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Maud(pn)"><f type="i">Maud<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gr" type="etymlang">(Germ.)</class> a Christian name of

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mavis(n)"><f type="i">Mavis<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>in Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Malviccium</term><f type="r">, a bird

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="maund(n)"><f type="i">Maund<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> a hand-basket, from

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Maundy Thursday(pn)"><f type="i">Maundy-Thursday<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>see <xref target="Mandy thursday"><f type="i">Mandy-Thursday<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Mars(pn)"><f type="i">Mavors<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the same as <f type="i">Mars<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Mauritania(pn)"><f type="i">Mauritania<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the utmost Region of
<f type="i">Africa<f type="r">, toward the <f type="i">Gaditan<f type="r"> Bay, now called the Streights of
<f type="i">Gibraltar<f type="r">, where the Gyant
<f type="i">Ant&aelig;us<f type="r"> is said to have raign'd, who was overcome
by <f type="i">Hercules<f type="r">, it is divided into <f type="i">Tingitana<f type="r"> and <f type="i">C&aelig;sariensis<f type="r">, which
<f type="i">Strabo<f type="r"> call's <f type="i">Massilia<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Mass&aelig;sylia<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Mausolus(pn)"><f type="i">Mausolus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a King of <f type="i">Caria<f type="r">, the
husband of <f type="i">Artemisia<f type="r">, by whom he was so intirely
loved, that after he was dead, she is said to have drunk
up his ashes in wine, and built him a very stately
Sepulcher, which from his name she called
<f type="i">Mousoleum<f type="r">, being one of the seven wonders of the
world, and from which every rich Monument is figuratively
called a <f type="i">Mausoleum<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="maxillar(a)" lexeme="maxillary(a)"><f type="i">Maxillar<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Maxillary<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class>
belonging to the jawbone.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="maxim(n)"><f type="i">A Maxime<f type="r"></form> <xpln><class type="register" subject="philosophy">in Phylosophy</class>, <class type="register" subject="law">or Law</class>, is a
proposition, or principle generally received, grounded upon
reason, and not to be denied, called also an axiome.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Maximilian(pn)"><f type="i">Maximilian<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a name, first given to one of
the German Emperours, by his father <f type="i">Frederick<f type="r"> the
third, composing it of the names of two famous Romans,
<f type="i">Quintus Fabius, Maximus<f type="r">, and <f type="i">Scipio Aemelianus<f type="r">, with hope
that his son would imitate their vertues.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="May(pn)"><f type="i">May<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>so called, because <f type="i">Romulus<f type="r">
dedicated it to <f type="i">Maya<f type="r">, the mother of <f type="i">Mercury<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="maze(n)"><f type="i">Maze<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an astonishment, also the same as
Labyrinth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mazer(n)"><f type="i">Mazer<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Beker, or standing Cup to drink
in, <class lang="du" type="etymlang">from the Dutch word <f type="i"><term lang="du">M&aelig;ser</term><f type="r">, i.
<f type="i">Maple<f type="r"></class>, of which sort of wood those Cups are
commonly made.</xpln></wordentry>

</wordgroup1>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="meagre(a)"><f type="i">Meagre<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> scraggy, or lean.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mean(n)">The <f type="i">Mean<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="music">in Musick</class> the Tenor, or
middle part, also <class type="register" subject="law">in Law</class>,
it is used for the interim, or middle time, as, the action
was mean, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Meander(pn)"><f type="i">Meander<f type="r">, or <f type="i">M&aelig;ander<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>a River of
<f type="i">Phrygia<f type="r">, which
hath many oblique diversions, whence a thing that is full
of intricate turnings and windings, is called a
<f type="i">M&aelig;ander<f type="r">, by way
of Metaphor.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mearstone(n)"><f type="i">Mearstones<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(in Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Lapides
terminales</term><f type="r">)</class>
certain stones, which are put as bounds and limits between
one mans land and anothers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mease(n)"><f type="i">Mease<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(in Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Mansus</term><f type="r">)</class> a Mansion
house, <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">from the French word <f type="i"><term lang="fr">Maison</term><f type="r">, i. e. a
house</class>, or as some say from <f type="i">Meix<f type="r">, i. e. a Mansion,
also Mease, or Mese, is used for a measure of Herrings,
consisting of 500.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="maisondieu(n)"><f type="i">Measandue<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an Hospital, <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">from the French
<f type="i"><term lang="fr">Maison de Dieu</term><f type="r"></class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Meath(pn)"><f type="i">Meath<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Province of <f type="i">Ireland<f type="r">,
containing these
following Counties, <f type="i">Eastmeath, Westmeath<f type="r">, and
<f type="i">Longford<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Mecaenus(pn)"><f type="i">Mec&aelig;nus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a learned Noble-man of <f type="i">Rome<f type="r">, who lived in the
time of <f type="i">Augustus<f type="r">, he was a great favourer of
<f type="i">Virgil<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Horace<f type="r">, whence every favourer
of learning, and learned men hath been ever since saluted
with the Title of <f type="i">Mec&aelig;nas<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Mecha(pn)"><f type="i">Mecha<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Citie in <f type="i">Arabia Foelix<f type="r">,
which is had in great reverence by the <f type="i">Turks<f type="r">, as
being the place where <f type="i">Mahomet<f type="r"> was
buried.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mechanic arts(n)"><f type="i">Mechanick Arts<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>or Handycrafts those Arts,
which require the labour of the hand, of which these seven
are esteemed the chief; <f type="i">Agriculture<f type="r">, Clothing,
Navigation, Hunting,
Architecture, Medecine, Military
Discipline: <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">the word comes from the Greek,
<f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Mechane</term><f type="r">,
an artifice, or invention</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mechation(n)"><f type="i">Mechation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a committing

whoredom.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="medal(n)"><f type="i">A Medal<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> a kinde of ancient coyn, or

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Media(pn)"><f type="i">Media<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a large Countrey in <f type="i">Asia<f type="r">,
so called from <f type="i">Madai<f type="r"> the son of <f type="i">Japheth<f type="r">,
or <f type="i">Medus<f type="r"> the son of <f type="i">Aegeus<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Medea<f type="r">, it is divided into the greater
<f type="i">Media<f type="r">, whose chief Citie is <f type="i">Ecbatana<f type="r">,
and the lesser called also <f type="i">Atropatia<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mediastine(n)"><f type="i">Mediastine<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="etymlang" lang="la">from the Latin
<f type="i"><term lang="la">Mediastinus</term><f type="r"></class>, is a drudge, or Kitchin slave, from
<f type="i"><term lang="la">Mediastinum</term><f type="r">
it signifies that partition made by certain thin skins,
dividing the whole breast into two hollow bosomes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Mediolanum(pn)"><f type="i">Mediolanum<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the chief Citie of that part of
<f type="i">Italie<f type="r">, formerly called <f type="i"><term lang="it">Gallia
Cisalpina</term><f type="r">, it was
first built by the <f type="i">Gauls<f type="r">, who as they were
digging in the earth, finding a sow half covered with wool
like a sheep, called the Citie <f type="i">Mediolanum<f type="r">,
vulgarly <f type="i">Millain<f type="r">, and the whole Countrey
afterwards being Conquered by the <f type="i">Lombards<f type="r">, was thence named
<f type="i">Lombardy<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="medisance(n)"><f type="i">Medisance<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> evil speaking, obloquy,

of the earth, or land, whence the Mediterranean Sea is
that Sea, which hath its course in the midst of the
earth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="medrinaque(n)"><f type="i">Medrinacles<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kinde of course
Canvas, called also
<f type="i">Pouledavies<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="medullar(a)"><f type="i">Medullar<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to the
marrow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Medusa(pn)"><f type="i">Medusa<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of <f type="i">Phorcys<f type="r">,
with whose golden hair Neptune was so much in love, that
he lay with her in the Temple
of <f type="i">Minerva<f type="r">, and begat <f type="i">Pegasus<f type="r">, at which
the goddesse being incenced, turned her hairs into
Serpents, whose sight converted all that look't on them
into stone, but at length <f type="i">Perseus<f type="r"> finding the
Serpents asleep, killed them, and cut off
<f type="i">Medusa's<f type="r"> head.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="meed(n)"><f type="i">Meed<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="old word">(old word)</class> merit, or reward.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mean(n)"><f type="i">Meen<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> the countenance, or

the outward Garb.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mere(n)"><f type="i">Meer<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="law">in Common-law</class>, hath been used for

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mese(n)"><f type="i">Mees<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="sx" type="etymlang">(Saxon)</class> Meadows.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Megabysus(pn)"><f type="i">Megabysus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>one of the <f type="i">Persian<f type="r">
Nobles, who in the behalf of <f type="i">Darius<f type="r"> overthrew the
Tyranny of the <f type="i">Magi<f type="r">, in <f type="i">Europe<f type="r"> he took
<f type="i">Perinthus<f type="r">, overcame the <f type="i">P&aelig;ones<f type="r">, and
attempted <f type="i">Macedonia<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Megaclo(pn)"><f type="i">Megaclo<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of <f type="i">Macares<f type="r">,
King of the <f type="i">Lesbians<f type="r">, who being of a froward
disposition, and alwayes contending with his wife,
<f type="i">Megaclo<f type="r"> was so grieved at her mothers calamity,
that she hired the Muses to
be her maids, and teaching them to sing, they by the
sweetnesse of their Musick,
so allayed the spirit of <f type="i">Megares<f type="r">, that his wife
ever after lived a better life with him, for which
benefite to her, she in thankfulnesse built pillars of
brasse to their glory, and caused them to be
honoured in all the
Temples thereabout.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="megacosm(n)"><f type="i">Megacosme<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> the great world.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Megaera(pn)"><f type="i">Meg&aelig;ra<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the name of one of the three
Furies, the other two being <f type="i">Alecto<f type="r">, and
<f type="i">Tisiphone<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Megalesian games(n)"><f type="i">Megalesian games<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>were certain games
celebrated in ancient times at <f type="i">Rome<f type="r">, in
honour of <f type="i">Cybele<f type="r">,
or the great goddesse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="megalopsychy(n)"><f type="i">Megalopsychie<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> Magnanimity, or
greatnesse of minde.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Megara(pn)"><f type="i">Megara<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of <f type="i">Creon<f type="r">,
King of <f type="i">Thebes<f type="r">, she was given in marriage to
<f type="i">Hercules<f type="r">, upon
condition that he should free the <f type="i">Thebans<f type="r"> from
the oppression of <f type="i">Erginus<f type="r">,
King of the <f type="i">Orchomenii<f type="r">, which he
performed, but <f type="i">Juno<f type="r"> being highly incenc't against him for
killing <f type="i">Lycus<f type="r">, possest him with such a madnesse
that he slew his wife <f type="i">Megara<f type="r">, and all the
Children he had by her.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="megrim(n)"><f type="i">Megrim<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a distemper which causeth a great
pain in the temples and fore part of the head; the word
seems to be contracted
<class lang="gk" type="etymlang">from the Greek word <f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Hemicrania</term><f type="r"></class>.</xpln></wordentry>

Cuppy<f type="r">.</xref></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="melampode(n)"><f type="i">Melampod<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(in Greek <f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Melampodium</term><f type="r">)</class> a
certain kind of herb, otherwise called
<f type="i">Hellebore<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Melampus(pn)"><f type="i">Melampus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Amythaon<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Dorippe<f type="r">, who
laying him abroad in the Sun and covering all his body
except his feet, they were so scorched by the Sun, that
they became black, whence he was called
<f type="i">Melampus<f type="r">, i. Blackfoot. He was a famous
Physitian and understood the voices of birds and beasts,
he cured the daughters of <f type="i">Pr&aelig;tus<f type="r"> of their
madnesse, one of whom named <f type="i">Iphianassa<f type="r"> he
married.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="melancholic(a)"><f type="i">Melancholick<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> sad, pensive,
troubled with melancholy, <f type="i">i. e.<f type="r"> black
choler, one of the 4
humours of the body, also a distemper caused by the
abounding of that humour.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Melantho(pn)"><f type="i">Melantho<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of <f type="i">Proteus<f type="r">,
who had a humour to ride upon a Dolphins back up and down
the Sea, which <f type="i">Neptune<f type="r"> observing turned himself
into a Dolphin, and carrying her to shore upon his back,
ravisht her and begot <f type="i">Amycus<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Melanthus(pn)"><f type="i">Melanthus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Andropompis<f type="r">,
he being a <f type="i">Messenian<f type="r"> was driven out of his
Country by the <f type="i">Heraclid&aelig;<f type="r">; he went and helpt the
<f type="i">Athenians<f type="r"> against the <f type="i">Boeotians<f type="r">, and
killed their Captain <f type="i">Xanthus<f type="r">; for which he was
chosen King of the <f type="i">Athenians<f type="r"> in the place of
<f type="i">Thymoetes<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Melborn(pn)"><f type="i">Melborn<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Castle in <f type="i">Darbyshire<f type="r">,
where <f type="i">John<f type="r"> Duke of <f type="i">Barbon<f type="r">, taken
prisoner at <f type="i">Agincourt<f type="r">, was detained prisoner 19
years under the custody of Sir <f type="i">Nicholas de
Mountgomery<f type="r"> the younger.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Melchior(pn)"><f type="i">Melchior<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the name of one of the Magi, or
Wise men of the East who offered gifts to our Saviour; He
offered Gold as to a King, the second call'd Jasper
frankincense as unto God, the third called Balthasar Myrrh
as to one that was to die; also the name of a great
Heretick, the founder of that sect called the
<f type="i">Melchiorists<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Melchites(pn)"><f type="i">Melchites<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a sort of Christians in
<f type="i">Syria<f type="r">, subject to the Patriarch of
<f type="i">Antioch<f type="r">, they are so called from <f type="i">Melchi<f type="r">,
which in the <f type="i">Syriack<f type="r">
tongue signifies a King, because they used to follow the
Emperours injunctions in matters of Religion.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Melicent(pn)"><f type="i">Melicent<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> honey-sweet, a Christian
name of women.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Meleager(pn)"><f type="i">Meleager<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Oeneus<f type="r"> King
of <f type="i">Calidonia<f type="r">, and <f type="i">Alth&aelig;a<f type="r">, he gathered a
company of valiant youths
together to slay a wild Bore that wasted the Country of
<f type="i">Aetolia<f type="r">, and
having slain it, presented the head to <f type="i">Atalanta<f type="r">
the daughter of <f type="i">Jasius<f type="r"> King of <f type="i">Argos<f type="r">,
which <f type="i">Plexippus<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Toxeus<f type="r">
the brothers of <f type="i">Alth&aelig;a<f type="r"> indeavouring to take
away, he slew them both, and married <f type="i">Atalanta<f type="r">,
but <f type="i">Alth&aelig;a<f type="r"> enraged at the death of her brothers,
threw the brand into the fire which she had saved from the
Destinies when he was borne, which as it burnt, he
consumed away.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="melimele(n)"><f type="i">Melimele<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>see <f type="i">Pome
Paradise<f type="r">.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="melioration(n)"><f type="i">Melioration<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a making better, an

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="melliloquent(a)"><f type="i">Melliloquent<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> speaking sweetly, as

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="melilot(n)" lexeme="melilote(n)"><f type="i">Mellilote<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Melilote<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>a certain
herb, bearing round leaves with slender
branches, <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">from the Greek
word <f type="i"><term lang="gkt">meli</term><f type="r">, i. honey, and <f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Lotus</term><f type="r"> the
Lote-tree, as it were, the Lote bearing honey</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Mellona(pn)"><f type="i">Mellona<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain goddesse worshipt by the
ancient Romans, as the Patronesse of Bees, perhaps the
same with <f type="i">Melissa<f type="r"> who first found out the use of
Honey, whom the Poets feign to have been turned into a
Bee; she was the daughter of <f type="i">Melissus<f type="r">
King of <f type="i">Creet<f type="r">, and the sister of
<f type="i">Amalthea<f type="r">, the
Nurse of <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="melody(n)"><f type="i">Melody<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a musical sound, or sweet aire, 
<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">from the Greek words, <f type="i"><term lang="gkt">meli</term><f type="r">, i. honey, and
<f type="i"><term lang="gkt">ode</term><f type="r">, i. a song,</class> as it were a honey'd or sweet
song.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Melpomene(pn)"><f type="i">Melpomene<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the name of one of the nine
Muses, the first inventresse of
Tragedies.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="membrane(n)"><f type="i">Membrane<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a certain little thin skin
which covereth every part of the
body, also a skin of
parchment, also the pill between the bark and the
tree.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Memnon(pn)"><f type="i">Memnon<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Tithonus<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Aurora<f type="r">, and brother of <f type="i">Laomedon<f type="r">, he was
slain by <f type="i">Achilles<f type="r"> in the <f type="i">Trojan<f type="r"> War, and
his body being burnt, it is reported that there flew out
certain Birds, which are thence
called <f type="i">Memnonian<f type="r">
Birds, who are said every year to come out of
<f type="i">Aethiopia<f type="r"> to visit the Tomb of <f type="i">Memnon<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="memorandum(n)"><f type="i">Memorandum<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a short note or token
for the better remembrance of any thing, or as we commonly
say, an <f type="i">Item<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="memorable(a)"><f type="i">Memorable<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> easie to be
remembred, worthy of
remembrance.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="memorial(n)"><f type="i">Memorial<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a remembrancer, or that
which puts one in mind of any thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Memphis(pn)"><f type="i">Memphis<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the chief City of <f type="i">Aegypt<f type="r">,
built
</page>

<page sig="Bb4v">
by <f type="i">Ogdous<f type="r">, and called after his daughters name,
and from whence the <f type="i">Aegyptians<f type="r"> are anciently
named <f type="i">Memphians<f type="r">; it is now vulgarly called
<f type="i">Alcairo<f type="r">.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Menalippus(pn)"><f type="i">Menalippus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a <f type="i">Theban<f type="r">, who having
given <f type="i">Tydeus<f type="r"> a mortal wound, was slain by the
friends of <f type="i">Tydeus<f type="r">, who causing
<f type="i">Menalippus<f type="r"> his head to be brought to him, tore it
in pieces for revenge, and immediately after died.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mendaciloquent(a)"><class type="unknown">&dagger;</class> <f type="i">Mendaciloquent<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> speaking
false, telling lyes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mendication(n)"><f type="i">Mendication<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a begging, whence a
Friar Mendicant is one that goes up and down begging
almes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Menelaus(pn)"><f type="i">Menelaus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Atreus<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Aerope<f type="r">, he marrying <f type="i">Helena<f type="r"> the daughter
of <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Leda<f type="r">, she was in his absence stollen away by
<f type="i">Paris<f type="r"> the son of <f type="i">Priam<f type="r">, which was the
occasion of the <f type="i">Trojan<f type="r"> war, wherein after 9 years
siege <f type="i">Troy<f type="r"> was destroyed, and <f type="i">Helena<f type="r">
recovered.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Menestheus(pn)"><f type="i">Menestheus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Peleus<f type="r">, he
with the help of the <f type="i">Tyndarid&aelig;<f type="r"> raising a
sedition against
<f type="i">Theseus<f type="r">, became King of the
<f type="i">Athenians<f type="r">,
but going to the siege of <f type="i">Troy<f type="r"> he there
died.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="menial servant(n)"><f type="i">Menial<f type="r"> or <f type="i">Moenial servant<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>one
that lives within the walls of his masters house, <class type="etymlang" lang="la">from the
Latin word <f type="i"><term lang="la">Moenia</term><f type="r">, i. walls</class>, or <class type="etymlang" lang="me">from the old word
<f type="i">Meny<f type="r">, which <emend err="significes">signifies</emend> a
Family</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="meninx(n)"><f type="i">Meninges<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> two thin skins which
enwrap the brain, the one called <f type="i">dura
mater<f type="r"> next to the skull, the other <f type="i">pia mater<f type="r">,
which immediately covereth the brain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="miniver(pn)"><f type="i">Meniver<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kind of Fur, being as some
think, the skin of a Squirrels belly, or as others say, of
a little white beast, (like to a wesel) breeding in
<f type="i">Muscovy<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="minnow(n)"><f type="i">Mennow<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(from the French word <f type="i"><term lang="fr">Menu</term>,
i.<f type="r"> small)</class> a little fish, otherwise called a Cackrel,
in Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Minimus</term><f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Menoecus(pn)"><f type="i">Menoecus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a <f type="i">Theban<f type="r"> youth, the son
of <f type="i">Creon<f type="r">, he was so zealous for the safety of his
Countrey, that when the Oracle had foretold that the
Citie, which was besieg'd by the <f type="i">Argives<f type="r">, could
not be saved unlesse the last of the race of
<f type="i">Cadmus<f type="r"> would voluntarily
kill himself, he slew himself with his own sword.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mensal(n)"><f type="i">Mensal<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to a table.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Mera(pn)"><f type="i">Mera<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of <f type="i">Pr&aelig;tus<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Antia<f type="r">, she being a
great Huntresse and following
<f type="i">Diana<f type="r"> in the Woods, was ravisht by
<f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">, who lay with her in the shape of
<f type="i">Diana<f type="r">, whereupon the goddesse shot her to death
with one of her arrows, and afterwards turning her into a
dog, she placed her among the heavenly
Constellations; also the name of <f type="i">Icarius<f type="r"> his dog. see <xref><f type="i">Icarius<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="merchenlage(n)"><f type="i">Merchenlage<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the law of the
<f type="i">Mercians<f type="r">, or the inhabitants of these eight Countries,
<f type="i">Glocester, Worcester, Hereford, Warwick, Oxford, Chester,
Salop<f type="r">, and <f type="i">Stafford<f type="r">, the Land being formerly
divided into three parts; the <f type="i">Mercians<f type="r">, the
<f type="i">West-Saxons<f type="r">,

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Mercury(pn)"><f type="i">Mercury<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>as it were <f type="i">Medius currens
inter Deos &amp; homines<f type="r">, i. e. sent on messages
between the gods and men,
the son of <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">
and <f type="i">Maia<f type="r"> the daughter of <f type="i">Atlas<f type="r">, he lay
with his sister <f type="i">Venus<f type="r"> and begat
<f type="i">Hermaphroditus<f type="r">,
he was counted the god of Eloquence, of Merchandry, of
Handycrafts-men, and the first inventour of the Harpe, also among
Astronomers the name of one of the seven Planets; among
<class type="register" subject="chemistry">Chymists of Quicksilver</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mercurial(n)" lexeme="mercurialist(n)"><f type="i">Mercurial<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Mercurialist<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>one
born under the Planet <f type="i">Mercury<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="meridian(a)"><f type="i">Meridian<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to noon,
also substantively used for
one of the greater circles dividing the Sphear into two
equal parts, and passing through the Poles of the World,
and the Zenith or Vertical point.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="Cc1r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="meridiation(n)"><f type="i">Meridiation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a sleeping at noon.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="meritot(n)"><f type="i">Meritot<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kinde of play used by
Children, wherein they
swing themselves up and down upon a Rope, to which is tied
a little beam, acrosse which they sit, it is
called in Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Oscillum</term><f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mermaid(n)"><f type="i">Meremaid<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>or <f type="i">Maremaid<f type="r">. see <xref target="Sirens"><f type="i">Syren<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Mern(pn)"><f type="i">Mern<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a County in the North of
<f type="i">Scotland<f type="r">, the
people whereof were anciently called <f type="i">Vernicones<f type="r">,
by some <f type="i">Vecturiones<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Meroe(pn)"><f type="i">Meroe<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an Island encompass't with the River
<f type="i">Nilus<f type="r">, in which there is a Citie of the same
name, built by <f type="i">Cambyses<f type="r">, whose sister was called
<f type="i">Meroe<f type="r">, from wence the Citie and Island took their
denomination, this
Citie Astronomers make to be the farthest of the Northern
Climats, whose parallel-line they call <f type="i">Dia 
Meroes<f type="r">, because it runs through the midst of the
Citie.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Merope(pn)"><f type="i">Merope<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>one of the seven daughters of
<f type="i">Atlas<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Pleione<f type="r">, they were feigned by
the Poets to be changed into seven stars, called the
<f type="i">Pleiades<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Merrick(pn)"><f type="i">Merrick<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a proper name of a man,
<class type="etymlang" lang="br">among the ancient
<f type="i">Brittains<f type="r"></class>, in Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Meuricus</term><f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mersion(n)"><f type="i">Mersion<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a ducking, or plunging over
head and eares into the water, a drowning.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Merton(pn)"><f type="i">Merton<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town in Surrey, where <f type="i">Kinalph<f type="r">,
King of the <f type="i">West-Saxons<f type="r"> was slain by a
<f type="i">Clito<f type="r">, or Prince of the bloud, in a Harlots
house, the <f type="i">Clito<f type="r"> himself being
also stab'd immediately by <f type="i">Kinulphs<f type="r"> followers:
in this place was born <f type="i">Walter de
Merton<f type="r">, founder of
<f type="i">Merton<f type="r"> Colledge in <f type="i">Oxford<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mease(n)"><f type="i">Mese<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>see <xref><f type="i">Mease<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mesel(n)"><f type="i">Mesel<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="sx" type="etymlang">(Sax.)</class> a Leaper.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mesentery(n)"><f type="i">Mesentery<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek as it were, the
middle of the entrails)</class> a
certain thick, and double skin that fastneth the bowels,
or entrails to the back, and affordeth
passage to a number of
veins, called the <f type="i">Mesenterick<f type="r">,
or <f type="i">Meseraick<f type="r"> veins.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mesquita(n)"><f type="i">Meskite<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Church, or Synagogue among the
Turks and Moors, from the Arabick word <f type="i"><term lang="ar">Mezquidun</term><f type="r">,
i. an Oration.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mesnagery(n)"><f type="i">Mesnagerie<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> husbandry, or

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mesnalty(n)"><f type="i">Mesnalty<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="law">a Term in Common-law</class>, the right
of the Mesn, that
is, a Lord of a Mannour, who hath Tenants holding of him,
yet holding himself of a Superiour Lord, <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">from the French
word <f type="i"><term lang="fr">Maisn&eacute;</term><f type="r">, i. e. younger by
birth</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Mesopotamia(pn)"><f type="i">Mesopotamia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a large Countrey of
<f type="i">Asia<f type="r">; so called because it is between the two
Rivers <f type="i">Tigris<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Euphrates<f type="r">, it was
called by the ancient Hebrews <f type="i"><term lang="he">Aram Naharaim</term><f type="r">, i.
e. <f type="i">Syria<f type="r"> of the Rivers, now <f type="i">Apamia<f type="r">, and
by some <f type="i">Adiabene<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="messagery(n)"><f type="i">Messagry<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="old word">(old word)</class> diligence in doing a
message.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Messalians(pn)"><f type="i">Messalians<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Sect of Hereticks, who held
the Lords Supper, and baptism to be but of indifferent
concernment.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Messana(pn)"><f type="i">Messana<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the chief Citie of
