unto the Promontory of <f type="i">Pelorum<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Messapia(pn)" lexeme="Mesapia(pn)"><f type="i">Messapia<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Mesapia<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>a Countrey
of <f type="i">Italie<f type="r">, anciently so called from
<f type="i">Messapus<f type="r">, the son of Neptune, it containeth those
Regions which are now called <f type="i">Calabria<f type="r">, and
<f type="i">Apulia<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Messenae(pn)"><f type="i">Messen&aelig;<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous Citie in
<f type="i">Greece<f type="r">, situate
in the <f type="i">Peloponnesus<f type="r">, whose ancient inhabitants
the <f type="i">Messenii<f type="r">, waged a long and bloudy war with
the <f type="i">Spartans<f type="r">, but at last were reduced to
absolute slavery.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="messias(n)"><f type="i">Messias<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="etymlang" lang="he">the same in Hebrew</class> as
<f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Christos</term><f type="r"> in Greek, <f type="i">i.<f type="r"> anointed, and is
oft used in the Holy Scriptures for our Saviour Christ.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="messorious(a)"><f type="i">Messorious<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to mowing,
reaping, or harvest.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="messuage(n)"><f type="i">Mesuage<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="law">in Common-law</class>, is used for a
dwelling house, with Garden, Courtilage, Orchard, and all
other things belonging to it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="metachronism(n)"><f type="i">Metachronisme<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> an errour in
Chronology by the mis-reckoning of time, or the ill
connexion of passages, <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">a word compounded of the Greek
preposition
<f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Meta</term><f type="r"> and <f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Chronos</term><f type="r">, i. time</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="metaleptic(a)"><f type="i">Metaleptick<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> belonging to the
<class type="register" subject="rhetoric">figure <f type="i">Metalepsie<f type="r"></class>, wherein one thing is used to
signifie another.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="metalline(a)"><f type="i">Metalline<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to
mettals.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="metamorphosis(n)"><f type="i">Metamorphosis<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a changing of one
body, or figure into another.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="metaphor(n)"><f type="i">A Metaphor<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a certain <class type="register" subject="rhetoric">figure</class>,
wherein one word is borrowed to expresse the signification
of another, as smiling Meadow's, youthfull Summer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="metaphysics(n)"><f type="i">Metaphysicks<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a science, which
treateth of supernatural things, as God, Angels, the Souls
of men, <f type="i">&amp;c.<f type="r"></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="metaplasmus(n)"><f type="i">Metaplasmus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> <class type="register" subject="rhetoric">a Rhetorical
figure</class>, wherein words, or
letters are plac't contrary to their usual order.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Metaris(pn)"><f type="i">Metaris<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an arm of the Sea in
<f type="i">Lincolnshire<f type="r">,
commonly called <f type="i">Maltraith<f type="r">, and the
<f type="i">Washes<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="metathesis(n)"><f type="i">Metathesis<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> transposition,
be&shy;
</page>

<page sig="Cc1v">
ing a certain <class type="register" subject="rhetoric">figure</class> wherein one letter is put for another.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Metellus(pn)"><f type="i">Metellus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous Roman Captain, who being
to go by Sea, with a great Army against the
<f type="i">Carthaginians<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Sicilians<f type="r">, prayed to
all the gods but <f type="i">Vesta<f type="r">, who
being thereby offended, kept back the Navy with contrary
windes, which <f type="i">Caius Julius<f type="r">
the Priest affirmed could not be diverted, but by the
sacrificing of his daughter <f type="i">Metella<f type="r">, which he
yielding unto, the goddesse
took compassion of the Virgin, and sent a Heifer in her
stead, also the name of a High-Priest of the Romans, who
when the Temple of <f type="i">Vesta<f type="r"> was on fire, running
into the <f type="i">Palladium<f type="r"> out of the flame, he lost his
sight by venturing too far into the fire.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="metempsychosis(n)"><f type="i">Metempsychosis<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a
Transmigration, or passing of the Soul out of one body
into another.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="meteor(n)"><f type="i">Meteor<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(from the Greek word
<f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Meteoros</term>, i.<f type="r">
high)</class> a certain imperfectly mixt body, consisting of
vapours drawn up into the middle Region, whereof are
ingendred Rain, Winds, Thunder, and Lightning.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="meteorology(n)"><f type="i">Meteorologie<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a discourse of
Meteors.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="meteoroscopy(n)"><f type="i">Meteoroscopie<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>that part of Astrology,
which handleth the difference of
Sublimities, and distance of Stars.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="metheglin(n)"><f type="i">Metheglin<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(in latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Mulsum</term><f type="r">)</class> a
kinde of drink made of Herbs, Hony, Spice,
<f type="i">&amp;c.<f type="r"></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="methodical(a)"><f type="i">Methodical<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> belonging to a Method,
<f type="i">i.<f type="r"> an orderly, or artificial
disposing, or placing of things.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Metiochus(pn)"><f type="i">Metiochus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Alcibiades<f type="r">,
he being taken by the
<f type="i">Ph&aelig;nicians<f type="r">, and brought a prisoner to
<f type="i">Darius<f type="r"> the King of <f type="i">Persia<f type="r">,
against whom his father
then made warre, was yet honourably received, the King
bestowing upon him large
possessions, and a wife named <f type="i">Persiba<f type="r">, by whom he
had many Children.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Metius Suffetius(pn)"><f type="i">Metius Suffetius<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>Dictator of the
<f type="i">Albans<f type="r">, who being bound by Covenant to aide
<f type="i">Tullus Hostilius<f type="r">, King of the Romans, against the
<f type="i">Fidenates<f type="r">, stood with his Army upon a Hill, to
see the event of the battel,
for which he was by the command of <f type="i">Hostilius<f type="r">,
torn in pieces with wilde horses.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="metonymy(n)"><f type="i">Metonymie<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> <class type="register" subject="rhetoric">a Rhetorical figure</class>,
wherein there is a changing of one name for another, as of
the cause for the effects, of the subject, for the
adjuncts, and contrarily.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="metope(n)"><f type="i">Metope<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="architecture">(a Term in Architecture)</class> the
distance of space in a pillar, between the Denticles and
Triglyph's.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="metoposcopy(n)"><f type="i">Metoposcopy<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> the guessing at mens
inclinations, as also the future events of men, by looking
on their faces.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="metrical(a)"><f type="i">Metrical<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to Meeter, or
verse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="metropolitan(a)"><f type="i">Metropolitan<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>belonging to a
<f type="i">Metropolis<f type="r">, <class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> <f type="i">i.<f type="r"> the chief Citie
of a Countrey, or Province, whence an Arch-bishop is
called a Metropolitan Bishop, because his Sea is alwayes
in the chief Citie.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Mexico(pn)"><f type="i">Mexico<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a great and famous Citie of the
<f type="i">Mexican<f type="r"> Province in <f type="i">Nova Hispania<f type="r">, the
Citie was the chief seat of <f type="i">Montezeuma<f type="r">,
who was Lord of the new world.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Mezentius(pn)"><f type="i">Mezentius<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a King of the <f type="i">Thuscans<f type="r">,
who with his son <f type="i">Lausus<f type="r">, assisting
<f type="i">Turnus<f type="r"> in the war against <f type="i">Aeneas<f type="r">, and
the <f type="i">Trojans<f type="r">, they both fell by the hand of
<f type="i">Aeneas<f type="r"> himself.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Miagrus(pn)"><f type="i">Miagrus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the God of flies, so called by

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Michael(pn)"><f type="i">Mich&aelig;l<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="he" type="etymlang">(Hebr.)</class> who is like God.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Michael's Mount, St.(pn)">St. <f type="i">Mich&aelig;ls<f type="r"> Mount</form>, <xpln>a Rocky cliffe, or
Promontory in <f type="i">Corn-wall<f type="r">, which <f type="i">John<f type="r">,
Earle of <f type="i">Oxford<f type="r"> fortified against King
<f type="i">Edward<f type="r"> the fourth, there is also a place so called in
<f type="i">Normandy<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mitch(v)"><f type="i">Miche<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>to play the Truant, or hide ones
self out of the way, <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">from the French word <f type="i"><term lang="fr">Muser</term><f type="r">,
i. to be idle</class>, or <class type="etymlang" lang="du">the Dutch <f type="i"><term lang="du">Micke</term><f type="r">, i. a wary
looking about</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mickle(a)"><f type="i">Mickle<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>much, <class lang="sx" type="etymlang">from the Saxon word
<f type="i"><term lang="sx">Micel</term><f type="r"></class>, or as some say <class lang="gk" type="etymlang">from the Greek word

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="microcosm(n)"><f type="i">Microcosme<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> the body of man is
commonly so called, being as it were a little world, see <xref><f type="i">Macrocosme<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="micrology(n)"><f type="i">Micrologie<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a discoursing about
petty small affairs.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="microscope(n)"><f type="i">Microscope<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a certain

full proportion of the smallest things may be
discerned.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Midas(pn)"><f type="i">Midas<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a King of <f type="i">Phrygia<f type="r">, the son of
<f type="i">Gordias<f type="r"> a
Cowheard, he having intertained <f type="i">Bacchus<f type="r">, and
being bid to ask of him what ever he had a minde to, he
desired that whatsoever he toucht, might be turned
into gold, which desire was immediately granted, and not
onely every thing else he touched, but his meat also,
before he could bring it to his mouth, was changed to
gold, whereupon he being forced to request that he might
be freed from that
</page>

<page sig="Cc2r">
gift he was counselled to wash himself in
<f type="i">Pactolus<f type="r"> streams, which immediately
became very bright with
the glistering of the sands which were turned into gold,
afterwards <f type="i">Pan<f type="r"> having challenged
<f type="i">Apollo<f type="r"> to a musick duell; <f type="i">Tmolus<f type="r"> being
chosen Judge, <f type="i">Midas<f type="r"> being the onely man that
gave the victory to <f type="i">Pan<f type="r">, was adjudged for his
ignorance to have Asses ears grow to his head, which
disgrace neverthelesse had been concealed, had not his
Barber gone into a hollow place of the earth, and cried
out <f type="i">Midas<f type="r"> hath Asses ears, and soon after the
reeds which grew in that place became vocal, and
continually uttered the same words.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Middleburgh(pn)"><f type="i">Middleburgh<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the chief City of
<f type="i">Zealand<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="midriff(n)"><f type="i">Midriffe<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>see <xref><f type="i">Diaphragme<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="migration(n)"><f type="i">Migration<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a removing, or
passing from place to place.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mile(n)"><f type="i">Mile<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>such a space of ground in length
onely, as containeth a thousand paces, or eight furlongs,
every furlong containing 125 paces.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Miles(pn)"><f type="i">Miles<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the proper name of a man, <class type="etymlang" lang="la">in
Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Milo</term><f type="r">, from
the grain called <f type="i"><term lang="la">Milium</term><f type="r">, i. <f type="i">Millet<f type="r"></class>,
others make it a contraction from <f type="i">Mich&aelig;l<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Miletus(pn)"><f type="i">Miletus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the chief
<emend err="Cicie">Citie</emend> of
<f type="i">Ionia<f type="r">, whose inhabitants the <f type="i">Milesii<f type="r">
were accounted the potentest, and the richest people of
all <f type="i">Asia<f type="r">; it was originally called
<f type="i">Anactoria<f type="r">, now <f type="i">Melazzo<f type="r">, also a Citie of
<f type="i">Caria<f type="r">, built by <f type="i">Miletus<f type="r"> the son of
<f type="i">Apollo<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Argea<f type="r">,
or as some say, by <f type="i"><emend err="Sarpendon" source="errata">Sarpedon</emend><f type="r"> the son of
<f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">, and the
brother of <f type="i">Minos<f type="r">, and <f type="i">Rhadamanthus<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Milford Haven(pn)"><f type="i">Milfordhaven<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a very commodious Haven in
<f type="i">Pembroke-shire<f type="r">, where <f type="i">Henry<f type="r"> Earle of
<f type="i">Richmond<f type="r"> landed, when by that famous battel at
<f type="i">Bosworth<f type="r">, he won the Crown from <f type="i">Richard<f type="r">
the third, this Haven hath sixteen Creeks, five Bay's, and
thirteen Rodes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="military(n)"><f type="i">Militarie<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to Souldiers or
War.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="milfoil(n)"><f type="i">Millefoile<f type="r"></form>., <xpln><class type="etymlang" lang="la"> (in Lat.

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Millenarians(pn)"><f type="i">Millenarians<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>see <xref><f type="i">Chiliasts<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="millet(n)"><f type="i">Millet<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="etymlang" lang="la">in Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Milium</term><f type="r"></class>, in Greek
<f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Cenchros</term><f type="r">) a kind
of plant, so called from the multitude of small granes, or
seeds which it beareth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Milo(pn)"><f type="i">Milo<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain <f type="i">Crotonian<f type="r"> of that
vast strength, that at the <f type="i">Olympick<f type="r"> games he
carried an Oxe the space of a whole
furlong, killed it with
his fist, and afterwards eat it all himself in one day.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Miltiades(pn)"><f type="i">Miltiades<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a great Captain of the
<f type="i">Athenians<f type="r">, who
with 11000 <f type="i">Greeks<f type="r"> overthrew 600000
<f type="i">Persians<f type="r"> in the fields of <f type="i">Marathon<f type="r">, yet
afterwards being accused of bribery, he was forced by the
<f type="i">Athenians<f type="r"> to die in Chains.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mime(n)" lexeme="mimic(n)"><f type="i">A Mime<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Mimick<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a
Jester, or one that counterfeits the gestures, or
countenances of others, whence Mimical, Apish, or given to
imitate.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="minacity(n)"><f type="i">Minacity<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a menacing, or
threatning.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="minchen(n)"><f type="i">Minchings<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an ancient word for those
consecrated <emend err="" source="errata">virgins</emend>, whom we call Nuns.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mundbriche(n)"><f type="i">Mindbruch<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="sx" type="etymlang">(a Saxon word)</class> a hurting of
honour and worship.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mien(n)"><f type="i">Mine<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> the same as meen, the
aspect, or garb of any person. <f type="i">Cleop.<f type="r"></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mineralist(n)"><f type="i">Mineralist<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>one skilfull in minerals,
<class type="etymlang" lang="la">(lat.)</class> <f type="i">i.<f type="r"> metals, or any thing growing in
mines.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Minerva(pn)"><f type="i">Minerva<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the goddesse of wisdom, she is
said to have been born without a mother, and to have
sprung out of <f type="i">Jupiters<f type="r"> head, she is reported also
to have invented the liberal sciences, and to have found
out the use of wool, about which a <f type="i">Lydian<f type="r"> Virgin
named <f type="i">Arachne<f type="r">, contesting with her, was
overthrown and turned into a Spider, also to her is
attributed the first finding out of the use of Oyl, she
was called in Greek
<f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Athen&aelig;a</term><f type="r">, and from her the Citie of
<f type="i">Athens<f type="r"> took its denomination.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="miniature(n)"><f type="i">Miniature<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a drawing of pictures in
little, which is many
times done with <f type="i">Minium<f type="r">, i. red lead.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="minim(n)"><f type="i">A Minime<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain quantity <class type="register" subject="music">in musick</class>,
containing one time up, or down, <class lang="la" type="etymlang">from the Latin word
<f type="i"><term lang="la">Minimus</term><f type="r">, i. least</class>, also <f type="i">Minime friars<f type="r">,
are a certain order instituted by <f type="i">Fran. de Paul<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="minion(n)" lexeme="mignon(n)"><f type="i">A Minion<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Mignon<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> one
that is in highest credit and esteem with a great person,
above any one besides, but especially
in an amorous sence, it is also used adjectively for neat,
spruice, polisht, or adorn'd.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="minious(a)"><f type="i">Minious<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> of a red, or Vermilion
colour.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="ministery(n)"><f type="i">Ministery<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> service, or charge in any
imployment, but used more especially
in a spiritual sence for the Priestly
function.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="miniver(n)"><f type="i">Miniver<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>see <xref><f type="i">Meniver<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="minor(n)">The <f type="i">Minor<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>in a syllogisme the latter part,
or assumption.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="minoration(n)"><f type="i">Minoration<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a diminishing, or
making lesse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="minority(n)"><f type="i">Minority<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> nonage, or being
under age.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Minos(pn)"><f type="i">Minos<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a King of <f type="i">Creet<f type="r"> the son of
<f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">, (or as
some say, of <f type="i">Xanthus<f type="r">) and <f type="i">Europa<f type="r">, he
having great wars with the <f type="i">Athenians<f type="r">
and <f type="i">Megareans<f type="r">, because they slew his son
<f type="i">Androgeus<f type="r">, had <f type="i">Megara<f type="r">
delivered to him by the
treachery of <f type="i">Scylla<f type="r">; he intertained
<f type="i">D&aelig;dalus<f type="r"> an <f type="i">Athenian<f type="r"> being banisht from
his Country, who being an excellent Artist, made that
famous Labyrinth into
which the <f type="i">Minotaur<f type="r"> was put; But afterwards for
making a wooden Heifer into which <f type="i">Pasiph&aelig;<f type="r"> the
wife of <f type="i">Minos<f type="r"> being
included, received the Bull again, by which she had
formerly had the <f type="i">Minotaur<f type="r">, he was shut up into
the Labyrinth himself, together with his son
<f type="i">Icarus<f type="r">; but he making
waxen wings for himself and his son, fled away into
<f type="i">Sicily<f type="r">, where he was stifled in a Bath by the
daughter of King <f type="i">Crocalus<f type="r">,
his son having melted his wings by the way, and fallen
into the Sea, which was thence called the <f type="i">Icarian
Sea<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Minotaurus(pn)"><f type="i">Minotaurus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the Monster which
<f type="i">Pasiph&aelig;<f type="r"> the wife of <f type="i">Minos<f type="r"> brought
forth, having had carnal copulation with a Bull, it had
partly the form of a man, partly of a Bull: to this
Monster the <f type="i">Athenians<f type="r"> overcome by <f type="i">Minos<f type="r">,
were bound by covenant to sent yearly seven of their
noblest youths to be devoured; but in the third year
<f type="i">Theseus<f type="r"> the son of <f type="i">Aegeus<f type="r"> was sent to
slay the <f type="i">Minotaur<f type="r">,
which having done, he escaped with the help of
<f type="i">Ariadne<f type="r"> out of the Labyrinth
by a clew of thread.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="minovery(n)"><f type="i">Minouery<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(from the French word
<f type="i"><term lang="fr">Mainovre</term><f type="r">, i.
handy-work)</class> is a trespasse committed
by a mans handy-work in the Forrest, as an engine to catch
Dear, <f type="i">&amp;c.<f type="r"></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="minster(n)"><f type="i">Minster<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="sx" type="etymlang">a Saxon word</class>, signifying a
Monastery.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mint(n)"><f type="i">Mint<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain herb, so called from
<f type="i">Minthe<f type="r"> the daughter of <f type="i">Cocytus<f type="r">, who
being taken away with <f type="i">Proserpina<f type="r"> by
<f type="i">Pluto<f type="r">, was changed into a plant of the same name,
also the place where the Kings coin is formed, which at
present is at the Tower of <f type="i">London<f type="r">, but in ancient
times it was at <f type="i">Caleis<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="minute(n)"><f type="i">Minute<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> little, small, whence
<f type="i">Minution<f type="r">, a
diminishing, or making little, also a Minute is
substantively used for a moment or the smallest part of
time.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mirable(a)"><class type="unknown">&dagger;</class> <f type="i">Mirabile<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> wonderful,
strange, to be admired.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="miraculous(a)"><f type="i">Miraculous<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mirmillon(n)"><f type="i">Mirmillions<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a sort of gladiators or
sword-fighters.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mirror(n)"><f type="i">Mirour<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Mirrour<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> a
looking-glasse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="misanthropy(n)"><f type="i">Misanthropy<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a man-hateing, a
flying the company of men.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Mirach(pn)"><f type="i">Mirach<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the Girdle of
<f type="i"><emend err="Adromeday" source="errata">Andromeda</emend><f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="misadventure(n)"><f type="i">Misaventure<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="law">in Common Law</class>, is the killing
of a man, partly by negligence, and partly by chance, as
by throwing a stone carelessely, shooting an arrow, or the
like.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="misbode(n)"><f type="i">Misbode<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="old word">(old word)</class> wrong.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="miscellany(n)"><f type="i">Miscellanies<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a mixture of several
things together, a collection of divers
notions treating of
different matters.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="miscreant(n)"><f type="i">Miscreant<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> an Infidel, or
unbeliever.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mise(n)"><f type="i">Mise<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="etymlang" lang="fr">a French word</class>, signifying in an
action of right or property, the point whereupon the
parties proceed to trial, either by Assize or Battle, as
issue is in an action personal.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="misericordia(n)"><f type="i">Misericordia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="law">in Common Law</class>, is an
arbitrary punishment, very moderate, and rather lesse than
the offence.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="miskenning(n)"><f type="i">Miskenning<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>is a changing of speech in
Court.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mizzen(n)" lexeme="mizzen-sail(n)">The <f type="i">Misne<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Misen-sail of a
Ship<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>is that which is between the poop and the main-sail.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="misogamy(n)"><f type="i">Misogamy<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a hating or contempt of
marriage.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mysogyny(n)"><f type="i"><emend err="Misoginy" source="errata">Mysogyny</emend><f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a hating of
women.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="misprision(n)"><f type="i">Misprision<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(from the French word
<f type="i"><term lang="fr">mespris</term><f type="r">)</class>
signifieth <class type="register" subject="law">in Common Law</class>, a neglect
or oversight, as a misprision of Felony, <f type="i">&amp;c.<f type="r">
is a neglect or light account had of Felony committed, by
not revealing it, when we know it to be committed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="misqueme(v)">To <f type="i">Misqueam<f type="r"><f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="old word">(old word)</class> to
displease.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="missal(n)"><f type="i">Missale<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a breviary or

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mistletoe(n)"><f type="i">Misseltoe<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Misseldin<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="du" type="etymlang">(in Dutch
<f type="i"><term lang="du">Mistel</term><f type="r">)</class> a certain plant which grows not upon the
ground, but upon other trees, of which it is reported,
that Thrushes eating the berries
of this plant and afterwards sitting to roust all night,
and shitting upon it, causeth it to bear bird-lime, whence
cometh the Proverb, The
Thrush shits her own sorrow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="missile(n)"><f type="i">Missile<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a dart or arrow, also <class type="register" subject="heraldry">a
term in Heraldry</class>, being a mixture of
several colours
together.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mission(n)"><f type="i">Mission<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a sending, it is also taken
</page>

<page sig="Cc3r">
peculiarly for a power given by the Church of
<f type="i">Rome<f type="r">, to go into other
Countries and preach
the Catholick Faith, and those that are thus sent, are
called <f type="i">Missionaries<f type="r">,
or fathers of the <f type="i">Mission<f type="r">.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="missive, letter(n)">A letter <f type="i">Missive<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a letter which is
sent from one friend to another.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mystery(n)"><f type="i">Mistery<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French <f type="i"><term lang="fr">Mistier</term><f type="r"></class>, <class lang="la" type="etymlang">Latin
<f type="i"><term lang="la">Magisterium</term><f type="r">)</class>
a craft, trade, or occupation, but coming from
<f type="i"><term lang="la">Mysterium</term><f type="r">, it signifieth a secret or hidden
businesse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Mithridates(pn)"><f type="i">Mithridates<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a King of <f type="i">Pontus<f type="r">, who
spake 22 Languages, he rebelling against the Romans was
overcome by <f type="i">Sylla<f type="r"> near <f type="i">Dardanus<f type="r">, and
afterwards by <f type="i">Lucullus<f type="r"> near <f type="i">Cyzicus<f type="r">, and
flying to <f type="i">Tigranes<f type="r"> King of <f type="i">Armenia<f type="r"> he
renewed the war, but at length was totally overthrown by
<f type="i">Pompey<f type="r">, and besieged in his own Palace, where
having in vain attempted to
poison himself, he assisted <f type="i">Gallus<f type="r"> the
Executioner (when his hand trembled) in the murdering of
himself. He was the first inventour of that excellent
Antidote against infection and poison, called from his own
name Mithridate.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mitigation(n)"><f type="i">Mitigation<f type="r"></form>. <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a pacifying or
asswaging.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mitten(n)"><f type="i">Mittins<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(in French <f type="i"><term lang="fr">Mitains</term><f type="r">)</class>
certain winter gloves made of cloth or furs.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mittimus(n)"><f type="i">Mittimus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Justice of peace his warrant to
send an offender to the Goale or prison.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Mitylene(pn)"><f type="i">Mitylene<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an ancient City of
<f type="i">Lesbos<f type="r">, not far from <f type="i">Methymna<f type="r">: from this
City the whole Island now takes its
denomination.</xpln></wordentry>

</page>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Monmouth(pn)"><f type="i">Monmouth<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the chief Town of
<f type="i">Monmouthshire<f type="r">,
called in the Brittish tongue <f type="i"><term lang="br">Mongwy</term><f type="r">, because it
is seated at the confluence of the Rivers <f type="i">Munow<f type="r">
and <f type="i">Wye<f type="r">. This Town is famous for the birth of
King <f type="i">Henry<f type="r"> the fifth, and of <f type="i">Geffry ap
Arthur<f type="r"> Bishop of <f type="i">Asaph<f type="r">, the compiler of the
ancient Brittish
Story.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="month(n)"><f type="i">Moneth<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="sx" type="etymlang">(Sax. <f type="i">Monad<f type="r"></class>, <class lang="du" type="etymlang">Dutch
<f type="i"><term lang="du">M&aelig;ndt</term><f type="r">, from <f type="i"><term lang="du">M&aelig;ne</term><f type="r">, i. the Moon)</class> the
space of 28 dayes, in which time the Moon
compleateth her
circle. There are four sorts of moneths. First a moneth of
Apparition, <f type="i">i.<f type="r"> the space of 26 dayes and 12
hours, wherein the Moon
appears, the other three days being deducted wherein it is
obscured by the Sun. Secondly Medical or
Decretorial, <f type="i">i.<f type="r"> the space of 26 days and 22 hours, Thirdly of
Consecution or Progression, <f type="i">i.<f type="r"> the space of one
conjunction of the Moon with the Sun, and the other being
29 dayes and a half. Fourthly of
Peragration, <f type="i">i.<f type="r"> the space of the Moons
revolution from any
part of the Zodiack unto the same again, being 27 dayes
and 8 hours.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="monger(n)"><f type="i">Monger<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Manger<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="sx" type="etymlang">a Saxon word
anciently used for a Merchant</class>, whence Woodmonger,
<f type="i">&amp;c.<f type="r"> i. a Woodmerchant.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="moneyer(n)"><f type="i">Moniers<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a word anciently used for
ministers of the Mint, coiners of money.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="monition(n)"><f type="i">Monition<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> an admonishing, or giving

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="monkshood(n)"><f type="i">Monkeshood<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kind of flower called in

that hath but one Case.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Monothelites(pn)"><f type="i">Monothelites<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a sort of

year 640, who held that there was but one will in
<f type="i">Christ<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

mountain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Monyma(pn)"><f type="i">Monyma<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the wife of King
<f type="i">Mithridates<f type="r">, who when her husband was overthrown,
attempted to have strangled her self by tying her Diadem
to her neck, but the rope breaking, she cursed her Diadem,
as being neither useful in prosperity, nor adversity, and
delivered her self up to an Eunuch to be slain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="moor a ship(v)">To <f type="i">Moor a ship<f type="r"><f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="navigation">a term in Navigation</class>, to

barren places thereabout
which have been anciently called Moores.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="moot(v)">To <f type="i">Moot<f type="r"><f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(from the French word <f type="i"><term lang="fr">Mot</term>,

meeting together)</class> <class type="register" subject="law">a term
used in the Innes of Court</class>, and signifieth to handle a
case in Law, and those that handle these cases are called
Mootmen, who after 7 or 8 years study, are chosen
Utterbaristers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="moral(a)"><f type="i">Moral<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> pertaining to manners or

hand) is in Common-law an Alienation of Lands, or

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Mounster(pn)"><f type="i">Mounster<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Province in <f type="i">Ireland<f type="r">,

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mountain of piety(n)"><f type="i">Mountain<f type="r"> of piety</form>, <xpln>a certain stock, or bank
of money, which used to be raised out of voluntary
contributions, and treasured up to be lent upon occasion
to poor people, who were
ruined by the usury and extortion of the Jews.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mountebank(n)"><f type="i">Mountebank<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="it" type="etymlang">(from the Italian word
<f type="i"><term lang="it">Montimbanco</term><f type="r">, because he monts upon some high
bench or form)</class> a Drugseller, or one that buys Drugs of
Apothecaries, and by much boasting of their vertues, sells
them again for choice Medecins. He is called in French
<f type="i"><term lang="fr">Charlatan</term><f type="r">, from his great talking and
bragging.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mow(n)">A <f type="i">Mowe<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(from the French <f type="i"><term lang="fr">Amas</term><f type="r">, i.
a heap)</class> a pile or
stack of corn or hay.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mew for hawks(n)">A <f type="i">Mue for Hawks<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kind of cage or aviary

comes from the <emend err="from the"></emend> French word <f type="i"><term lang="fr">Muer</term><f type="r">, to
change, whence that place called the <f type="i">Mues<f type="r"> near
Charing-crosse came to be so called, it having been
anciently appointed for the keeping of the Kings
Hawks.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mulier(n)"><f type="i">Mulier<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="law">in Common Law</class>, is a word taken
contradistinct to a bastard, as if a man have a son by a
woman before marriage,
and then marrying the mother of that son who is called a
bastard, have another son,
this second son is called <f type="i">Mulier<f type="r">, and being
compared together, they have this addition, Bastard
eldest, and Mulier youngest; but the most proper
signification of
Mulier is a woman that hath had the company of man.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Muses(pn)"><f type="i">Muses<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the 9 daughters of <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">
and <f type="i">Mnemosyne<f type="r">, born in the Country of
<f type="i">Pieria<f type="r"> (whence they are called <f type="i">Pierides<f type="r">)
and inhabiting
<f type="i">Helicon<f type="r"> a hill of <f type="i">Boeotia<f type="r">, they were

of the ingenuous Arts and Sciences, their names were
<f type="i">Calliope, Clio,

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Mutius, Q.(pn)">Q. <f type="i">Mutius<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a stout Roman, who in the war
with <f type="i">Porsenna<f type="r"> King of the <f type="i">Hetrurians<f type="r">
went into the enemies Camp with an
intent to have killed the
King; but being taken and threatned with extraordinary
punishments, he thrust his right hand into the fire and
burnt it off, to shew his contempt
of torments; whence he was called <f type="i">Sc&aelig;vola<f type="r">, and
telling <f type="i">Porsenna<f type="r">, that 300 youths had in like
manner conspired against
him, he was so terrified that immediately
he made a peace with the Romans.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mutual(a)"><f type="i">Mutual<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> passing between two,

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="myriad(n)"><f type="i">Myriad<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> the number of ten

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Myrmidons(pn)"><f type="i">Myrmidons<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain people of
<f type="i">Thessaly<f type="r">, who went under the conduct of
<f type="i">Achilles<f type="r"> to the wars of <f type="i">Troy<f type="r">. They were
so called from <f type="i">Myrmidon<f type="r"> an ancient King of
<f type="i">Thessaly<f type="r"> the son
of <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> and the Nimph
<f type="i">Corymosa<f type="r">, or else from a certain Virgin called
<f type="i">Myrmice<f type="r">, who for contemning <f type="i">Ceres<f type="r">, was
changed into an Ant, from which there springing up a
multitude of Ants, they were by the prayers of
<f type="i">Aeacus<f type="r">, when <f type="i">Thessaly<f type="r">
was almost depopulated, changed into men.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="myrobalan(n)"><f type="i">Myrobalanes<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a sort of medicinal fruit, by
some called Egyptian acorns, of which there are five
sorts, Bellerick, Chebule, Citrine, Emblick, and
Indian.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="myropolist(n)"><f type="i">Myropolist<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a seller of ointments
or sweet oiles.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Myrrha(pn)"><f type="i">Myrrha<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of <f type="i">Cynaras<f type="r">
King of <f type="i">Cyprus<f type="r">, who by the help of her Nurse
coming to lie with her father, was got with child by him,
and brought forth <f type="i">Adonis<f type="r"> the Paramour of
<f type="i">Venus<f type="r">, but <f type="i">Cynaras<f type="r">
afterwards being sensible of what was done, would have
slain her with his sword, whereupon she fled into
<f type="i">Arabia Felix<f type="r"> and was changed into a Tree of her
own name, from which there distilleth a sweet
aromatick Gum called
also Myrrhe.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="myrrhine(a)"><f type="i">Myrrhine<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to myrrhe, made
of myrrhe.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Myrsilus(pn)"><f type="i">Myrsilus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Myrsus<f type="r">, a
King of <f type="i">Lydia<f type="r">, called also <f type="i">Candaules<f type="r"> the
last of the race of the <f type="i">Heraclid&aelig;<f type="r">. see <xref target="_notfound"><f type="i">Candaules<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Myrtilus(pn)"><f type="i">Myrtilus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Mercury<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Ph&aelig;thusa<f type="r">, he
was the Chariot-driver of <f type="i">Oenomaus<f type="r">,
who being to run a race with <f type="i">Pelops Myrtilus<f type="r">
being promised a great reward, loosened the axeltree so,
that the Chariot being overturned <f type="i">Oenomaus<f type="r"> fell
out and broke his neck, but before he died, he
intreated <f type="i">Pelops<f type="r"> to revenge his death;
whereupon when
<f type="i">Myrtilus<f type="r"> came to demand his reward, he was thrown
into that Sea which from thence was called <f type="i">Mare
Myrtoum<f type="r">, now <f type="i">Mar
de Mandria<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="myrtle(n)"><f type="i">Myrtle<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kind of low tree which
beareth a little blackish
leaf of a very fragrant scent, and groweth onely in hot
Countries; this tree
was by the ancients acounted sacred to
<f type="i">Venus<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Mysia(pn)"><f type="i">Mysia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Country of <f type="i">Asia<f type="r"> the
Lesse, anciently divided into Higher <f type="i">Mysia<f type="r"> and
Lower <f type="i">Mysia<f type="r">, it containeth those
Countries which are now called <f type="i">Servia, Bulgaria<f type="r">,
and <f type="i">Wallachia<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mystagogical(n)"><f type="i">Mystagogical<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> belonging to a
Mystagogue, <f type="i">i. e.<f type="r"> he that interprets
Divine mysteries or ceremonies, also he that
</page>

<page sig="Dd2r">
hath the keeping of Church relicks, and shewing them to
strangers.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mysteriarch(n)"><f type="i">Mysteriarch<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a chief overseer of
sacred mysteries.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mystical(a)"><f type="i">Mystical<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> mysterious, secret,

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="mythology(n)"><f type="i"><emend err="Mithology" source="errata">Mythology</emend><f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a discourse and
exposition of fables.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="naam(v)"><f type="i">NAam<f type="r"></form> <xpln><class lang="du" type="etymlang">(from the Dutch word
<f type="i"><term lang="du">Memmen</term><f type="r">, i. to nim
or take hold on)</class> <class type="register" subject="law">in Common Law</class> is the taking of anothers
moveable goods, which if it be by
reasonable distresse
proportionable to the value of the thing distrained for,
it is called lawful Naam.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="nacre(n)"><f type="i">Nacre<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> mother of pearle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="nadir(n)"><f type="i">Nadir<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="etymlang" lang="ar">an Arabick word</class> oft used <class type="register" subject="astrology and astronomy">in
Astronomy</class>, signifying
that point of heaven directly under our feet, and opposite
to the Zenith.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="naenia(n)"><f type="i">N&aelig;nia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> Funeral-songs,

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="naiant(a)"><f type="i">Naiant<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> swimming or

<f type="i">Heraldry<f type="r"></class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="naif(a)"><f type="i">Naif<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> <class type="register" subject="jeweling">a term in Jewelling</class> and is
spoken of a Diamond or other Stone, which looketh quick
and natural, and hath all its properties as in water,
cleannesse, <f type="i">&amp;c.<f type="r"></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Nantwich(pn)"><f type="i">Nantwich<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town in <f type="i">Cheshire<f type="r">,
famous for the pits of brine or salt water, which are
called <f type="i">Wiches<f type="r">; it was named by the ancient
Brittains <f type="i"><term lang="br">Hellath Wen</term><f type="r">, i. the white Wich or Salt
pit; and by Latin Writers <f type="i">Vicus Malbanus<f type="r">, perhaps
from one <f type="i">William
Malbedeng<f type="r"> or <f type="i">Malbanc<f type="r">, anciently Lord
thereof.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="napaea(n)"><f type="i">Nap&aelig;&aelig;<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the Nimphs of the woods and
mountains, <class lang="gk" type="etymlang">from the Greek word <f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Nape</term>, i.<f type="r"> a
wood</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="naphthe(n)"><f type="i">Napthe<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a kind of sulphureous
substance, called Median oile, or
Babylonish bitumen.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Narcissus(pn)"><f type="i">Narcissus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a youth of great beauty, the son
of <f type="i">Cephisus<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Liriope<f type="r">, of whom the
Prophet <f type="i">Tyresias<f type="r"> foretold that he should live so
long as he should abstain from beholding
himself; he being beloved of many Nimphs and especially of
<f type="i">Echo<f type="r">, was insensible to all their loves, &amp; at
length coming to drink of a clear Fountain, and beholding
his image in the water, he fell in love with it, and
seeing no hopes of injoying
it, he pined away for grief and was changed into a Flower
of the same name, vulgarly called a white Daffadilly, and
<f type="i">Echo<f type="r"> seeing her self despised likewise, pined
away, and was changed into a voice. Also the name of a
Bishop of <f type="i">Jerusalem<f type="r">, who when oil was wanting at
Divine service for the
Lamps, by his prayers turned water into oil.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="narcotic(a)"><f type="i">Narcotique<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> of a stupefying and
benumming quality, whence divers things which are used <class type="register" subject="medicine">in
physick</class> to that end, are called <f type="i">Narcotic<f type="r">
<class type="register" subject="medicine">Medicines</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="nare(n)"><f type="i">Nares<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="hawking and hunting">a term in Faulconry</class>, the holes in
the Hawks beake.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="narration(n)" lexeme="narrative(n)">A <f type="i">Narration<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Narrative<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class>
a report, discourse, or relation of any thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Narses(pn)"><f type="i">Narses<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an Eunuch who being General of the
Emperour <f type="i">Justinians<f type="r"> Army in <f type="i">Italy<f type="r">, after
<f type="i">Belizarius<f type="r"> performed very great service against
the <f type="i">Goths<f type="r">, but at last being affronted by
<f type="i">Sophia<f type="r"> the Empresse, he
called in the <f type="i">Lombards<f type="r"> into <f type="i">Italy<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="nasicornous(a)"><class type="unknown">&dagger;</class> <f type="i">Nasicornous<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class type="neologism">a made word</class> which

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Nauplius(pn)"><f type="i">Nauplius<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Neptune<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Amymone<f type="r"> the
daughter of <f type="i">Danaus<f type="r">, he was King of
<f type="i">Eub&aelig;a<f type="r">, and father of <f type="i">Palamedes<f type="r">, who
being by the means of <f type="i">Vlisses<f type="r"> stoned to death,
<f type="i">Nauplius<f type="r"> in revenge made a great fire upon the
Mountain <f type="i">Caphareus<f type="r">, which the Greek Navy taking
to be the light of some near Harbour, sailed so near, that
they were cast away upon the rocks.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="nauseous(a)" lexeme="nauseative(a)"><f type="i">Nauseous<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Nauseative<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Nausicae(pn)"><f type="i">Nausic&aelig;<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of <f type="i">Alcinous<f type="r">
and <f type="i">Arete<f type="r">, she going out of the City one night
with her maid-servants to bath her, met with
<f type="i">Vlisses<f type="r"> who was shipwrack't upon that shore and
almost naked, whom she brought to her fathers Palace, gave
him cloths, and entertained him with a great deal of
respect.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Nazarites(pn)"><f type="i">Nazarites<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="he" type="etymlang">(Hebr.)</class> a sort of Jews who separated themselves from all

which they abstained from wine and suffered their hair to
grow, also the Disciples were called Nazarites, from

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Neaera(pn)"><f type="i">Ne&aelig;ra<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the name of a very fair Nimph, who
being got with child by <f type="i">Ph&aelig;bus<f type="r">, brought forth
two daughters, <f type="i">Lampetia<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Ph&aelig;thusa<f type="r">,
who kept the flocks of their father the Sun in
<f type="i">Sicily<f type="r">, many of which were killed by the
companions of <f type="i">Vlisses<f type="r">, for which they were cast
away at sea.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="neal-to(a)"><f type="i">Neale-too<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="navigation">in Navigation</class>, is when it is

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Neapolis(pn)"><f type="i">Neapolis<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the City of <f type="i">Naples<f type="r">
situate in <f type="i">Campania<f type="r"> in <f type="i">Italy<f type="r">, upon the
<f type="i">Mediterranean<f type="r">
Sea-side; it was built first of all by the Citizens of
<f type="i">Cuma<f type="r"> and called <f type="i">Parthenope<f type="r">,
from the name of one of the <f type="i">Syrens<f type="r"> who was there
buried, afterwards it was destroyed, then rebuilt and
called <f type="i">Neapolis<f type="r">,
which in Greek signifieth the new City; from this City the
Kingdom of <f type="i">Naples<f type="r"> takes its denomination,
containing all those
Countries of <f type="i">Italy<f type="r"> which are called <f type="i">Campania,
Apulia, Lucania, Magna
Gr&aelig;cia<f type="r">, and part of <f type="i">Latium<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="neap-tide(n)"><f type="i">Neap-tides<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>those smaller tides which
happen 7 dayes after the change, and 7 dayes after the
full of the Moon, whereas the greater tides which happen 7
dayes before the change and full, are called
Spring-tides.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="neat(n)"><f type="i">Neat<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="du" type="etymlang">(from the Dutch <f type="i"><term lang="du">Nieten</term><f type="r">, i.
to but)</class> an Oxe, Cow, or Stear.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Nemoea(pn)"><f type="i">Nemoea<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain wooddy Countrey of
<f type="i">Achaia<f type="r">, between <f type="i">Cleon&aelig;<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Phlius<f type="r">, here it was that <f type="i">Hercules<f type="r"> slew a
Lyon of a Monstrous
bignesse, which from the place was called the <f type="i">Nem&aelig;an<f type="r"> 
Lyon, in remembrance of which exploit he instituted
certain games, called also <f type="i">Nem&aelig;an<f type="r"> games.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Nemesis(pn)"><f type="i">Nemesis<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the goddesse of reward and

of <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> and Necessity, she was also called
<f type="i">Adrastia<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Rhamnusia<f type="r">, and placed by
the <f type="i">Aegyptians<f type="r">
above the Moon.</xpln></wordentry>

to woods, wooddy, shaded with trees.

age he lived to.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Nestorians(pn)"><f type="i">Nestorians<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a sort of Hereticks, so called

as well as two natures in Christ.</xpln></wordentry>

<f type="i">Alexander<f type="r"> Bishop of <f type="i">Lincoln<f type="r">. In this

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Newcastle(pn)"><f type="i">Newcastle<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a noted Town in
<f type="i">Northumberland<f type="r">,
situate upon the River <f type="i">Tine<f type="r">, which maketh a very
commodious Haven for ships: It derived this name from the
new Castle built by <f type="i">Robert<f type="r"> son to
<f type="i">William<f type="r"> the Conquerour. Some think it to have
been that Town which was anciently called
<f type="i">Gabrosentum<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="new year's gift(n)"><f type="i">Newyears-gift<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a gift presented to friends
or great persons the first day of <f type="i">January<f type="r">, a
custom derived from the ancient Romans who used to offer
Presents to the Emperors in the Capitol though they were
absent. In <f type="i">Italy<f type="r"> it is the custom for the
greatest persons to give to the meanest, whereas here the
meanest give to the greatest.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Nilus(pn)"><f type="i">Nilus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a River running through the midst of
<f type="i">Aegypt<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Aethiopia<f type="r">, counted the
chiefest and the father of all other Rivers, and as some
say, taketh its name from <f type="i">Nilus<f type="r"> an ancient King
of <f type="i">Aegypt<f type="r">. This River is famous for overflowing
the Country every year, and making the soil fruitful, and
for falling into the Sea within seven mouths in <emend err="he">the</emend> figure
of a Greek &Delta;.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Ninus(pn)"><f type="i">Ninus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an ancient King of the
<f type="i">Assyrians<f type="r"> the son of <f type="i">Jupiter Belus<f type="r">, he
very much enlarged the <f type="i">Assyrian<f type="r"> Empire, overcame
<f type="i">Barzanes<f type="r"> King of the <f type="i">Armenians, Pharus<f type="r">
King of the <f type="i">Medes, Zoroaster<f type="r"> the King of the
<f type="i">Bactrians<f type="r">, the first inventour of
Magick, and
<f type="i">Sabarius<f type="r"> King of the <f type="i">Sag&aelig;<f type="r">, at length he
was secretly made away by his wife <f type="i">Semiramis<f type="r">,
(whom he had taken from <f type="i">Menon<f type="r"> the Prefect of
<f type="i">Syria<f type="r">) who conspiring against his life succeeded
him in the Kingdom.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Niobe(pn)"><f type="i">Niobe<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of <f type="i">Tantalus<f type="r">
and sister of <f type="i">Pelops<f type="r">, she was married to
<f type="i">Amphion<f type="r">, and by
him had 6 sons and 6 daughters,
whom <f type="i">Juno<f type="r"> prevailed with <f type="i">Apollo<f type="r"> to kill
with his Bow and Arrows, because their mother had
adventured to preferre her self above the goddesse, and
<f type="i">Niobe<f type="r"> her self while she was railing against
<f type="i">Juno<f type="r"> was carried by a whirlewind into
<f type="i">Asia<f type="r">, and there changed into a stone.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Niphates(pn)"><f type="i">Niphates<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Hill parting <f type="i">Armenia<f type="r">
the greater from <f type="i">Assyria<f type="r">, from this Hill the
River <f type="i">Tigris<f type="r"> springs.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Niseus(pn)"><f type="i">Niseus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Tyrant of <f type="i">Syracuse<f type="r">, who
being admonish't by the <f type="i">Augurs<f type="r"> that he had but a
short while to live, spent the remainder of his life in
excesse of luxury, and revelling.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="nisi prius(n)"><f type="i">Nisi prius<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Writ judicial that lieth
where the Enquest is panelled and
returned before the
Justices of the bank, the one party, or the other making
petition to have this
Writ for the ease of the Countrey.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Nisus(pn)"><f type="i">Nisus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a King of the <f type="i">Megarenses<f type="r">,
against whom war was made by <f type="i">Minos<f type="r">, a King of
<f type="i">Crete<f type="r">, to revenge the death of his sonne
<f type="i">Androgeus<f type="r">, who was slain by the
<f type="i">Megarenses<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Athenians<f type="r">, conspiring together; at length
<f type="i">Megara<f type="r"> was taken by the treache&shy;
</page>

<page sig="Dd4r">
ry of <f type="i">Scylla<f type="r">, who for the love of <f type="i">Minos<f type="r">
cut off her fathers purple Lock on which depended the
fate of his life and Kingdom,
whereupon <f type="i">Nisus<f type="r"> pined away for grief, and was
changed into a Hawk, and <f type="i">Scylla<f type="r"> seeing her self
despised of <f type="i">Minos<f type="r"> pined away also, and was
changed into a Partridge.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="nitidity(n)" lexeme="nitor(n)"><f type="i">Nitidity<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Nitour<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class>
cleannesse, gaynesse, brightnesse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="nitrous(a)"><f type="i">Nitrous<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> full of, or savouring of
<f type="i">Nitre<f type="r">, i. a kinde of substance like unto Salt,
somewhat spongy, and full of holes, it a little resembleth
Salt peter, but is not the same as some suppose it to

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="niveous(a)"><f type="i">Niveous<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> snowy, white, like unto

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Nixii(pn)"><f type="i">Nixii<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>certain gods among the Romans, who
were said to be assisting to women in Childbirth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Nixus(pn)"><f type="i">Nixus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>one of the heavenly
constellations,
resembling <f type="i">Hercules<f type="r"> with his knee bent, and
indeavouring to strike at the Dragons head; it is also
called <f type="i"><term lang="la">Ingeniculum</term><f type="r">,
in Greek <f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Engonasin</term><f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

substantively taken
for a night Dial.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="noli me tangere(n)"><f type="i">Noli me tangere<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kinde of Herb whose seed
spurts away as soon as it is touch't; also a disease so
called wherein the part affected, the oftner it is toucht
the worse it grows.</xpln></wordentry>

<f type="i">Spain<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

or County.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="nombril(n)"><f type="i">Nombreil<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="heraldry">a Term in Heraldry</class>, being the
lower part of an Escutcheon, the
honour point being the
uppermost part, the Fesse the middle part, the word
signifieth in French a Navel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="nomenclator(n)"><f type="i">Nomenclator<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(from the Latin word
<f type="i"><term lang="la">Nomen</term><f type="r">, i. e. a name</class>, and <class lang="gk" type="etymlang">the Greek
<f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Caleo</term><f type="r">, i.
e. to call)</class> one that calleth things by their proper and
significant names,
among the Romans there were certain Officers, so called,
who gave unto their Lord an account of the names of all
such as saluted him as
they passed, they were also such as we call the Criers of
a Court.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="nominal(a)"><f type="i">Nominal<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to a name.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="nominalia(n)"><f type="i">Nominalia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> certain festival dayes
among the Romans wherein they gave names to their
Children, for Males it was the eighth day, for Females the
ninth, which was called <f type="i">dies lustricus<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="nomination(n)"><f type="i">Nomination<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a naming, also in Common
and Canon-law, it is taken for a powr that man hath by
virtue of a Mannour, or otherwise to appoint a Clark to a
Patron of a benefice by him to be presented to the
ordinary.</xpln></wordentry>

he cannot Commence any suit in Law.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Nonacris(pn)"><f type="i">Nonacris<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Mountain of <f type="i">Arcadia<f type="r">,
at the foot of which is the River <f type="i">Styx<f type="r">, whose
water is so cold that it cannot be contain'd in any other
Vessel, but onely in the hoof of a Mule.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="non compos mentis(n)"><f type="i">Non compos mentis<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>or one that is not in his
right wits, signifieth <class type="register" subject="law">in Common-law</class>; first, an Ideot
born; secondly, one that
</page>

<page sig="Dd4v">
by accident looseth his wits; thirdly, a Lunatick;
fourthly, a drunkard.
</xpln></wordentry>

July<f type="r">, and <f type="i">October<f type="r">, they are six dayes, in

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Normannia(pn)" lexeme="Normandy(pn)"><f type="i">Normannia<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Normandy<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>a Countrey
of <f type="i">Gallia Celtica<f type="r">; so called from the
<f type="i">Normanni<f type="r">, a
people anciently inhabiting <f type="i">Norwegia<f type="r">,
who in the time of Charles the Grosse had this Countrey
assigned them to dwell in, it being formerly called
<f type="i">Neustria<f type="r">, and the people were all baptised with
their Duke <f type="i">Rollo<f type="r">, whose name was changed into
<f type="i">Robert<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Northallerton(pn)"><f type="i">Northallerton<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>or <f type="i">Northalverton<f type="r">,
the chief Town of <f type="i">Northallertonshire<f type="r">, being a
part of <f type="i">York-shire<f type="r">, anciently so called, near
this Town was fought that famous pitcht field, commonly
called the battail of the Standard, where <f type="i">Ralph<f type="r">
Bishop of <f type="i">Durham<f type="r">
overthrew <f type="i">David<f type="r"> King of <f type="i">Scots<f type="r">, it was so
called because the <f type="i">English<f type="r"> receiving the first
onset of the <f type="i">Scots<f type="r">, kept themselves close
together about the Standard, which resembled the
<f type="i">Caroccio<f type="r">, so much used by the
<f type="i">Italians<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Northampton(pn)"><f type="i">Northampton<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the chief Citie of
<f type="i">Northamptonshire<f type="r">,
so called by contraction from <f type="i">Northfandon<f type="r">, near
this place was fought that bloudy battel wherein King
<f type="i">Henry<f type="r"> the sixth was taken prisoner, by
<f type="i">Richard Nevil<f type="r">, Earle of <f type="i">Warwick<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="nostoc(n)"><f type="i">Nostoch<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>is taken by some for a certain
kinde of excrement, or polluted matter like to a gelly, of

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Norwegia(pn)"><f type="i">Norwegia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Countrey of <f type="i">Europe<f type="r">,
formerly a Kingdom by it self; it is now called
<f type="i">Norwey<f type="r">, and is under the Government of the
<f type="i">Danes<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Norwich(pn)"><f type="i">Norwich<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the chief Citie of
<f type="i">Northfolk<f type="r">, heretofore called <f type="i">Northwick,
i.<f type="r"> Northerly Creek, <class type="etymlang" lang="sx"><f type="i">Wick<f type="r"> signifying in the
<f type="i">Saxon<f type="r"> tongue, the Creek, or Cove of a River</class>, it
was set on fire by <f type="i">Sweno<f type="r"> the <f type="i">Dane<f type="r">, in
the time of King <f type="i">Ethelred<f type="r">, but it flourisht again
after the Conquest, and the Castle was re-edified by
<f type="i">Hugh Bigod<f type="r">, Earle of <f type="i">Northfolk, Lewis<f type="r">
the <f type="i">Frenchman<f type="r"> won it by assault from King
<f type="i">John<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Nottingham(pn)"><f type="i">Nottingham<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the chief Town of
<f type="i">Nottinghamshire<f type="r">,
it is so called by a mollified pronuntiation, <class type="etymlang" lang="sx">from the
<f type="i">Saxon<f type="r"> word <f type="i"><term lang="sx">Snottengaham</term><f type="r">,
i. a house of Dennes, or Caves</class>, it hath a strong Castle,

<f type="i">Aethered<f type="r">, King of the <f type="i">West-Saxons<f type="r">, and
his brother <f type="i">Aelfrid<f type="r">, who were stirred up by

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Novatians(pn)"><f type="i">Novatians<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a sort of Hereticks, who
condemned second marriages, and held that those who had
once fall'n, ought not to be received into the Church,
although they afterwards repented: they were
seduced by one
<f type="i">Novatus<f type="r">, in the year 215.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="nullo(n)"><f type="i">Nullo<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="mathematics">(Arithm.)</class> a Cipher that stands for
nothing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Numa Pompilius(pn)"><f type="i">Numa Pompilius<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the second King of the
Romans, a <f type="i">Sabine<f type="r"> born, he built the Temple of
<f type="i">Janus<f type="r">, created the <f type="i">Dial
Martial<f type="r">, and
<f type="i">Quirinal<f type="r"> Flamins, he made the twelve
<f type="i">Salii<f type="r">, or Priests of <f type="i">Mars<f type="r">, and the
High-Priest, consecrated the <f type="i">Vestal<f type="r">
Virgins, distinguisht the
dayes into hallow'd and unhallowed, and divided the year
into twelve moneths, and that
these things might gain the greater credit with the
people, he faign'd that every night he had private
discourse with the Nymph <f type="i">Aegeria<f type="r">,
and that what he had instituted was by her
appointment.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="numbles(n)"><f type="i">Numbles<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> the entrailes of a Stag,
or Dear.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="numeration(n)"><f type="i">Numeration<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a numbring.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="numerical(a)"><f type="i">Numerical<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to number, also
<class type="register" subject="logic">a Term in Logick</class>, as Numerical difference
is that difference which together with the lowermost
species constitutes the <f type="i">Individuum<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Numitor(pn)"><f type="i">Numitor<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Procas<f type="r">, King
of the <f type="i">Albanians<f type="r">, he was driven out of his
Kingdom by his younger
brother <f type="i">Amulius<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

obligeth her self to perpetual virginity,
and espouseth her self to the Church.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="nuncupation(n)"><f type="i">Nuncupation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a pronouncing, or

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="nundinary(a)"><f type="i">Nundinary<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to fairs, or

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="nuntio(n)"><f type="i">Nuntio<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="it" type="etymlang">(Ital.)</class> a Messenger Legat or

the Popes Legat</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="nuper obiit(n)"><f type="i">Nuper Obiit<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the name of a Writ, which
lieth for a Coheir, being deforced by her Coheir of Land,
or Tenements, whereof any of their Ancestours died seised
in fee-simple.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Nycteus(pn)"><f type="i">Nycteus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of Neptune and Celene, the
daughter of Atlas, he married a
Cretan Nymph, called
Amalth&aelig;a, by whom he had Antiope and Nyctimene, the
latter of which falling in love with her father, came
</page>

<page sig="Ee1v">
by the help of her Nurse to injoy him, but being
afterwards known, and flying from her fathers wrath, she
was changed into an Oake.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="nymphal(a)"><f type="i">Nymphal<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to the Nymphs,
which were accounted by the ancients certain rural
goddesses, of which some were called the Nymphs of the
woods, or <f type="i">Dryades<f type="r">, some of the
mountains, or
<f type="i">Oreades<f type="r">, some of the waters, or <f type="i">Naiades<f type="r">,
&amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

situate in a very fruitfull soyl; also one of the tops of
the mountain <f type="i">Parnassus<f type="r">,
consecrate to Bacchus.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Nysus(pn)"><f type="i">Nysus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a King of the <f type="i">Megarenses<f type="r">,

raign'd.</xpln></wordentry>

at the top, differing onely
from a <f type="i">Pyramid<f type="r">, in that it is four-square, and

is amisse, and better left out then inserted.</xpln></wordentry>

</page>

<page sig="Ee2v">
Regions to which it is annext. Among the Poets the son
of <f type="i">Coelus<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Vesta<f type="r"> is cal&shy;
led <f type="i">Oceanus<f type="r">, who marrying <f type="i">Tethys<f type="r">, was
thought to be the father of all the Rivers and Fountains.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Ochus(pn)"><f type="i">Ochus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the sirname of <f type="i">Artaxerxes<f type="r">
the son of <f type="i">Artaxerxes Mnemon<f type="r"> by his daughter
<f type="i">Ancestris<f type="r">, he subdued <f type="i">Aegypt<f type="r">, overcame
<f type="i">Tennes<f type="r"> King of <f type="i">Phoenicia, Hermias<f type="r"> the
<f type="i">Acarnensian<f type="r"> Tyrant, <f type="i">Euagoras<f type="r"> King of
<f type="i">Cyprus<f type="r">, took <f type="i">Sidon<f type="r">, by the help of
<f type="i">Mentor<f type="r">, he buried his Sister and Mother in Law
alive, caused his Uncle with a hundred of his children and
grandchildren to be slain, but at last was poisoned by his Physitian
<f type="i">Bagoas<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Olympia(pn)"><f type="i">Olympia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a City of <f type="i">Greece<f type="r">, near
unto which were solemnized the great Games instituted by
<f type="i">Hercules<f type="r"> in honour of <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">;
they were from the name of this City called the Olympian
Games, and were celebrated every fifth year, which space
was observed as an Epoch of time by the Greeks, and called
an Olympiad.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Olympias(pn)"><f type="i">Olympias<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the Christian name of divers

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Olympus(pn)"><f type="i">Olympus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a hill in that part of
<f type="i">Thessaly<f type="r"> that lieth against <f type="i">Macedon<f type="r">, the
top of this hill toucheth the clouds, and therefore it
hath been taken by the Poets for Heaven, or the seat of
the gods.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Olynthus(pn)"><f type="i">Olynthus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a City of <f type="i">Thrace<f type="r"> which
<f type="i">Philip<f type="r"> of <f type="i">Macedon<f type="r"> won from the
<f type="i">Athenians<f type="r"> by corrupting the souldiers with
