<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Omphale(pn)"><f type="i">Omphale<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Queen of <f type="i">Lydia<f type="r"> by whom
<f type="i">Hercules<f type="r"> was highly rewarded for killing a
great Serpent upon the River <f type="i">Sangaris<f type="r">, and
afterwards he falling in love with her and desiring to
be intertained in her service,
she compelled him to sit and spin, while she leaving her
distaff, put on his armes and Lions skin; others say that he
</page>

<page sig="Ee3v">
was sold to her by <f type="i">Mercury<f type="r"> at the
command of
<f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">, for having slain <f type="i">Iphitus<f type="r"> the
son of <f type="i">Euritus<f type="r">.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="onyx(n)"><f type="i">Onyx<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain pretious Stone, so
called <class lang="gk" type="etymlang">from the Greek word
<term lang="gk">&#x1F40;&#x03B9;&#x03BD;&#x03BE;</term>. <f type="i">i.<f type="r"> a naile of a mans hand</class>,

<f type="i">Chalcedonie<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

but they all ceast immediately after the coming of

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="orbation(n)"><f type="i">Orbation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a bereaving, depriving, or

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="orb(n)"><f type="i">Orbe<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a body contained under one round
superficies; those <f type="i">Orbs<f type="r"> that belong to the
coelestial firmament, are either with, or without Stars,
that without Stars is the <f type="i">primum mobile<f type="r">, the
other are all stellified, either with fixed Stars, or
Planets.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="orbicular(a)"><f type="i">Orbicular<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> round, in fashion of a

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="orbity(n)"><f type="i">Orbity<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> the lack of Parents, or

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Orbona(pn)"><f type="i">Orbona<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain goddesse among the

whirle-pool, also a Butt for wine, or figs.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="orcanet(n)"><f type="i">Orchanet<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="ar" type="etymlang">(Arab. <f type="i"><term lang="ar">Alcanet</term><f type="r">)</class> a
certain Herb, called in <f type="i">Spanish<f type="r"> <term lang="sp">Buglosse</term>, or

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="orchil(n)"><f type="i">Orchel<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Orchal<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>a certain stone
like Allum, wherewith Dyers use to colour red, in some old
Statutes it seemeth to be the same thing with Cork.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="orchestre(n)"><f type="i">Orchester<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> that part of the Scene
in a Theater, where the <f type="i">Chorus<f type="r"> useth to dance; it
is also sometimes taken for the place where the Musicians sit.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Orcus(pn)"><f type="i">Orcus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a River of <f type="i">Thessaly<f type="r">,
flowing out of the Lake <f type="i">Styx<f type="r">, whose waters are so
thick, that they swim like Oyl upon the top of the River
<f type="i">Peneus<f type="r"> into which it flows, it is oft times taken
by the Poets for Hell.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="ordeal(n)"><f type="i">Ordeal<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="sx" type="etymlang">(a Sax. word, signifying
judgement)</class> a kinde of
purgation practised in ancient times, whereby the party
purged was judged free from Crime, it is called in
Common-law <f type="i">purgatio vulgaris<f type="r">, of this purgation
there are several kindes; as <f type="i">Camp-fight<f type="r">, wherein
he that overcame in single Combat, was judged to have the
right on his side. <f type="i">Fire-Ordeal<f type="r">, i. a passing blindfold with
bare feet over red hot plough-shares, and
<f type="i">Water-Ordeal, i. e.<f type="r"> a putting ones arms up to the
elbows in seething water.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="ordinary(n)"><f type="i">Ordinary<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> <class type="register" subject="law">in the Civil-law</class>,
signifieth any judge
that hath authority to take knowledge of causes in his own
right, as he is a Magistrate, and not by deputation, in
Common-law it is usually taken for him that hath ordinary
Jurisdiction in Causes Ecclesiastical; also <class type="register" subject="heraldry">in Heraldry</class>,
<f type="i">Ordinaries<f type="r"> are those charges that by a certain
property do belong, to that art, and are of ordinary use
therein, they are also called proper charges.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="oread(n)"><f type="i">Oreads<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> Nymphs of the
Mountains.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="oredelf(n)"><f type="i">Oredelf<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>ore lying under ground, also a
liberty whereby a man claims the ore found in his own
ground.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Oreford(pn)"><f type="i">Oreford<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town in <f type="i">Suffolk<f type="r">, where in
the reign of King <f type="i">Henry<f type="r"> the second, a certain
hairy creature perfectly resem&shy;
</page>

<page sig="Ee4v">
bling a man, in all parts and proportions, was taken out of
the Sea by fisher-men in a Net, who after he had been
kept awhile, secretly slipt away into the Sea, and was
never seen after, this <f type="i">Ralph Cogeshall<f type="r"> an old
Writer recordeth.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Orestes(pn)"><f type="i">Orestes<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Agamemnon<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Clytemnestra<f type="r">,
he was preserved from <f type="i">Aegisthus<f type="r">, by his sister
<f type="i">Electra<f type="r">, and sent to <f type="i">Strophius<f type="r">, King of
the <f type="i">Phocences<f type="r">, where he remained twelve years,
after which returning disguised
to <f type="i">Argos<f type="r">, he slew <f type="i">Aegysthus<f type="r"> (who had
murthered his father <f type="i">Agamemnon<f type="r">) together with his
mother <f type="i">Clytemn&aelig;stra<f type="r">, with whom
<f type="i">Aegysthus<f type="r"> had lived in
adultery, he also with
the help of <f type="i">Macarus<f type="r"> the Priest slew
<f type="i">Pyrrhus<f type="r">, in the temple of <f type="i">Apollo<f type="r">,
because he had taken away <f type="i">Hermione<f type="r">, the daughter
of <f type="i">Menelaus<f type="r">, who had been first espoused to him,
for which crimes, being strucken with madness, he was
cured at the Altar of <f type="i">Diana<f type="r">, being brought
thither by <f type="i">Pylades<f type="r">, who was so faithfull a friend
to him, that when <f type="i">Thoas<f type="r"> King of <f type="i">Taurica<f type="r">
had designed to sacrifice <f type="i">Orestes<f type="r">, he affirmed
himself to be <f type="i">Orestes<f type="r">, that he might die for his
friend; but <f type="i">Orestes<f type="r"> slaying <f type="i">Thoas<f type="r">, freed
both himself and <f type="i">Pylades<f type="r">, with the help of his
sister <f type="i">Iphigeneia<f type="r">, who had been made the
over-seer of those sacrifices, at last he was bitten by a
Viper in <f type="i">Arcadia<f type="r">, at a place called
<f type="i">Orestion<f type="r">, of which wound he died, and his body
being digged up, was found to be seven Cubits in
length.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="orewood(n)"><f type="i">Orewood<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kinde of Sea-weed.</xpln></wordentry>

the Clergy, and Kings themselves.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Orion(pn)"><f type="i">Orion<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the name of a great hunter, who
vaunting himself to be of that strength of body, that
there was no wilde beast that he could not kill, the earth
brought forth a Scorpion, which stinging him to death, he
was placed together with the Scorpion among the heavenly
constellations, some say he was the son of
<f type="i">Oenopion<f type="r"> King of <f type="i">Sicilie<f type="r">, and that lying
with his sister <f type="i">Candiope<f type="r">,
he had his eyes put out by his father,
others deliver him to have been born by a very strange
way, of which see more in <xref><f type="i">Hyreus<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Orithyia(pn)"><f type="i">Orithyia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of
<f type="i">Erectheus<f type="r">, King of <f type="i">Athens<f type="r">, she was
ravish't away by <f type="i">Boreas<f type="r">, who fell in love with
her, and brought forth <f type="i">Zethus<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Calais<f type="r">, who going
with the <f type="i">Argonauts<f type="r"> to <f type="i">Colchos<f type="r">, put the
<f type="i">Harpies<f type="r"> to flight.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="orle(n)"><f type="i">Orle<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Term in <f type="i">Blason<f type="r">, being an
ordinary composed, of a
threefold line doubled,
admitting a transparency of the field through the
innermost space.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="orlop(n)"><f type="i">Orlop<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="navigation">a Term in Navigation</class>, signifying the

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Ormus(pn)"><f type="i">Ormus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous Citie of <f type="i">Persia<f type="r">,
being most pleasantly situated in an Island, and abounding
with shells which breed the fairest and clearest Pearles
that are; it was taken by the Lieutenant General to the
King of <f type="i">Portugal<f type="r">, in the year 1506.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Orontes(pn)"><f type="i">Orontes<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a River of <f type="i">Coelosyria<f type="r">,

ground, till it come to <f type="i">Apamia<f type="r">, and falleth into

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Orpheus(pn)"><f type="i">Orpheus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous Poet, and Musician of
<f type="i">Thrace<f type="r">, the son of <f type="i">Calliope<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Apollo<f type="r">, he took so heavily the losse of his wife <f type="i">Euri&shy;
</page>

<page sig="Ff1r">
dice<f type="r"> (of which see <xref><f type="i">Euridice<f type="r"></xref>) that he
utterly abandoned the
company of women, for which he was torn in pieces by the
<f type="i">M&aelig;nades<f type="r"> at the Feast of <f type="i">Bacchus<f type="r">, and
his several members being cast down the
River <f type="i">Hebrus<f type="r"> were gathered up by the
Muses and buried, and his
Harp translated up to Heaven.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="orpiment(n)"><f type="i">Orpiment<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain drug found deep in the
earth, being a kind of Arsenick or Ratsbane, and is called
in Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Auripigmentum</term><f type="r">,

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Osiris(pn)"><f type="i">Osiris<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Niobe<f type="r"> the daughter of <f type="i">Phoroneus<f type="r">, whom he
succeeded in the Kingdom of <f type="i">Argos<f type="r">, but after a
while leaving that Kingdom to his brother <f type="i">Aegialeus<f type="r">, he
went and subdued <f type="i">Aegypt<f type="r">, and married the daughter
of <f type="i">Inachus<f type="r"> called <f type="i">Io<f type="r"> or <f type="i">Isis<f type="r">,
who first taught the <f type="i">Egyptians<f type="r"> Letters, and
sundry Arts and Sciences; he was at length slain by
<f type="i">Typhon<f type="r"> his brother,
and after his death was worshipped by the
<f type="i">Egyptians<f type="r"> in the shape of an Oxe.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Osith, St.(pn)">St. <f type="i">Osith<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town in <f type="i">Essex<f type="r"> so

<f type="i">Osith<f type="r"> a Virgin of a Royal Family, who having
consecrated her self to the service of God, was here slain
by Danish Pirates.</xpln></wordentry>

manner.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Othryades(pn)"><f type="i">Othryades<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain <f type="i">Lacedemonian<f type="r">, who
in a combat of 300 <f type="i">Lacedemonians<f type="r"> to 300
<f type="i">Argives<f type="r">, being the onely man of all his party
left alive, put to flight those two who were the onely
men left alive of the <f type="i">Argives<f type="r">, and writing upon
his shield these words, <f type="i">I have overcome<f type="r">, he
slew himself, as being ashamed to return to
<f type="i">Sparta<f type="r">, all the rest of his companions being slain.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="otraque(n)"><f type="i">Otraque<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain drink which is made of a

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Ottadini(pn)"><f type="i">Ottadini<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the ancient name of a people
inhabiting that part of <f type="i">Brittain<f type="r">, which is now
called <f type="i">Northumberland<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Otterbourn(pn)"><f type="i">Otterbourn<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town in
<f type="i">Northumberland<f type="r"> near which was fought a famous
battle between the <f type="i">English<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Scots<f type="r">, in
which <f type="i">William Douglas<f type="r"> the Leader of the
Scottish Army was slain,
and Sir <f type="i">Henry Percy<f type="r"> called <f type="i">Hotspur<f type="r">
Commander of the English,
having lost 1500 of his men, was
taken prisoner
himself.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Otus(pn)" lexeme="Ephialtes(pn)"><f type="i">Otus<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Ephialtes<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the <emend err="son" source="errata">sons</emend> of
<f type="i">Neptune<f type="r"> by <f type="i">Iphimedeia<f type="r"> the wife of
<f type="i">Aloeus<f type="r">, they were of those Gyants that made war
with heaven, throwing huge rocks and hills
against the gods, and were
at last shot to death by <f type="i">Apollo<f type="r">: they were
reported to have grown the length of nine acres in nine years.</xpln></wordentry>

</wordgroup1>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="ovation(n)"><f type="i">Ovation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a kind of petty Triumph for
a Victory obtained with the slaughter of a few men onely,
it is so called from the souldiers following their
Commander shouting and singing <f type="i">O, O<f type="r">, or from
<f type="i">Ovis, i.<f type="r"> a sheep which used to be sacrificed by
him, whereas in a greater Triumph the General sacrificed a
Bull, and his souldiers following cryed out <f type="i">Io, Io,
Triumpho<f type="r">, also
<f type="i">Ovation<f type="r">, from <f type="i">Ovum<f type="r">, i. an egge
signifying the season wherein hens lay egges.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="ouche(n)">An <f type="i">Ouch<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a collar of Gold, a Jewel or

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="oviary(n)"><f type="i">Oviary<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a flock of sheep.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="ounce(n)"><f type="i">Ounce<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain weight, being the twelfth

pois<f type="r">, it is the sixteenth part; also a kind of

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="ox"><alpha>O X</alpha>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Oxford(pn)"><f type="i">Oxford<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the chief City of
<f type="i">Oxfordshire<f type="r">, which some say hath been anciently
called <f type="i">C&aelig;r
Vortigern<f type="r">, and <f type="i">C&aelig;r Vember<f type="r">, as being thought
to have been built by <f type="i">Vortigern<f type="r">
and <f type="i">Memprix<f type="r">; but the Saxons
called it <f type="i"><term lang="sx">Oxenford</term><f type="r">
(corresponding to <f type="i">Bosphorus<f type="r">
among the Greeks) from a foard of Oxen. <f type="i">Leland<f type="r">
deriveth it from the River <f type="i">Ouse<f type="r">, and supposeth it
may have formerly been called <f type="i">Ouseford<f type="r">. It is
chiefly famous for its
University which <f type="i">Cambden<f type="r">
calleth, Our most noble <f type="i">Athens<f type="r">, the Muses seat,
the Sun, the Eye, and the Soul of <f type="i">England<f type="r">. This
University was begun, as most Authors agree, in the year
of our Lord 806. three Colledges being built by the
learned <f type="i">Aelfred<f type="r"> who then reigned.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="oxgang of land(n)"><f type="i">Oxgang of land<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>see <f type="i">Bovata
terr&aelig;<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="oxygon(n)"><f type="i">Oxygon<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> <class type="register" subject="mathematics">a term in Geometry</class>, being a

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="oxymel(n)"><f type="i">Oxymel<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a certain kind of

vinegar, and water boyled together, being good to
attenuate grosse phlegmatick humours.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Palamedes(pn)"><f type="i">Palamedes<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Nauplius<f type="r">
King of <f type="i">Eub&aelig;a<f type="r">, he was the occasion of
<f type="i">Vlisses<f type="r"> being
forced against his will to go to the <f type="i">Trojan<f type="r"> wars,
but was himself by a forged accusation of
<f type="i">Vlisses<f type="r">, stoned to death by the <f type="i">Gr&aelig;cian<f type="r">
Army. He is said to have been the first that accomodated
the year to the course of the Sun; he is also said to have
found out the use of weights and measures, and to have
added to the Greek tongue these 4 letters,
<term lang="gk">&#x03B8;. &#x03BE;. &#x03C7;. &#x03C6;</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Palatinate(n)"><f type="i">Palatinate<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the Country or chief Seat of a

Sovereign Princes Palace;
but it is more especially taken for one of the Electors of
the Roman Empire called the

certain Knights of this Island, in ancient times called
Knights of the round Table, were called
<f type="i">Paladines<f type="r">, also Palatine signifieth adjectively
belonging to a Princes Palace.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Palici(pn)" lexeme="Palisci(pn)"><f type="i">Palici<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Palisci<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>two twins the
sons of <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> and the Nimph <f type="i">Thaleia<f type="r">,
whom he ravisht by the River <f type="i">Simethius<f type="r">, when she
was with child she wished that the earth would open and
hide her from the wrath of <f type="i">Juno<f type="r">, whereupon the
earth immediately
opened and received her within its bowels, and as soon as
she was delivered, it opened again and let out the two
twins into the World.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Palladium(pn)"><f type="i">Palladium<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain Image of

stollen out of the Temple by <f type="i">Vlisses<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Diomede<f type="r">, the City was soon after
taken by the Greeks, it was
at last brought to <f type="i">Rome<f type="r"> and placed in the Temple
of <f type="i">Vesta<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

concealing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="pallid(a)"><f type="i">Pallid<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> pale, whitish, bleak.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="pallification(n)"><f type="i">Pallification<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> <class type="register" subject="architecture">a term in
Architecture</class>, it
signifies the piling of the ground-work, or the
strengthning of the ground-work with piles of timber
driven into the ground, when they build upon a moist or
marshy soile.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="palmar(n)"><f type="i">Palmar<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to a Palm,
<f type="i">i.<f type="r"> the inward part of the hand called the Palm of
the hand; also a measure containing
the breadth of 4 fingers, a hand breadth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="palm-tree(n)"><f type="i">Palm-tree<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a certain tree bearing
the fruit called Dates, it is reported to be both male and
female, the male bearing blossomes onely, the female both
blossoms and fruit. The leaves shoot upward though
oppressed with never so much weight. Whence the Palm is
metaphorically used for Victory, Praise, and Commendations.
<f type="i">Cleop.<f type="r"></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Palm Sunday(pn)"><f type="i">Palm-Sunday<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the Sunday before Easter, so
called because on that day the people went to meet our
Saviour with Palm and Olive-branches in their hands when
he rode solemnly into <f type="i">Jerusalem<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="palmer(n)"><f type="i">Palmer<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain instrument wherewith
school-boys are struck on the palms of their hands,
otherwise called a Ferular; also a kind of caterpillar or
worm with many feet. also a poor Pilgrim that
travels up and down to
visit Holy places with branches of Palm in his hand.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="palmestry(n)"><f type="i">Palmestry<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the same as Cheiromancy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="palmetto tree(n)"><f type="i">Palmeto-tree<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain tree in the Isle

pleasant sort of wine.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="palmiferous(a)"><f type="i">Palmiferous<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> bearing Palms,

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Pan(pn)"><f type="i">Pan<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Demogorgon<f type="r">, he was
worshipp'd in <f type="i">Arcadia<f type="r">; as the God of sheapherds,
being smitten by Cupid, he fell in love with the Nymph
<f type="i">Syrinx<f type="r">, who passing over the River
<f type="i">Ladon<f type="r">, was turned into a Reed, which <f type="i">Pan<f type="r">
beholding, made him a Pipe with the same Reed, whence he
is said to have first found out the use of the Pipe and
Oaten Reed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="panada(n)"><f type="i">Panado<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="sp" type="etymlang">(Span.)</class> a certain kinde of meat,

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Pandora(pn)"><f type="i">Pandora<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>by the Poets fained the first of
all women, made by <f type="i">Vulcan<f type="r"> at the command of
<f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">, and endowed with
several gifts, by all the
gods and goddesses, she was espoused to
<f type="i">Epimetheus<f type="r">, to whom she was sent with a box shut,
which he unadvisedly
opening, filled the world with all manner of diseases and calamities.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="pandora(n)"><f type="i">Pandure<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> <class type="register" subject="music">a kinde of Musical

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Paphus(pn)"><f type="i">Paphus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Pygmalion<f type="r">, the
son of <f type="i">Cilix<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Eburnea<f type="r">, for
<f type="i">Pygmalion<f type="r"> being an excellent graver, came into
the Island of <f type="i">Cyprus<f type="r">, made the statue of a woman
so admirable, that he
fell in love with it, and prayed to <f type="i">Venus<f type="r"> that he
might have a wife as like as might be, to the statue he
had made, which prayer was granted, and he coming home one
time found the statue enlivened, with whom having lain he
begat <f type="i">Paphus<f type="r">, who
became King of <f type="i">Cyprus<f type="r">, and built a Citie which he
called by his own name, and dedicated it to
<f type="i">Venus<f type="r">, who was thence called the <f type="i">Paphian<f type="r">
Queen.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Papian law(n)"><f type="i">Papian Law<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>see <f type="i">Pop&aelig;an

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="parallax(n)"><f type="i">Parallax<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the difference between the true
place, or apparent place of a Comet, Eclipse, or Planet,
by reason we behold it from the superficies not from the
center.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="parallel(n)"><f type="i">Parallels<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> <class type="register" subject="mathematics">a Term in
Geometry</class>, lines running
at an equal distance one from the other and never meeting,
<class type="register" subject="astrology and astronomy">in Astronomy</class> they are
certain imaginary Circles
in the Globe, for the better Calculation
of the degrees of Northern, or Southern Latitude.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="parallel(v)"><f type="i">Parallel<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> to compare.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="parallelogram(n)"><f type="i">Parallelogram<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> <class type="register" subject="mathematics">a certain
Geometrical figure</class>,
wherein on each side the lines run parallel one to another.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="paragolism(n)"><f type="i">Paragolisme<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a fallacious, or
deceitfull way of arguing, wherein from true extreams, a
false conclusion is brought out.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="paralytic(n)"><f type="i">Paralytick<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> sick of a

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="parament(n)"><f type="i">Paraments<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>robes of state.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Paramount, Lord(pn)">Lord <f type="i">Paramount<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="law">in Common-law</class>, is the
highest Lord of the Fee, as he that
holdeth of a Superiour Lord, yet hath a Tenant
under him, is called Lord of the Mesne, but the lowest
Tenant is called <term lang="la">Tenant paravail</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="paramour(n)"><f type="i">Paramour<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Lover, or Sweetheart.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="paranymph(n)"><f type="i">Paranymph<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> he, or she that is
joyn'd with the Bridegroom, or Bride, to see all things
well ordered at a Wedding, also one that maketh a speech
in commendation of those that are to commence Doctors.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="parapet(n)"><f type="i">Parapet<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> <class type="register" subject="architecture">a Term in
fortification</class>, a
wall, or battlement of a wall, <emend err="brest" source="errata">brestwork</emend>, to defend from the
enemies shot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Parilian feast(n)"><f type="i">Parilian<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Palilian<f type="r"> feasts,</form> <xpln>see <f type="i">Pales<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Paris(pn)"><f type="i">Paris<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Priamus<f type="r">, and
<f type="i">Hecuba<f type="r">, he was also called <f type="i">Alexander<f type="r">,
whom his mother caused to be nursed up privately on the
Mountain <f type="i">Ida<f type="r"> by the shepherds, where, coming to
age he fell in Love with the Nymph <f type="i">Oenone<f type="r">, and
lying with her, had two Children by her; afterwards, there
growing a contention between the three goddesses,
<f type="i">Juno, Pallas<f type="r">, and <f type="i">Venus<f type="r">, they agreed to
submit themselves to the judgement of <f type="i">Paris; Juno<f type="r">
proffering him a Kingdom, <f type="i">Pallas<f type="r"> wisdom, and
<f type="i">Venus<f type="r"> the handsomest of women, whereupon he gave
his judgement for <f type="i">Venus<f type="r">; soon after he was
returned home, he was sent into <f type="i">Greece<f type="r"> as an
Ambassadour to demand <f type="i">Hesione<f type="r">,
and being intertained by <f type="i">Menelaus<f type="r">, he fell in
Love with <f type="i">Helena<f type="r"> his wife, and <f type="i">Menelaus<f type="r">
being absent about some affairs,
he soon won her to his desires, and carried her away with
him by stealth, whereupon there immediately grew a violent
warre between the Greeks and the Trojans, wherein after
nine years siege <f type="i">Troy<f type="r"> was taken, and
<f type="i">Paris<f type="r"> (having shot <f type="i">Achilles<f type="r"> in the heel
with his Bow and Arrows in the Temple of <f type="i">Apollo<f type="r">,
whither he had led him under pretence of
marrying him to his
sister <f type="i">Polixena<f type="r">) was himself slain by
<f type="i">Pyrrhus<f type="r">, the son of <f type="i">Achilles<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="parish(n)" lexeme="parochial church(n)"><f type="i">Parish<f type="r"> or <f type="i">Parochial Church<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>is
that which is instituted for the saying of Divine
Service to the people
dwelling within a certain
compasse of ground near unto it, the other Churches being
either Cathedral, that is where the Bishop hath his chair
or seat, and conventual consisting of Dean and Chapter, or
of regular Clerks professing
some order of Religion.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="parisyllabical noun(n)"><f type="i">Parisyllabical Nounes<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="grammar">(a term in
Grammar)</class> those Nounes
which consist of equal syllables, or those Nouns that have
not more syllables in one Case than in another.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="parity(n)"><f type="i">Parity<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> equallity or
evennesse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="park(n)"><f type="i">Park<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an Inclosure or place fenced
about for the keeping of
Deer, or any other sort of wild beasts; it seems to be
derived <class lang="la" type="etymlang">from the Latin word <f type="i"><term lang="la">Parcus</term><f type="r"></class> which
<f type="i">Varro<f type="r"> useth in the same sense.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="parliament(n)"><f type="i">Parliament<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="it" type="etymlang">(Ital. <f type="i"><term lang="it">q. parlar la mente</term><f type="r">)</class>
</page>

<page sig="Ff4v">
the chief Assembly and Council of a Kingdom met together
to make or correct Laws, and to debate matters touching
the Common-wealth: in this Kingdom it used to consist of
the King and the three Estates of the Realm, <f type="i">i.<f type="r">
the Lords Spiritual,
Lords Temporal, and Commons.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="parmacety(n)"><f type="i">Parmacety<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a pretious and very
excellent confection, so
called from <f type="i">Parma<f type="r"> a City of <f type="i">Italy<f type="r">
between <f type="i">Placentia<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Cremonia<f type="r">,

called <f type="i">Sperma Ceti<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Parmesan(pn)"><f type="i">Parmesan<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an inhabitant of <f type="i">Parma<f type="r">,

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Parnassus(pn)"><f type="i">Parnassus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Mountain of <f type="i">Phocis<f type="r"> in

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="parole, lease(n)">A lease <f type="i">Parole<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="law">in Common Law</class>, is a lease
made onely by word of mouth, also when a prisoner of war
hath liberty given him upon his word to return at such a
time, he is said to go upon his Parole, <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">which in French
signifieth a word or saying</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Paros(pn)"><f type="i">Paros<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an Island of the <f type="i">Aegean<f type="r">

there is an excellent sort of Marble called <f type="i">Parian Marble<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Parrhasius(pn)"><f type="i">Parrhasius<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous Painter, the first
that painted by the life, he drew the picture of a linnen
Tablecloth so admirablely,
that <f type="i">Zeuxis<f type="r"> looking on it, bid him take away the
cloth that he might see the picture
underneath it.</xpln></wordentry>

<f type="i">paricidium<f type="r">, it signifieth the act it self.</xpln>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="passion(n)"><f type="i">Passion<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a suffering, also an
affection of the mind,
also in Poems and Romances
it is more peculiarly taken for the passion of love.
<f type="i">Artam.<f type="r"></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Patroclus(pn)"><f type="i">Patroclus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Menoetius<f type="r">
and <f type="i">Sthenele<f type="r">, he having slain <f type="i">Cleonymus<f type="r"> the son of
<f type="i">Amphidamas<f type="r">, fled to <f type="i">Phia<f type="r">, where he was
intertained by
<f type="i">Peleus<f type="r">, and together with <f type="i">Achilles<f type="r">
educated by the <f type="i">Centaure Chiron<f type="r">, afterwards he
went to the wars of <f type="i">Troy<f type="r"> with <f type="i">Achilles<f type="r">,
with whom he had contracted
an inviolable friendship, and when <f type="i">Achilles<f type="r">
having made a defection from the <f type="i">Grecian<f type="r"> Army
could by no means be won to fight with <f type="i">Hector<f type="r">, he
at last was prevailed
with to send <f type="i">Patroclus<f type="r"> in his stead, and with his
own armour, in which fight <f type="i">Patroclus<f type="r"> being slain,
<f type="i">Achilles<f type="r"> then whom no other respect could move,
would fight to revenge the death of his friend, and having
new arms made for him by <f type="i">Vulcan<f type="r">, he fought with
<f type="i">Hector<f type="r"> and slew him.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="patronal(a)"><f type="i">Patronal<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to a Patron,

certain reverence and
duty during his life, and <class type="register" subject="law">in the
</page>

<page sig="Gg1v">
Canon Law</class> for him that hath the gift of a Benefice.

called <f type="i">Pelasgia<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Pelias(pn)"><f type="i">Pelias<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Neptune<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Tyro<f type="r"> the daughter of <f type="i">Salmoueus<f type="r">, he was
the brother of <f type="i">Aeson<f type="r"> King of <f type="i">Thessaly<f type="r">,
and meditating the ruine of his brothers son, he sent him
to <f type="i">Colchos<f type="r"> for the Golden Fleece, he was at last
slain by his daughters at the instigation of <f type="i">Medea<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Pelion(pn)"><f type="i">Pelion<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a mountain of <f type="i">Thessaly<f type="r">
which the <f type="i">Titans<f type="r"> when they made war against the
gods heaped upon <f type="i">Ossa<f type="r"> a neighbouring
mountain; the top of this mountain is thick set with
Pine trees, and hangeth over the <f type="i">Pelasgian<f type="r">
Gulph.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="pelican(n)"><f type="i">Pellican<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain bird that pecking her

ones.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Pelops(pn)"><f type="i">Pelops<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Tantalus<f type="r"> King
of <f type="i">Phrygia<f type="r">, by <f type="i">Taygete<f type="r">, he, when his
father had invited the gods to a Feast, was killed and set
before them to eat, from the eating
of which when all the gods abstained, onely <f type="i">Ceres<f type="r">
eat up his shoulder, for which <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> restoring
him to life again, made him an Ivory shoulder, he being to
run with <f type="i">Oenomaus<f type="r"> King of <f type="i">Elis<f type="r">, was to
marry his daughter <f type="i">Hippodamia<f type="r"> on condition he won
the race, which he did by corrupting <f type="i">Myrtilus<f type="r"> the
Chariot-driver of <f type="i">Oenomans<f type="r">. see <f type="i">Myrtilus<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<class type="etymlang" lang="br">in Brittish called <f type="i"><term lang="br">Penbro</term>, i.<f type="r"> a Cape or Head of

head</class>. It hath a little Castle (built by <f type="i">Arnulph<f type="r">
of <f type="i">Montgomery<f type="r">, brother to the Earle of
<f type="i">Shrewsbury<f type="r">) which <f type="i">Girald<f type="r"> his Constable
valiantly holding out with a small Garrison against the
force of all <f type="i">South-Wales<f type="r"> laying siege to it,
thereby purchased to
himself much honour, and raised his Family to a great
height, from which the <f type="i">Giraldines<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Fitzgiralds<f type="r"> in <f type="i">Ireland<f type="r"> are
descended.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Penelope(pn)"><f type="i">Penelope<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of <f type="i">Icarius<f type="r">
and the wife of <f type="i">Vlisses<f type="r">, she being careful to
preserve her chastity in her husbands absence,
being importuned by many suiters, who having been put off
a great while, were at last resolved to ravish her; she
desired onely so much time till she had made an end of
what was upon her distaff, which when she had obtaind, she
ravelled over night what she had spun in the day time, by
which means she put them off till her husband returned home.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="petalism(n)"><f type="i">Petalisme<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a manner of

<f type="i">Siracusians<f type="r">, which was
inflicted by writing the
offenders name upon an Olive leaf.</xpln></wordentry>

Mortar, wherewith strong gates are burst open in war.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="petarade(n)"><f type="i">Petarrade<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> a gun-shot of farting,

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Peter(pn)"><f type="i">Peter<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the proper name of a man, <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">from the
Greek word <f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Petra</term><f type="r"> a rock</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Peter's penny(n)"><f type="i">Peterpence<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a tribute given by
<f type="i">Inas<f type="r"> King of the <f type="i">West-Saxons<f type="r"> being in pilgrimage at
<f type="i">Rome<f type="r"> in the year 720, which was a penny for every
house, it was also called the fee of <f type="i">Rome<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Peter's Post(pn)"><f type="i">Peters post<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>that famous delph or quarry of
stone in <f type="i">Yorkshire<f type="r">, out of which the stones that
built St. <f type="i">Peters<f type="r"> Church in <f type="i">York<f type="r"> were
hewed, by the liberal grant of the
<f type="i">Vavasours<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Petit Bag, Clerk of the(pn)">Clerks of the <f type="i">Petit bag<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>three officers of
Chancery who record the return of all inquisitions out of
every Shire, all liveries
granted in the Court of Wards, make all Patents of
Customes, Gaugers, Controllers,
<f type="i">&amp;c.<f type="r"> each record being put in a petit or
little leather bag; whence they had the denomination of
Clerks of the <f type="i">Petit bag<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="petitory(n)"><f type="i">Petitory<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to a petition,
<f type="i">i.<f type="r"> a request or intreaty made by an
inferiour to a Superiour.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Petreius(pn)"><f type="i">Petreius<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous Roman Captain who was
<f type="i">C&aelig;sars<f type="r"> Legat in <f type="i">Gallia<f type="r">, but
afterwards taking part
with <f type="i">Pompey<f type="r">, he was overthrown in
<f type="i">Mauritania<f type="r">, together with King <f type="i">Juba<f type="r">,
whereupon they consented
mutually together to kill one another.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Petrobusians(pn)"><f type="i">Petrobusians<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a sort of Hereticks that

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="petrol(n)"><f type="i">Petrol<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a sort of marle or chalky

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Petropolis(pn)"><f type="i">Petropolis<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town in
<f type="i">Northamptonshire<f type="r">, commonly called
<f type="i">Peterborow<f type="r">, from a Monastery
dedicated to St. <f type="i">Peter<f type="r">, begun by <f type="i">Penda<f type="r">,
a Christian King of the <f type="i">Mercians<f type="r"> &amp; finisht by
his brother <f type="i">Wolpher<f type="r"> to expiate the crime of
murdering his two sons <f type="i">Wolphald<f type="r">
and <f type="i">Rufin<f type="r">. This Town was
anciently called
<f type="i">Medeswelhamsted<f type="r"> or <f type="i">Medeshamsted<f type="r">, from
<f type="i">Medeswell<f type="r"> a deep whirlpool.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="pettifogger(n)"><f type="i">Pettifogger<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a silly Advocate, Attorny, or

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Phaedra(pn)"><f type="i">Ph&aelig;dra<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daught of <f type="i">Minos<f type="r"> King
of <f type="i">Creet<f type="r">, and the wife of <f type="i">Theseus<f type="r">, she contrived the
destruction of her son in Law <f type="i">Hippolytus<f type="r"> because
he would not yeild to her allurements. see <xref><f type="i">Hippolytus<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Phaemonoe(pn)"><f type="i">Ph&aelig;monoe<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Virgin who first invented
Heroick Verses, and who was the first Priestesse of
<f type="i">Apollo<f type="r"> at <f type="i">Delphos<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="phenomena(n)"><f type="i">Ph&aelig;nomena<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> appearances of Meteors
or any other Signs in the Aire or Heavens.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Phaeton(pn)"><f type="i">Ph&aelig;ton<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Sol<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Clymene<f type="r">, he, when <f type="i">Epaphus<f type="r"> the son of
<f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Isis<f type="r"> had objected to him
that he was not the son of <f type="i">Phoebus<f type="r">, requested of
his father that he might have the guidance of his chariot
for one day, which being granted, he set the Heavens all
of a flame, for which <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">
struck him down with his thunder into the River
<f type="i">Padus<f type="r"> or <f type="i">Po<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Phaetontiades(pn)"><f type="i">Ph&aelig;tontiades<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the sisters of
<f type="i">Ph&aelig;ton<f type="r">. see <xref><f type="i">Heliades<f type="r">.</xref></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="phagedaenic(a)"><class type="unknown">&dagger;</class> <f type="i">Phaged&aelig;nick<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> troubled with

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="phalanx(n)"><f type="i">Phalanx<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a Military squadron consisting
of 8000 men, most in use among
</page>

<page sig="Gg4v">
the <f type="i">Macedonians<f type="r">; some think it was first
invented by <f type="i">Phalanx<f type="r">, and from him so
called; he was the
brother of <f type="i">Arachne<f type="r">, and was instructed in
Military discipline by <f type="i">Pallas<f type="r">, and taught his
sister the use of the needle, but afterwards lying with
his sister, they were both turned into vipers by <f type="i">Pallas<f type="r">.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Phalaris(pn)"><f type="i">Phalaris<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Tyrant of <f type="i">Agrigentum<f type="r">
who caused <f type="i">Perillus<f type="r">, a rare Artificer, to make a
brazen Bull wherein he tormented many by putting them into
the belly of the Bull after it had been heated with a
vehement fire, and among many others <f type="i">Perillus<f type="r"> the
author of it was served in the same
manner.</xpln></wordentry>

ointment, became therewith so beautiful, that the chief

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="pharisaism(n)"><f type="i">Pharisaism<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>hypocrisie, the profession and
opinion of the Pharisees, who were a sect of the Jews so
called <class type="etymlang" lang="he">from the Hebrew word <f type="i"><term lang="he">Pharesh</term><f type="r">, i. to separate</class>, because they were
Interpreters of the Law, and separatists from the rest of
the Jewish Church, pretending more holinesse than the rest
of the people.</xpln></wordentry>

dart into the the stream of <f type="i">Nilus<f type="r">, was advised by
the oracle to wash his eyes in the urine of a woman that
had known but one man, which having done, he recovered his sight.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Philoctetes(pn)"><f type="i">Philoctetes<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">P&aelig;as<f type="r">, and the
companion of <f type="i">Hercules<f type="r">, to him <f type="i">Hercules<f type="r">
dying left his bow and arrows dipt in the
<f type="i">Lern&aelig;an<f type="r"> poison, and because the
<f type="i">Delphian<f type="r"> Oracle admonished that there was need
of the arrows of <f type="i">Hercules<f type="r">, he was brought to
the wars of <f type="i">Troy<f type="r">, where he received an almost
irrecoverable wound by letting fall one of his arrows
upon his foot, whereupon
being ashamed to return lame into his own Country, he
went into <f type="i">Calabria<f type="r">
</page>

<page sig="Hh1r">
in <f type="i">Italy<f type="r"> where he built <f type="i">Petilia<f type="r">, at
length by the help of <f type="i">Machaon<f type="r"> he was cured.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="philology(n)"><f type="i">Philology<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> the love of learning or

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Philomela(pn)"><f type="i">Philomela<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of <f type="i">Pandion<f type="r">
King of <f type="i">Athens<f type="r">, her sister <f type="i">Progne<f type="r"> was
married to <f type="i">Tereus<f type="r"> King of <f type="i">Thrace<f type="r"> (the
son of <f type="i">Mars<f type="r"> by the Nimph <f type="i">Bistonis<f type="r">) who
having ravisht
<f type="i">Philomela<f type="r"> and cut out her tongue, that she might
not declare her sufferings to any one, she wrought the
story of them with her needle, and sent it to her sister
<f type="i">Progne<f type="r">, who in revenge caused her son
<f type="i">Itys<f type="r"> to be killed at the Feast of
<f type="i">Bacchus<f type="r">, and set before <f type="i">Tereus<f type="r">, who
following <f type="i">Progne<f type="r"> with his sword drawn was changed
into a Moorcock, <f type="i">Itys<f type="r"> into a Pheasant,
<f type="i">Progne<f type="r"> into a Swallow, and <f type="i">Philomele<f type="r">
into a Nightingale.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Philomusous(pn)"><class type="unknown">&dagger;</class> <f type="i">Philomusous<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a lover of the
Muse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Philonomia(pn)"><f type="i">Philonomia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of
<f type="i">Nyctinus<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Arcadia<f type="r">, she, as she went a
hunting one day with <f type="i">Diana<f type="r">, was got with child by
<f type="i">Mars<f type="r">, and after she had brought forth twins she
cast them into the River <f type="i">Erymanthus<f type="r">,
who being a little after found by the Shepherd
<f type="i">Tyliphus<f type="r"> sucking a she Woolf, they were brought
up by <f type="i">Tyliphus<f type="r">, and being called
<f type="i">Lycastus<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Parrhasius<f type="r">, succeeded in
the Kingdom of <f type="i">Arcadia<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="philosophical(a)"><f type="i">Philosophical<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> belonging to a Philosopher or Philosophy,
<f type="i">i.<f type="r"> the love and study of wisdom, knowledge of

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="philtre(n)"><f type="i">Philtre<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a potion, powder, or <class type="register" subject="medicine">any
kind of Medicine</class> procuring love.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Philyra(pn)"><f type="i">Philyra<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of <f type="i">Oceanus<f type="r">,
with whom <f type="i">Saturn<f type="r"> lying in the shape of a horse,
begat the Centaur <f type="i">Chiron<f type="r">, who being wounded with
one of the arrows of <f type="i">Hercules<f type="r">
that had been dipt in <f type="i">Lern&aelig;an<f type="r">
poison, wished to die, but
being immortal was placed among the heavenly Signs, and
called <f type="i">Sagitarius<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Phineus(pn)"><f type="i">Phineus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Agenor<f type="r">, or as
others say of <f type="i">Phoenix<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Cassiop&aelig;a<f type="r">, he
was King of <f type="i">Thrace<f type="r">, and had by his first wife
<f type="i">Cleopatra,
Orythus<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Crambus<f type="r">, whose eyes he put out
at the perswasion of his second wife <f type="i">Harpalice<f type="r">
the sister of <f type="i">Zethes<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Calais<f type="r">, for which
he was strucken blind himself,
and the <f type="i">Harpyes<f type="r"> were sent against him who
continually defiled his meat as it came to his table; but
at last they were driven by <f type="i">Zethes<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Calais<f type="r"> into the <f type="i">Strophades<f type="r">
Islands, and <f type="i">Phineus<f type="r"> himself was killed by
<f type="i">Hercules<f type="r"> after he understood that the children
were blinded without a cause.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="phlebotomy(n)"><f type="i">Phlebotomy<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a cutting of a veine, a
letting blood.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="phlegmatic(a)"><f type="i">Phlegmatick<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> full of phlegm or
fleam, <f type="i">i.<f type="r"> one of the four humours of the body
being cold and moist.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="phlegmon(n)"><f type="i">Phlegmon<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a hot and red
swelling of the body, caused by an inflammation
of the blood.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Phlegraean Fields(pn)"><f type="i">Phlegr&aelig;an<f type="r"> fields</form>, <xpln>certain fields of
<f type="i">Thessaly<f type="r">, where the Gyants fought against the gods.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Phlegyas(pn)"><f type="i">Phlegyas<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>son of <f type="i">Mars<f type="r"> and King of
the <f type="i">Lapitheans<f type="r"> in <f type="i">Thessaly<f type="r">, he was the
father of <f type="i">Ixion<f type="r"> and the Nimph <f type="i">Coronis<f type="r">,
who being ravisht by <f type="i">Apollo, Phlegyas<f type="r"> in revenge
burnt his Temple, for which being cast into Hell, he
remained in continual fear of the falling of a great stone
which hung over his head.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Phoebus(pn)"><f type="i">Phoebus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Latona<f type="r">, born at the same birth with
<f type="i">Diana<f type="r">, he is also called <f type="i">Apollo<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Sol<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="phoenix(n)"><f type="i">Phoenix<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> an <f type="i">Arabian<f type="r"> Bird
of which it is reported that there is but one of them in
the World at a time, and that having lived 500 years, it
builds a nest of combustible spices, which taking fire
from the Sun, she fans it with her wings, and burns her
self therein, out of whose ashes there springs up a new
Phoenix; It is also an ancient name of several famous men.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Phorbas(pn)"><f type="i">Phorbas<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Priamus<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Epithesia<f type="r"> the daughter of <f type="i">Stasippus<f type="r"> King of
<f type="i">Mygdonia<f type="r">, he was, after many great atcheivements
performed in the <f type="i">Trojan<f type="r"> war, slain by
<f type="i">Menelaus<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Phorcys(pn)"><f type="i">Phorcys<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Neptune<f type="r"> and the Nimph <f type="i">Thesea<f type="r">,
and father of <f type="i">Medusa<f type="r">, he was King of
<f type="i">Corsica<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Sardinia<f type="r">, and
being overthrown by <f type="i">Atlas<f type="r"> in a Sea-fight, was turned into a Deity of
the Sea.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Phospher(pn)"><f type="i">Phospher<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> as it were a bringer of
light, the morning Star.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="phrenetic(a)"><f type="i">Phrenetick<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Pisistratus(pn)"><f type="i">Pisistratus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a King of the
<f type="i">Orchomenians<f type="r">, who for too much favouring of the
people was slain in the
Senate-house by a faction of the Nobility, his son
<f type="i">Telesimachus<f type="r">
being chief of the conspiracy; also the name of a famous
Tyrant of <f type="i">Athens<f type="r">, the son of
<f type="i">Hippocrates<f type="r">, he was a man of singular
eloquence, and a great favourer of the Arts and Sciences.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="pissasphalt(n)"><f type="i">Pissaphalt<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a kinde of mineral,

being <class type="register" subject="medicine">often used in Physick</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Pittacus(pn)"><f type="i">Pittacus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Philosopher of

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Platonic(pn)"><f type="i">Platonick<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>belonging to, or affirm'd by
<f type="i">Plato<f type="r">, (whence <f type="i">Platonick<f type="r"> love, or
<f type="i">Platonick<f type="r"> year <f type="i">i.<f type="r"> the space of 36000 years) he was the chief of
the <f type="i">Academick<f type="r"> Philosophers,
he was at first called <f type="i">Aristocles<f type="r">, was a great
wrestler, and much given to painting;
afterwards became a hearer of <f type="i">Socrates<f type="r">,
then he sayl'd into <f type="i">Italy<f type="r">, to hear
<f type="i">Pythagoras<f type="r">, and took many things out of the books
of <f type="i">Philolaus Crotoniatos<f type="r">, next he went into
<f type="i">Aegypt<f type="r"> to hear the <f type="i">Gymnosophists<f type="r">, and as
some say, read the books of <f type="i">Moses<f type="r">, he was called
Divine <f type="i">Plato<f type="r">, &amp; was
esteemed the most famous
Philosoper of the world, his chief opinion being, that the
abstract <f type="i">Idea<f type="r">'s, or images of all virtues, and of
all forms had a peculiar subsistence by themselves.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Polycrates(pn)"><f type="i">Polycrates<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Tyrant of <f type="i">Samos<f type="r">,
being a man of very great wealth, and of that
fortune, that having let
fall into the Sea a ring of great value, it was found the
next day in the belly of a fish; but in his later end he
was taken by <f type="i">Orontes<f type="r"> the
<f type="i">Persian<f type="r"> and crucified.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Polydamas(pn)"><f type="i">Polydamas<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Antenor<f type="r"> and

of <f type="i">Hecuba<f type="r">, he marryed <f type="i">Lycaste<f type="r">,
the daughter of <f type="i">Priamus<f type="r"> by a
Concubine, and is said together with his father
<f type="i">Antenor<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Aeneas<f type="r">, to have
betrayed the City
<f type="i">Troy<f type="r"> to the Greeks. Also the son of
<f type="i">Panthous<f type="r"> the master of <f type="i">Hector<f type="r">, he was a
man of vast strength.</xpln></wordentry>

</page>

<page sig="Hh3v">
was one of the <f type="i">Cyclops<f type="r">, and faling in love with
the Nimph <f type="i">Galatea<f type="r">, slew the youth <f type="i">Acis<f type="r">
whom she preferred before him; he devoured four of the
companions of <f type="i">Vlisses<f type="r">
when they were cast upon that shore, and would have
served the rest in like manner, but that
<f type="i">Vlisses<f type="r"> made him drunk with black wine, and put
out that one eye which he had in the midst of his
forehead.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Pomfret(pn)" lexeme="Pontfract(pn)"><f type="i">Pomfret<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Pontfract<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>a Town in
<f type="i">Yorkshire<f type="r">, so
called (for in the Saxons time it was named <f type="i">Kirkby<f type="r">)
from a wooden bridge over <f type="i">Are<f type="r">, broken by the
confluence of a great multitude of people that accompanied
<f type="i">William<f type="r"> Arch-Bishop of <f type="i">York<f type="r">, King
<f type="i">Stephens<f type="r"> Nephew when he returned from
<f type="i">Rome<f type="r">. This place hath been stained with the
blood-shed of many Great men; here <f type="i">Thomas<f type="r"> Earle
of <f type="i">Lancaster<f type="r"> was beheaded by King <f type="i">Edward<f type="r">
the second; King <f type="i">Richard<f type="r">
the second was here made away by the appointment of King
<f type="i">Henry<f type="r"> the fourth. Also <f type="i">Anthony<f type="r"> Earle
<f type="i">Rivers<f type="r">, and Sir <f type="i">Richard Grey<f type="r">, were here
beheaded by King <f type="i">Richard<f type="r"> the third.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Pomona(pn)"><f type="i">Pomona<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the goddesse of Orchards, with whom
<f type="i">Vertumnus<f type="r"> falling in love, courted her in several
shapes, at last in
the form of an old woman he spake so effectually for
<f type="i">Vertumnus<f type="r">, that he prevailed, and
returning to his own
shape he married her.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Pompeius the Great, Cneus(pn)">Cneus <f type="i">Pompeius<f type="r">, sirnamed the Great</form>, <xpln>which title was
given him by the Army of <f type="i">Sylla<f type="r"> for Triumphing
over <f type="i">Iarbas<f type="r"> a King of <f type="i">Africa<f type="r">, then
joyning with <f type="i">Metellus<f type="r"> he overcame
<f type="i">Sertorius<f type="r"> in <f type="i">Spain<f type="r">; next he was chosen
Emperour in the <f type="i">Pyratick<f type="r"> War, which he finisht in
three moneths; afterwards
he triumphed over <f type="i">Mithridates<f type="r">, and restored
<f type="i">Tigranes<f type="r"> to the Crown of
<f type="i">Armenia<f type="r">. Lastly
he quelled the <f type="i">Iberians, Albans<f type="r">, and
<f type="i">Jews<f type="r">, taking prisoner their King
<f type="i">Aristobulus<f type="r">;
at length in the Civil War between
him and <f type="i">Julius C&aelig;sar<f type="r"> he was
overcome at the Battle of
<f type="i">Pharsalia<f type="r">, and flying into <f type="i">Aegypt<f type="r"> was
slain by <f type="i">Aquila<f type="r">, through the treachery of
<f type="i">Ptolomy<f type="r"> the young King.</xpln></wordentry>

breathing; also a lighting down of birds.</xpln>

Not found in OED.

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="predicable(n)" lexeme="predicament(n)" lexeme="predicate(n)"><f type="i">Pr&aelig;dicable, Pr&aelig;dicament<f type="r">, and
<f type="i">Pr&aelig;dicate<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class type="etymlang" lang="la">(lat.)</class> three words which are most
commonly used as terms <class type="register" subject="logic">in
Logick</class>, <f type="i">Pr&aelig;dicables<f type="r"> (which are 5. <f type="i">viz.
genus, species, proprium, differentia<f type="r">, and
<f type="i">accidens<f type="r">) are those things which may truly,
naturally, and immediately, be affirmed of more things than one.
<f type="i">Pr&aelig;dicaments<f type="r"> (which are also called
<f type="i">Categories<f type="r">, and are 10 in all, <f type="i">viz.<f type="r">
Substance, Quantity, Quality, Relation, Action, Passion, Where, When,
Situation, and Habit) are the Series of things
gradually disposed under
the same <f type="i">summum genus<f type="r">. A <f type="i">Pr&aelig;dicate<f type="r"> is
the last part of the Proposition or the major term of a Syllogisme.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="premunire, fall into a(n)">To fall into a <f type="i">Pr&aelig;munire<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>signifieth <class type="register" subject="law">in
Common Law</class>, to forfeit a mans goods to the Prince, and his
body to remain in prison: it is a word corruptly used for
<f type="i">pr&aelig;monere<f type="r">, i.
to admonish or forewarn, and is taken either for the writ,
or for the offence whereupon the writ is granted.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="premonition(n)"><f type="i">Pr&aelig;monition<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a forewarning.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="premunition(n)"><f type="i">Pr&aelig;munition<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a fortifying before
hand.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="prender(n)"><f type="i">Prender<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="law">a word used in Common Law</class>, things
which lie in prender are those things which the Lord of a
Manour may have before atturnment, as the ward of the
body of an heir, or of the
land escheats; whereas those things which lie in Render he
cannot take before atturnment; as rents, releifs, heriots,
<f type="i">&amp;c.<f type="r"></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Priamus(pn)"><f type="i">Priamus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Laomedon<f type="r"> King
of <f type="i">Troy<f type="r">, he having been led captive by
<f type="i">Hercules<f type="r"> into
<f type="i">Greece<f type="r">, was afterwards ransomed for a great summe
of money: He had 50 sons whereof 17 he had by his wife <f type="i">Hecuba<f type="r">; in his
time it was that <f type="i">Troy<f type="r"> was taken and sackt by the
<f type="i">Greeks<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="priapismus(n)"><f type="i">Priapismus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a disease wherein there
is an erection of the yard without lust, from
<f type="i">Priapus<f type="r"> the son of <f type="i">Bacchus<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Venus<f type="r">, he being born at <f type="i">Lampsacus<f type="r">,
became through the malice
of <f type="i">Juno<f type="r">, who was his mothers Midwife, very ugly
and deformed, yet he had
something about him so pleasing to the women of
<f type="i">Lampsacus<f type="r"> that after he was banisht by the men of
that place, they built a Temple to him where they were
wont to sacrifice an asse, and called him the god of Gardens.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Prochyta(pn)"><f type="i">Prochyta<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an Island in the
<f type="i">Tyrrhene<f type="r"> sea, not far from <f type="i">Puteoli<f type="r"> in
<f type="i">Campania<f type="r">, so called
from <f type="i">Prochyta<f type="r"> the Nurse of <f type="i">Aeneas<f type="r">; it
hath been reported of old, that a mountain of
<f type="i">Inarime<f type="r"> a neighbouring Island
being cast into the Sea by an Earthquake, was the original of this Island.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="proctor(n)"><f type="i">Proctors<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(in Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Procuratores</term><f type="r">)</class> 
Advocates, or those
that sollicit other mens businesses; also those that
appear in Parliament
for Cathedral or other collegiate Churches, or for the
common Clergy of every diocesse. There are also in the
University two men chosen from among the Schollars to see good orders kept
and exercises performed,
who are called Proctors. Also in the State of
<f type="i">Venice<f type="r"> there are certain
chief officers called Procurators.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="proculcation(n)"><f type="i">Proculcation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a trampling, or
treading under foot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Prometheus(pn)"><f type="i">Prometheus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the father of
<f type="i">Deucaleon<f type="r">, and son of <f type="i">Iapetus<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Asia<f type="r">, he having formed of Clay the Image of a
man, and climbing up to Heaven by the help of
<f type="i">Minerva<f type="r">, he kindled a little stick at the Sun,
and with that celestial fire, inlivened the man he had
made, for which he was at the command
of <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">, bound by <f type="i">Mercury<f type="r"> to the
Mountain <f type="i">Caucasus<f type="r">, where a Vulture was
continually pecking at his Liver, but afterwards having
diswaded <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> from marrying <f type="i">Thetis<f type="r">,
he was for his good counsel freed by <f type="i">Hercules<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Proserpina(pn)"><f type="i">Proserpina<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of
<f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Ceres<f type="r">, she being ravisht by
<f type="i">Pluto<f type="r">, was sought for by <f type="i">Ceres<f type="r"> all over
the earth, but after the whole matter was related by the
Nymph <f type="i">Cyane, Jupiter<f type="r"> at her earnest request, granted that her
daughter should return again to earth, on condition she
had tasted no meat since she came to Hell, but
<f type="i">Ascalaphus<f type="r"> having declared that she had eaten
part of a Pomegranate (for which <f type="i">Ceres<f type="r"> turned him
into an Owl) she could obtain no more, but that she should
be 6 moneths upon earth, and 6 moneths with
<f type="i">Pluto<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="prosody(n)"><f type="i">Prosodie<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> the art of giving words

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Protesilaus(pn)"><f type="i">Protesilaus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Iphiclus<f type="r">,
who going to the <f type="i">Trojan<f type="r"> war, contrary to the Oracles advice, was

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="protestation(n)"><f type="i">Protestation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> an open declaring of
ones minde, whence the Reformers in
<f type="i">Germany<f type="r">, from the
protestation they made at <f type="i">Spires<f type="r">, were called Protestants.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Proteus(pn)"><f type="i">Proteus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Sea deity, the son of
<f type="i">Oceanus<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Thetys<f type="r">, he was reported to
have been <f type="i">Neptune<f type="r">'s Sheapheard, and the keeper
of his Sea-calfs; the Poets also feign that he was a
great Prophet, and that he could
</page>

<page sig="Ii3v">
transform himself into what shape he pleased,
<f type="i">Servius<f type="r"> affirms that he reigned in the
<f type="i">Carpathian<f type="r"> Island, leaving
<f type="i">Pallene<f type="r">, a Citie of <f type="i">Thessaly<f type="r">, where he first lived.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="protocol(n)"><f type="i">Protocol<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> the first draught of a
deed, contract, or instrument, or a short Register kept
thereof; also the upper part of the leaf of a book,
wherein the Title is written.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Protolicia(pn)"><f type="i">Protolicia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Castle in

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="prune(v)"><f type="i">Pruneth<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="hawking and hunting">a Term in Faulconry</class>, they say a
Hawk <f type="i">Pruneth<f type="r">, and not picketh her self; yet a
Hawk cannot be said properly to prune her self, but when
she beginneth at her legs, and fetcheth moisture at her
tail, wherewith she embalmeth her feet, and striketh the
feathers of her wings through her beak, and this fetching
off the Oyl is called the <f type="i">Note<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="pygmy(n)"><f type="i">Pygmies<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain people inhabiting the
uttermost mountains of <f type="i">India<f type="r">, not above a cubit
in heighth, of whom it is reported that they ride forth
in the Spring time upon Goats or Rams toward the Sea
side, armed with bows and arrows to destroy the nests of
the Cranes, which else would grow so numerous, that they
would not be able to overcome them.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Pyrrhus(pn)"><f type="i">Pyrrhus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Achilles<f type="r">, also
a King of <f type="i">Epirus<f type="r"> who made war with the Romans for
a long while, he was slain at the taking of
<f type="i">Argos<f type="r">, by the fall of a tile.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="relief(n)"><f type="i">Relief<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="law">in Common Law</class>, is a certain summe
of money that the Tenant holding by knights-service,
grandsergeantry, or other Tenure, for which homage or
regal service is due, or by soccage for which no homage is
due; and being at full age at the death of his Ancestour,
doth pay to his Lord at his entrance. Also <class type="register" subject="architecture">a term in
Architecture</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="relegation(n)"><f type="i">Relegation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a sending or conveying

used metaphorically for to melt into pitty or compassion.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="reluctation(n)" lexeme="reluctance(n)"><f type="i">Reluctation<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Reluctance<f type="r">,</form> <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class>

or strugling against.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="remainder(n)"><f type="i">Remainder<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="law">in Common Law</class>, signifieth a

the estate of another expired.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="remancipation(n)"><f type="i">Remancipation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a returning back a
commodity into the hands of him of whom it was first bought.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Remembrancer(n)"><f type="i">Remembrancers<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>three officers belonging to
the Exchequer; the first is called the Kings Remembrancer,
who entreth in his office all recognisanses taken before
the Barons, and maketh bonds for any of the Kings debts,
or for appearance or observing
of orders, and maketh proces for the breach of them. The
second the Lord Treasurers Remembrancer, who puts him and
the rest of the Justices in remembrance
of such things as are to be dealt in for the Princes
behoof. The third is the Remembrancer of the first fruits
and tenths, who taketh all composition for first fruits
and tenths, and maketh process against such as pay not the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<f type="i">Redwald<f type="r"> King of the East <f type="i">Saxons<f type="r">, who

</page>

<page sig="Kk4r">
baptized, neverthelesse by his wifes seducement, he had
in the same Church one altar for Christian Religion, and

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="robigalia(n)"><f type="i">Robigalia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>certain feasts kept in

<f type="i">Robigus<f type="r">, who was worshipt as a God among them, for that he was thought to
keep the Corn from blasting.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="robiginous(a)"><f type="i">Robiginous<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> full of rust, also
blasted as Corn.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="roboration(n)"><f type="i">Roboration<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a strengthning, or

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="robustous(a)"><f type="i">Robustous<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> strong as an Oak.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="roche(n)"><f type="i">Roch<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="old word">(old word)</class> a Rock.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Rochester(pn)"><f type="i">Rochester<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Citie in <f type="i">Kent<f type="r">, called in Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Roffa</term><f type="r">,
from one <f type="i">Rhufus<f type="r">, but more anciently <f type="i">Durobrevis<f type="r">, in the year 676. it was laid waste by
<f type="i">Aetheldred<f type="r">, King of the <f type="i">Mercians<f type="r">, and many a time afterwards sacked by the
<f type="i">Danes<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="rochet(n)"><f type="i">Rochet<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kinde of fish, so called; also a kinde of surplice, or Bishops Robe.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="rod-knight(n)" lexeme="radknight(n)"><f type="i">Rodknights<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Radknights<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>certain
