<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="rogation(n)"><f type="i">Rogation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> an asking, demanding, or
intreating, whence <f type="i">Rogation<f type="r">
week, the next week but one before <f type="i">Whitsunday<f type="r">;
so called from the duty of fasting and prayer injoyned at
that time by the Church, as a preparative to the feast of
the <f type="i">Ascention<f type="r">, it is also called Gang week, and
by some Grasse week.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Roger(pn)"><f type="i">Roger<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the proper name of a man, <class type="etymlang" lang="du">from the
Dutch word <f type="i"><term lang="du">Ruger</term><f type="r">, i. quiet, or <f type="i"><term lang="du">Rodgar</term><f type="r">, i. strong Councel</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="rogitation(n)"><f type="i">Rogitation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> an asking often, an
intreating earnestly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Roiston(pn)"><f type="i">Roiston<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town in <f type="i">Hertfordshire<f type="r">,
anciently called <f type="i">Roises<f type="r"> Crosse, from a Crosse built by Dame
<f type="i">Roise<f type="r"> (as some think) Countesse of
<f type="i">Norfolk<f type="r">, but being augmented
by <f type="i">Eustace de Marck<f type="r">, it came to be called
<f type="i">Roiston<f type="r">, q. <f type="i">Roises<f type="r"> Town.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Rolls, the(pn)">The <f type="i">Rolls<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a place appointed by
<f type="i">Edward<f type="r"> the third,
for the keeping of the Rolls, or Records of Chancery, the
master whereof in the absence of the Lord Chancelour sitteth as Judge.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Rollo(pn)"><f type="i">Rollo<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous Captain, who with a
select Company of <f type="i">Danish<f type="r"> youths going to seek out new habitations,
setled in that part of <f type="i">France<f type="r">, which is now
called <f type="i">Normandy<f type="r">, the <f type="i">French<f type="r"> at last after much War were glad to
make a league with them, and to allow them quiet
possession of what they had conquered, and <f type="i">Rollo<f type="r">
marrying the daughter of <f type="i">Charls<f type="r"> the simple, was
both himself baptised, and likewise
caused all his people to
imbrace the Christian faith.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Roma(pn)"><f type="i">Roma<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the chief Citie of <f type="i">Italy<f type="r">,
and most famous of the world, built by <f type="i">Romulus<f type="r">
and <f type="i">Remus<f type="r">, the Grand-children of
<f type="i">Numitor<f type="r">, the
inhabitants of this Citie and parts adjacent, called the
Romans, were anciently a people renowned, both in warre
and peace, and masters of a great part of the world.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="romance(n)"><f type="i">Romance<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a feigned history from
<f type="i">Romant<f type="r">, the most
eloquent sort of <f type="i">French<f type="r">, or Roman, which hath
heretofore been used to signifie any thing written, or
expressed eloquently.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="roam(v)"><f type="i">Rome<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="old word">(old word)</class> to wander, or walk up and
down.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Rome-scot(n)" lexeme="romefeoh(n)"><f type="i">Romescot<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Romefeoh<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>a certain
tribute paid to Rome, commonly called <f type="i">Peter<f type="r">-pence.</xpln>

The term "Rome-feoh" is not found in the OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Romulus(pn)" lexeme="Remus(pn)"><f type="i">Romulus<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Remus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the sons of
<f type="i">Sylvia<f type="r">, (as some suppose by <f type="i">Mars<f type="r">) the
daughter of <f type="i">Numitor<f type="r">, King of the <f type="i">Albans<f type="r">,
they were preserved from the cruelty of their Unkle
<f type="i">Amulius<f type="r"> by <f type="i">Laurentia<f type="r"> (of which see more
in <f type="i">Laurentia) Romulus<f type="r"> having slain his brother
<f type="i">Remus<f type="r">, obtained the sole
Government of the Citie to himself; he overcame 
the <f type="i">Veientes<f type="r"> (who made warre upon the Romans,
because that they wanting wives, had ravisht the Virgins
that came from Neighbouring places to see their shews
called <f type="i">Consualia<f type="r">) dedicating the spoiles to
<f type="i">Jupiter Feretrius<f type="r">; he also overcame the
<f type="i">Fidenates<f type="r"> and the <f type="i">Sabines<f type="r">, whom he
caused with <f type="i">Titus Toetius<f type="r"> their King, to inhabit
Rome, and to joyn into one Common-wealth with the Romans,
at length in a great Assembly at the Lake of
<f type="i">Caprea<f type="r">, a sudden Tempest arising, he vanisht
away, none knowing what became of him.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Rosamunda(pn)"><f type="i">Rosamunda<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of
<f type="i">Cunimundus<f type="r">, King of the <f type="i">Gepid&aelig;<f type="r">, she was married to
<f type="i">Alboinus<f type="r">, King of the <f type="i">Lombards<f type="r">, who
having made a feast, drank a health to her out of a Cup
made of his fathers skull, for which she procured his
death by the means of <f type="i">Herminges<f type="r">, with whom she
fled to <f type="i">Longinus<f type="r">,
Exarch of <f type="i">Ravenna<f type="r">, and married him, but
afterwards being in hopes to marry <f type="i">Longinus<f type="r">, she
offered a potion to <f type="i">Helminges<f type="r"> in the bath, which
was poison, which he suspecting, forced her to drink it
her self, <class type="etymlang" lang="sx">the word signifieth in <f type="i">Saxon<f type="r"> rose of peace</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="rosary(n)"><f type="i">Rosarie<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a place where Roses grow;

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Sabaoth(pn)"><f type="i">SAbaoth<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="he" type="etymlang">(from the Hebrew <f type="i"><term lang="he">Scabath</term><f type="r">
to rest,)</class> a celebration of the seventh day of the week; as
a day of rest among the Jews, in remembrance of Gods
resting from the work of the creation on that day, instead
of which the first day of the week, called the Lords day,
hath been ever observed by Christians, in remembrance of Christs
Resurrection.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Sabbatarians(pn)"><f type="i">Sabbatarians<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>those that observe the
Jewish-Sabbath.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Sabellians(pn)"><f type="i">Sabellians<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a sort of Hereticks; so called
from <f type="i">Sabellius<f type="r"> their first Author, they
affirmed the Father, Son,
and holy Ghost, to be one onely person, having three names.</xpln></wordentry>

rich furre, taken from a Russian beast, so called.</xpln></wordentry>

Hills in <f type="i">Wales<f type="r">, and taking its course through
<f type="i">Shropshire, Worcestershire<f type="r">, and several other Shires; it

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="salacity(n)"><f type="i">Salacity<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> wantonnesse, or
inclination to Venery, perhaps from <f type="i">Salacia<f type="r"> a goddesse of the water,
whom the ancients held to be the wife of <f type="i">Neptune<f type="r">,
and that she caused the fluctuation, or moving up and down
of the Sea; also the Ebbing and flowing of the Sea was
called by the <f type="i">Romans<f type="r"> in old time <f type="i">Salicia<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Venilia<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="salamander(n)"><f type="i">Salamander<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kinde of little beast like a

<f type="i">Sal<f type="r">, i. <f type="i">Salt<f type="r">, both being alike necessary.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Salic law(n)"><f type="i">Salique<f type="r"> Law</form>, <xpln>a Law whereby the Crown of
<f type="i">France<f type="r"> cannot fall from the Lance to the
distaffe, <f type="i">i.<f type="r"> cannot be inherited by
women; it is so called, either from these words <f type="i"><term lang="la">si aliqua</term><f type="r">, often
mentioned in the Law (which as some say was made by
<f type="i">Pharamond<f type="r">, others by <f type="i">Philip<f type="r"> the fair) or
else from the River <f type="i">Sala<f type="r">, near unto which the
<f type="i">Francks<f type="r"> anciently inhabited.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Salisbury(pn)"><f type="i">Salisbury<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the chief Citie of
<f type="i">Wiltshire<f type="r">, risen up out of the ruines of a very
ancient Town called <f type="i">Sorbiodunum<f type="r">, and by vulgar <f type="i">Latinists
Sarum<f type="r">, and <f type="i">Sarisburia<f type="r">, this place is famous
for a stately Minster, built here in the reign of King
<f type="i">Henry<f type="r"> the third, by <f type="i">Richard Poor<f type="r">, then
Bishop of <f type="i">Salisbury<f type="r">; this Cathedral hath as many
windows as there are dayes in the year, as many pillars as
there are hours in a year, and the gates are answerable in
number to the 12 moneths.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="salivation(n)"><f type="i">Salivation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a fluxing, or drawing
humours out of the mouth by spettle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="sallow(n)"><f type="i">Sallow<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Salix</term><f type="r">)</class> the Goats

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Salmacis(pn)"><f type="i">Salmacis<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Fountain of <f type="i">Caria<f type="r">,
near <f type="i">Halicarnassus<f type="r">;
so called from <f type="i">Salmacis<f type="r">, a Nymph, who falling in
love with <f type="i">Hermaphroditus<f type="r">,
the son of <f type="i">Mercury<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Venus<f type="r">, when she
could by no other means draw him to her love, she leapt
into the Fountain, and
imbracing him, prayed unto the gods that they might grow
into one, whereupon they immediately became one person,
having both Sexes; also at the prayers of
<f type="i">Hermaphroditus<f type="r"> the Fountain contracted this
quality, that who ever entred
into it, were transformed into both Sexes, and called
<f type="i">Hermaphrodites<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Salmoneus(pn)"><f type="i">Salmoneus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a King of <f type="i">Elis<f type="r">, the son
of <f type="i">Aeolus<f type="r">, who aspiring to be a god, drove his
Chariot over a brazen bridge, which he had made, that he
might imitate Thunder, at which <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> inraged,
struck him down to Hell with a Thunderbolt.</xpln></wordentry>

effeminacy, <f type="i">Arbaces<f type="r">, the Satrap of <f type="i">Media<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Belochus<f type="r"> of <f type="i">Balylon<f type="r"> rebelling,
transferred the Empire to <f type="i">Media<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Babilonia. Sardanapalus<f type="r">,
as soon as he saw himself in danger, throwing himself
and all his riches into a burning Pyre, which
</page>

<page sig="Ll4v">
he built for that purpose.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="saturnal(n)"><f type="i">Saturnals<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> Feasts dedicated to
<f type="i">Saturn<f type="r">, an ancient heathen deity, the son of
<f type="i">Coelus<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Vesta<f type="r">, who married his sister
<f type="i">Ops<f type="r"> and cut off the genital members of his father
<f type="i">Coelus<f type="r">, and threw them into the Sea, out of the
froth of which sprung <f type="i">Venus<f type="r">, from thence called
<f type="i">Aphrodite<f type="r">, he sought to devour all his male
children, wherefore <f type="i">Ops<f type="r"> as soon as she was
delivered of <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">, and <f type="i">Juno<f type="r"> at a
birth, she gave him instead of <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> a great
stone wrapt up in swadling-clouts, which he devoured; next she
brought forth <f type="i">Neptune<f type="r">, whom she concealed, as
also <f type="i">Pluto<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Glaucus<f type="r"> whom she had at a
birth; He was overthrown by his brother <f type="i">Titan<f type="r"> who
made war against him for the Kingdom, and shut up him and
his wife in prison, whence he was delivered by his son
<f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">, against whom also making war himself,
he was driven out of his Kingdom, and fled into
<f type="i">Italy<f type="r"> to <f type="i">Janus<f type="r"> whom he taught Husbandry
and the use of the Vine. <f type="i">Saturn<f type="r"> is also the name
of one of the 7 Planets, the slowest in motion and of the
melancholiest influence; also <class type="register" subject="chemistry">among Chymists 
it is taken for lead</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="satyr(n)"><f type="i">Satyre<f type="r"></form> <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(from <f type="i">Satyrus<f type="r">)</class> a certain
deity of the Wood, much spoken of by ancient Poets,
resembling in the upper part of their bodies the shape of
a man, in the lower part, of a goat, and being all over
hairy, (from <f type="i">Satyra<f type="r">) a kind of sharp and
invective Poem full of taunting expressions against any person or thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="satirical(a)"><f type="i">Satyrical<f type="r"><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class></form>, <xpln>bitter invective,

<f type="i">Epirus<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Albania<f type="r">, who having been

Emperour, at last caused <f type="i">Epirus<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Macedonia<f type="r"> to revolt and valiantly kept
<f type="i">Croia<f type="r"> against a mighty power of the

<f type="i">Yorkshire<f type="r"> is denominated, as it were a Burgh upon the Scar or steep Rock.</xpln></wordentry>

or as they term it wood and wood.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Scipio(pn)"><f type="i">Scipio<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the name of several famous
Romans, as <f type="i">Scipio
Africanus<f type="r">, the son of <f type="i">Cornelius<f type="r">,
he overthrew the <f type="i">Carthaginians<f type="r"> in <f type="i">Spain<f type="r">,
taking new <f type="i">Carthage<f type="r">, afterwards wafting over his
Army into <f type="i">Africa<f type="r">, he utterly defeated
<f type="i">Hannibal<f type="r"> in a mighty battel; <f type="i">Scipio
Aemilianus<f type="r">, the adopted son of <f type="i">Africanus<f type="r">,
who demolish't new <f type="i">Carthage<f type="r">,
and <f type="i">Numantia<f type="r"> in <f type="i">Spain<f type="r">, and was killed by
a conspiracy of the <f type="i">Gracchi; Scipio Nasica<f type="r">, a man
very eloquent, skilfull in the Law, and much beloved of the people, by whom he was
called <f type="i">Corculum; Scipio<f type="r"> the father in Law of
<f type="i">Pompey<f type="r"> the Great; first succesfull,
afterwards unfortunate in the wars against <f type="i">C&aelig;sar<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Scylla(pn)"><f type="i">Scylla<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of <f type="i">Nysus<f type="r">,
King of <f type="i">Megara<f type="r">, which being besieged by
<f type="i">Minos<f type="r">, King of <f type="i">Creet<f type="r"> was betrayed into
his hands by <f type="i">Scylla<f type="r">, who falling in love with
<f type="i">Minos<f type="r">, cut off her fathers purple lock (upon
which the fate of the Citie depended) and sent it to him;
but afterwards seeing her self despised, and dying for
grief, she was turned into a Partridge, and <f type="i">Nisus<f type="r">
into a Hawk; also the daughter of <f type="i">Phorcus<f type="r">, who
falling in love with <f type="i">Glaucus<f type="r">, was envied by
<f type="i">Circe<f type="r">, who poisoning the water wherein she used
to bath her self, the lower part of her body became
altogether like the grinning of Dogs; whereupon she threw
her self headlong down the next pr&aelig;cipice, and was
transformed to a Rock over against <f type="i">Charybdis<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Scyllas(pn)"><f type="i">Scyllas<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>one so skilfull in diving, that he
regained a great quantity of gold and
silver, which had been lost in a shipwrack.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Scythia(pn)"><f type="i">Scythia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the most Northern Countrey of the
world, divided into <f type="i">Europ&aelig;a<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Asiatica<f type="r">; it was so called from <f type="i">Scythes<f type="r">
the son of <f type="i">Hercules<f type="r"> by one that was half a woman,
and half a viper; it is at this day called <f type="i">Tartarick<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="scytal(n)"><f type="i">Scytale<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a kinde of secret way of
writing; also a kinde of Serpent, also a field Mouse, called an Ermine, or a shrew.</xpln></wordentry>

<f type="i">Seckinton<f type="r">,

<f type="i">Mercians<f type="r">, was in

extream of the given Arch,
till it meet with the Tangent raised from the Diameter, at the other extream.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Sertorius(pn)"><f type="i">Sertorius<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous Roman Captain who took
part with <f type="i">Marius<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Cinna<f type="r">,
after <f type="i">Scylla<f type="r">, returning from the <f type="i">Mithridatick<f type="r"> War, had got
possession of <f type="i">Rome<f type="r">, he fled into <f type="i">Spain<f type="r">,
and being chosen Captain by the <f type="i">Lusitanians<f type="r">
overthrew the Romans in several battles, at last having
stoutly defended himself
against <f type="i">Pompey<f type="r">, he was slain by <f type="i">Perpenna<f type="r">
as he sate at supper. <f type="i">Diana<f type="r">
is said to have attended him in all his designs, in the
form of a Hart.</xpln></wordentry>

anciently termed Scheafts, in Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Septonia</term><f type="r">.
This place is famous for <f type="i">Aquila<f type="r"> (some say a
reall Eagle, others a Prophet so called) who foretold that the
<f type="i">Brittish<f type="r"> Empire, after the <f type="i">Saxons<f type="r">
</page>

and the <f type="i">Normans<f type="r"> should return again to the

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Shrewsbury(pn)"><f type="i">Shrewsbury<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the chief Town of
<f type="i">Shropshire<f type="r">, anciently called <f type="i">Schroesbury<f type="r">, for that it was a
Thicket of shrubs upon a Hill; <class type="etymlang" lang="br">it is called in the
<f type="i">Brittish<f type="r"> tongue <f type="i"><term lang="br">Ymwithig</term><f type="r"> from
<f type="i"><term lang="br">Mewithaw</term><f type="r"></class>, which is as much as
<f type="i">Placentia<f type="r"> or <f type="i">Plaisance<f type="r">, in regard that for the pleasantnesse
of the situation, the Princes of <f type="i">Wales<f type="r"> chose it
in times past for their chief Seat. Here <f type="i">Edrick
Streona<f type="r"> Duke of the <f type="i">Mercians<f type="r"> lay in wait for
Prince <f type="i">Afhelm<f type="r">, and
slew him as he rode on hunting. This Town is also commonly
called <f type="i">Salop<f type="r">, and in Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Salopia</term><f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="shrift(n)"><f type="i">Shrift<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="sx" type="etymlang">(Saxon,</class> <class lang="la" type="etymlang">from the Latin
<f type="i"><term lang="la">Scrinium</term><f type="r">, i. the
inward brest)</class> auricular confession;
whence Shrovetide among the Catholicks is the time of

they derive themselves from <f type="i">William de Sidney<f type="r">

flower and chief glory of this Family, was that most
accomplisht Gentleman Sir <f type="i">Philip Sidney<f type="r">, who
valiantly fighting before <f type="i">Zutphen<f type="r"> in
<f type="i">Gelderland<f type="r">, lost his life.</xpln></wordentry>

observed them to have been placed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="siren(n)"><f type="i">Sirens<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>certain Sea-deities, three in
number, <f type="i">Parthenope, Ligea<f type="r">, and <f type="i">Leucosia<f type="r">,
the daughters of <f type="i">Achelous<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Calliope<f type="r">,
having their upper part like maids, and their lower parts
like fishes; they used by the sweetnesse of their voices
to allure Mariners to the rocks and cause them to be cast
away: which <f type="i">Vlisses<f type="r"> foreseeing, stopt the ears of
his associates with soft wax, and caused himself to be
bound to the mast of the ship; whereupon they
seeing themselves contemned, cast themselves headlong into the Sea.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Sirius(pn)"><f type="i">Sirius<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a star in the mouth of that
constellation which
is called <f type="i">Canicula<f type="r"> or the <f type="i">Dog<f type="r">, which
toward the latter end of Summer
casts forth a vehement and raging heat; whence the
Dog-dayes derive their name.</xpln></wordentry>

of <f type="i">Athens<f type="r">, and abolished those of <f type="i">Draco<f type="r">;

<f type="i">Clausentum<f type="r">, from the <f type="i">Brittish
<term lang="br">Cladh-Henton</term><f type="r">, i. the Haven of
<f type="i">Henton<f type="r">, in the wars between King
<f type="i">Edward<f type="r"> the third, and <f type="i">Philip Valoise<f type="r">,
it was burnt to the ground by the <f type="i">French<f type="r">, out of the ashes
</page>

<page sig="Nn2r">
whereof immediately sprung up the Town which is now in being.

<f type="i">Oenomaus<f type="r">, broke
out of <f type="i">Capua<f type="r">, got together an Army of slaves, and
overthrew <f type="i">Clodius, Glaber, Lentulus<f type="r">, and
<f type="i">Cassius<f type="r">; thereby making
himself very formidable to the Romans;
at last he was put to flight by
<f type="i">Crassus<f type="r">,
but afterwards making head again,
was vanquisht and slain.</xpln></wordentry>

all passengers that came that way, and none being able to
unfold it, she destroyed them all: at last
<f type="i">Oedipus<f type="r"> coming
that way and expounding it, she threw her self headlong down a rock for grief.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Stanford(pn)"><f type="i">Stanford<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="sx" type="etymlang">in Saxon <f type="i">Steanford<f type="r"></class>, a Town
in <f type="i">Lincolnshire<f type="r">, situate upon the River
<f type="i">Welland<f type="r">; it is so called as being built of
rough stone, <f type="i">Stean<f type="r"> signifying <class lang="sx" type="etymlang">in the Saxon
tongue a stone</class>. In this Town, under the reign of King
<f type="i">Edward<f type="r"> the third, an University
was instituted, and publick profession
of Arts began to flourish; but this Academy continued
not long, it being soon after provided by oath, that no Stu&shy;
</page>

<page sig="Nn3r">
dent in <f type="i">Oxford<f type="r"> should publickly professe at
<f type="i">Stanford<f type="r"> to the prejudice of <f type="i">Oxford<f type="r">.
There is also another <f type="i">Stanford<f type="r"> situate upon the
River <f type="i">Avon<f type="r"> in <f type="i">Northamptonshire<f type="r">.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Stonehenge(pn)"><f type="i">Stonehenge<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a wonderfull Pile of stones
upon <f type="i">Salisbury<f type="r"> plain, erected within the Circuit
of a Ditch, in manner of a Crown in three ranks, one
within another, whereof
some are 28 foot high, and seven foot broad, upon the
heads of which others lie overthwart with Mortises; so as
the whole frame seemeth to hang; it is termed by the old
Historians <f type="i">Chorea Gigantum<f type="r">, i. the Gyants dance.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Stygian(pn)"><f type="i">Stygian<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to the River

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="sybaritical(a)"><f type="i">Sybaritical<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>dainty, wanton, effeminate,
from the <f type="i">Sybari&aelig;<f type="r">, the inhabitants of the City
<f type="i">Sybaris<f type="r">, a people advanced to that height of
luxury and voluptuousnesse, that they had their horses
taught to dance to the sound of the Flute, by which means,
the <f type="i">Crotoniat&aelig;<f type="r"> who waged war with them, bringing
pipers along with them into the field, made their horses
to fall a dancing; whereupon they rushed in among them,
broke their ranks, and utterly overthrew them, and
destroyed their City.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Sybill(pn)"><f type="i">Sybill<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="he" type="etymlang">(Heb.)</class> divine doctrine, a

concerning the birth of our Saviour Christ; they were
thought to be ten in number, the <f type="i">Persian, Cum&aelig;an,
Lybian, Delphian, Erythr&aelig;an, Samian,
Hellespontian, Phrygian, Tiburtine, Cuman<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Sylla(pn)"><f type="i">Sylla<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous Roman Captain, who brought
<f type="i">Jugurth<f type="r"> in chaines to <f type="i">Rome<f type="r">, overcame
<f type="i">Mithridates<f type="r">, broke the tyranny of <f type="i">Cinna<f type="r">,
and banished <f type="i">Marius<f type="r">: afterwards being made
Dictatour, he became Tyrannical
himself, till at last the Commonwealth
being setled, he retired to <f type="i">Puteoli<f type="r">,
where he lived a private life.</xpln></wordentry>

the Dominion of the <f type="i">Turks<f type="r">, with a vast
multitude of men, and
having overthrown and taken <f type="i">Bajazeth<f type="r">, the
Emperour of the <f type="i">Turks<f type="r">, he led him up and down all
<f type="i">Asia<f type="r"> in an Iron Cage, he was, as some say, at
first a Swinheard, but by a full gale of
fortune, was blown up
into the Imperial Thrown.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Tamworth(pn)"><f type="i">Tamworth<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town so called from the River
<f type="i">Tame<f type="r">, and <class lang="sx" type="etymlang">the Saxon word <f type="i"><term lang="sx">Weordh</term><f type="r">, which
signifieth a <f type="i">Barton, Ferm-house<f type="r">, or River Island</class>;
it is situate partly in <f type="i">Warwick-shire<f type="r">,
partly in <f type="i">Stafford-shire<f type="r">, and was anciently the
chief residence of the Kings of the <f type="i">Mercians<f type="r">.
this Town after it had suffered much by the
<f type="i">Danish<f type="r"> Wars, was repaired by <f type="i">Aethelfleda<f type="r">, Lady of the
<f type="i">Mercians<f type="r">; also <f type="i">Edith<f type="r"> King <f type="i">Eadgar's<f type="r"> sister founded here
a Religious house for veiled Virgins.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Tanet(pn)"><f type="i">Tanet<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an Island in <f type="i">Kent<f type="r">, so
called, as some vainly imagin <term lang="gk">&#x1F00;&#x03C0;&#x03BF; &#x03C4;&#x1F44; 
&#x03B8;&#x03B1;&#x03BD;&#x03B1;&#x03C4;&#x1F44;</term>,
<f type="i">i.<f type="r"> from the death of Snakes, here the
<f type="i">Saxons<f type="r"> first seated themselves, but were
vanquish't with a great slaughter at <f type="i">Stovar<f type="r">;
neverthelesse,
afterwards at <f type="i">Whipped-fleet<f type="r">, a place so called
from <f type="i">Whipped<f type="r">, a <f type="i">Saxon<f type="r"> there slain,
<f type="i">Hengist<f type="r"> overthrew the <f type="i">Brittains<f type="r">,
and put them to flight.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="tangent(n)"><f type="i">Tangent<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> <class type="register" subject="mathematics">a Mathematical Term</class> used
chiefly <class type="register" subject="astrology and astronomy">in Astronomy</class>, and signifies, a
</page>

<page sig="Oo3v">
right line perpendicular, to the Diameter drawn by the
one extream of the given Arch, and terminated by the
Secant, and drawn from the Center through the other
extream of the said Arch.

the <f type="i">Saxon<f type="r"> word <f type="i"><term lang="sx">Thane</term><f type="r"></class>, i. a Nobleman.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Tantalus(pn)"><f type="i">Tantalus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an ancient King of
<f type="i">Phrygia<f type="r">, the son of <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> by the Nymph
<f type="i">Plotis<f type="r">, he inviting the gods to a feast, killed
his son <f type="i">Pelops<f type="r">, and set before them to eat, for
which he was condemned to this punishment
in Hell, namely to stand up to the chin in water, and to
have pleasant apples hang over his head, and yet to be
neither able to eat nor to drink, whence a man that is
brought near to happinesse, and yet deprived of it, is
commonly said to be <f type="i">Tantaliz'd<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="tap(v)">To <f type="i">Tap<f type="r"><f type="r"></form>, <xpln>vide, to <xref><f type="i">Beat<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Taphus(pn)" lexeme="Telebus(pn)"><f type="i">Taphus<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Telebus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the sons of
<f type="i">Pterelas<f type="r">, the son of Neptune and
<f type="i">Hippothoe<f type="r">, the daughter of <f type="i">Nestor<f type="r">; their
Successours, the <f type="i">Taphii<f type="r">,
and <f type="i">Telebo&aelig;<f type="r"> inhabited the <f type="i">Taphian<f type="r">, or
<f type="i">Echinades<f type="r"> Islands, see <xref target="Amphitryo"><f type="i">Amphitryon<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="tapinage(n)"><f type="i">Tapinage<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> a lurking, or lying
secret, whence <f type="i">Tapissant<f type="r">, lurking, or
squatting, <class type="register" subject="hawking and hunting">a Term in
Hunting</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Taprobane(pn)"><f type="i">Taprobane<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an Island in the <f type="i">Indian<f type="r">
Sea, 1000 mile long, and 625 mile broad, now called
<f type="i">Sumatra<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="taratantarize(v)"><f type="i">Taratantarize<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> to imitate the sound
of a Trumpet, which seemeth to expresse the word
<f type="i">Taratantara<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="tarantula(n)"><f type="i">Tarantula<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kinde of venemous
Creature, abounding in
<f type="i">Tarantum<f type="r">, a Citie in the Kingdom of
<f type="i">Naples<f type="r">, which casteth forth a sting, onely
curable by the sound of Musick.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="tardigrade(a)"><f type="i">Tardigrade<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> going a slow
place.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="tardity(n)"><f type="i">Tardity<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> slownesse, or
delaying.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Tarentum(pn)"><f type="i">Tarentum<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Citie of <f type="i">Magna Gr&aelig;cia<f type="r">
in <f type="i">Italy<f type="r">, built by <f type="i">Tarentus<f type="r"> the son of
<f type="i">Neptune<f type="r">, and
augmented by <f type="i">Phalantus<f type="r">, a
<f type="i">Laced&aelig;monian<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="tarpaulin(n)"><f type="i">Tarpawling<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="navigation">a Term in Navigation</class>, a piece
of Canvasse that is all tarr'd over to lash upon a deck,
or grating, to keep the rain from soaking through.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Tarpeia(pn)"><f type="i">Tarpeia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a vestal Virgin, the daughter of
<f type="i">Tarpeius<f type="r">, she betrayed the Roman <f type="i">Capitol<f type="r">
to the <f type="i">Sabines<f type="r">, desiring for a reward what ever
they carried upon their right Arms, whereupon they all
threw their sheilds upon her, and pressed her to death.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Tarquinius Priscus(pn)"><f type="i">Tarquinius Priscus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of
<f type="i">Demaratus<f type="r"> a
<f type="i">Corinthian<f type="r">, who by the perswasion of his wife
<f type="i">Tanaquil<f type="r"> went to <f type="i">Rome<f type="r">, where by
insinuating himself into the favour of <f type="i">Ancus
Martius<f type="r">, he at length obtained the Kingdom.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Tarquinius Superbus(pn)"><f type="i">Tarquinius Superbus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the seventh King of
the Romans, whose son <f type="i">Tarquinius Sextus<f type="r"> ravishing
<f type="i">Lucretia<f type="r">, the wife of <f type="i">Tarquinius
Collatinus<f type="r">, was the cause that kingly
Government was utterly
expelled out of Rome.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Tarracon(pn)"><f type="i">Tarracon<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous Citie of
<f type="i">Arragon<f type="r">, anciently called <f type="i">Tarraconia<f type="r">, a
Province of Spain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="terrace(n)"><f type="i">Tarrasse<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>see <xref><f type="i">Terrasse<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Tarsus(pn)"><f type="i">Tarsus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous Citie of <f type="i">Cilicia<f type="r">,
where St. <f type="i">Paul<f type="r"> was born, which Citie together
with <f type="i">Anchialus<f type="r"> are said to have been built in one
day, by <f type="i">Perseus<f type="r"> the son of <f type="i">Dan&aelig;<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Tartarean(a)"><f type="i">Tartarean<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to
<f type="i">Tartarus<f type="r">, i. a
deep place in Hell often mentioned
by the Poets.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Tartaria(pn)"><f type="i">Tartaria<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a large Countrey of
<f type="i">Asia<f type="r">, containing <f type="i">Sarmatia, Asiatica<f type="r">, the
two <f type="i">Scythia's<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Cataia<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="tartar(n)"><f type="i">Tarter<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the Lees of Wine; also a kinde of
Gravelly-stone, growing in the inside of Wine
vessels.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="tasck(n)"><f type="i">Tasck<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="etymlang" lang="br">an old <f type="i">Brittish<f type="r"> word,
signifying as much as Tribute</class>, from whence haply cometh
our word <f type="i">Task<f type="r">, which is a duty, or labour imposed
upon any one.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="tassel(n)"><f type="i">Tassel<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> 
<class type="register" subject="hawking and hunting">a Term in Falconry</class>, the
Male of any Hawk.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Titus Tatius(pn)"><f type="i">Titus Tatius<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Captain of the
<f type="i">Sabines<f type="r">, who after great Wars with the Romans, at
length concluding a peace with them, was received as a
sharer in the Government.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Tavistoke(pn)" lexeme="Teavistok(pn)"><f type="i">Tavistoke<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Teavistok<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>a Town in
<f type="i">Devonshire<f type="r">; so
called from the River <f type="i">Teave<f type="r">, it hath been famous
in times past, for the <f type="i">Abbey<f type="r"> built by
<f type="i">Ordolph<f type="r">, the son of <f type="i">Ordgare<f type="r">,
Earle of <f type="i">Devonshire<f type="r">, in the year 961. he being
admonished, as some say by a Vision from Heaven; this
<f type="i">Abby<f type="r"> was destroyed
by the <f type="i">Danes<f type="r">, but afterwards
flourish'd again, and in it Lectures were instituted
of the <f type="i">English Saxon<f type="r"> tongue.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Tawnton(pn)" lexeme="Thonton(pn)"><f type="i">Tawnton<f type="r">, or <f type="i">Thonton<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>a Town in
<f type="i">Somersetshire<f type="r">;
so called as it were a Town watered
by the River <f type="i">Thone<f type="r">, here
<f type="i">Ina<f type="r"> King
of the <f type="i">West-saxons<f type="r">, built a Castle, which
<f type="i">Desburgio<f type="r"> his wife rased to the ground, after she
had expelled from thence <f type="i">Eadbritch<f type="r">,
King of the <f type="i">South-saxons<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

stretched out a mighty length through divers Countreys,
and called by several names; as <f type="i">Imaus, Parapomisus,
Circius, Taurus, Caucasus, Sarpedon,
Ceraunius<f type="r">, &amp;c. also the name of one of the twelve
signes of the Zodiack, <class type="etymlang" lang="la">the word signifying in
Latin a Bull</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

great Wars with the <f type="i">Ph&aelig;neat&aelig;<f type="r">;

<f type="i"><emend err="Rherimachus" source="errata">Therimachus</emend><f type="r"> for the <f type="i">Tegeans<f type="r">,
and the three sons of <f type="i">Demostratus<f type="r"> for the
<f type="i">Ph&aelig;neat&aelig;<f type="r">, like that of the <f type="i">Horatii<f type="r"> and

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Telamon(pn)"><f type="i">Telamon<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Aeacus<f type="r">, King
of <f type="i">Salamis<f type="r">, he
was the first that got upon the Walls of <f type="i">Troy<f type="r">,
when <f type="i">Hercules<f type="r"> besieged it, whereupon he gave him
<f type="i">Hesione<f type="r"> the daughter of <f type="i">Laomedon<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Telegonus(pn)"><f type="i">Telegonus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Vlisses<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Circe<f type="r">, who slew his father at <f type="i">Ithaca<f type="r"> not
knowing him, afterwards
going into <f type="i">Italy<f type="r"> he built
<f type="i">Tusculum<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Telephus(pn)"><f type="i">Telephus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Hercules<f type="r">, and
the Nymph <f type="i">Auge<f type="r">, who being exposed to the Woods by
his Grand-father, was brought up by a Hart, afterward
becoming King of <f type="i">Mysia<f type="r">, he was wounded by
<f type="i">Achilles<f type="r">, whom he denied passage through his
Countrey going to the Wars of <f type="i">Troy<f type="r">, but at length
was cured by the same dart that wounded him.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="telescope(n)"><f type="i">Telescope<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> <class type="register" subject="mathematics">a certain

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Tempe(pn)"><f type="i">Tempe<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>certain pleasant fields in

watered by the River <f type="i">Pencus<f type="r">,
which makes them so ever green and flourishing, that all
delightfull places are
by <f type="i">Metaphor<f type="r"> called <f type="i">Tempe<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="tendril(n)"><f type="i">Tendrells<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the young branches of a tree, and

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="tenebres(n)"><f type="i">Tenebres<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>certain divine Services
performed among the
Catholicks some dayes of the week before Easter Sunday, in
representation of our Saviours Agony in the Garden, there
being put out, of the 15 lamps which they light, one at
the end of every Psalm they repeat, untill all the lights
are extinguished.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="tenebrio(n)"><f type="i">Tenebrion<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> one that lurks in the

parts <class type="register" subject="music">in Musick</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="tensile(a)"><f type="i">Tensil<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> easie to be bent or stretcht

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Tewkesbury(pn)"><f type="i">Tewkesbury<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town in
<f type="i">Glocestershire<f type="r">, called by the Saxons
<f type="i"><term lang="sx">Theoc'sbury</term><f type="r">, by the Latins <f type="i"><term lang="la">Theoci curia</term><f type="r">,
from one <f type="i">Theocus<f type="r"> who here led an Hermites life.
Here was fought that memorable battle between the Houses
of <f type="i">York<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Lancaster<f type="r">, where King
<f type="i">Edward<f type="r"> the fourth had the Victory, and Prince
<f type="i">Edward<f type="r"> the onely son of King <f type="i">Henry<f type="r"> the
sixth was killed in a barbarous manner: this Town is also
famous for making of woollen cloth, and the best
mustard.</xpln></wordentry>

<f type="i">Alexander<f type="r"> the
Great, and was according to her request got with child by him.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Theano(pn)"><f type="i">Theano<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the wife of <f type="i">Metapontus<f type="r">
King of <f type="i">Icaria<f type="r">, she, wanting children of her own,
brought up two twins the sons of
<f type="i">Neptune<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Menalippe<f type="r"> the daughter of
<f type="i">Desmontes<f type="r">; but
afterwards bringing forth two sons of her own, which were
likewise twins, and seeing her husbands affections
inclining more to <f type="i">Menalippe<f type="r">'s sons, than to her
own, she was much troubled, and as soon as her sons came
of age, she set them on to kill their supposed brethren;
but <f type="i">Neptune<f type="r"> their father coming to their aid,
they killed the sons of <f type="i">Theano<f type="r">, which as soon as
she came to hear, she killed her self.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="theatral(a)"><f type="i">Theatral<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> belonging to a Theater,

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Themis(pn)"><f type="i">Themis<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of <f type="i">Coelus<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Terra<f type="r">, who flying the Nuptialls of
<f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">, was
ravisht by him in <f type="i">Macedonia<f type="r">; she was worshipt as
the goddesse that first taught men right and justice, and
had an ancient Oracle in <f type="i">Boeotia<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Themiscyra(pn)"><f type="i">Themiscyra<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Region bordering upon

<f type="i">Thermodon<f type="r">, having also its chief City of the same

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Themistocles(pn)"><f type="i">Themistocles<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous <f type="i">Athenian<f type="r">
Captain,
</page>

<page sig="Pp1v">
who fortified the <f type="i">Pyr&aelig;um<f type="r">, and overcame the
<f type="i">Persians<f type="r"> at <f type="i">Salamina<f type="r">; but afterwards
being banished his Country, he was
intertained by
<f type="i">Xerxes<f type="r"> and made Captain of an army against the
<f type="i">Athenians<f type="r">, whereupon he drank Oxes blood and
poisoned himself, that
he might neither be ingratefull to the King, nor fight
against his Countrymen.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Theodamas(pn)"><f type="i">Theodamas<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a King of <f type="i">Chaonia<f type="r">,
against whom <f type="i">Hercules<f type="r"> made war, because he
denied him provisions when
he came to <f type="i">Dryope<f type="r"> with <f type="i">Dejanira<f type="r"> and his
son <f type="i">Hyllus<f type="r">, and having got the Victory he slew
<f type="i">Theodamas<f type="r">,
carrying away his son <f type="i">Hylas<f type="r"> whom he alwayes had
in very great esteem.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Theobald(pn)"><f type="i">Theobald<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the proper name of a man,
signifying <class lang="sx" type="etymlang">in Saxon, bold over the people</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="theodolite(n)"><f type="i">Theodolite<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class type="register" subject="mathematics">a certain Mathematical

used <class type="register" subject="surveying">in Surveying</class>, consisting
of the Planisphere, Geometrical square, Quadrant, and

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Theodoricus(pn)"><f type="i">Theodoricus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a King of the East
<f type="i">Goths<f type="r">, who having overcome
<f type="i">Odoacer<f type="r">,
was Crowned King of <f type="i">Italy<f type="r">, and reigned there 33
years; also the name of a King of the <f type="i">Gaules<f type="r">, who
with his favorite <f type="i">Ebroinus<f type="r"> was deposed, and
<f type="i">Childerick<f type="r"> set up in his room: <class type="etymlang" lang="du">the word
signifieth in Dutch, rich in people</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Theodorus(pn)"><f type="i">Theodorus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a proper name of several famous
men, the word signifying <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">in Greek a gift of God</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Theodosia(pn)"><f type="i">Theodosia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Christian name of women, answering to <f type="i">Theodorus<f type="r">
or <f type="i">Theodosius<f type="r"> in men.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Theodosius(pn)"><f type="i">Theodosius<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the name of two famous
Emperours of
<f type="i">Constantinople<f type="r">, the first the son of the Emperour
<f type="i">Gratian<f type="r">, the second the son of <f type="i">Arcadius<f type="r">
and <f type="i">Eudoxia<f type="r">,
he had wars with the <f type="i">Persians, Vandalls<f type="r">, and
<f type="i">Hunns<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="theogony(n)"><f type="i">Theogonie<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> the generation of the
gods.</xpln></wordentry>

may guesse at the change of weather, a

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Thermopylae(pn)"><f type="i">Thermopyl&aelig;<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a long ridge of mountains in
<f type="i">Greece<f type="r">, at whose streights <f type="i">Leonidas<f type="r"> the
<f type="i">Spartan<f type="r"> King with 300 <f type="i">Laced&aelig;monians<f type="r">
stoutly fighting, were all cut off by
<f type="i">Mardonius<f type="r"> the <f type="i">Persian<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Theseus(pn)"><f type="i">Theseus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Aegeus<f type="r"> King of
<f type="i">Athens<f type="r">, he
overcame the <f type="i">Amazonians<f type="r">, and brought away their
Queen <f type="i">Hippolyte<f type="r">, on whom he begat
<f type="i">Hippolytus<f type="r">, he slew the <f type="i">Minotaur<f type="r"> at
<f type="i">Creet<f type="r">, and brought away
<f type="i">Ariadne<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Ph&aelig;dra<f type="r"> the daughters
of <f type="i">Minos<f type="r">, the last of whom he took to wife. He
overthrew three famous
theeves, <f type="i">Sciron, Procrustes<f type="r">,
and <f type="i">Schinis<f type="r">; Lastly he went down with
<f type="i">Pirithous<f type="r"> into Hell to fetch away
<f type="i">Proserpina<f type="r">.
See <f type="i">Pirithous<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="thesis(n)"><f type="i">Thesis<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a general argument or
position.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Thessalia(pn)"><f type="i">Thessalia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Region of <f type="i">Greece<f type="r">
lying between
<f type="i">Boeotia<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Macedon<f type="r">, it was anciently called
<f type="i">Pelasgicus<f type="r">, from <f type="i">Pelasgus, Aemonia<f type="r">, from King
<f type="i">Aemon, Pyrrh&aelig;a<f type="r"> from <f type="i">Pyrrha<f type="r"> the wife of <f type="i">Deucalion<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Thetis(pn)"><f type="i">Thetis<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of <f type="i">Nereus<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Doris<f type="r">, whom <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> being about to have
married, was disswaded by <f type="i">Prometheus<f type="r">, so that she
married <f type="i">Peleus<f type="r"> the son of <f type="i">Aeacus<f type="r">, to
whom she brought forth <f type="i">Achilles<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Thomyris(pn)"><f type="i">Thomyris<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Queen of <f type="i">Scythia<f type="r">, who
</page>

<page sig="Pp2r">
inraged that <f type="i">Cyrus<f type="r"> had slain her son
<f type="i">Spargapises<f type="r">
in a battle, recollected all her
forces, overthrew his
Army, and slew him, and putting his head in a tub of
blood, said in an upbraiding manner, Fill thy self with
the blood for which thou hast thirsted.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Thon(pn)"><f type="i">Thon<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a King of <f type="i">Canopus<f type="r">, who
falling in love with <f type="i">Helena<f type="r">, was slain by
<f type="i">Menelaus<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Thongcaster(pn)"><f type="i">Thongcaster<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Castle in
<f type="i">Lincolnshire<f type="r">, commonly called <f type="i">Castor<f type="r">, in
Brittish <f type="i"><term lang="br">C&aelig;regary</term><f type="r">,
it took the name from the same occasion
as <f type="i">Byrsa<f type="r"> a Castle of the
<f type="i">Carthaginians<f type="r">;
for <f type="i">Hengist<f type="r"> obtaining so much ground in this tract, of
<f type="i">Vortigern<f type="r">, as he could measure out with an
Oxehide, cut the hide out into very small laners, which we
commonly call Thongs, and therewith measuring out the
ground, built upon it this Castle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Thor(pn)"><f type="i">Thor<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain Idol worshipped by the
ancient Saxons, thought to be the same with
<f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">, or the god of Thunder; whence
<f type="i">Thursday<f type="r"> took its denomination.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Thymaetes(pn)"><f type="i">Thym&aelig;tes<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a <f type="i">Trojan<f type="r">, who marrying
<f type="i">Arisbe<f type="r"> the daughter of <f type="i">Priamus<f type="r">, had a
son born on the same day with <f type="i">Paris<f type="r">, and because
the <f type="i">Augurs<f type="r"> had foretold that one born that day
should be the destruction of <f type="i">Troy, Priamus<f type="r">
commanded that both the children
should be slain; but <f type="i">Paris<f type="r"> being
saved by his mother,
<f type="i">Thym&aelig;tes<f type="r"> son was onely
killed, for which he bearing a revenge in his mind, was
the first that caused the <f type="i">Trojan<f type="r"> horse to be let
in.</xpln></wordentry>

</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="titanic(a)"><f type="i">Titanick<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>belonging to <f type="i">Titan<f type="r">, i.
the son of <f type="i">C&aelig;lus<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Vesta<f type="r">, and the
brother of <f type="i">Saturn<f type="r">,
he is by the Poets oftentimes taken for the Sun.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="tithing(n)"><f type="i">Tithing<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a company of ten men, with their

the chief whereof is called a Tithing man.</xpln></wordentry>

solemn shew at the return of a General from some noted

of laughter. In this Cave there was an Oracle of

Trophonius<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

membrane or thin skin,
covering any part of the body: there are four especially
which cover the eye, the Corneal or
Horny, the Uveal, the
Vitreal or glassy, and the Christalline, and to each of
these there are foure humours answerable.
And four that cover the cods, the Scrotum, the
Erythroides, the Epididymis,
and one other which is called Dartos.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Tunnocellum(pn)"><f type="i">Tunnocellum<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the ancient name of a Town in

the same with that which we now call <f type="i">Tinmouth<f type="r">, q
the mouth of the River <f type="i">Tine<f type="r">, where the first
Cohort <f type="i">Aelia Classica<f type="r"> was in pay for Sea-service.
This Town hath a very strong Castle, which <f type="i">Robert
Mowbray<f type="r"> Earle of <f type="i">Northumberland<f type="r"> holding
against King <f type="i">William Rufus<f type="r">, was therein closely
besieged and taken prisoner.</xpln></wordentry>

</page>

<page sig="Qq1v">
to the River <f type="i">Tybur<f type="r">, prayed to <f type="i">Vesta<f type="r"> that

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Tybur(pn)"><f type="i">Tybur<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a City not far from <f type="i">Rome<f type="r">,
built as some say by <f type="i">Catillus<f type="r"> the
<f type="i">Arcadian<f type="r"> the Admiral of <f type="i">Euander<f type="r">;
others by <f type="i">Tyburtus<f type="r"> the grandchild of <f type="i">Amphiaraus<f type="r">:
it is now called <f type="i">Tivoli<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Tydeus(pn)"><f type="i">Tydeus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Oeneus<f type="r"> King of
<f type="i">Caledonia<f type="r">, he
having slain his brother <f type="i">Menalippus<f type="r">,
fled to <f type="i">Adrastus<f type="r">, whose daughter
<f type="i">Delphile<f type="r"> he married; afterwards being sent by
<f type="i">Polynices<f type="r"> to his brother <f type="i">Eteocles<f type="r">, King
of <f type="i">Thebes<f type="r">, he overcame all his guests at several
Combats; whereupon at his return they set 50 young men to
lie in wait for him under the command of <f type="i">M&aelig;on<f type="r">
the son of <f type="i">Aemon<f type="r">, and <f type="i">Lycophon<f type="r"> the son
of <f type="i">Autophonus<f type="r">, who were all slain by him
except <f type="i">M&aelig;on<f type="r">, whom
he sent back to carry news of the others deaths: at length
he was mortally wounded by one <f type="i">Menalippus<f type="r"> a
<f type="i">Theban<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Tymaetes(pn)"><f type="i"><emend err="Tymn&aelig;tes" source="errata">Tym&aelig;tes</emend><f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a great Prophet, the son of

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Tyndarus(pn)"><f type="i">Tyndarus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a King of <f type="i">Oebalia<f type="r">, whose

whereof was contained <f type="i">Pollux<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Helena<f type="r">,

<f type="i">Clytemnestra<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<f type="i">Terra<f type="r">, a Gyant of a very vast bignesse, who
going to make War with <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">, was by him struck with Thunder.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Typhon(pn)"><f type="i">Typhon<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a King of <f type="i">Aegypt<f type="r">, who
killing his brother <f type="i">Osiris<f type="r">, and cutting him into
several pieces, dispersed him through
divers Countreys.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="typical(a)"><f type="i">Typical<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> bearing a <f type="i">Type<f type="r">,

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Tyre(pn)"><f type="i">Tyre<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous Citie of <f type="i">Phoenicia<f type="r">,
anciently called
<f type="i">Sarra<f type="r">, which in the <f type="i">Phoenician<f type="r">
language signifieth a fish, that place abounding with a
kind of shell-fish, the liquour whereof coloureth of a
purple dye.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Tyro(pn)"><f type="i">Tyro<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a <f type="i">Thessalian<f type="r"> Virgin, the
daughter of <f type="i">Salmoneus<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Alcidice<f type="r">,
after the death of her own mother, she was very harshly
dealt with by her mother in law <f type="i">Sidero<f type="r">, she being
got with child by <f type="i">Neptune<f type="r"> (who lay with her in
the shape of <f type="i">Enipeus<f type="r">, with whom she was in love)
brought forth twins, <f type="i">Pelias<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Neleus<f type="r">,
and afterwards being married to her Uncle
<f type="i">Cretheus<f type="r">, she brought forth <f type="i">Aeson,
Amythaon<f type="r">, and <f type="i">Pheres<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="tirociny(n)"><f type="i">Tyrociny<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> an apprentiship, or new
beginning in any Art or Faculty; but more peculiarly
<class type="register" subject="war">Military discipline</class>, from <f type="i">Tyron<f type="r">, a rawe young
souldier, one newly entred into the Art of war.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Tyrrheni(pn)"><f type="i">Tyrrheni<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a people inhabiting
<f type="i">Tuscia<f type="r"> or <f type="i">Tyrrhenia<f type="r">, being that part of
<f type="i">Italy<f type="r"> which lieth upon the Sea, called from
thence the <f type="i">Tyrrhen Sea<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

Rockesly<f type="r">, held Lands at <f type="i">Seaton<f type="r"> by Sergeanty to be <f type="i"><term lang="la">Vantrarius
Regis donec perusus fuerit

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="vein(n)">A <f type="i">Vein<f type="r"></form> <xpln>is defined by <f type="i">Anatomists<f type="r"> to
be a common Organ of the body, round, and oblong apted for
the conveyance of bloud and natural spirits through all
the parts, and according to the several parts, it
passeth through, it taketh
several Denominations, as the Basilick vein, that which
passeth from the Liver through the inward processe of the arm, the
<f type="i">Cephalick<f type="r"> the head vein, the <f type="i">Coeliacal<f type="r">,
that which runs into the blinde Gut, the Cystick, that
which runs up toward the Neck of the Gall, the
Epigastrick, the flank veins Gastroepiploick,
that which spreads it self through the bottom of the
Ventricle, Intercostal, those which run through the upper
Ribs. Port vein, that which is rooted in the Liver, and
from thence passeth into the Ventricle, Mesentery, and
other parts. <f type="i">Ranular<f type="r">, that which ascends from the
Throat to the tongue. <f type="i">Salvatel<f type="r">, that which from
the Liver runnes through the wrist into the hand;
<f type="i">Saph&aelig;na<f type="r"> that which runnes through the inward
part of the Legge to the Ankle. <f type="i">Subclavicular<f type="r">, a
branch of the hollow vein, which runnes under the Neck
bone. <f type="i">Thymick<f type="r">, a branch of the Subclavicular.
<f type="i">Torcular<f type="r">, that which ascends by the inside of the
scull to the brain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="velification(n)"><f type="i">Velification<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a hoising of
sayls.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="velites(n)"><f type="i">Velites<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> the light armed Souldiers
among the Romans, see <f type="i"><emend err="Triani" source="errata"><xref target="_notfound">Triarii</xref></emend><f type="r">, whence
<f type="i">Velitation<f type="r">, a light skirmishing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="velivolent(a)"><f type="i">Velivolent<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> flying as it were with
full sayl.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="vellication(n)"><f type="i">Vellication<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a plucking, twitching,
or giving a sudden pull. <class type="register" subject="medicine">In Physick</class> they are said to be
certain convulsions that happen in the Fibers of the
Muscles.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Venetiae(pn)"><f type="i">Veneti&aelig;<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous Citie of <f type="i">Italy<f type="r">,
built in the year 421. upon certain Islands of the
<f type="i">Adriatick<f type="r"> Sea, 60 in number, by the
inhabitants of <f type="i">Aquileia<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Pavia<f type="r">, who fled thither for
fear of the Huns; it is now become
a great Common wealth, and hath large Territories, both in
<f type="i">Italy<f type="r"> and other places.</xpln></wordentry>

<f type="i">Vrolanium<f type="r">, the
name of a City heretofore of very great repute in
<f type="i">Hertfordshire<f type="r">, the ruines whereof appear at this
day, near unto Saint <f type="i">Albans<f type="r">; the <f type="i">Saxons<f type="r">

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="vespillon(n)"><f type="i">Vespilone<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> one who in the time of a

bodies in the night time to

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Vesta(pn)"><f type="i">Vesta<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the daughter of <f type="i">Saturn<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Ops<f type="r">, taken ofttimes by the Poets for the earth
and sometimes for the fire, in honour of whom <f type="i">Numa
Pompilius<f type="r"> instituted many Rites and Ceremonies, and
conscecrated to her service certain Virgins called
<f type="i">Vestalls<f type="r">, who
were to take care of the Vestal fire, which when it went
out, was not to be kindled by any earthly fire, but to be
renewed by the beams of the Sun. They were injoyned to
preserve their virginity inviolable so long as they
remained in the service of the goddesse, and who ever was
found faulty among them was buried alive.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="vestiary(n)"><f type="i">Vestiary<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a Wardrope or place to lay
clothes or apparrel in.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="vestigation(n)"><f type="i">Vestigation<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a seeking any one by
the print of their foot, a searching
diligently.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="vestige(n)"><f type="i">Vestige<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(lat.)</class> a footstep, or print of any

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Ulisses(pn)"><f type="i">Vlisses<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">L&aelig;rtes<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Anticlea<f type="r">, he married <f type="i">Penelope<f type="r"> the
daughter of <f type="i">Icarius<f type="r">,
by whom he had <f type="i">Telemachus<f type="r">; he was by
<f type="i">Palamedes<f type="r"> forced against his will to go to the
wars of <f type="i">Troy<f type="r"> where he proved very serviceable
to the <f type="i">Greeks<f type="r"> by reason of his great subtilty;
for he brought <f type="i">Achilles<f type="r"> to them who had hid
himself among the daughters of <f type="i">Lycomed<f type="r">; He
stole away the ashes of <f type="i">Laomedon<f type="r"> which were
kept in one of the gates of the City; He took away the
<f type="i">Palladium<f type="r">, and with the help of
<f type="i">Diomed<f type="r"> slew King
<f type="i">Rh&aelig;sus<f type="r"> and brought away his white horses; He
by a wile caused <f type="i">Palamed<f type="r">
to whom he bore a grudge, to be stoned to death, and
after <f type="i">Achilles<f type="r"> was slain, he was preferred
before <f type="i">Ajax<f type="r"> by the common sentence of the
<f type="i">Greeks<f type="r">, to have his armes: after the wars of
<f type="i">Troy<f type="r">, intending
to sail back to his own Country, he was cast by tempest
together with his companions
upon unknown Regions; being cast upon <f type="i">Aeolia<f type="r">,
he obtained of <f type="i">Aeolus<f type="r"> the winds in a bottle,
which was broken by his companions thinking there had
been a treasure concealed in it; next coming to the
Country of the <f type="i">L&aelig;strigones<f type="r">,
</page>

<page sig="Rr1r">
his companions were changed into beasts by
<f type="i">Circe<f type="r">, whom he compelled to restore them to
their former shapes, and lying with her he begat
<f type="i">Telegonus<f type="r">; having scap't the charms of the
<f type="i">Syrens<f type="r">, his companions were afterward cast away
for killing the flocks of <f type="i">Ph&aelig;thusa<f type="r"> the
daughter of the Sun, and he onely escaping, was cast
uppon <f type="i">Ogygia<f type="r"> and
intertained by <f type="i">Calypso<f type="r">, on whom he begat
<f type="i">Nausithous<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Nausinous<f type="r">; at length he
was intertained by <f type="i">Nausicaa<f type="r"> the daughter of
<f type="i">Alcinous<f type="r"> King of the <f type="i">Ph&aelig;acenses<f type="r">,
and his wife <f type="i">Arete<f type="r">, he obtained of them a new
ship and attendants, with whom he arrived safe at
<f type="i">Ithaca<f type="r">, where he slew all his rivals, and was
himself slain unknown by his son <f type="i">Telegonus<f type="r">.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="ulophone(n)"><f type="i">Vlophone<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kind of plant called the black
<f type="i">Cham&aelig;leon<f type="r"> thistle; it is also called
<f type="i">Vervilago<f type="r">.</xpln>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Vulcan(pn)"><f type="i">Vulcan<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the God of fire, the son of
<f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Juno<f type="r">, he was thrown out of
heaven for his deformity, into the Isle of <f type="i">Lemnos<f type="r">,
by which fall he became lame, he was brought up by
<f type="i">Eurynome<f type="r">, the daughter of <f type="i">Oceanus<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Thetis<f type="r">, he was the master of the
<f type="i">Cyclops<f type="r">, and made Thunderbolts for
<f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r">; also <f type="i">Hermione<f type="r">'s bracelet,
<f type="i">Ariadne<f type="r">'s Crown, the Chariot of the Sun, the
Armour of <f type="i">Achilles<f type="r">
and <f type="i">Aeneas<f type="r">, &amp;c. he would have married
<f type="i">Minerva<f type="r">, but she refusing him, he married
<f type="i">Venus<f type="r">, whom he having caught in bed with
<f type="i">Mars<f type="r">, threw a Net over them, and exposed them to
the view of all the gods.</xpln></wordentry>

<f type="i">Civilians<f type="r"> call <f type="i"><term lang="la">derelictum</term><f type="r">, any thing
(whether it be Cattel
strayed, or goods stolen and quitted upon Hue and Cry)
which being found are to be proclaimed sundry Market
dayes, and if they challenge them
</page>

<page sig="Rr2v">
within a year and a day are to be restored, otherwise
they are to belong to the Lord of the Franchise; also as
a man forsaken of the Law, to which he was sworn is said
out-lawed, so a woman not being sworn to the Law is
called <f type="i">Waive<f type="r">.
</xpln></wordentry>

he that came to take the government of a hundred was met
by all the better sort, who came and touch't his Lance, or
Weapon, by which Ceremony they were sworn and
confederate.</xpln></wordentry>

over her back; which action is called the warbling of the
wings.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Warwick(pn)"><f type="i">Warwick<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the principal Town of
<f type="i">Warwick-shire<f type="r">,
which with much probability is judged to be the same with
that, which anciently
was called <f type="i">pr&aelig;sidium<f type="r">, i. a Garrison; for the
<f type="i">Saxons<f type="r">, called it <f type="i"><term lang="sx">Warringwyck</term><f type="r">, the
<f type="i">Brittains, <term lang="br">C&aelig;r Guarvick</term><f type="r">,
both which words seem to have sprung <class type="etymlang" lang="br">from the
<f type="i">Brittish<f type="r"> word
<f type="i"><term lang="br">Guarth</term><f type="r"></class>, which also signifieth a Garrison; here
the Captain of the <f type="i">Dalmatian<f type="r">
hors-men kept his residence, under
the command of <f type="i">Dux Britanni&aelig;<f type="r">, this Town is
situate over the River <f type="i">Avon<f type="r">, upon a steep Rock,
fortified with strong walls, and a Castle toward the
South-west.</xpln></wordentry>

wharf, or brought thither to be
exported.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="while(r)"><f type="i">While<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="sx" type="etymlang">(Sax.)</class> which.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Whitespur(n)"><f type="i">Whitespurres<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>certain Squires made by the
King.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Whitsuntide(pn)"><f type="i">Whitsuntide<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>as it were the time of the
white son; also Whitsunday seemeth to signify as much as
sacred Sunday; <class lang="sx" type="etymlang">from the <f type="i">Saxon<f type="r"> word
<f type="i"><term lang="sx">Wihed</term><f type="r">, i. sacred</class>, being a
certain feast celebrated,
in memory of the holy Ghost, descending upon the Apostles
in fiery tongues; it is called in Greek
<f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Pentecost</term><f type="r">, as
being the 50<expan type="^th">th</expan>. day from the
Resurrection.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="whole-chase boot(n)"><f type="i">Whole-chace-boots<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>large hunting, or
winter riding bootes;
summer riding bootes, being called demichace.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="whoodings(n)"><f type="i">Whoodings<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>plancks, which are joyn'd and fastned along the ship-sides
into the stem.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="whorlbat(n)"><f type="i">Whorlbat<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(in lat. <f type="i">C&aelig;stus<f type="r">)</class> a
certain game or exercise among the ancients, wherein they
whirled leaden plummets at one another.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Wigornia(pn)"><f type="i">Wigornia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the chief Citie of
<f type="i">Worcestershire<f type="r">,
commonly called <f type="i">Worcester<f type="r">, the
<f type="i">Brittains<f type="r">
call'd it <f type="i"><term lang="br">C&aelig;r-Wrangon</term><f type="r">, and
<f type="i">C&aelig;rGuarangon<f type="r">,
the Saxons <f type="i">Weorgaceaster<f type="r">; it was set on fire in
the year 1041. by <f type="i">Hardy Cnute<f type="r"> the <f type="i">Dane<f type="r">,
in revenge, because the Citizens had slain his
<f type="i">Huscarles<f type="r">; it was also very much harrassed in the
time of the Civil Wars, in King <f type="i">Stephens<f type="r"> reign,
but soon it flourish't again, with greater splendour then
before.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Wilfred(pn)"><f type="i">Wilfred<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="sx" type="etymlang">(Sax.)</class> much peace, a proper name of
men.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Wilfrid's Needle, Saint(pn)">Saint <f type="i">Wilfrid's needle<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain narrow
hole in the Church of <f type="i">Wakeman<f type="r">, in
<f type="i">Yorkshire<f type="r">,
wherein womens honesties were in times past tried, for
such as were chaste did easily passe through, but such as
had been faulty, were miraculously held fast, and could
not get through.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="William(pn)"><f type="i">William<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="du" type="etymlang">(Dutch <f type="i"><term lang="du">Wilhelm</term><f type="r">)</class> the
proper name of a man, the word signifying a
defence to many.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Wilton(pn)"><f type="i">Wilton<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town of <f type="i">Wiltshire<f type="r">, in
ancient times the
principal Town of the whole Shire, and from which it took
its denomination, that it was heretofore
called <f type="i">Ellandunum<f type="r">,
appears by the Testimony
of old Records, when <f type="i">Weolstan<f type="r">
being stiled Earle of
<f type="i">Ellandunum<f type="r">; it is farther
added, <f type="i">that is to say of<f type="r"> Wilton, here in a very
bloudy battel, <f type="i">Egbert<f type="r"> King of the
<f type="i">West-Saxons<f type="r">, overcame <f type="i">Beorwulf<f type="r">, King of
<f type="i">Mercia<f type="r">, in the year of our salvation 821. here
also about fifty years after King <f type="i">Aelfrid<f type="r">,
joyning battel with the <f type="i">Danes<f type="r">, was at length put
to the worst.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="wimple(n)"><f type="i">Wimple<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a plaited linnen cloath, which Nuns
wear about their necks; also a flag or streamer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Wimund(pn)"><f type="i">Wimund<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="sx" type="etymlang">(Sax.)</class> sacred peace, a proper

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="windlass(n)"><f type="i">Windlasse<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a piece of Timber placed from

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Windsor(pn)"><f type="i">Windsore<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Town in <f type="i">Bark-shire<f type="r">, by
the <f type="i">Saxons<f type="r"> called <f type="i">Windleshore<f type="r">, haply
from the <f type="i">Winding-shore<f type="r">; it is famous for a most
stately Castle, built by King <f type="i">Edward<f type="r"> the third,
who in this Castle held prisoners at the same time,
<f type="i">John<f type="r"> King of <f type="i">France<f type="r">, and <f type="i">David<f type="r">
King of <f type="i">Scots<f type="r">; he also founded that Noble Order
of the Garter, of which see more in the word Knight, there
is likewise a magnificent Church begun by the same King,
and consecrated to the Virgin <f type="i">Marie<f type="r">, but finisht
by King <f type="i">Henry<f type="r">, and Sir <f type="i">Reginald
Bray<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Winefrid(pn)"><f type="i">Winefrid<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the name of an ancient
<f type="i">Brittish<f type="r"> Virgin
Saint, of whom it is reported that after her head was cut
off by <f type="i">Cradacus<f type="r">,
there sprung up in the same place the Well, which at this
day is called Saint <f type="i">Winefrids<f type="r"> Well, and that
<f type="i">Benno<f type="r"> the Priest joyned her head again to her
body; it is also the proper name of divers women, the word
signifying <class lang="sx" type="etymlang">in the <f type="i">Saxon<f type="r"> tongue an obtainer of
peace</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Winwidfield(pn)"><f type="i">Winwidfield<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a place near <f type="i">Leeds<f type="r"> in
<f type="i">York-shire<f type="r">, so called from the great
victory, which
<f type="i">Oswy<f type="r">, King of <f type="i">Northumberland<f type="r">
had over <f type="i">Penda<f type="r">, King of the
<f type="i">Mercians<f type="r">,
wherein <f type="i">Penda<f type="r"> was utterly
overthrown.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="wizard(n)"><f type="i">Wisard<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a witch, a cunning man, one that

comes <class lang="sx" type="etymlang">from the <f type="i">Saxon<f type="r"> word <f type="i"><term lang="sx">Witega</term>, i.<f type="r"> a

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="wiseacre(n)"><f type="i">Wiseacre<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the same, <class lang="du" type="etymlang">from the Dutch words
<f type="i"><term lang="du">W&aelig;r</term>, i.<f type="r"> truth, and <f type="i"><term lang="du">Sagen</term>, i.<f type="r"> to tell</class>;
it is vulgarly taken for a fool.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="witchcraft(n)"><f type="i">Witchcraft<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain evil Art,
whereby with the
assistance of the Devil, or evil Spirits, some wonders may
be wrought, which exceed the common
apprehension of men.
It cometh <class lang="du" type="etymlang">from the Dutch word <f type="i"><term lang="du">Wiechelen</term>, i.<f type="r"> to
divine, or guesse</class>; it is called in Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Veneficium</term><f type="r">, in Greek <f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Pharmaceia</term>, i.<f type="r"> the
art of making poysons.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="withernam(n)"><f type="i">Withernam<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="du" type="etymlang">(from the Dutch words
<f type="i"><term lang="du">Wider</term><f type="r">, i. again, and <f type="i"><term lang="du">Namp</term><f type="r">, i. a taking)</class>
is <class type="register" subject="law">in Common Law</class>, when a distresse is
taken and driven into a hold
or out of the County, so that the Sheriff cannot upon the
replevin, make delivery thereof to the party
distreined.</xpln></wordentry>
