<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Woden(pn)"><f type="i">Woden<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain Idol worshipt by the

<f type="i">Mars<f type="r">, or the god of Battle; whence the fourth day
of the week came to be called <f type="i">Wodensday<f type="r">, or
<f type="i">Wednseday<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Wodensburgh(pn)"><f type="i">Wodensburgh<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>(q. the Burgh or Town of

King of the <f type="i">West-Saxons<f type="r">, was in a bloody battle
vanquisht by the <f type="i">Brittains<f type="r">, and
forced to end his dayes in exile.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="wold(n)"><f type="i">Wolds<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="sx" type="etymlang">(Sax.)</class> mountains or hills

part of <f type="i">Leicestershire<f type="r">
lying Northward beyond the <f type="i">Wreken<f type="r">, is called the
Wold or Would of <f type="i">Leicestershire<f type="r">,

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="wolf's head(n)"><f type="i">Wolfetchsod<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="sx" type="etymlang">(Sax.)</class> the condition of an Utlary,

</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Woodstock(pn)"><f type="i">Woodstock<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="sx" type="etymlang">(Sax. a wooddy place)</class> a Town in
<f type="i">Oxfordshire<f type="r">, where King
<f type="i">Ethelred<f type="r">
assembled the States of the Kingdom and enacted Laws; here
King <f type="i">Henry<f type="r"> the first built a very magnificent
Royal Palace, in which King <f type="i">Henry<f type="r"> the second, that he might keep his
Paramour <f type="i">Rosamund Clifford<f type="r"> concealed, built a
Labyrinth with many intricate turnings and windings, which
was called <f type="i">Rosamunds<f type="r"> Bower; but it is so utterly
effaced, that at this day it is not to be discerned where
it was. In this Town <f type="i">Geffery
Chaucer<f type="r"> a most
famous English Poet was
brought up.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="woodward(n)"><f type="i">Woodward<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an officer of the Forrest, whose
function is to present any offence of Vert or Venison done
within his charge, and if he find any Deer killed or
wounded, to give the
Verderer notice of it.</xpln></wordentry>

between the Mantle and the
Crest, called also a Torce; also a Boares tail <class type="register" subject="hawking and hunting">so termed
among Hunters</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="wreck(n)"><f type="i">Wreck<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(Fr. <f type="i">Varech<f type="r"></class>, <class lang="la" type="etymlang">Lat.
<f type="i">Veriscum &amp; naufragium<f type="r">)</class> is when a ship
perisheth at sea, and no man escapeth alive, in which case
whatever goods are cast upon land belong to the King or
the Lord of the soile; but if any person come to land, or
if either dog or cat escape alive, the goods return to the
owner if he claim them within
a year and a day.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="wreedt(n)"><f type="i">Wreedt<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="du" type="etymlang">(Dutch)</class> angry, fierce, furious;
whence the word wroth is commonly used by us for anger or fury.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED.
</lemenote>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="writ(n)"><f type="i">Writ<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="la" type="etymlang">(Lat. <f type="i"><term lang="la">Breve</term><f type="r"> because the
intention of it is expounded in few words)</class>
signifieth <class type="register" subject="law">in Common
Law</class>, the Kings precept whereby any thing is commanded to
be done touching the suit of action, as a
defendant to be summoned, a distresse to be taken, <f type="i">&amp;c.<f type="r"> It is
called by the Civilians, <f type="i"><term lang="la">Actio</term><f type="r"> or
<f type="i"><term lang="la">Formula</term><f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Xanthippe(pn)"><f type="i">Xanthippe<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the wife of <f type="i">Socrates<f type="r">, a
woman of a very froward and petulant disposition,
insomuch as <f type="i"><emend err="Alcibies" source="errata">Alcibiades</emend><f type="r"> told <f type="i">Socrates<f type="r"> that
he wondred how he could indure to live with her, to which
he answered, that he kept her to exercise his patience at
home, that he might the better bear the petulancy of
others abroad.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Xantippus(pn)"><f type="i">Xantippus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous Captain among the
<f type="i">Laced&aelig;monians<f type="r">, who assisting the
<f type="i">Carthaginians<f type="r">,
overcame the <f type="i">Romans<f type="r"> in a great battle, and took
<f type="i">Regulus<f type="r"> the Consul prisoner.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Xantho(pn)"><f type="i">Xantho<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>one of the Sea-Nimphs, the daughter

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Xanthus(pn)"><f type="i">Xanthus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a River of <f type="i">Troas<f type="r">, called

succeeded in the Academy of <f type="i">Speusippus<f type="r">, he was a

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Xenophon(pn)"><f type="i">Xenophon<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Gryllus<f type="r"> a
famous <f type="i">Athenian<f type="r"> Philosopher and expert Captain,
he went with an Army of 10000 men
along with <f type="i">Cyrus<f type="r">
into <f type="i">Persia<f type="r">, and after <f type="i">Cyrus<f type="r"> was slain,
brought back his Army with little
losse through many strange Countries and divers great
difficulties and dangers. He was for his Eloquence stiled
the Attick Muse, and writ many choice and elegant
books.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Xerxes(pn)"><f type="i">Xerxes<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a King of <f type="i">Persia<f type="r">, the
grandchild of <f type="i">Cyrus<f type="r"> and son of <f type="i">Darius<f type="r">
and <f type="i">Atossa<f type="r">; he with an Army of 1700000 men, and a
Navy so vast that it filled
the whole <f type="i">Hellespont<f type="r">
and joyned the two Continents together,
was vanquisht at <f type="i">Thermopyl&aelig;<f type="r"> by 4000 men, and
afterwards in a Sea-fight at <f type="i">Salamis<f type="r"> by
<f type="i">Themistocles<f type="r">,
and his General whom he left in <f type="i">Boeotia<f type="r">, was
faine to retire with almost
all his forces cut off, he was at length slain in his own
Palace by <f type="i">Artabanus<f type="r"> one of his own
Captains.</xpln></wordentry>

</wordgroup1>

</wordgroup1>
<wordgroup1 type="a" object="ye"><alpha>Y E</alpha>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="year and day(n)"><f type="i">Year and Day<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a certain time in
construction of
<class type="register" subject="law">Common Law</class> thought fit in many
cases to determine a right in one, and prescription in
another, as in case of an Estray, of No claim, of
Protection, of a Wreck <f type="i">&amp;c.<f type="r"></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="yeoman(n)"><f type="i">Yeoman<f type="r">,</form> <xpln>(contract, a youngman) the
next degree to a Gentleman, and called in Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">Ingenuus</term><f type="r">; <class type="register" subject="law">in our Laws</class> he is defined to be a
freeborn man, who can dispend of his own free land in
yearly revenue to the summe of 40 shillings Sterling.</xpln></wordentry>

</wordgroup1>
<wordgroup1 type="a" object="yo"><alpha>Y O</alpha>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="younker(n)"><f type="i">Yonker<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="du" type="etymlang">(Dutch <f type="i"><term lang="du">Junker</term><f type="r">, i. a Knight
or Nobleman)</class> a lusty lad.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="York(pn)"><f type="i">York<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>see <xref><f type="i">Eboracum<f type="r"></xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="youthwort(n)"><f type="i">Youthwort<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a kind of plant called in
Latin <f type="i"><term lang="la">ros solis</term><f type="r">.</xpln>
<lemenote>
See OED "youth."
</lemenote>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Ythel(pn)"><f type="i">Ythel<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="br" type="etymlang">(Brittish)</class> a proper name,
contracted <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">from the
Greek <f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Euthalius</term><f type="r">, i. very flourishing</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="za"><alpha>Z A</alpha>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Zachary(pn)"><f type="i">ZAchary<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the proper name of a man,
signifying <class type="etymlang" lang="he">in Heb. Memory of the Lord</class>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Zachynthus(pn)"><f type="i">Zachynthus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an Island of the
<f type="i">Ionian<f type="r"> Sea, between <f type="i">Cephalenia<f type="r">, and
<f type="i">Achaia<f type="r">, now called
<f type="i">Zante<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Zaleucus(pn)"><f type="i">Zaleucus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous Lawgiver among the
<f type="i">Locrians<f type="r">, who having made a Law for the punishing
Adultery, and his son hapning to be found guilty of the
same crime, he that he might fulfill the Law and
mitigate his sons punishment, caused one of his sons eyes to be put out, and
one of his own.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Zameis(pn)"><f type="i">Zameis<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the fifth King of <f type="i">Assyria<f type="r">,
the son of <f type="i">Ninus<f type="r"> and <f type="i">Semiramis<f type="r">,
otherwise called <f type="i">Ninias<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="zany(n)"><f type="i">Zany<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="fr" type="etymlang">(French)</class> one that in ridiculous
manner, imitates other mens actions to stir up laughter.</xpln></wordentry>

</wordgroup1>
<wordgroup1 type="a" object="ze"><alpha>Z E</alpha>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Zebennia(pn)"><f type="i">Zebennia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the wife of <f type="i">Odenatus<f type="r">
King of the <f type="i">Palmyreni<f type="r">, who behaved himself with
much gallantry against <f type="i">Sapores<f type="r"> King of
<f type="i">Persia<f type="r">; she after the death of her husband
injoyed the Kingdom with her sons
<f type="i">Herennianus<f type="r">
and <f type="i">Timolaus<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="zecchin(n)"><f type="i">Zecchine<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="it" type="etymlang">(Ital.)</class> a certain Coin of Gold,
valuing about 7 shillings 6 pence Sterling.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="zealot(n)"><f type="i">Zelot<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> one that is envious or
jealous of anothers actions; also one that is hot and
fervently zealous in Religion.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="zelotypy(n)"><f type="i">Zelotypie<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> jealousie.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="zenith(n)"><f type="i">Zenith<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="ar" type="etymlang">(Arab.)</class> the vertical point, or that
point of Heaven which is directly over our heads, and
opposite to the Nadir.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Zeno(pn)"><f type="i">Zeno<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous Greek Philosopher, who was the
first Authour of the Sect of the Stoicks, he strangled
him self in the 72 year of his age, after he had broke his
</page>

<page sig="[%1r]">
finger by hitting it against a stone. There was also
another <f type="i">Zeno<f type="r"> of <f type="i">Elea<f type="r"> a hearer of
<f type="i">Parmenides<f type="r">, he having conspired against the
Tyrant <f type="i">Nearchus<f type="r">, and being put upon the rack to
make him confesse who were the rest of the
conspiratours, he bit off a piece of his tongue and spit
it in the Tyrants face;
whereupon the Citizens stoned the Tyrant to death.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Zenobia(pn)"><f type="i">Zenobia<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>called also <f type="i">Zebennia<f type="r">, a
Queen of <f type="i">Palmyrene<f type="r">, and the wife of
<f type="i">Odatus<f type="r">, she governed the Roman Provinces in
<f type="i">Syria<f type="r">, being reckoned among the 30 Tyrants who
usurpt the government of the World in the time of
<f type="i">Galenus<f type="r">; she was at length overcome by the
Emperour <f type="i">Aurelian<f type="r">, and led in Triumph through the
City of <f type="i">Rome<f type="r"> with Golden Chains: Yet he in
compassion afterwards gave her a possession in
<f type="i">Tybur<f type="r">. She understood the <f type="i">Aegyptian,
Greek<f type="r">, and <f type="i">Roman<f type="r"> Languages, and brought up
her sons <f type="i">Herennianus<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Timolaus<f type="r"> in
learning, of whom it is not known what became, whether
they died a natural death or were killed by
<f type="i">Aurelian<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Zephyrus(pn)"><f type="i">Zephyrus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the West-wind so <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">called by the
<f type="i">Greeks<f type="r"></class>; by the <f type="i">Latins, <term lang="la">Favonius</term><f type="r">, and
begins to blow as <f type="i">Varro<f type="r">
affirms, about the beginning of <f type="i">February<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="zereth(n)"><f type="i">Zereth<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>an <class type="etymlang" lang="he">Hebrew measure</class> containing nine
inches.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Zethes(pn)"><f type="i">Zethes<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Boreas<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Orithya<f type="r">,
and the brother of <f type="i">Calais<f type="r">; these two brothers
went with the Argonants to <f type="i">Colchos<f type="r">,
&amp; because they had wings they were sent to drive away
the <f type="i">Harpys<f type="r"> from <f type="i">Phineus<f type="r">
his Table, whom they pursued to the <f type="i">Strophades<f type="r">
Islands.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Zethus(pn)"><f type="i">Zethus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the son of <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> and
<f type="i">Antiope<f type="r"> the wife of <f type="i">Lycus<f type="r"> King of the
<f type="i">Thebans<f type="r">, who divorcing <f type="i">Antiope<f type="r">, married
<f type="i">Dirce<f type="r">; after which <f type="i">Jupiter<f type="r"> falling in
love with <f type="i">Antiope<f type="r">, got her with child, which
<f type="i">Dirce<f type="r"> perceiving, fearing lest she might come
again into favour with her Husband, she put her in prison;
but the time of her delivery drawing nigh, she was set at
liberty, and flying to
the mountain <f type="i">Citheron<f type="r">,
she brought forth twins in the highway,
and the children being afterwards found by the Shepherds,
were brought up by them, and called the one
<f type="i">Zethus<f type="r">, the other <f type="i">Amphion<f type="r">, who coming to
age, and hearing of the injuries which <f type="i">Dirce<f type="r"> had
done to their mother, they tied her to the tail of a wild
Bull, whereby she was draged through rough and stony wayes
to a miserable death, and changed by <f type="i">Bacchus<f type="r"> into
a Fountain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Zeuxis(pn)"><f type="i">Zeuxis<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a famous
Painter of <f type="i">Greece<f type="r">, who contended with
<f type="i">Timantes, Androcides, Eu&shy;
pompus<f type="r">, and <f type="i">Parrhasius<f type="r">, all excellent
Painters of his time; he
painted a Boy carrying
Grapes, the Grapes being done with so much life, that the
Birds taking them for true Grapes, flew to them to peck at
them, whereat he grew very angry at his own work, saying,
That if the Boy had been drawn as well as the Grapes, they
would not have peckt at them for fear of the Boy.</xpln></wordentry>

</wordgroup1>
<wordgroup1 type="a" object="zo"><alpha>Z O</alpha>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="zodiac(n)"><f type="i">Zodiack<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>one of the greater imaginary
Circles, being 12 degrees in breadth, and 360 in length,
and dividing the Sphere obliquely into two parts, and
containeth the 12 Signs, which are called <f type="i">Aries,
Taurus, Gemini, Cancer, Leo, Virgo, Libra, Scorpio,
Sagittarius, Capricornus, Aquarius, Pisces<f type="r">, through
the whole length of this Circle runneth a line just in the
middle which is called the Ecliptick line, or the path-way
of the Sun, because in that line the Sun performeth its
course. The word <f type="i">Zodiack<f type="r"> cometh from the Greek
<f type="i"><term lang="gkt">Zodion</term><f type="r">, because of the representations of sundry animals which it
containeth; in Latin it is called
<f type="i"><term lang="la">Signifer</term><f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Zoilus(pn)"><f type="i">Zoilus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Sophist of <f type="i">Amphipolis<f type="r">,
who lived in the time of <f type="i">Ptolom&aelig;us<f type="r"> King of
<f type="i">Aegypt<f type="r">, and writ a
book against <f type="i">Homer<f type="r">, (whence he was called
<f type="i">Homeromastix<f type="r">)
which he presented to <f type="i">Ptolomy<f type="r">
expecting a great reward; but when he saw that he gave him
nothing, he being compelled by want, set on some friends
to beg something of him;
but <f type="i">Ptolomy<f type="r"> answered
that since <f type="i">Homer<f type="r">, so many Ages past deceased had
fed so many men, he wondred how <f type="i">Zoilus<f type="r"> could want
so much, being more learned than <f type="i">Homer<f type="r">.
Concerning his death some say, that being convicted of
Parricide, he was crucified at the
command of <f type="i">Ptolomy<f type="r">. Others that returning into
<f type="i">Greece<f type="r">, he was thrown down
headlong from the rock
<f type="i">Scyron<f type="r">. From him every envious carping Critick is called a
<f type="i">Zoilus<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="zone(n)"><f type="i">Zone<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a belt or girdle, more
particularly it is taken for a girdle
worn anciently by maides about their middle
</page>

<page sig="[%1v]">
when they were near marriage, which the Husband untied
the first night of their marriage; also a souldiers
belt; also in Cosmography it is used for a certain space
or division of the Heavens or Earth,
bounded by the lesser
circles, whereof there are 5 in all; namely, the
<f type="i">Torrid Zone<f type="r"> included
between the two <f type="i">Tropicks<f type="r">, the two <f type="i">Temperate
Zones<f type="r"> included between the <f type="i">Tropicks<f type="r"> and
the Polar Circles, and the two <f type="i">Frigid Zones<f type="r">
which are included between
the Polar Circles and the Poles themselves.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="zoography(n)"><f type="i">Zoography<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> a discription of beasts,
a painting of any kind of animals.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="zoophyte(n)"><f type="i">Zoophytes<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> certain substances which
partake of the nature partly of plants, partly of animals,
and are also called Plantanimals.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Zophyrus(pn)"><f type="i">Zophyrus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Nobleman of <f type="i">Persia<f type="r">,
who when <f type="i">Darius<f type="r"> had besieged <f type="i">Babylon<f type="r"> a
long time in vain, he fled to the <f type="i">Babylonians<f type="r"> as
a fugitive, cutting off his eares and his lips,
complaining of the cruelty of his King; whereupon being
received by them, he was made their Captain, and betrayed
the City to <f type="i">Darius<f type="r">, who notwithstanding would
often say, That he had rather have one <f type="i">Zophyrus<f type="r">
whole, than take twenty <f type="i">Babylons<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Zoroaster(pn)"><f type="i">Zoroaster<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>the first King of the
<f type="i">Bactrians<f type="r">, who, as <f type="i">Pliny<f type="r"> saith, was the
first inventour of Magick among the <f type="i">Persians<f type="r">, he
is said to have laught the first day he was born, and his
brain is said to have beat so strongly, that it repelled
any ones hand which was laid on, which was held to be a
signe of his future sagacity, he wrote the liberal arts
upon seven pillars of brick, and also upon seven of
brasse; he wrote also one volume concerning nature, one of
precious stones, with several other works; some say, he
was consumed with fire from heaven, and that he foretold
to the <f type="i">Assyrians<f type="r">, that if they preserved his
ashes, their Kingdom should never fail, others say, he was
slain in the wars he had with <f type="i">Ninus<f type="r">, King of
<f type="i">Assyria<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

</wordgroup1>
<wordgroup1 type="a" object="zu"><alpha>Z U</alpha>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Zulemon(pn)"><f type="i">Zulemon<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Captain of those
<f type="i">Saracens<f type="r">, inhabiting <f type="i">Asia<f type="r">, who invading
<f type="i">Thrace<f type="r"> with a numerous Army, part of them
besieged <f type="i">Constantinople<f type="r">, part making an
irruption into <f type="i">Bulgaria<f type="r">, were overcome by the
<f type="i">Bulgarians<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Zuventebaldus(pn)"><f type="i">Zuventebaldus<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a Duke of the
<f type="i">Maraveni<f type="r">, to
whom <f type="i">Arnolphus<f type="r"> gave the Dukedom of
<f type="i">Bohemia<f type="r">, he rebelling against the Emperour,
overcame him with the help of the
<f type="i">Hungarians<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

</wordgroup1>
<wordgroup1 type="a" object="zy"><alpha>Z Y</alpha>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="Zygactes(pn)"><f type="i">Zygactes<f type="r"></form>, <xpln>a River of <f type="i">Thrace<f type="r">, near
the City <f type="i">Philippi<f type="r">, in the passing of which,
<f type="i">Pluto<f type="r"> is said to have broke his Chariot, when he
ravish't <f type="i">Proserpina<f type="r">.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lexeme="zygostat(n)"><f type="i">Zygostat<f type="r"></form>, <xpln><class lang="gk" type="etymlang">(Greek)</class> one appointed to look to
weights, a Clark of a market.</xpln></wordentry>
</wordgroup1>

<blockquote>FINIS.</BLOCKQUOTE>
</section>
</page>

<page sig="Ss1r">
<section type="errata">

<heading>
The <f type="i">Errata<f type="r"> committed in the Capital Words are to
be found by the order of the Alphabet as followeth.
</heading>

<f type="i">FOr<f type="r"> Adory <f type="i">r.<f type="r"> Adoxy. Alderanainim
<f type="i">vid.<f type="r"> Pap. <f type="i">to be left out. for<f type="r"> Archirrave
<f type="i">r.<f type="r"> Architrave. <f type="i">for<f type="r"> Arcuare <f type="i">r.<f type="r">
Arcuate. <f type="i">for<f type="r"> Aniso <f type="i">r.<f type="r"> Aviso.

Bacchus <f type="i">to begin a break after<f type="r"> Baccharach.
<f type="i">for<f type="r"> Becebick <f type="i">r.<f type="r"> Becchick. <f type="i">for<f type="r">
Bedobeer <f type="i">r.<f type="r"> Bedpheer. <f type="i">for<f type="r"> Bourrean <f type="i">r.<f type="r">
Bourreau.

<f type="i">For<f type="r"> Calcent <f type="i">r.<f type="r"> Calecut. <f type="i">for<f type="r"> Carm
<f type="i">r.<f type="r"> Carine. <f type="i">for<f type="r"> Cartilagindous <f type="i">r.<f type="r">
Cartilagineous. <f type="i">for<f type="r"> Casuit <f type="i">r.<f type="r"> Casuist Cnossus
<f type="i">should begin a break. for<f type="r"> Columbarg <f type="i">r.<f type="r">
Columbarie. <f type="i">for<f type="r"> Sir Crispin <f type="i">r.<f type="r"> St.
Crispin.

<f type="i">For<f type="r"> Dantry <f type="i">r.<f type="r"> Dautry. Dative <f type="i">to begin a
break after<f type="r"> Datism. Diple <f type="i">to begin a break after<f type="r">
Dipththong.

<f type="i">For<f type="r"> Entire perngents <f type="i">r.<f type="r"> Entire pertingents.
<f type="i">for<f type="r"> Euperation <f type="i">r.<f type="r"> Exuperation.

<f type="i">For<f type="r"> Fastigation <f type="i">r.<f type="r"> Fastigiation.
<f type="i">for<f type="r"> Fontegeld <f type="i">r.<f type="r"> Foutegeld.

<f type="i">For to be<f type="r"> Agog <f type="i">r.<f type="r"> to be a Gog. Grith <f type="i">to
be in the same break with<f type="r"> Grithbreach. Gryph, <f type="i">to begin
a break after<f type="r"> Gryffen. Gibbosity <f type="i">misplaced in<f type="r"> G.
Y.

<f type="i">For<f type="r"> Langid <f type="i">r.<f type="r"> Languid. <f type="i">for<f type="r"> Lucida
Laucis <f type="i">r.<f type="r"> Lucida Lancis.

<f type="i">For<f type="r"> Misoginy <f type="i">r.<f type="r"> Mysogyny. <f type="i">for<f type="r">
Mithology <f type="i">r.<f type="r"> Mythology.

<f type="i">For<f type="r"> Nephglian <f type="i">r.<f type="r"> Nephelian.

<f type="i">For<f type="r"> Obigillation <f type="i">r.<f type="r"> Obsigillation.
<f type="i">for<f type="r"> Obtruration <f type="i">r.<f type="r"> Obturation.

<f type="i">For<f type="r"> Paraselinii <f type="i">r.<f type="r"> Paraselenii.
<f type="i">for<f type="r"> Paretii <f type="i">r.<f type="r"> Parelii. <f type="i">for<f type="r"> Paricide
<f type="i">r.<f type="r"> Parricide, <f type="i">which should have been placed
after<f type="r"> Parrhasius. <f type="i">for<f type="r"> Percontation <f type="i">r.<f type="r">
Percunctation. <f type="i">for<f type="r"> Portmantean <f type="i">r.<f type="r">
Portmanteau. <f type="i">for<f type="r">
Proem <f type="i">r.<f type="r"> Prooem. <f type="i">for<f type="r"> Propagotion <f type="i">r.<f type="r">
Propagation.

<f type="i">For<f type="r"> Quadrulation <f type="i">r.<f type="r"> Quadruplation.

Relohihin <f type="i">to be left out<f type="r">.

<f type="i">For<f type="r"> Septunical <f type="i">r.<f type="r"> Septuncial. <f type="i">for<f type="r">
Sicambre <f type="i">r.<f type="r"> Sicambri. <f type="i">for<f type="r"> Smectimnus
<f type="i">r.<f type="r"> Smectimnuus. <f type="i">for<f type="r">
Supercilous <f type="i">r.<f type="r">
Supercilious. <f type="i">for<f type="r"> Suparlative
<f type="i">r.<f type="r"> Superlative.

<f type="i">In<f type="r"> Thirdboroughs <f type="i">leave out<f type="r"> s <f type="i">at the
later end. for<f type="r"> Tonicul <f type="i">r.<f type="r"> Tonical. <f type="i">for<f type="r">
Traperzium <f type="i">r.<f type="r"> Trapezium  <f type="i">for<f type="r"> Tymn&aelig;tes
<f type="i">r.<f type="r"> Tym&aelig;tes.

<f type="i">For<f type="r"> Vicidity <f type="i">r.<f type="r"> Viscidity.

<heading>
The other <f type="i">Errata<f type="r"> are to be found under some or
other of the Alphabetical words.
</heading>

<f type="i">In<f type="r"> Corporal, <f type="i">for<f type="r"> or <f type="i">r.<f type="r"> of a.
